APW_ENG_19941201.0063;0	Despite the criticism NATO has taken over its failure to stop the war in Bosnia , the Western alliance remains attractive to Eastern European countries eager to join .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;1	Future Bosnia policy is sure to dominate today 's meeting of the 16 North Atlantic Treaty Organization members .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;2	But the NATO allies also will launch a debate on its eastward expansion , beginning with a study that examines what effect newcomers will have on NATO 's command structure , how much enlargement will cost , and whether NATO troops will have to be based in the new member states .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;3	The study is expected to take a year to complete and will not address the issue of which countries can join , or when .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;4	Hungary , Poland , the Czech Republic and Slovakia are among those most anxious to join .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;5	The study will also make clear to prospective applicants what membership would cost them in money and materiel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;6	NATO is keenly aware of the anxieties in Moscow over the alliance 's enlargement plans .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;7	Russia no longer opposes NATO expansion as such , but argues the issue is advancing too fast .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;8	To counter fears that it seeks to isolate Russia , the allies today were to endorse a sweeping military cooperation program with Russia and agree to hold regular talks with Moscow on security matters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;9	Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev will meet with the NATO foreign ministers to wrap up details for Moscow 's participation in what NATO calls its Partnership for Peace program .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;10	Twenty-three East European nations have joined that program , unveiled at a January summit of President Clinton and other NATO leaders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;11	Russia will be the eighth with a detailed military cooperation plan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;12	The Russian deal , however , is thicker .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;13	It runs the gamut from joint training and exercises to Western help in drafting defense budgets , force levels , proper defense plans and arms procurement practices .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;14	What is special about the Russian plan is that NATO , outside the partnership program , will hold regular discussions with Moscow on European security issues , including nuclear arms safety and non-proliferation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0063;15	Russia linked its participation in Partnership for Peace to such special treatment , saying it was entitled to that as a nuclear power .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;0	As the old Democratic gang that long has ruled the U.S. Congress takes its final bows this week , another group of veteran Democrats is finding new stature : President Clinton 's old-timers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;1	The jobs of Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen have never looked more secure .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;2	And Clinton 's chief of staff , former Republican Leon Panetta , now is the point man in White House efforts to reach out to Clinton 's newly powerful opponents in Congress .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;3	Christopher , Bentsen and Panetta all have a history of working congenially with some of the Republicans who will be in command on Capitol Hill in Washington thanks to a major victory in Nov. 8 midterm elections .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;4	In Christopher 's case the White House also might not be keen to ask the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to approve a successor once it passes into the hands of arch-antagonist Jesse Helms , a Republican senator from North Carolina .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;5	Panetta has been at the center all week , representing the White House 's views , sounding conciliatory and centrist , as the 103rd Congress meets for the last time to consider the world trade treaty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;6	He 's even spoken for the administration on Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;7	Panetta , a Democrat since he switched parties in the early 1970s and former chairman of the House of Representatives ' Budget Committee , is signaling he will continue to search for common ground with the Republicans .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;8	In listing Clinton 's new legislative priorities , Panetta says the first is `` to keep the economic recovery going and keep the deficit going downward . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;9	Second is welfare reform , which also has much Republican support .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;10	Only after that does Panetta mention health care reform , once Clinton 's centerpiece initiative .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;11	The old-timers ' represent the center of the U.S. political spectrum , toward which Clinton is moving in order to deal with Republicans .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;12	`` All Democrats after Nov. 8 will be centrists , '' jokes Democratic Sen. John Breaux .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;13	`` I think the message was very clear , it was very loud , very emphatic . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;14	Expect to see more of Panetta and Bentsen and other old hands as the White House tries to work with the new leadership and sort out its identity crisis .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;15	That means less of the younger , brasher faces , such as George Stephanopoulos and Democratic adviser Paul Begala , who have often spoken for the White House over the past two years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;16	`` This concept of a youthful White House is not reassuring to anybody , at home or abroad , '' said Sheila Tate , former aide to former first lady Nancy Reagan and to George Bush and now a public relations executive .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;17	`` I think that has finally sunk in . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;18	Not only does the Clinton White House have to learn to work with the new Republican leadership and deal with the party 's emergent right wing , but it also will have to work with the new Democratic congressional leadership .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;19	That could be a blessing in disguise for Clinton , since he got off to such a bad start the first time around .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;20	Many veteran Democratic figures were having their last hurrah this week , including House Speaker Tom Foley , Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell and Rep. Dan Rostenkowski , the former chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;21	In reaching out to Republicans on the new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreement , Clinton was off to a good beginning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;22	But GATT also was an easy first test .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;23	It already had considerable support from both parties .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;24	Come January , things will be far more complicated .
APW_ENG_19941201.0064;25	EDITOR 'S NOTE -- Tom Raum has covered the White House for The Associated Press since 1989 and has reported on government and national politics since 1973 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0065;0	Off-spinner Carl Hooper struck twice in a space of four deliveries to restrict India to 74 for the loss of two wickets at lunch on the opening day of the second test on Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0065;1	India lead 1-0 in the three test series .
APW_ENG_19941201.0065;2	Indian skipper Mohammed Azharuddin won the toss and decided to bat first on a slow wicket .
APW_ENG_19941201.0065;3	West Indian fast bowlers Courtney Walsh and Kenneth Benjamin posed no problems for Indian openers who scored 35 off 14 overs in the first hour .

APW_ENG_19941201.0065;5	Bowling a good line and turning the ball just enough to beat the bat , he dislodged Manoj Prabhakar and Vinod Kambli in quick succession .

APW_ENG_19941201.0066;0	In China 's only World AIDS Day activity not organized by the government , about a dozen activists took to Beijing streets Thursday to distribute pamphlets about AIDS prevention .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;1	The leafleting was sponsored by the AIDS Action Project , a group with no government ties and no money , said one member , who asked that his name not be used .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;2	The group wants to encourage gay and bisexual men to serve as peer educators , he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;3	It called for volunteers late Wednesday on a radio program .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;4	It 's rare for a group not sanctioned by the government to be allowed to organize high-profile public activities such as passing out leaflets .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;5	The government 's apparent tolerance for the volunteers Thursday was in line with recent calls for more efforts to teach people how to avoid the spread of AIDS .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;6	The leaflet the volunteers distributed on Wangfujing Street , one of the city 's main shopping areas , and in other parts of the city gave basic information about AIDS .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;7	It also said drug abusers and prostitutes , who are at high risk for the disease , `` have rights as human beings that should be respected . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;8	Prostitution and drugs have become growing problems in China since economic reforms and opening to the outside world began in the late 1970s .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;9	Until recently , Chinese officials characterized AIDS as a disease that strikes only foreigners or fringe groups such as drug users .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;10	The director of a government-sponsored AIDS hotline was accused of empathizing with homosexuals and prostitutes and fired last year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;11	Homosexuality is not accepted in China , and is technically illegal .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;12	This fall , an official report noted an alarming lack of knowledge about AIDS and called for strengthening anti-AIDS programs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;13	AIDS is spread through sexual contact , contaminated needles shared by drug users , and infected blood or blood products and from pregnant women to their offspring .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;14	Government statistics show 1,453 people have tested positive for HIV , the virus that causes AIDS , since 1985 in China , the China Daily reported Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;15	But AIDS activists said the number would be higher if the government used statistical methods to estimate the incidence of the virus , rather than simply counting the number of known cases .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;16	The China Daily said experts at an international AIDS symposium this week in Beijing concluded that AIDS could spread rapidly in China in the next decade if preventive measures are not taken immediately .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;17	They also called for government funding for laboratories for blood testing and mass publicity campaigns to explain the testing 's importance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;18	China 's blood supply now is checked for HIV only in Beijing , Shanghai , Canton and Yunnan province , the official newspaper said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;19	Yunnan is on the border with Burma , a major source of heroin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;20	Nearly 200 blood donors nationwide have been carriers of the virus , the official Xinhua News Agency reported Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;21	Officially sanctioned World AIDS Day events in Beijing included educational activities at hospitals and a television special .
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;22	On Wednesday , about 200 people attended the opening of a play titled `` Things Related to AIDS . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0066;23	Another show was planned Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;0	A law strengthening Bangladesh 's electoral watchdog agency has failed to satisfy the opposition , whose campaign against the government has produced a nine-month political stalemate .
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;1	The law , passed by Parliament late Wednesday , provides for voter identity cards and gives the Election Commission authority to punish officials involved in malpractice .
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;2	It also empowers the commission to stop voting at any polling station if it suspects `` coercion , intimidation and pressure . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;3	The legislation was rejected by the opposition , which has boycotted Parliament since March 2 , accusing Prime Minister Khaleda Zia 's government of election fraud , corruption and mismanagement .
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;4	Opposition spokesman Mohammad Nasim said the bill `` is nowhere close to our demand for free and fair polls under an interim government . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;5	The opposition wants the government to step down three months before elections , yielding to a neutral caretaker government that would supervise voting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;6	Mrs. Zia rejects the demand as `` unjustified and unconstitutional '' and has offered to bring opposition members into a pre-election Cabinet .
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;7	The next election is scheduled for 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;8	After international mediation failed last month to break the deadlock , opposition leader Sheikh Hasina called for an accelerated campaign of national strikes and demonstrations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;9	On Tuesday , a strike backed by a rail and road blockade choked off routine business in the capital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;10	Hasina has called for a 48-hour general strike next week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0067;11	Businessmen have complained that the prolonged dispute is hurting exports , discouraging foreign investment and diverting the government 's attention from its program to deregulate the economy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;0	Ernesto Zedillo becomes president Thursday , promising profound political and legal reforms to match the market-opening that resulted in a free trade agreement with the United States and Canada .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;1	The 42-year-old U.S.-trained economist caps an unlikely journey when he assumes the red , green and white presidential sash to start a six-year term as leader of this country of 90 million .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;2	The former Mexicali shoeshine boy achieved a Yale University doctorate in economics .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;3	Bypassed once for his party 's presidential nomination , he was thrust into the campaign by the March assassination of Luis Donaldo Colosio , first choice of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party , or PRI .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;4	He won the presidency Aug. 21 in the most credible elections ever held in Mexico .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;5	U.S. Vice President Al Gore and President Fidel Castro are among 63 foreign dignitaries attending the inauguration .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;6	Zedillo has pledged to use the near-absolute powers of Mexico 's presidency to weaken his own office .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;7	He says he will give greater independence to the congress , the courts and local governments as well as the PRI itself .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;8	He says he will end the practice of having the president hand-pick all top PRI candidates .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;9	Zedillo , former budget and planning minister under President Carlos Salinas de Gortari , is sure to continue his predecessor 's free-market economic policies -- a commitment underlined by the Cabinet choices announced Wednesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;10	Leading negotiators of the North American Free Trade Agreement were named heads of treasury , trade and foreign policy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;11	Seven other free-market economists also were named to the 25-person cabinet .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;12	Zedillo also made a political opening by naming an opposition party member to the Cabinet for the first time .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;13	Antonio Lozano , a conservative , will be attorney general -- a crucial post since Zedillo has made fighting government corruption a major part of his campaign .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;14	The Cabinet includes three women -- the most ever appointed at the outset of a Mexican administration .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;15	They are Norma Samaniego as controller ; Silvia Hernandez for tourism ; and biologist Julia Carabias for fisheries .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;16	On Tuesday , Zedillo reached out to the left as well , meeting with leaders of the Democratic Revolution Party and promising reforms to help make Mexico more democratic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;17	Salinas never met publicly with leaders of that main leftist opposition during his administration .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;18	The party apparently responded by pulling some 4,000 protesters out of the capital 's main plaza Wednesday , indicating an effort to avoid the confrontations that marred Salinas ' inauguration in 1988 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;19	The demonstrators were protesting alleged vote fraud in recent state elections .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;20	A protest was planned Thursday by leftist supporters of the Zapatista National Liberation Army rebels of southern Mexico .
APW_ENG_19941201.0068;21	That rebellion , stalled since January by a cease-fire , is one of the toughest problems facing the new president .
APW_ENG_19941201.0070;0	President Boris Yeltsin ordered the government to sell off shares of Russia 's largest state television and radio company , with 51 percent of the stock remaining in state hands .
APW_ENG_19941201.0070;1	Ostankino , once called commonwealth television , is broadcast throughout the former Soviet Union .
APW_ENG_19941201.0070;2	Its Moscow broadcasting tower was the scene of the worst fighting during the political uprising in October 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0070;3	Yeltsin 's decree Wednesday said the new venture , called Russian Public Television , would inherit Ostankino 's nationwide Channel One and would pay for the broadcast time on unchanged terms .
APW_ENG_19941201.0070;4	Ostankino chief Alexander Yakovlev , who was the architect of `` glasnost '' under former Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev , told the ITAR-Tass news agency that the sale would help make Russia 's television independent .

APW_ENG_19941201.0070;6	Twelve major companies and organizations will buy the 49 percent of Ostankino 's stock , including ITAR-Tass , Menatep , Stolichny and Inkombank commercial banks , Aeroflot International Airlines and the Avtovaz car manufacturer .
APW_ENG_19941201.0071;0	NATO foreign ministers met Thursday to begin laying the groundwork for the entry of former Warsaw Pact foes as new members in the coming years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0071;1	But their two-day meeting was likely to be overshadowed by the crisis in Bosnia that has put extraordinary strains on the relationship between the United States and its European allies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0071;2	During the talks , U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher was expected to tell the allies the Clinton administration has swung behind their view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the Bosnian conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0071;3	It marks the first time in the post-World War II history of the alliance that the Europeans , led by France , prevailed over Washington in formulating a major policy .

APW_ENG_19941201.0072;0	Laos has agreed for the first time to let former North Vietnamese soldiers into that country to help locate possible burial sites of missing American servicemen , U.S. officials said Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;1	Laos ' agreement marks a breakthrough in efforts with Vietnam and the United States to resolve the fates of some of the 505 Americans listed as missing in that country .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;2	`` This is something the United States has wanted to do for a long time , getting Vietnamese witnesses into Laos , '' said Navy Lt. Cmdr. Thomas Adams , who works at the Hawaii headquarters of the unit responsible for MIA investigations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;3	Four Vietnamese , who claim to have witnessed the burials of several Americans inside Laos during the war in Indochina , will join in searches for their remains later this month and in January , said James Wold , U.S. deputy assistant secretary of defense for POW-MIA affairs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;4	Wold led an American delegation that met with Laotian and Vietnamese officials about cases that require the help of both Asian countries .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;5	`` The progress was good , '' Wold said after the four-hour meeting ended Thursday in Hanoi .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;6	`` We achieved most of our objectives . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;7	He said the three sides agreed on a mechanism for additional visits by Vietnamese witnesses in other investigations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;8	Representatives of the three countries last met in November 1993 to discuss joint MIA investigations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;9	President Clinton has said Vietnam must show more cooperation in such efforts with neighboring Laos before the United States will establish full diplomatic relations with Hanoi .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;10	Wold said Laotian and Vietnamese officials both expressed a willingness to help , but he spoke with particular praise about Vietnam 's efforts .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;11	`` I would characterize their cooperation in working jointly with the U.S. and Laos as excellent , '' Wold said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;12	U.S. officials have said Laos generally has lagged behind Vietnam in helping to settle cases of the 2,214 Americans unaccounted for from the war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;13	Communist Vietnamese troops occupied large sections of Laos during the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;14	Investigators plan to take one Vietnamese witness later this month to help look for evidence of 11 Americans missing at Phou Pha Thi mountain in northern Houaphan province , said Air Force Maj. Roger Overturf , public affairs officer for the MIA investigation task force .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;15	Communist troops overran a secret U.S. aircraft navigation base there in 1968 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;16	Another three Vietnamese veterans will travel to central Savannakhat province in January for the search for clues to eight airmen shot down while flying in an AC-47 aircraft in 1966 , Overturf said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;17	Winning Laotian cooperation for the Vietnamese to visit the sites has been `` a tough nut to crack , '' Adams said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;18	Laos insisted on interviewing the witnesses first to gauge their credibility before letting them inside Laotian territory , Adams said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;19	Of the remaining U.S. servicemen still unaccounted for from the war , the Pentagon lists 1,624 in Vietnam , 505 in Laos and eight in China .
APW_ENG_19941201.0072;20	Most are known to be dead , U.S. officials say .
APW_ENG_19941201.0073;0	The Export-Import Bank of Japan is planning to extend 26 million dollars in a loan for a Japanese-Dutch joint venture for battery production in Poland , bank officials said Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0073;1	The governmental bank and the joint venture company are expected to sign an agreement on the loan while President Lech Walesa is on a three-day visit to Japan beginning Tuesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0073;2	Since Paris Club donor countries agreed to reduce Poland 's debts at its session in April 1991 , Japan has not provided public loans to the East European nation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0073;3	However , the loan is exceptional because it will help fund a private firm 's project , the officials said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0073;4	Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. , Matsushita Battery Industrial Co. and N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken of the Netherlands set up the joint venture , called Philips Matsushita Poland S.A.
APW_ENG_19941201.0073;5	It is capitalized at 9.5 million dollars .
APW_ENG_19941201.0073;6	The firm will produce manganate batteries starting next September , with annual output expected to reach 600 million units in fiscal 1999 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0073;7	Factory construction is now underway .
APW_ENG_19941201.0073;8	The loan will be used to finance the building of production facilities and establishment of a sales network , bank officials said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0074;0	Red Army Faction terrorist Irmgard Moeller leaves prison .
APW_ENG_19941201.0075;0	Irmgard Moeller , the Red Army Faction terrorist who blew up three American soldiers with a car bomb 22 years ago , walked out of prison Thursday after being freed early from her life sentence .
APW_ENG_19941201.0075;1	Wearing jeans , a leather jacket and red sweater , Moeller smiled , waved and gathered up bouquets as supporters `` international solidarity . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;0	About 150 supporters with red flags , champagne bottles and Christmas gifts waited outside the blue steel prison gates , chanting revolutionary slogans and singing 1960s anti-Vietnam War songs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;1	Demands for Moeller 's freedom have been a feature of leftist demonstrations for years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;2	The U.S. State Department and relatives of the victims objected to her release .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;3	Moeller , 47 , the longest serving female prisoner in Germany , was freed because of her poor health , although she has shown no remorse and refused to cooperate with psychiatric evaluations to determine whether she is still dangerous .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;4	A court in the state of Schleswig-Holstein , where the prison is located , determined that she is not likely to commit another violent crime , and placed her on probation for five years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;5	Moeller 's release could lead to freedom for the seven other Red Army Faction terrorists still imprisoned in Germany .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;6	After its last actions -- assassinating a German official in 1991 and blowing up a new prison in 1993 -- the Red Army Faction issued statements saying it was ending its 20-year campaign of attacks on what it called `` imperialist '' targets .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;7	Moeller was convicted of driving one of two explosives-laden cars that blew up in a parking lot at U.S. Army Headquarters in Heidelberg on May 24 , 1972 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;8	Capt. Clyde R. Bonner and two enlisted men , Charles L. Peck and Ronald A. Woodward , were killed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;9	In a statement after the bombing , the leftist Red Army Faction called the attack a protest against `` genocide '' in Vietnam .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;10	Moeller was arrested six weeks after the attack and sentenced to life in prison plus 15 years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;11	She lived through 12 hunger strikes and survived the night of Oct. 18 , 1977 , when three other imprisoned Red Army Faction leaders were found dead in their cells in what authorities said were suicides .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;12	Moeller was found with four stabs in her chest , but survived .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;13	Politicians , theologians , authors and her prison warden campaigned for Moeller 's release on humanitarian grounds , although she apparently has not given up her political views .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;14	The news magazine Der Spiegel reported recently that Moeller still believes `` the armed struggle was legitimate . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;15	In a 1992 interview with the magazine , she was asked if she felt sympathy for the victims of Red Army Faction violence .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;16	`` I ca n't deal with this so personally and individually , '' she replied .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;17	A striking black-haired woman when she went to jail at the age of 25 , Moeller 's lined face and graying hair now reflect her long life behind bars .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;18	She is also said to be in deteriorating health , suffering from skin , eye and other ailments .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;19	State prosecutors did not challenge the decision ordering her release .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;20	But the U.S. State Department said on Nov. 1 , before the court 's decision , that the U.S. government opposes freeing terrorists who show no remorse for politically motivated attacks .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;21	U.S. Air Force Sgt. Charles Bonner , the 29-year-old son of victim Clyde Bonner , contacted German officials to protest against the decision .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;22	`` I was only 7 when my father was killed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;23	Our housing was just across from that parking lot .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;24	That 's something I 'll never forget .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;25	I think releasing her is ridiculous , '' he said in a telephone conversation last week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;26	A daughter of strict Roman Catholic parents from Munich , Moeller became involved in the leftist student movement of the 1960s , got to know the founders of the Red Army Faction , Andreas Baader and Ulrike Meinhof , and went underground in 1971 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;27	Moeller could throw some light on the deaths of Baader , Jan-Carl Raspe and Gudrun Ensslin , who died in October 1977 in the top-security Stuttgart Stammheim prison .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;28	German authorities and foreign experts ruled the deaths suicides , but Moeller , who survived , has always maintained they were state-ordered murders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;29	Early in her imprisonment , Moeller was held in isolation and harsh conditions in Stammheim , with no human contact apart from her guards and wardens .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;30	In 1980 , she was moved to the relative comfort of the Luebeck prison .
APW_ENG_19941201.0076;31	There , she and two other convicted terrorists shared a special unit that includes a kitchen , a bathroom , a television room and a library .
APW_ENG_19941201.0077;0	The government will appeal a court ruling that could deprive Hong Kong anti-corruption officials of one of their most powerful weapons .
APW_ENG_19941201.0077;1	The Legal Department announced its decision Thursday , the day after a District Court invalidated a law whereby public servants can be prosecuted for failing to explain a standard of living above their salary .
APW_ENG_19941201.0077;2	Judge Gerard Muttrie said the law violates Hong Kong 's Bill of Rights because it requires the defendant to explain his income , thus reversing the principle of innocence until guilt is proved .
APW_ENG_19941201.0077;3	The law is part of the Prevention of Bribery Ordinance , a tough legislative package enacted in 1971 to curb the corruption then rampant in Hong Kong .
APW_ENG_19941201.0077;4	The case before Muttrie , involving a senior estate surveyor , was the first based on the earnings clause since the enactment of the 1991 Bill of Rights , which affirms a person 's innocence until proved guilty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0077;5	The Independent Commission Against Corruption , Hong Kong 's powerful anti-graft agency , says 51 people were prosecuted under the clause before 1991 , and 32 were convicted .
APW_ENG_19941201.0077;6	ICAC official Jim Buckle was quoted by the South China Morning Post as saying Muttrie 's ruling was `` quite a blow . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0077;7	`` The legislation is designed to catch people where you ca n't prove receiving individual bribes , '' he was quoted as saying .
APW_ENG_19941201.0077;8	`` People do n't normally come in and complain that they have been given bribes . ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0079;5	The ultimatum has been met with defiance by Chechens .

APW_ENG_19941201.0079;7	Chechen elders in tall fur hats , tunics and high leather boots , danced in a circle , chanting , `` Freedom or death ! ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0079;8	The conflict in the Caucasus Mountains region of southern Russia has escalated in the past week after months of skirmishes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0079;9	Chechen President Dzhokhar Dudayev , a former Soviet air force general who was elected in 1991 and declared Chechnya 's independence , accuses Moscow of leading and arming his opponents in a civil war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0079;10	Moscow , which openly supports the opposition politically , denies offering any military assistance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0079;11	After Dudayev 's forces captured Russian fighters in fierce fighting Saturday , Moscow officials said mercenaries were fighting on both sides .
APW_ENG_19941201.0079;12	In Moscow , Yeltsin spokesman Vyacheslev Kostikov indicated that Moscow was already moving to resolve the Chechen conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0079;13	`` A series of measures designed to improve resolutely the situation in the Chechen republic and restore the constitutionao order , law and protection of human rights has begun to be implemented , '' he said .

APW_ENG_19941201.0079;18	`` I have no relatives to go to , and my father and mother are ill here -- I can not leave them . ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0080;0	The decision to authorize the study will mark a cautious move forward in drawing former adversaries in Eastern Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0080;1	Poland , Hungary and others have appealed for membership and the security guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0080;2	`` Today , we take an important step in the process that will lead to NATO expansion , '' Christopher told the opening session of the ministers ' meeting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0080;3	The study -- dubbed an `` owner 's manual '' for NATO membership -- will take a year to complete .
APW_ENG_19941201.0080;4	It will not name candidates for membership , nor will it set a deadline for admittance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0080;5	Instead , it will focus on such questions as : What effect will newcomers have on NATO 's common military command structure ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0080;6	How much will enlargement cost NATO ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0080;7	Do NATO troops need to be based in the new member states ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0080;8	The study will also make clear to prospective applicants what membership would cost them in money and materiel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0080;9	To counter Russian worries about an eastward expansion of NATO , the allies intend later Thursday to endorse a sweeping military cooperation program with Russia and agree to hold regular talks with Moscow on security matters .

APW_ENG_19941201.0084;1	Management and representatives of the carrier 's two main unions had reached a tentative agreement Tuesday on a viability plan that entailed a wage freeze , salary cuts averaging 8.5 percent and a reduction of some 3,500 jobs through early retirements and pay-offs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;2	Acceptance by the pilots would have paved the way for the plan to be implemented .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;3	The plan was considered crucial if the European Commission is to consider allowing the Spanish government to grant Iberia a 130 billion peseta -LRB- dlrs 1 billion -RRB- capital injection .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;4	Iberia chairman said the state-owned company would hold meetings with other unions Thursday to evaluate the situation in view of the pilots ' rejection .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;5	It was not immediately clear whether the lack of an across-the-board agreement meant a much more drastic plan touted last week by Iberia -- involving 5,200 job cuts and the sale of company assets -- might be implemented .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;6	That proposal triggered an one-day wildcat strike that paralyzed Spain 's airports and affected more than 100,000 travelers here and abroad .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;7	Negotiations with the pilots reached a dead end as Iberia demanded a salary reduction of 15 percent based on 1992 earnings .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;8	The pilots insisted that an existing wage agreement through 1995 must be implemented before the 15 percent salary cut could be enforced .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;9	`` The company has presented a generic plan that does not guarantee the future of Iberia and only concentrates on disproportionate salary cuts , '' said Armando Guajardo of the pilots ' union SEPLA .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;10	`` Management has let the situation rot to such an extent so that it could enforce such a plan worked out in advance , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;11	SEPLA said the company needed a complete overhaul and not just a reduction in salaries and staff .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;12	He said SEPLA had sent a letter to Iberia warning of drastic action by the pilots if the current wage agreement was broken .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;13	Pilots represent some 5 percent of the 24,000-strong staff .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;14	Salas has warned that the company would be technically bankrupt by March 1995 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;15	Iberia has posted losses since 1990 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0084;16	It ended last year 67 billion pesetas -LRB- dlrs 530 million -RRB- in the red while losses for this year are expected to top 40 billion pesetas -LRB- dlrs 300 million -RRB- .

APW_ENG_19941201.0084;18	The company has said it would continue to operate all its flights on that day .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;0	Despite attempts to keep the focus on new members , the Bosnian crisis will no doubt occupy a large amount of the ministers ' time .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;1	At a breakfast with Hurd , Christopher reviewed the warning U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali delivered Wednesday that unless warring Serbs and Muslims cooperate with the U.N. mission the peacekeepers might be withdrawn .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;2	Christopher and Hurd said they may go to Belgrade , the Yugoslav capital , this weekend to preach reconciliation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;3	`` We will redouble our efforts to find a diplomatic solution , '' Christopher said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;4	The latest American approach centers on a call for an international peace conference that would let Bosnian Serbs seek changes in the peace plan they repeatedly have rejected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;5	That plan would require them to cut their holdings in Bosnia from 70 percent to 49 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;6	The Clinton administration , officials say , is also leaning toward approval of political ties between Serbs in Bosnia and Serbia proper -- a big step toward a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;7	On Friday , Christopher will meet with here his counterparts from France , Germany , Britain and Russia to discuss new plans to revive their moribund peace plan for Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;8	If nothing else , the new American stance is bound to heal a nasty rift within NATO over the alliance 's mission in the Bosnian war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;9	In his opening statement , Christopher sought to underscore the importance of NATO to the United States .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;10	`` This alliance will continue to be the anchor of American engagement in Europe , the linchpin of transatlantic security , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;11	He also assured the 15 foreign ministers that the Clinton administration was committed to keep 100,000 American troops in Europe `` as part of our continuing engagement . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;12	France and Britain have been criticized in the U.S. Congress for refusing to let the United Nations use the Western military alliance 's air power to the full .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;13	In turn , Congress has forced the Clinton administration to seek a lifting of the arms embargo against Bosnia 's Muslim-led government , something the European NATO allies oppose for fear it would escalate the fighting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;14	The transatlantic rift came to a head with the de-facto loss of the Muslim enclave of Bihac as a U.N. `` safe area . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;15	Seeking to mend fences , Christopher told the allies :
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;16	`` Let me stress one important fact : The crisis in Bosnia is about Bosnia and the former Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0085;17	It does not diminish NATO 's enduring importance . ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0089;0	A German diplomat 's report in advance of Thursday 's NATO ministerial meeting in Brussels accused the United States of sowing mistrust over Bosnia and the eastward expansion of the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;1	NATO Ambassador Hermann von Richthofen filed the cable to the German Foreign Ministry on Nov. 22 , according to the Suddeutsche Zeitung , which published excerpts and provided a copy to The Associated Press on Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;2	At the time it was written , U.S. policymakers were urging more forceful attacks against Bosnian Serbs and lifting the arms embargo against the Muslim-led government .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;3	There were reports , denied by U.S. officials , of secret military assistance to the Muslims .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;4	The U.S. moves caused especially deep mistrust in France , which is not part of NATO 's military structure but had been drawing closer to the alliance , the cable said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;5	U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher was expected to tell the allies in Brussels that the Clinton administration had swung behind their view that diplomacy , not force , was the best way to deal with the Bosnian conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;6	While the conflicts described in the classified document come as no surprise , the cable offered an unusually detailed view into NATO in the midst of a severe crisis .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;7	Richthofen accused the United States of acting behind the backs of its allies and of lacking a clear strategy in its push to expand NATO membership eastwards at a time when NATO states are at odds on priorities .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;8	Greece and Italy favor expanding NATO in the south , to include Romania , Bulgaria and possibly Malta , the paper says , while the northern alliance members think the top priorities are Poland , Hungary , and the Czech republic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;9	The U.S.-designed Partnership for Peace for eastern Europe and the former Soviet republics has n't convinced many of the states it 's aimed at , `` thereby discrediting a piece of Alliance policy , '' the cable says .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;10	`` Yet the U.S. administration is moving quickly to expand NATO without consultations on the ... consequences for the alliance , '' it said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;11	The Republican victory in U.S. Congressional elections raised the threat of a U.S. policy even more alienating to Russia , it said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0089;12	`` The alliance is divided and in crisis , '' the cable concludes , because in the post-Cold War era , it can only hold together with a clear sense of mission and strategy -- which it lacks .

APW_ENG_19941201.0091;0	Defenders and attacking Serbs traded heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire around embattled Bihac on Thursday in the wake of a failed peace mission by U.N. chief Boutros Boutros-Ghali , the United Nations said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;1	The Bosnian army commander pledged that despite heavy losses in the northwest corner of Bosnia , Bihac would not fall into Serb hands and the Muslim-led army would win the war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;2	Comments by Gen. Rasim Delic to the Sarajevo daily Oslobodjenje underscored the government 's unwillingness to compromise further to reach a cease-fire and a comprehensive peace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;3	Intransigence by both sides led Boutros-Ghali to suggest for the first time Wednesday that the U.N. peacekeeping mission might have to end .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;4	Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic told Boutros-Ghali that his government would negotiate only after Serbs accepted a peace plan they repeatedly have rejected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;5	He reiterated his government 's offer of a three-month cease-fire .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;6	Serbs want something more permanent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;7	Bosnian Serbs snubbed Boutros-Ghali altogether .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;8	Their leader , Radovan Karadzic , refused to come to the Sarajevo airport to meet him , and Boutros-Ghali rejected entering Serb-held territory for the meeting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;9	Maj. Herve Gourmelon , a U.N. spokesman in Sarajevo , said heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire broke out around Bihac late Wednesday and in the predawn hours Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;10	That was after it was clear the Boutros-Ghali mission was a failure .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;11	Some shelling also was reported .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;12	There was no immediate information on any changes in the frontlines .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;13	Sketchy information indicates that they have been stable in recent days , with Serbs holding 30-40 percent of the U.N.-declared `` safe area '' consisting of Bihac town and its environs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;14	Bosnian Serbs have been joined in the fighting by Serbs from neighboring Croatia and renegade Muslims under warlord Fikret Abdic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;15	In the newspaper interview , Delic said government forces still could win .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;16	`` Bihac will not fall , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;17	The Bosnian army is much stronger and better-organized than the rag-tag group that formed at the beginning of the war with rebel Serbs in 1992 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;18	`` That does not mean we will not lose some battles , '' Delic said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;19	`` But we definitely will win the war . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;20	But with the threat of Western military force against them discredited , the Serbs appeared to be in no mood to compromise .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;21	NATO ministers meeting in Brussels on Thursday were to hear a proposal from U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher for a new international conference on former Yugoslavia at which the Serbs could make demands for new peace proposals .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;22	Already , senior Western officials are proposing that the Bosnian Serbs be allowed links to Serb-led Yugoslavia , which they long have desired .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;23	That would be a step toward creation of Serb nationalists ' goal , a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;24	Bosnian Serbs have rejected a peace plan that would reduce their holdings in Bosnia to 49 percent from about 70 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;25	The Bosnian Serbs would n't mind seeing the United Nations leave Bosnia , believing it would allow them to force the government to settle on Serb terms .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;26	A withdrawal would likely lead to a bloodier conflict and could draw peacekeepers into battle as both sides rushe to seize U.N. equipment .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;27	Widespread hardship probably would result .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;28	Boutros-Ghali stressed that the United Nation feeds an estimated 3 million people across the former Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;29	Most are in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0091;30	More than 200,000 are dead or missing in the 31-month conflict launched by Serbs who rebelled against a Muslim-Croat vote to declare independence from Serb-led Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;0	A German diplomat 's report in advance of Thursday 's NATO ministerial meeting in Brussels accused the United States of sowing mistrust over Bosnia and the eastward expansion of the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;1	NATO Ambassador Hermann von Richthofen filed the cable to the German Foreign Ministry on Nov. 22 , according to the Suddeutsche Zeitung , which published excerpts and provided a copy to The Associated Press on Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;2	At the time it was written , U.S. policymakers were urging more forceful attacks against Bosnian Serbs and lifting the arms embargo against the Muslim-led government .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;3	There were reports , denied by U.S. officials , of secret military assistance to the Muslims .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;4	The U.S. moves caused especially deep mistrust in France , which is not part of NATO 's military structure but had been drawing closer to the alliance , the cable said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;5	U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher was expected to tell the allies in Brussels that the Clinton administration had swung behind their view that diplomacy , not force , was the best way to deal with the Bosnian conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;6	While the conflicts described in the classified document come as no surprise , the cable offered an unusually detailed view into NATO in the midst of a severe crisis .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;7	Richthofen accused the United States of acting behind the backs of its allies and of lacking a clear strategy in its push to expand NATO membership eastwards at a time when NATO states are at odds on priorities .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;8	Greece and Italy favor expanding NATO in the south , to include Romania , Bulgaria and possibly Malta , the paper says , while the northern alliance members think the top priorities are Poland , Hungary , and the Czech republic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;9	The U.S.-designed Partnership for Peace for eastern Europe and the former Soviet republics has n't convinced many of the states it 's aimed at , `` thereby discrediting a piece of Alliance policy , '' the cable says .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;10	`` Yet the U.S. administration is moving quickly to expand NATO without consultations on the ... consequences for the alliance , '' it said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;11	The Republican victory in U.S. Congressional elections raised the threat of a U.S. policy even more alienating to Russia , it said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0092;12	`` The alliance is divided and in crisis , '' the cable concludes , because in the post-Cold War era , it can only hold together with a clear sense of mission and strategy -- which it lacks .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;0	Secretary of State Warren Christopher is telling the NATO allies the Clinton administration has swung to their view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the war in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;1	It is the first time in the post-World War II history of the alliance that the Europeans led by France prevailed over the United States in formulating a major policy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;2	It is a difficult assignment for Christopher , putting him in the awkward position of shifting gears even while denying U.S. policy on the war has changed or that there is a trans-Atlantic rift .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;3	Trying to patch over the embarrassing dispute , Christopher pronounced the alliance strong and he charted a plan for growth through absorption of East European countries .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;4	A ceremony was scheduled to establish links to Russia , for decades the direct target of NATO 's massive military preparedness program .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;5	He told the allies in a speech that `` the tragedy of the war and bloodshed in Bosnia does not diminish our responsibility to build a comprehensive European security architecture . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;6	`` America 's interests in Europe have not changed , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;7	`` Neither have the basic principles guiding our engagement . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;8	And at the top of the list , Christopher said today , was that `` the United States has enduring political , military , economic and cultural links to europe that must and will be preserved . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;9	Earlier , at breakfast with Douglas Hurd , the British foreign secretary , Christopher reviewed the warning U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali delivered Wednesday that unless warring Serbs and Muslims cooperate with the U.N. mission the peacekeepers might be withdrawn .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;10	Christopher and Hurd said they may go to Belgrade , the Yugoslav capital , this weekend to preach reconciliation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;11	`` We will redouble our efforts to find a diplomatic solution , '' Christopher said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;12	However , his aides spread the word a trip by Christopher to Belgrade was unlikely .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;13	Asked if the troops would be withdrawn , Hurd replied grimly : `` We certainly hope not . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;14	National Security Adviser Anthony Lake , in a speech Wednesday at Princeton University , acknowledged it is a path `` rife with frustrations and setbacks . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;15	Nonetheless , he said , `` it 's the best , the steadiest course .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;16	... Both sides face the same choice : They can perpetuate a bloody military stalemate or they can stop the senseless killing and come to terms . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;17	By chance , it is the U.S. turn to preside over a meeting today of the North Atlantic Council , NATO 's policy-making arm .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;18	This puts Christopher under an even brighter spotlight , and he was responding both with a brief speech opening the session and a detailed one outlining U.S. plans for NATO 's expansion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;19	On Friday , Christopher intends to lay out the U.S. approach to the Bosnian war in a meeting with Hurd and Foreign Ministers Alain Juppe of France , Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia and Klaus Kinkel of Germany .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;20	It is centered on a call for an international peace conference that would give the Bosnian Serbs an opportunity to demand changes in the peace plan they have rejected repeatedly .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;21	They already have strong intimations of support from the Clinton administration in pressing for cross-border political ties to the Serb-dominated government in Belgrade -- a big step toward their goal of a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;22	And even the peace plan map the Bosnian Serbs rejected is open to negotiations , Clinton administration officials promised in this week of candid admissions by Defense Secretary William Perry and other senior U.S. officials that the Bosnian Serbs can not be stopped in their territorial conquests by military force .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;23	`` This alliance will continue to be the anchor of American engagement in Europe , the linchpin of trans-Atlantic security , '' Christopher said in a brief statement opening the North Atlantic Council session .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;24	He also assured the 15 foreign ministers that the Clinton administration was committed to keep 100,000 American troops in Europe `` as part of our continuing engagement . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;25	The European allies , particularly France and Britain , have taken this position throughout the 31-month war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;26	They managed to limit NATO air strikes despite U.N. assurances that Bihac , the mostly Muslim town on the verge of falling to the Serbs , was a `` safe area '' from which heavy weapons were to be excluded .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;27	They also hemmed in the 23,000 peacekeepers in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;28	Lake , in his speech at Princeton , stressed that NATO had chosen not to intervene directly in Bosnia and had given the lead to the United Nations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;29	`` Right or wrong , that decision has consequences with which we must continue to struggle , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;30	Before leaving Washington , Christopher grumbled to reporters about NATO 's refusal to engage in a sustained bombardment of Serb positions in the northwestern region of the bloodied country .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;31	But having threatened the Serbs in the past with NATO might , he abandoned the threat when asked what `` sticks '' the United States was using to persuade the Serbs to relinquish their grip on Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;32	If they kept fighting , Christopher said , they risked Serbia closing its border and a tightening of sanctions -- measures that are far less threatening than attacks by NATO warplanes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;33	Serbia has been the principal arms supplier to Serbs in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;34	And while Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic has promised to cut them off , a senior U.S. official said there was considerable `` leakage '' and arms were getting through .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;35	Seeking to limit the damage to the alliance , which successfully stood up to the Soviet Union but has caved on Bosnia , Christopher said he wanted to stress that `` the crisis in Bosnia is about Bosnia and the former Yugoslavia ; it 's not about NATO and its future . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;36	But NATO 's impotence has raised questions about NATO 's future .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;37	Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas suggested after meeting in Brussels with alliance officials that the alliance may have become irrelevant .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;38	`` There 's been no pressure on the Serbs and until there 's some leverage , it 's going to be very difficult to stop the fighting and reach some kind of settlement , '' Dole said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;39	Challenging the influential Republican , Hurd said Dole `` does not understand the consequences '' for Sarajevo , the Bosnian capital , for Muslim enclaves and for the people of the country if U.N. peacekeepers were withdrawn .
APW_ENG_19941201.0093;40	`` NATO is a collective security organization and that is to say it is the organization which keeps us safe in our beds at night , '' Hurd said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;0	Bitter Russians lashed out at the U.S. Embassy on Thursday after being surprised by what one called `` the latest insult '' to Russians trying to visit the United States : a new dlrs 20 visa application fee .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;1	`` I wonder why we 're trying so hard to go to this ` wonderful ' country , America , when its embassy has so little respect for us , '' said Sergei Tumbasov , a construction engineer hoping to go to Virginia on business .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;2	The U.S. Embassy announced Wednesday several changes to its much-criticized visa application process , including the new fee , which was payable in rubles and went into effect Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;3	Human rights activists and Russian officials have criticized consular officials in recent months for rudeness and for humiliating visa applicants .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;4	Tumbasov said no one had told him of the fee until he arrived at the embassy Thursday morning , not even the consular officer he had spoken to the day before .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;5	The new non-refundable application fee is especially painful for the more than 100 applicants who are rejected for visas by the Moscow embassy daily .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;6	`` This unexpected fee is the final insult in an absolutely absurd process , '' said Marina Orlova , an eye doctor from the prestigious Fyodorov Clinic , who was turned away Thursday for not sufficiently proving her intent to return to Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;7	`` Who do they think we are ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;8	We 're doctors , professionals . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;9	If Orlova returns to the embassy with further documentation to support her application , she must pay an additional dlrs 20 , according to the new regulations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;10	This fee does not include the cost of the visa itself , which runs an additional dlrs 20 for a single-entry visa , or dlrs 120 for a multi-entry visa .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;11	`` The system is made for the mafia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;12	No one else can afford it , '' Orlova added loudly , prompting a guard to ask her to leave the crowded sidewalk in front of the embassy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;13	An average of 550 people apply for U.S. visas at this embassy daily , and about 133,000 people have applied in the past year , according to embassy figures .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;14	But the overwhelmed consular office can not hold all the applicants , forcing them to wait for hours outside , even in the city 's bitter December weather .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;15	Vladimir Gulagin , a technical consultant planning a business trip to New York , brushed the falling snow off a medium-sized suitcase full of documents Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;16	Gulagin was refused a visa on Tuesday and was told to return with further documentation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;17	He was not told , however , about the new fee .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;18	`` It 's a good thing I had borrowed money from my wife this morning , '' Gulagin said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;19	`` I spent most of my paycheck yesterday , getting all these documents copied . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;20	After announcing the new fee , U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering on Wednesday outlined a number of steps designed to ease the visa process , including an `` express lane '' and easier processing for business visa applications .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;21	Vasily Ignatkin , head of the visa department at the Diplomatic Corps Administration Bureau , said the changes in the process were welcome , but that it would be `` some time before any serious improvements are evident . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;22	Those in line outside the embassy were even more skeptical .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;23	`` It 's all talk , '' Tumbasov said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0094;24	`` They 're trying to comfort us -LRB- with the other changes -RRB- while they ask us for more money . ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0098;0	Taiwan 's first homemade patrol boat became operational Thursday to help defend the island 's coastal waters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0098;1	The 500-ton vessel will be equipped with a locally developed Hsiung-feng I anti-ship missile system and 40mm artillery , the navy said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0098;2	`` The boat is very swift and has powerful ammunition .
APW_ENG_19941201.0098;3	The navy 's defense capability can be significantly boosted if we can have more of the boats in the future , '' navy chief Ku Chung-lien said at the commissioning ceremony in Kaohsiung , southern Taiwan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0098;4	The `` Chinchiang '' was privately manufactured by the Lien Ho Shipbuilding Co. and the United Ship Design and Development Center .
APW_ENG_19941201.0098;5	The navy declined to say how many it will buy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0098;6	It was priced at 490 million Taiwan dollars -LRB- U.S. dlrs 18.15 million -RRB- and construction began in August last year , said Lien Ho 's vice manager , Tai Fu-pin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0098;7	The navy said the boat also will be used to crack down on smuggling activities and protect Taiwanese fishing boats .
APW_ENG_19941201.0098;8	Taiwan wants to buy advanced weapons abroad and develop military technology at home to meet threats from China , which regards the island as a breakaway province and has not renounced the use of force to recover it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0098;9	Taiwan is the seat of the Nationalist government which fled China 's mainland in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Communists .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;0	A 44-year-man convicted of stabbing three women to death in 1977 was hanged Thursday , news reports said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;1	It was the first execution reported in one year in Japan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;2	The mass-circulation newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun and Kyodo News Service reported that Yukio Ajima was hanged at the Tokyo Detention House , nine years after the Supreme Court rejected his final appeal .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;3	Executions in Japan , all by hanging , are carried out in secret and authorities give no information afterward to media , relatives or the public , although there has been recent discussion of announcing executions .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;4	Relatives and lawyers now confirm executions by checking whether the condemned person 's name has been crossed off registration lists at government offices .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;5	The execution came five days after the Prime Minister 's Office announced the results of its first survey in five years on the death penalty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;6	It showed 73.8 percent of those responding favored retaining the death penalty , the highest percentage since such surveys began in 1956 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;7	The office said 13.6 percent favored abolition , the lowest figure in 38 years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;8	Senior Justice Ministry officials suggested that public opinion may have been influenced by recent increases in violent crime in Japan , generally considered a safe country .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;9	In the survey , the office questioned 3,000 adults at random throughout the country in early September .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;10	In the last survey , in 1989 , 67 percent favored the death penalty and 16 percent opposed it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;11	Before Thursday , the last reported executions were four on Nov. 26 , 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;12	Before that , three on March 26 , 1993 , were the first reported in three years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;13	Executions require an order from the justice minister , and some holders of the office have declined .
APW_ENG_19941201.0099;14	Before Thursday 's reported hanging , 59 convicts had been awaiting execution , according to Amnesty International Japan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0100;0	Asian stock markets closed generally lower Thursday , with share prices falling in Tokyo after three days of gains .
APW_ENG_19941201.0100;1	Tokyo 's 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 62.02 points , or 0.33 percent , closing at 19,013.60 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0100;2	On Wednesday , the average had gained 149.13 points , or 0.79 percent , to 19,075.62 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0100;3	The Tokyo Stock Price Index of all issues listed on the first section was down 1.21 points , or 0.08 percent , to 1,519.20 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0100;4	It had gained 17.59 points , or 1.17 percent , to 1,520.41 on Wednesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0100;5	Traders said share prices opened lower on profit-taking , recovered in midday on bargain-hunting , but then fell back in the afternoon session due to persistent arbitrage-linked sales .
APW_ENG_19941201.0100;6	Meanwhile , the U.S. dollar closed at 99.01 , up 0.03 yen from Wednesday 's finish in Tokyo and also above its overnight closing of 98.93 yen in New York .
APW_ENG_19941201.0100;7	It was the first time that the dollar had closed above 99.00 yen in Tokyo since Oct. 13 , when it finished at 99.88 yen .
APW_ENG_19941201.0100;8	In Hong Kong , share prices closed lower for the second straight day in light trading .
APW_ENG_19941201.0100;9	The Hang Seng Index , the market 's key indicator of blue chips , fell 35.46 points , or 0.4 percent , closing at 8,430.80 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0100;10	On Wednesday , the index had plunged 192 points .

APW_ENG_19941201.0100;21	The Philippines ' PSE index of 43 selected issues fell 45.83 points to 2,645.36 .

APW_ENG_19941201.0101;0	NATO foreign ministers met Thursday to begin laying the groundwork for the entry of former Warsaw Pact foes as new members in the coming years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;1	But their two-day meeting was likely to be overshadowed by the crisis in Bosnia that has put extraordinary strains on the relationship between the United States and its European allies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;2	During the talks , U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher was expected to tell the allies the Clinton administration has swung behind their view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the Bosnian conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;3	It marks a major policy switch by Washington under pressure from the European allies , led by Britain and France .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;4	The change in U.S. policy will help heal an unprecedented rift within the alliance over Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;5	Seeking to mend fences , Christopher told the allies :
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;6	`` Let me stress one important fact : The crisis in Bosnia is about Bosnia and the former Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;7	It does not diminish NATO 's enduring importance . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;8	NATO 's new Secretary General Willy Claes appealed for unity .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;9	`` We are now being put to -LRB- the -RRB- test , and I have every confidence that our solidarity will see us through now has it has in even darker circumstances . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;10	The foreign ministers are anxious their talks not be entirely hijacked by the Bosnian crisis .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;11	They intend to order a study that would set out the terms and conditions for the acceptance of East European countries as new members .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;12	`` We have a moral duty not to squander this historic opportunity to anchor the new democracies of central and eastern Europe permanently in the West , '' Claes told the meeting 's opening ceremony .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;13	The decision to authorize the study will mark a cautious move forward in drawing former adversaries in Eastern Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;14	Poland , Hungary and others have appealed for membership and the security guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;15	`` Today , we take an important step in the process that will lead to NATO expansion , '' Christopher said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;16	The study -- dubbed an `` owner 's manual '' for NATO membership -- will take a year to complete .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;17	It will not name candidates for membership , nor will it set a deadline for admittance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;18	Instead , it will focus on such questions as : What effect will newcomers have on NATO 's common military command structure ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;19	How much will enlargement cost NATO ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;20	Do NATO troops need to be based in the new member states ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;21	The study will also make clear to prospective applicants what membership would cost them in money and materiel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;22	To counter Russian worries about an eastward expansion of NATO , the allies intend later Thursday to endorse a sweeping military cooperation program with Russia and agree to hold regular talks with Moscow on security matters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;23	Despite attempts to keep the focus on new members , the Bosnian crisis will no doubt occupy a large amount of the ministers ' time .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;24	At a breakfast with British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd , Christopher reviewed the warning U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali delivered Wednesday that unless warring Serbs and Muslims cooperate with the U.N. mission the peacekeepers might be withdrawn .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;25	Christopher and Hurd said they may go to Belgrade , the Serbian capital , this weekend to preach reconciliation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;26	`` We will redouble our efforts to find a diplomatic solution , '' Christopher said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;27	The latest American approach centers on a call for an international peace conference that would let Bosnian Serbs seek changes in the peace plan they repeatedly have rejected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;28	That plan would require them to cut their holdings in Bosnia from 70 percent to 49 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;29	The Clinton administration , officials say , is also leaning toward approval of political ties between Serbs in Bosnia and Serbia proper -- a big step toward their aim of a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;30	On Friday , Christopher will meet with here his counterparts from France , Germany , Britain and Russia to discuss new plans to revive their moribund peace plan for Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;31	France and Britain have been criticized in the U.S. Congress for refusing to let the United Nations use the Western military alliance 's air power to the full .
APW_ENG_19941201.0101;32	In turn , Congress has forced the Clinton administration to seek a lifting of the arms embargo against Bosnia 's Muslim-led government , something the European NATO allies oppose for fear it would escalate the fighting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;0	Defenders and attacking Serbs traded heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire around embattled Bihac on Thursday in the wake of a failed peace mission by U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;1	The Bosnian army commander pledged that despite heavy losses in the northwest corner of Bosnia , Bihac would not fall into Serb hands .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;2	Comments by Gen. Rasim Delic to the Sarajevo newspaper Oslobodjenje underscored the government 's unwillingness to compromise to reach a cease-fire and a comprehensive peace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;3	Intransigence by both sides led Boutros-Ghali to suggest for the first time Wednesday that U.N. peacekeepers might be withdrawn .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;4	Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic told Boutros-Ghali that his government would negotiate only after Serbs accepted a peace plan they repeatedly have rejected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;5	Under the plan , the Serbs would have to give up about a third of the territory they have conquered .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;6	He reiterated his government 's offer of a three-month cease-fire .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;7	Serbs want something more permanent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;8	Bosnian Serbs snubbed Boutros-Ghali altogether .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;9	Their leader , Radovan Karadzic , refused to come to the Sarajevo airport to meet him , and Boutros-Ghali rejected entering Serb-held territory for the meeting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;10	Maj. Herve Gourmelon , a U.N. spokesman in Sarajevo , said heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire broke out around Bihac late Wednesday and into Thursday , after it was clear that Boutros-Ghali 's mission had failed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;11	Some shelling was also reported .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;12	There was no information on any changes in the frontlines , which have been stable in the past few days .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;13	Sketchy reports indicate the Serbs hold 30 to 40 percent of the U.N.-declared `` safe area '' consisting of Bihac town and its environs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;14	Bosnian Serbs have been joined in the offensive by Serbs from neighboring Croatia and renegade Muslims under warlord Fikret Abdic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;15	In the newspaper interview , Delic said government forces still could win .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;16	The Bosnian army is much stronger and better-organized than the rag-tag group formed at the beginning of the war with rebel Serbs in 1992 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;17	`` That does not mean we will not lose some battles , '' Delic said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;18	`` But we definitely will win the war . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;19	With members of NATO and the United Nations unwilling to use vigorous military force , the Serbs appeared to be in no mood to compromise .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;20	NATO ministers meeting in Brussels on Thursday were to hear a proposal from U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher for a new international conference on the former Yugoslavia at which the Serbs could make demands for new peace proposals .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;21	Already , senior Western officials are proposing that the Bosnian Serbs be allowed links to Serb-led Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;22	Serb nationalists have in part waged war to create a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;23	The Bosnian Serbs would n't mind seeing the United Nations leave Bosnia , believing it would allow them to force the government to settle on Serb terms .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;24	A withdrawal would likely lead to a bloodier conflict and could draw peacekeepers into battle as both sides rush to seize U.N. equipment .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;25	Widespread hardship probably would result .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;26	Boutros-Ghali stressed that the United Nations feeds an estimated 3 million people across the former Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;27	Most are in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0102;28	More than 200,000 are dead or missing in the 31-month conflict launched by Serbs who rebelled against a Muslim-Croat vote to declare independence from Serb-led Yugoslavia .
