APW_ENG_19941201.0230;0	The Achille Lauro smoldered on a placid sea Thursday , a day after a raging fire forced the nearly 1,000 people aboard to take to lifeboats and abandon the cruise ship listing off Somalia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;1	Two passengers were reported dead from the Italian liner , which gained notoriety in 1985 when Palestinian terrorists hijacked and killed a wheelchair-bound American passenger .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;2	After a night aboard the oil tanker that picked them up , hundreds of passengers began transferring aboard an armada of commercial vessels and two U.S. Navy ships for passage to nearby ports , including Mombasa in Kenya , the Seychelles and Djibouti .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;3	`` The fire was so big you had to fight through smoke which poured down toward the cabins , '' one survivor , Tony Webb , was quoted as telling the London Daily Telegraph .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;4	Webb , a 44-year-old Briton who now lives in Cape Town , South Africa , had taken his wife and 2-year-old son on the cruise after winning a contest .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;5	He said he was still wearing his dinner jacket after a ship 's dance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;6	`` People were in their evening suits and dressing gowns , '' the paper quoted Webb as saying .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;7	`` They had to ferry the children to the lifeboats first , '' Webb said , adding that the smoke grew thicker as the rest waited .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;8	As his son Michael clung to him , terrified , Webb recalled , '' flames were leaping up and there was smoke all around '' as passengers looked back .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;9	Thursday 's transfer operation was '' very organized , '' said Cmdr. T McCreary , spokesman for the U.S. Navy 's Central Command , based in Bahrain . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;10	Folks down there have a pretty good handle on the situation . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;11	At mid-morning on Thursday , the empty , scarred Achille Lauro was still afloat , listing badly to port .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;12	White steam and gray smoke poured from its port side and smaller streams came drifting out of the lower starboard deck .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;13	Though her name was still visible on the stern , the cruise ship 's blue and white paint was scorched and mottled , the white stars on her two smokestacks blackened by heat and soot .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;14	Although crippled , the Achille Lauro appeared in no danger of sinking quickly .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;15	The ship was listing at about 20 degrees , John Briand , captain of the oil tanker Lima , told the BBC .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;16	The fire started Wednesday , apparently in the passenger area , but the cause was not known , said the ship 's owner , Starlauro of Genoa , Italy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;17	But Dmitrios Skapinkais , the Greek captain of the Treasure Island , said the liner 's captain , who came aboard to use his ship 's radiotelephone , said the fire started in the engine room .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;18	Eight people were injured in the fire .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;19	About 60 crewmembers fought the fire before abandoning the 23,478-ton ship 210 kilometers -LRB- 130 miles -RRB- south of the Horn of Africa .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;20	The pilot of a plane carrying an Associated Press reporter and cameramen put the ship 's position at 160 miles east of the small Somali fishing village of Eil .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;21	Capt. Ferdinando Lolli , a port official in Rome , said the ship was carrying 581 passengers and 404 crew .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;22	Most of the crew was Italian , and the passengers mainly South African , German , Dutch and British .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;23	Late Wednesday evening , Italian Coast Guard officials reported that everyone on the Achille Lauro was accounted for .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;24	Starlauro identified the dead as a Briton and a German .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;25	The Panamanian oil ship Hawaiian King was one of the first ships to arrive at the scene and took on about 800 people , said a coast guard official in Rome , Adm. Eugenio Sicurezza .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;26	`` Quite a few people were injured in the transfer -- there 's a few broken bones and some pretty tortured souls , '' Briand said , adding that many of the rescued passengers were elderly .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;27	Many had to spend the night on the Hawaiian King 's deck , Briand said , and other ships sent over food , blankets and toiletries .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;28	Two U.S. warships , the USS Gettysburg and USS Halyburton , arrived overnight and dispatched helicopters to ferry water , food and medical supplies to the survivors , McCreary said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;29	The Achille Lauro left Genoa on Nov. 19 , stopped in Israel , and its next port of call was to be Durban , South Africa , on Friday , said Carla Gotta , a spokeswoman for the cruise ship 's owner .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;30	The terrorists who hijacked the Achille Lauro in 1985 shot American Leon Klinghoffer and pushed him in his wheelchair off the ship .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;31	The hijackers escaped the vessel and boarded a jet , but U.S. fighter planes forced it to land in Italy and the hijackers were captured .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;32	Launched in 1946 in the Netherlands , the Achille Lauro was acquired 20 years later by the Neapolitan shipping dynasty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;33	It first transported Italian immigrant workers to and from Australia and was outfitted for pleasure cruises in 1970 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;34	The liner rammed a fishing boat in 1971 off Italy , killing a Neapolitan fisherman .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;35	And on Dec. 2 , 1981 , fire broke out aboard ship off the Canary Islands .
APW_ENG_19941201.0230;36	Panicked passengers jumped into the sea , and two of them drowned .
APW_ENG_19941201.0231;0	The Union Bank of Switzerland officially opened a representative office in Kuala Lumpur Thursday , saying it saw tremendous prospects for growth in Malaysia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0231;1	A key task of the office would be to help clients tap into regional and global capital sources , said Lim Ho Kee , the bank 's executive vice president and chief executive officer for East Asia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0231;2	He said many Malaysian companies were going offshore to develop infrastructure projects , for which UBS could be the financier .
APW_ENG_19941201.0231;3	`` The prospects for growth of UBS Malaysia are tremendous , '' he said at a news conference .
APW_ENG_19941201.0231;4	UBS began operations in Malaysia with the opening of a research office in Kuala Lumpur in 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0231;5	It plans to open a full office soon in Labuan , 1,380 kilometers -LRB- 860 miles -RRB- east of Kuala Lumpur .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;0	Rich countries are expected to grab the biggest share of benefits from an extensive trade liberalizing agreement , while the poor may have to scrabble for crumbs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;1	The GATT trade accord , which is meant to take effect Jan. 1 , is forecast to boost global incomes by as much as dlrs 510 billion over the next 10 years and will be the biggest trade bonanza the world has ever seen .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;2	It will cut barriers to hundreds of thousands of exports ranging from radios to roses , make it easier for companies to win untapped markets , and reduce store prices for consumers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;3	The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade predicts that incomes in the European Union will be boosted by dlrs 164 billion per year and in the United States by dlrs 122 billion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;4	Gains in Japan are put at dlrs 27 billion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;5	The forecasts are for 2005 because the accord will be phased in gradually .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;6	GATT predicts that developing countries and transition economies like the former Soviet bloc will share dlrs 116 billion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;7	But this conceals the fact that some of the poorest nations -- especially in sub-Saharan Africa might actually be worse off .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;8	So why the winners and losers ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;9	The lion 's share of the gains in the United States and European Union are expected as a result of the 10-year phase out of textile and clothing import quotas which protect domestic industries from cheaper Third World competition and raise prices .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;10	Asian and Latin American countries , which have been infuriated by the limits on their exports , are expected to benefit from the liberalization , though it does n't go as far as they wanted .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;11	In the short term it will be painful for local U.S. and European industries .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;12	A U.S. government study last year said nearly 47,000 jobs might be lost in the clothing sector alone -- about 6 percent of its total employment .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;13	But in the long term , jobs lost in the textiles sector will be recreated in more efficient industries , leading to a better use of resources and more wealth -- at least in theory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;14	The price of clothing for American families is expected to fall by 11 percent once the restrictions end .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;15	Efficient food producers in Canada , Australia and Brazil are rubbing their hands at the prospect of bigger exports .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;16	The trade accord cuts back subsidies over a six-year period to European and American farmers who have used the government grants to undercut competitors on world markets .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;17	French farmers in particular are outraged at the perceived threat to their livelihood .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;18	And there have been repeated riots in Japan and South Korea in support of rice farmers who will for the first time face foreign competition , albeit on a limited scale .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;19	But it should good news to taxpayers and consumers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;20	For instance , the average cow in the United States and Europe gets more government funds than many Third World workers earn in a year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;21	Inflated prices in shops should also be cut .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;22	Ironically , the immediate impact may be the opposite in some poor African food importing nations , which are clamoring for compensation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;23	For example , Egypt imports dlrs 1 billion worth of subsidized cereals each year from the United States and Europe and expects price increases once those subsidies are cut .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;24	This loss will be only partly offset by more open markets in Europe for Egyptian fruit and vegetables .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;25	Europe has kept its doors open to products from former colonies in Africa and the Caribbean under a preferential deal .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;26	The benefits of this are expected to dry up as other countries gain more access to European markets under the GATT accord .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;27	And if freer trade drives down already weak prices for commodities like cocoa and coffee , then some African nations may be double or triple losers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;28	Charities like the British-based Christian Aid estimate that Africa may end up losing dlrs 3 billion annually within the next ten years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;29	Other studies indicate the losses will be much smaller .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;30	`` North and West Africa will do particularly badly because they are very dependent on preferential trade agreements , because they import a lot of their food and because they are poor and vulnerable , '' says Peter Madden of Christian Aid .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;31	GATT critics also point out that large multinationals are likely to profit at the expense of small producers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;32	This is especially true of the planned new laws to increase patent protection .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;33	In India , there have been widespread protests over anticipated royalty payments and increased prices for farm seeds and medicines .
APW_ENG_19941201.0233;34	Mistrust of the GATT accord is so strong in India that it still goes under the title of Dunkel Draft Text -- after former GATT chief Arthur Dunkel -- and is equated with the deadly pesticide `` DDT . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0234;0	Monaco 's Prince Rainier , who last week underwent double bypass heart surgery , is recovering well and is expected to the leave the hospital early next week , the principality press office said Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0234;1	Rainier , 71 , was in excellent spirits at the principality 's Heart and Thoracic Clinic , eating normally , walking unassisted and receiving daily visits from his family , the statement said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0234;2	Rainier is expected to return to his cliffside palace next week to continue to convalesce .
APW_ENG_19941201.0234;3	Dr. Vincent Dor , who performed the open-heart surgery last Friday , called the operation a success .
APW_ENG_19941201.0234;4	The base of Rainier 's left coronary artery had been restricting the flow of blood to and from the heart .
APW_ENG_19941201.0234;5	The press office denied recent rumors that Rainier was about to abdicate in favor of his son , Prince Albert .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;0	With a brief lull in the civil war , the United Nations is trying to send a large relief convoy into Kabul for the first time in six months , an official said Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;1	Trucks carrying hundreds of tons of food , medicine and plastic sheeting recently left from Pakistan and is now south of the besieged city .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;2	U.N. officials are trying to negotiate safe passage across the front line in south Kabul , said a U.N. official who requested anonymity .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;3	Opposition leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar controls the main roads leading into the city and no large convoys can reach Kabul without his approval .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;4	And as winter descends on Kabul , the food situation is expected to worsen .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;5	The city 's food is now being supplied mostly by traders who cross the front line daily to buy flour , wood and gasoline from merchants in opposition-held territory to the south and the east of Kabul .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;6	There 's enough food available , but prices have skyrocketed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;7	If the U.N. effort is successful , the convoy could reach Kabul this weekend .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;8	It would be the first U.N. relief convoy to reach the capital since June .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;9	Hekmatyar 's forces tightened their blockade last winter and food supplies were running low until U.N. Secretary Boutros Boutros-Ghali made a personal appeal to Hekmatyar , who then eased the roadblocks .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;10	But many Afghans are critical of the United Nations , which removed its international staff from Kabul when heavy fighting erupted in January .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;11	A small staff made up entirely of Afghans now handles the limited U.N. operation in Kabul , while the U.N. 's international staff remains in Pakistan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;12	President Burhanuddin Rabbani 's government controls most of the capital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0235;13	But nine separate Islamic factions remain locked in a bitter battle that broke out after the groups ousted a Communist government in 1992 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;0	Two more journalists have been assassinated in Algeria , security forces said Thursday , bringing the death toll among journalists to about two dozen since the profession became a target of Islamic militants 18 months ago .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;1	The latest victims were Ahmed Issaad , a reporter for state television , and Nasseredine Lekhal , a journalist with the state-run daily El-Massa .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;2	They were stabbed to death Wednesday in Boufarik , south of Algiers , security forces said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;3	More than 11,000 people have been killed in a three-year insurgency pitting Muslim fundamentalist militants against the army-backed government .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;4	The toll sharply increased in November , with more than 400 people killed in the bloodiest month since the start of the insurgency .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;5	Most of the known victims for November were extremists killed by security forces , ordered to step up their campaign to `` eradicate terrorists '' after a failed government effort to negotiate with fundamentalists .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;6	The militants , depicting the media as government pawns , have designated journalists as a prime target of their assassination campaign , along with foreigners and intellectuals .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;7	About two dozen journalists have been murdered since May 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;8	Security forces said three other people were killed Wednesday along with the two journalists .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;9	Among them were the vice president and a member of Boufarik 's municipal council , appointed to replace fundamentalists elected but later banned from office .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;10	An estimated 200 Algerian journalists have left the country because of the killings and harsh government action against newspapers which violate strict security regulations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;11	Some 600 Islamic sympathizers remain in detention in a Sahara desert camp , the president of the government Observatory for Human Rights said Wednesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;12	In a sweeping roundup , Algeria placed at least 10,000 suspected fundamentalist sympathizers in seven desert camps after the February 1992 state of emergency was declared .
APW_ENG_19941201.0236;13	Kamel Rezzag-Bara said one center holding 600 prisoners was still in operation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;0	A Russian ultimatum demanding an end to Chechnya 's civil war expired today amid signs that Moscow was preparing to send troops into the breakaway southern republic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;1	A trickle of heavily loaded cars and trucks left the capital this morning as civilians headed for the countryside , fearing an attack by Russian soldiers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;2	Central Grozny was virtually empty following another nerve-jangling night of intermittent gunfire from jumpy fighters around the city .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;3	A military jet roared over the capital as the Russian deadline passed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;4	Later , heavy machine-gun fire rang out from the city center .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;5	The fighting in this republic of 1.2 million people pits forces loyal to Chechen President Dzhokhar Dudayev , who has declared Chechnya independent from Russia , against rebels who the maverick general says are armed and led by Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;6	President Boris Yeltsin ordered warring Chechens to lay down their arms and release all prisoners by this morning or face Russian military intervention .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;7	Dudayev and his forces defied the ultimatum .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;8	In Freedom Square outside the presidential building , several hundred volunteer fighters cradling Kalashnikov rifles and grenade-launchers gathered to hear speeches while a tank maneuvered into position .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;9	Chechen elders in tall fur hats , tunics and high leather boots danced in a circle , chanting , `` Freedom or death ! ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;10	Russian media reported troop movements around the borders of Chechnya , in the Caucasus Mountains region 650 miles southeast of Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;11	The Interfax and ITAR-Tass news agencies said Russian army units would support Interior Ministry forces to `` ensure stability in the region , safety of the population and avert the spread of the conflict . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;12	The conflict is the latest to underline tensions among the scores of ethnic groups in the former Soviet Union .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;13	The Caucasus region has been especially fractious , with fighting in the Ossetian and Abkhazian regions of Georgia and the Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;14	For Moscow , which governs dozens of republics and regions in the Russian Federation , Chechnya has become a test of whether it is willing to use military might to hold the country together .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;15	No other region has gone as far as Chechnya and declared independence .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;16	Moscow openly supports Dudayev 's opponents politically , but denies offering military assistance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;17	After Dudayev 's forces captured Russian fighters Saturday , Moscow said mercenaries were fighting on both sides .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;18	In Moscow , Yeltsin spokesman Vyacheslev Kostikov said Moscow had begun `` a series of measures '' to resolve the crisis .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;19	`` All necessary measures are being taken to save the Russian soldiers , '' he said , referring to those captured Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;20	He did not elaborate .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;21	Grozny 's central bazaar , which once thronged with thousands of people , was nearly empty today .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;22	A few elderly women trudged around in search of bread .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;23	Although the Chechens are fighting among themselves , many agreed that they have one thing in common : distrust of Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0238;24	Wrapped in an old leather coat and a scarf , 60-year-old Tamara Ofsayeva walked among the bazaar 's empty stalls and said Russia would have a tough time overrunning Chechnya .
APW_ENG_19941201.0239;0	President Clinton to name outgoing Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell special adviser for economic initiatives in Ireland .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;0	Yasser Arafat 's government took control of tax collection in the West Bank on Thursday , the latest step in transferring the day-to-day administration of the Palestinian territories to the PLO .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;1	The Palestine Liberation Organization , which runs the 6-month-old autonomy arrangement in the Gaza Strip and West Bank town of Jericho , has in recent months taken charge of education , tourism and welfare in the West Bank .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;2	Taxes and the health system , which is to be turned over later Thursday , complete the initial stage of self-rule , allowing Palestinians to control most aspects of their lives despite continued Israeli occupation in the West Bank .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;3	`` What we have completed gives the Palestinians a first entrance to the West Bank , '' said West Bank military governor Brig. Gen. Gadi Zohar , signing over the tax department to Palestinian Finance Minister Mohammed Nashashibi .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;4	The move came days before Israel and the PLO were to begin difficult negotiations on the next stage of autonomy -- redeployment of Israeli troops in the West Bank and Palestinian elections .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;5	Israel is worried that the PLO can not guarantee the safety of the 120,000 Jewish settlers once the army pulls out of Palestinian towns as stipulated in their peace accord .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;6	There are calls to renegotiate the agreement , including a proposal Wednesday by Deputy Foreign Minister Yossi Beilin to skip the interim phase altogether and begin talks now on the final status of the West Bank , Gaza Strip and Jerusalem .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;7	This coincides with a growing desire among Israelis for greater separation from the Palestinians .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;8	Police Minister Moshe Shahal on Thursday called for a complete closure of the West Bank and Gaza Strip once troops redeploy in the West Bank .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;9	He spoke a day after a Palestinian from the West Bank killed a 19-year-old woman soldier with an ax in northern Israel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;10	`` There is no alternative other than to demand separation , '' Shahal said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;11	`` Separation means that we do not have to open the territory out of economic and employment concerns until the Palestinians prove that they can prevent attacks . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;12	A closure would prevent 1.8 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza , including tens of thousands of day workers , from entering Israel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;13	Palestinian tax officials said Thursday their goal was to make their impoverished autonomy administration self-sufficient .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;14	`` We can not depend for the rest of our lives on the donor countries and the foreign investors in building our Palestinian state , '' said Deputy Finance Minister Atef Alawneh .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;15	In Brussels , foreign donors this week released dlrs 125 million already promised to the PLO , mostly to help the Palestinians meet running costs for a few months .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;16	Alawneh said he eventually hoped to raise dlrs 300 million to dlrs 400 million annually in taxes , much more than the sum raised by Israel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;17	During the six-year uprising against Israeli occupation , many Palestinians refused to pay taxes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;18	Israel retaliated by denying tax evaders documents such as drivers ' licenses and travel papers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;19	Soldiers accompanied tax collectors in night raids to confiscate goods from Palestinian homes in lieu of payment .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;20	The West Bank town of Beit Zahour staged a collective tax revolt , becoming the target of many such raids .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;21	George Rishmawi , a Beit Zahour textile factory owner , said he hoped the Palestinians would adopt a different policy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;22	`` We hope the whole system will be changed and we will start a new era , '' said Rishmawi , who was jailed for three months for not paying taxes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;23	`` We have paid the Israelis enough .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;24	They ripped us off .
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;25	They were thieves with licenses . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0240;26	Alawneh said tax debts going back to the Israeli era would not be forgiven , and only fines and interest would be canceled .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;0	NATO foreign ministers on Thursday approved an American proposal to draw up a blueprint setting out conditions for the entry of former Warsaw Pact foes as new members in the coming years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;1	After a turnaround in U.S. policy , they also agreed to relaunch diplomatic efforts to end the Bosnian war -- steering away from Washington 's previous calls to step up air strikes on the Serbs and end the ban on arms supplies to the Muslim-led government in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;2	The ministers endorsed a 12-month study to consider how to expand the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization to include East European democracies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;3	Issues will include financing , integrating the newcomers ' armies and nuclear issues , officials said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;4	Anxious to ease Russian fears about the expansion , the foreign ministers emphasized the alliance was not trying to create a hostile bloc .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;5	`` Having just overcome the division of Europe , we have no desire to see the emergence of new lines of partition , '' the ministers said in their final communique .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;6	The plan to open up to the East was to be the centerpiece of the two-day meeting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;7	But unprecedented strains between the United States and its European allies over the crisis in Bosnia overshadowed the talks .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;8	In an effort to heal the divisions , U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher swung behind the European view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;9	`` An agreement has been reached on the idea of relaunching the negotiations , '' French Foreign Minister Alain Juppe told reporters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;10	Juppe said he hoped a meeting Friday with Christopher and the foreign ministers of Germany , Britain and Russia would launch `` a new initiative '' to end the fighting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;11	Juppe added he will travel to Belgrade , the Serbian capital , on Sunday with British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd for talks with President Slobodan Milosevic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;12	However , in an apparent attempt to beef up its air power over Bosnia , NATO has asked Germany to add its warplanes to the allied forces on hand in case air strikes are called against the Serbs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;13	German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel said his government was considering the request .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;14	The request is highly sensitive because of Germany 's postwar pacifist tradition , and the history of Nazi atrocities in the Balkans during World War II .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;15	The foreign ministers were anxious their talks not be entirely hijacked by the Bosnian crisis .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;16	They ordered a study that would set out the terms for the acceptance of East European countries as new members .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;17	It should be ready when the ministers meet in Brussels a year from now .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;18	The United States had initially proposed a six-month study of enlargement , but the Europeans , mindful of Russia 's fears of isolation , extended it to 12 months .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;19	`` We should avoid premature enlargement that gives the impression that we seek a redivision of the European continent , '' said Juppe , according to a spokesman .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;20	The study will not name candidates for membership -- although Poland , Hungary , the Czech Republic and Slovakia are considered front-runners -- nor will it set a deadline for admittance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;21	`` It is premature to discuss the timeframe for enlargement or which particular countries would be invited to join the alliance , '' the final communique said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;22	Instead , the study will focus on such questions as whether NATO troops will need to be based in new member states ; how much enlargement will cost ; how to integrate the newcomers army into NATO 's command structure
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;23	To counter Russian worries about NATO 's eastward expansion , the allies intend on Thursday to endorse a sweeping military cooperation program with Moscow and agree to hold regular talks on security .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;24	Despite attempts to keep the focus on new members , ministers could not avoid the Bosnian crisis .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;25	The latest American approach centers on a call for an international peace conference that may allow Bosnian Serbs seek changes in the peace plan they repeatedly have rejected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;26	That plan requires them to cut their holdings in Bosnia from 70 percent to 49 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;27	The Clinton administration , officials say , is also leaning toward approval of political ties between Serbs in Bosnia and Serbia proper -- a big step toward their aim of a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;28	France and Britain have been criticized in the U.S. Congress for refusing to let the United Nations use the Western military alliance 's air power to the full .
APW_ENG_19941201.0241;29	In turn , Congress has forced the Clinton administration to seek a lifting of the arms embargo against Bosnia 's Muslim-led government , something the European NATO allies oppose for fear it would escalate the fighting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0242;0	President Clinton will name retiring Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell to be a special adviser for economic initiatives in Ireland , White House officials said Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0242;1	The officials , who spoke on condition of anonymity , said the appointment will be part-time , and not tied directly to peace talks between Britain and Ireland .
APW_ENG_19941201.0242;2	Mitchell , who did not run for re-election , will not be involved in the peace talks between Britain and Northern Ireland , the source said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;0	Clashes among rival political groups left at least four persons dead and 20 injured Thursday in two states legislature polls seen as a test of Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao 's popularity .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;1	The clashes occurred mostly in Andhra Pradesh , the home state of Rao , where leftist guerrillas called for a boycott of the elections in their northern stronghold to protest successive corrupt governments .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;2	The neighboring state of Karnataka was peaceful .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;3	But one political activist was killed when a mob hurled rocks at him while he tried to mobilize voters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;4	Polling was considered to be peaceful by Indian standards , where dozens of people have in the past been killed on the day of the balloting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;5	More than half of the 38 million voters cast their ballots across the two states Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;6	In Andhra Pradesh , police said they also killed three militants of the Peoples War Group , a rebel group fighting for poor farmers that carried out a series of sabotage incidents in the final weeks of the campaign to disrupt the voting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;7	At least 29 people were killed in land mine explosions blamed on the group .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;8	Two of the deaths in the state were blamed on explosives hurled during clashes political rivals .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;9	The third death occurred when a truck carrying crude bombs and activists of the Telugu Desam Party overturned while being chased by police .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;10	Four of the 38 bombs exploded and killed one person and injured another , police said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;11	Police received many cases of villagers looting ballot boxes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;12	Voting for state legislatures in the two south Indian states was seen as an important bellwether for Congress , which already has suffered setbacks in the north and must retain its support in the south .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;13	A loss in Rao 's own state could unleash rivalries in the governing party that he suppressed with difficulty last year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;14	Results will be announced Dec. 9 for elections in Andhra Pradesh , Karnataka and two other states that voted last month .
APW_ENG_19941201.0244;15	The voting is staggered to allow police forces to move from one to another to protect polling stations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;0	A Russian ultimatum demanding an end to Chechnya 's civil war expired early Thursday but Moscow appeared to back away from threats to send troops into the breakaway southern republic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;1	Russia had threatened on Tuesday to impose a state of emergency on the Caucasus Mountain region if its president , Dzhokhar Dudayev , and the rebels opposing him do not surrender prisoners and stop fighting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;2	Neither side showed any indication of doing so .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;3	But on Thursday evening , President Boris Yeltsin 's office issued an altered text of Yeltsin 's original ultimatum saying `` there was some disagreement in the media in interpreting certain clauses of the document . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;4	The reissued document skipped all reference to any introduction of a state of emergency .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;5	Meanwhile , Yeltsin issued a limited amnesty to Chechens who lay down their arms and are not implicated in grave crimes against civilians , ITAR-Tass said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;6	A delegation of Russian lawmakers and other leaders arrived in Grozny on Thursday afternoon and began closed-door talks with Chechen officials .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;7	In Grozny , jet flyovers jangled nerves for a third day , and dropped bombs at least once .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;8	Dudayev , looking tired under neon lights in the basement of his presidential palace , told a news conference his house had been bombed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;9	A small airport near the city was hit Thursday and a woman 's corpse was seen .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;10	The ITAR-Tass news agency said two women were killed in the raid at the military air base , and fuel depots were burning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;11	Meanwhile , a trickle of heavily loaded cars and trucks continued leaving Grozny before a feared attack by Russian soldiers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;12	Chechnya declared independence from Russia in 1991 , soon after Dudayev 's election .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;13	The fighting , which intensified last week after months of skirmishes , pits forces loyal to Dudayev against the rebels , who Dudayev says are armed and led by Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;14	Moscow openly supports Dudayev 's opponents politically , but denies offering military assistance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;15	After Dudayev 's forces captured Russian fighters Saturday , Moscow said mercenaries were fighting on both sides .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;16	A single military jet roared over Grozny as the Russian deadline passed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;17	Later , heavy machine-gun fire rang out from the city center .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;18	In Freedom Square outside the presidential building , several hundred volunteer fighters cradling Kalashnikov rifles and grenade launchers gathered to hear speeches while a tank maneuvered into position .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;19	Chechen elders in tall fur hats , tunics and high leather boots , danced in a circle , chanting , `` Freedom or death ! ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;20	Russian media reported troop movements around the borders of Chechnya , in southern Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;21	The Interfax and ITAR-Tass news agencies said Russian army units would support Interior Ministry forces to `` ensure stability in the region , safety of the population and avert the spread of the conflict . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;22	The conflict is the latest to underline the tensions among scores of ethnic groups in the former Soviet Union .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;23	The Caucasus region has been especially fractious , with fighting in the Ossetian and Abkhazian regions of Georgia and the Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;24	For Moscow , which governs dozens of republics and regions in the Russian Federation , Chechnya has become a test of whether it is willing to use military might to hold the country together .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;25	No other region has gone as far as Chechnya and declared independence .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;26	`` All necessary measures are being taken to save the Russian soldiers , '' Yeltsin 's spokesman Vyascheslav Kostikov said , referring to those captured Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;27	Dudayev told reporters the prisoners would be `` judged by a court . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;28	Most of the residents fleeing Grozny went only a few kilometers -LRB- miles -RRB- to stay with relatives in the countryside .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;29	`` Already , the majority of people have left the city , '' said 43-year-old Lyuba Ishkirchira , a Russian woman married to an ethnic Bashkir .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;30	`` I have no relatives to go to , and my father and mother are ill here -- I can not leave them . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;31	Grozny 's central bazaar , once thronged with thousands of people , was nearly empty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;32	A few old women trudged through the mud and wet leaves in search of bread .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;33	Although the Chechens are fighting among themselves , many agreed that they have one thing in common : Distrust of Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;34	`` I do n't like the opposition or Dudayev , but I 'll fight the Russians , '' said one restaurant owner who refused to give his name .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;35	Wrapped in an old leather coat and a thick , gray scarf , a 60-year-old Chechen woman walking among the bazaar 's empty stalls said Russia would have a tough time trying to overrun Chechnya .
APW_ENG_19941201.0245;36	`` Whoever fights the Muslims never wins , '' Tamara Ofsayeva said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;0	The Clinton administration has swung to the viewpoint of NATO allies that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the war in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;1	`` We will redouble our efforts to find a diplomatic solution , '' Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;2	It is the first time in the post-World War II history of the alliance that the Europeans led by France prevailed over the United States in formulating a major policy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;3	It is a difficult assignment for Christopher , putting him in the awkward position of shifting gears even while denying U.S. policy on the war has changed or that there is a trans-Atlantic rift .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;4	Trying to patch over the embarrassing dispute , Christopher pronounced the alliance strong and he charted a plan for growth through absorption of East European countries .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;5	A ceremony was scheduled to establish links to Russia , for decades the direct target of NATO 's massive military preparedness program .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;6	The plan was adopted .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;7	Over the next 12 months , bureaucrats will study the financial , structural and nuclear implications of taking in Eastern and Central European countries -- despite Russia 's reservations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;8	Christopher told the allies in a speech that `` the tragedy of the war and bloodshed in Bosnia does not diminish our responsibility to build a comprehensive European security architecture . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;9	`` America 's interests in Europe have not changed , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;10	`` Neither have the basic principles guiding our engagement . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;11	And at the top of the list , Christopher said today , was that `` the United States has enduring political , military , economic and cultural links to Europe that must and will be preserved . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;12	Earlier , at breakfast with Douglas Hurd , the British foreign secretary , Christopher reviewed the warning U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali delivered Wednesday that unless warring Serbs and Muslims cooperate with the U.N. mission the peacekeepers might be withdrawn .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;13	Christopher and Hurd said they may go to Belgrade , the Yugoslav capital , this weekend to preach reconciliation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;14	`` We will redouble our efforts to find a diplomatic solution , '' Christopher said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;15	However , his aides spread the word a trip by Christopher to Belgrade was unlikely .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;16	Asked if the troops would be withdrawn , Hurd replied grimly : `` We certainly hope not . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;17	By chance , it was the Unites States ' turn to preside over a meeting today of the North Atlantic Council , NATO 's policy-making arm .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;18	This puts Christopher under an even brighter spotlight , and he was responding both with a brief speech opening the session and a detailed one outlining U.S. plans for NATO 's expansion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;19	On Friday , Christopher intends to lay out the U.S. approach to the Bosnian war in a meeting with Hurd and Foreign Ministers Alain Juppe of France , Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia and Klaus Kinkel of Germany .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;20	It is centered on a call for an international peace conference that would give the Bosnian Serbs an opportunity to demand changes in the peace plan they have rejected repeatedly .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;21	They already have strong intimations of support from the Clinton administration in pressing for cross-border political ties to the Serb-dominated government in Belgrade -- a big step toward their goal of a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;22	`` This alliance will continue to be the anchor of American engagement in Europe , the linchpin of trans-Atlantic security , '' Christopher said in a brief statement opening the North Atlantic Council session .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;23	He also assured the 15 foreign ministers that the Clinton administration was committed to keep 100,000 American troops in Europe `` as part of our continuing engagement . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;24	The European allies , particularly France and Britain , have managed to limit NATO air strikes despite U.N. assurances that Bihac , the mostly Muslim town on the verge of falling to the Serbs , was a `` safe area '' from which heavy weapons were to be excluded .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;25	They also hemmed in the 23,000 peacekeepers in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;26	Christopher , having threatened the Serbs in the past with NATO might , abandoned the threat when asked what `` sticks '' the United States was using to persuade the Serbs to relinquish their grip on Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;27	If they kept fighting , Christopher said , they risked Serbia closing its border and a tightening of sanctions -- measures that are far less threatening than attacks by NATO warplanes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;28	Seeking to limit the damage to the alliance , which successfully stood up to the Soviet Union but has caved on Bosnia , Christopher said he wanted to stress that `` the crisis in Bosnia is about Bosnia and the former Yugoslavia ; it 's not about NATO and its future . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;29	The other foreign ministers eagerly joined in his campaign to smooth over the disagreement .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;30	`` We had a lot of tension in the past few days , '' Spanish Foreign Minister Javier Solana said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;31	`` Fortunately , this has passed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;32	We all agree the only way to end this conflict is in a negotiated way . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;33	Kinkel , the German foreign minister , acknowledged U.S. policy on Bosnia had changed , and on dealing with the expansion of NATO as well .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;34	German Ambassador Hermann von Richthofen had filed a cable to his foreign ministry accusing the United States of sowing mistrust over Bosnia and the eastward expansion of the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0246;35	It is `` divided and in crisis , '' he concluded .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;0	The planned European Union-wide police force will not have its marching orders this year , as the dozen governments ended talks Thursday by failing to agree on rules for Europol .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;1	Despite growing public concern about organized crime and international drug trafficking , justice and interior ministers here for a 2-day meeting again spent it squabbling over details on how to coordinate their police forces .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;2	The ministers have already missed an October deadline for adopting a convention for the Netherlands-based Europol .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;3	Germany has sought an FBI-style agency , independent and with a long arm to track individuals or organizations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;4	But France wants national police forces to have easy access to Europol data , and would limit the exchange of information between member states .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;5	British officials are reluctant to feed sensitive information to a data bank that authorities in other member states can inspect any time .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;6	Crime fighting remains the responsibility of individual governments , who have agreed to work together on the subject .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;7	Their lack of progress has caused frustration among EU officials , who remain powerless on the matter .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;8	Commissioner Padraig Flynn , the EU 's justice and immigration chief , railed against the ministers Thursday , criticizing their slow pace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;9	`` We have made no progress '' on Europol , he told reporters after the meeting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;10	`` There are some very obvious questions and they have to be faced up to . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;11	Flynn also complained that governments have not yet fixed immigration rules , and that `` nothing has happened '' with a plan to seal the union 's external frontiers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0247;12	Both are necessary to allow free movement for people inside the trade bloc , a prime goal of the group 's border-free , single market that took effect Jan. 1 , 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;0	A Russian ultimatum demanding an end to Chechnya 's civil war expired early Thursday but Moscow appeared to back away from threats to send troops into the breakaway southern republic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;1	Russia had threatened on Tuesday to impose a state of emergency on the Caucasus Mountain region if its president , Dzhokhar Dudayev , and the rebels opposing him do not surrender prisoners and stop fighting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;2	Neither side showed any indication of doing so .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;3	But on Thursday evening , President Boris Yeltsin 's office issued an altered text of Yeltsin 's original ultimatum saying `` there was some disagreement in the media in interpreting certain clauses of the document . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;4	The reissued document skipped all reference to any introduction of a state of emergency .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;5	Meanwhile , Yeltsin issued a limited amnesty to Chechens who lay down their arms and are not implicated in grave crimes against civilians , ITAR-Tass said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;6	A delegation of Russian lawmakers and other leaders arrived in Grozny on Thursday afternoon and began closed-door talks with Chechen officials .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;7	In Grozny , jet flyovers jangled nerves for a third day , and dropped bombs at least once .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;8	Dudayev , looking tired under neon lights in the basement of his presidential palace , told a news conference his house had been bombed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;9	A small airport near the city was hit Thursday and a woman 's corpse was seen .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;10	The ITAR-Tass news agency said two women were killed in the raid at the military air base , and fuel depots were burning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;11	Meanwhile , a trickle of heavily loaded cars and trucks continued leaving Grozny before a feared attack by Russian soldiers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;12	Chechnya declared independence from Russia in 1991 , soon after Dudayev 's election .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;13	The fighting , which intensified last week after months of skirmishes , pits forces loyal to Dudayev against the rebels , who Dudayev says are armed and led by Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;14	Moscow openly supports Dudayev 's opponents politically , but denies offering military assistance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;15	After Dudayev 's forces captured Russian fighters Saturday , Moscow said mercenaries were fighting on both sides .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;16	A single military jet roared over Grozny as the Russian deadline passed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;17	Later , heavy machine-gun fire rang out from the city center .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;18	In Freedom Square outside the presidential building , several hundred volunteer fighters cradling Kalashnikov rifles and grenade launchers gathered to hear speeches while a tank maneuvered into position .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;19	Chechen elders in tall fur hats , tunics and high leather boots , danced in a circle , chanting , `` Freedom or death ! ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;20	Russian media reported troop movements around the borders of Chechnya , in southern Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;21	The Interfax and ITAR-Tass news agencies said Russian army units would support Interior Ministry forces to `` ensure stability in the region , safety of the population and avert the spread of the conflict . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;22	The conflict is the latest to underline the tensions among scores of ethnic groups in the former Soviet Union .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;23	The Caucasus region has been especially fractious , with fighting in the Ossetian and Abkhazian regions of Georgia and the Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;24	For Moscow , which governs dozens of republics and regions in the Russian Federation , Chechnya has become a test of whether it is willing to use military might to hold the country together .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;25	No other region has gone as far as Chechnya and declared independence .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;26	`` All necessary measures are being taken to save the Russian soldiers , '' Yeltsin 's spokesman Vyascheslav Kostikov said , referring to those captured Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;27	Dudayev told reporters the prisoners would be `` judged by a court . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;28	Most of the residents fleeing Grozny went only a few kilometers -LRB- miles -RRB- to stay with relatives in the countryside .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;29	`` Already , the majority of people have left the city , '' said 43-year-old Lyuba Ishkirchira , a Russian woman married to an ethnic Bashkir .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;30	`` I have no relatives to go to , and my father and mother are ill here -- I can not leave them . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;31	Grozny 's central bazaar , once thronged with thousands of people , was nearly empty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;32	A few old women trudged through the mud and wet leaves in search of bread .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;33	Although the Chechens are fighting among themselves , many agreed that they have one thing in common : Distrust of Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;34	`` I do n't like the opposition or Dudayev , but I 'll fight the Russians , '' said one restaurant owner who refused to give his name .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;35	Wrapped in an old leather coat and a thick , gray scarf , a 60-year-old Chechen woman walking among the bazaar 's empty stalls said Russia would have a tough time trying to overrun Chechnya .
APW_ENG_19941201.0248;36	`` Whoever fights the Muslims never wins , '' Tamara Ofsayeva said .

APW_ENG_19941201.0251;0	Unions extracted concessions from Premier Silvio Berlusconi 's government Thursday in exchange for calling off a general strike .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;1	The agreement , reached during all-night talks , was a big step toward gaining support from the leftist opposition in the Senate for approval of the deficit-reducing budget .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;2	`` The pension war is over , '' said Berlusconi told a news conference after emerging from a meeting with his Cabinet and union leaders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;3	The unions declared themselves satisfied with the settlement and revoked a strike set for Friday which would have been the second general strike in six weeks .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;4	The agreement restores so-called old age pensions giving the green light to people with 35 years of work under their belt to receive full pension benefits .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;5	It also includes measures that will increase social security benefits for large or poor families and provide more assistance to Italy 's less industrialized southern regions .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;6	However , Berlusconi insisted the government had not backed down on its austerity plan and still intended to cut 50 trillion lire -LRB- dlrs 31 billion -RRB- of the country 's dlrs 100 billion budget-deficit as planned .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;7	`` I have always said that not one , not two , not even 10 strikes would have modified the figures -LRB- of the budget cuts -RRB- , '' said Berlusconi .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;8	As part of the agreement the government pledged to turn its attention to a full-scale permanent pension reform that would bring Italy 's generous welfare and pension system in line with other European countries .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;9	The reforms must be approved by June 30 if the accord between the government and unions is respected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;10	`` More money is taken out of the social security safe than what gets put in ... and it 's not possible to continue like this , '' Berlusconi said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;11	`` We are talking about a very satisfactory agreement that concludes a complex dispute , '' Giancarlo Fontanelli leader of the UIL union told the ANSA news agency .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;12	The budget is being discussed in the Senate after it was approved by the Chamber of Deputies on Nov. 16 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0251;13	The Berlusconi government has a comfortable majority in the chamber but falls just short in the Senate .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;0	In a further challenge to the crumbling U.N. bid to stop fighting in Bosnia , Serb forces on Thursday detained peacekeepers , blocked humanitarian supplies and fired missiles at Sarajevo .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;1	In embattled northwest Bosnia , where Serb forces have nearly surrounded the Muslim enclave of Bihac , machine-gun and small-arms fire raged a day after a failed peace mission by U.N. chief Boutros Boutros-Ghali .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;2	Military intervention by the allies on behalf of the besieged Muslim-led government grew more unlikely .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;3	In Brussels , Belgium , U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher told NATO allies the Clinton administration now agrees with European allies that diplomacy is the best way to deal with the war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;4	U.N. spokesman Alexander Ivanko said in Zagreb , Croatia , that Bosnian Serb units crossed into Croatia and kidnapped seven Ukrainian peacekeepers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;5	They took the soldiers and a U.N. armored carrier into Bosnian Serb-held territory , he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;6	The Ukrainians ' observation point is now occupied by the Serbs , Ivanko said , and the United Nations has not been able to make contact with its troops .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;7	More than 400 other U.N. soldiers are detained by the Serbs as insurance against further NATO airstrikes following three allied bombing raids on Serb targets last week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;8	In Sarajevo , U.N. spokesman Thant Myint-U said Serbs ignored 21 requests to allow food and fuel supply convoys to pass through Serb-held territory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;9	He said U.N. supplies were running low in government-held eastern Bosnian enclaves and in Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;10	Humanitarian convoys were also blocked .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;11	In downtown Sarajevo , two buildings of the Interior Ministry were hit by anti-tank missiles .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;12	Four people were wounded .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;13	Sarajevo 's airport remained closed because Serbs denied flight clearance , ruling out any relief flights to the besieged Bosnian capital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;14	Neither side seemed ready for peace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;15	The Bosnian government rejected a cease-fire plan proposed by Boutros-Ghali during a brief visit on Wednesday , and Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic refused even to meet with the U.N. chief .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;16	The intransigence on both sides led Boutros-Ghali to suggest for the first time that the U.N. peacekeeping mission might have to end .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;17	Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic told Boutros-Ghali that his government would negotiate only after Serbs accepted a peace plan that they repeatedly have rejected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;18	He reiterated his government 's offer of a three-month cease-fire , but Serbs want something more permanent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;19	Comments by the Bosnian army commander , Gen. Rasim Delic to the Sarajevo daily Oslobodjenje underscored the government 's unwillingness to compromise further .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;20	He said Bihac would not fall , and that the Bosnian army eventually would win the war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;21	Bosnian Serbs snubbed Boutros-Ghali altogether .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;22	Radovan would not come to the Sarajevo airport to meet him , and Boutros-Ghali refused to enter Serb-held territory for the meeting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;23	But the U.N. chief executive will be in Geneva between Friday and Sunday to `` continue his intensive diplomatic efforts for a peaceful solution , especially for a cease-fire '' in Bosnia , his spokeswoman Therese Gastaut said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;24	Maj. Herve Gourmelon , a U.N. spokesman in Sarajevo , said heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire broke out around Bihac late Wednesday and in the predawn hours Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;25	Ivanko said later that Bosnian Serb forces kept the heat on the government 's hard-pressed 5th Corps , with significant fighting reported to the southwest and south of the Bihac pocket .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;26	But there was no immediate information on any changes in the frontlines .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;27	Serbs are holding 30-40 percent of the U.N.-declared `` safe area '' consisting of Bihac town and its environs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;28	One civilian was killed near the Bihac stadium by small-arms fire , while a number of shells exploded near the Bihac hospital , badly injuring one person , Ivanko said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;29	In Brussels , Christopher and Douglas Hurd , the British foreign secretary , said they may go to Belgrade , the Yugoslav capital , this weekend to preach reconciliation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;30	`` We will redouble our efforts to find a diplomatic solution , '' Christopher said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;31	Some senior Western officials are proposing that the Bosnian Serbs be allowed links to Serb-led Yugoslavia , which they long have desired .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;32	That would be a step toward creation of Serb nationalists ' goal , a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;33	At a breakfast with Hurd , Christopher reviewed the Boutros-Ghali 's warning that that unless warring Serbs and Muslims cooperate with the U.N. mission , the peacekeepers might be withdrawn .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;34	The threat reflects a growing frustration as the Serbs continue their assaults and the government refuses new concessions .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;35	Bosnian Serbs have rejected a peace plan that would reduce their holdings in Bosnia to 49 percent from about 70 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0252;36	More than 200,000 are dead or missing in the 31-month conflict begun by Serbs who rebelled when Muslims and Croats voted for independence from Serb-led Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;0	Under a furious lobbying barrage from the Clinton administration and a small army of corporate executives , the Senate stood on the verge Thursday of ratifying a sweeping expansion of global free trade .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;1	The climatic vote will not occur until the end of a second full day of debate , but supporters were claiming they now had an ample number of votes for the agreement itself and , more importantly , a small cushion for the three-fifths majority they need on a budget waiver .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;2	`` By the time the vote is actually taken tonight , we expect GATT will pass , '' said presidential press secretary Dee Dee Myers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;3	While administration officials and Senate supporters said their vote counts showed victory in their grasp , they did not let up in their lobbying efforts .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;4	President Clinton met at the White House with a group of mostly undecided senators in an attempt to build the victory margin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;5	Opponents , while conceding that the momentum was not going their way , did not let up in their efforts , either .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;6	A group of two-dozen protesters , one dressed as a lame-duck , chanted outside the White House as senators arrived for breakfast with Clinton .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;7	Sen. Fritz Hollings of South Carolina said that the new trade agreement was a bad deal that , by lowering trade barriers , would subject American workers to even more unfair competition from low-wage countries , further weakening the country 's economic standing .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;8	`` The reality is that we are in decline .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;9	Everybody knows that , '' said Hollings , whose home-state textile industry will be one of the biggest losers in the deal .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;10	`` Wake up , Washington . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;11	However , GATT supporters said that the Senate 's choice on the last day of the 103rd Congress was between continuing to hold a position of economic leadership in the global economy or retreating behind protectionist barriers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;12	The House endorsed the accord , negotiated under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade , by a 288-146 vote on Tuesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;13	Thirty-three other countries already have ratified the 124-nation accord and supporters said other countries are poised to act before Jan. 1 if the Senate follows the House .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;14	According to an Associated Press survey , GATT proponents appeared on the verge of victory , when counting those who were leaning in favor but not firmly committed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;15	The AP head count had 60 senators for or leaning for waiving budget rules , 26 against or leaning against and 14 undeclared .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;16	Opponents ' only hope was to change enough senators ' minds to muster 41 votes in favor of the procedural hurdle imposed by Sen. Robert Byrd .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;17	Under Senate rules , the implementing bill must offset all of the projected dlrs 43 billion in lost tariff revenues over the first decade of the accord .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;18	To make up for the lost tariffs , the administration is cutting farm subsidies and raising revenue with a number of measures , including changing the minimum rate on savings bonds and auctioning licenses for a new generation of wireless broadcast services .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;19	Byrd said the bill falls dlrs 14.5 billion short and some senators , while declaring themselves in favor of free trade , said they would not vote to bust the budget .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;20	Byrd and others also complain that a new Geneva-based World Trade Organization , created to referee trade disputes , will inevitably infringe on U.S. sovereignty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;21	The administration is predicting 500,000 new American jobs as a result of increased U.S. export sales under GATT .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;22	In addition to bringing foreign tariffs closer to U.S. levels , it reduces barriers to trade in agricultural goods and services and protects U.S. intellectual property , such as computer programs , from being pirated .
APW_ENG_19941201.0253;23	Opponents charge the trade agreement would simply make it easier for big companies to move more jobs to low-wage countries , including Third World nations where child labor is prevalent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;0	ISLAMABAD , Pakistan -LRB- AP -RRB- - The main opposition party on Thursday accused Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto 's government of paying bribes to win the support of key politicians .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;1	The opposition leader , Nawaz Sharif , and Ms. Bhutto have been making charges and counter-charges of corruption for months , and the attacks have become increasingly personal .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;2	Both have denied allegations of wrongdoing and none of the charges has been proven in court .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;3	Sharif told a news conference that Ms. Bhutto , her husband Asif Zardari , and President Farooq Leghari all took part in a scheme that set aside 260 million rupees -LRB- dlrs 8.5 million -RRB- of government money for personal use and for paying bribes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;4	`` The trail of corruption leads to the very top , including Farooq Leghari , Benazir Bhutto and Asif Zardari , '' Sharif said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;5	Sharif claimed a large chunk of the money was used to buy the support of independent legislators in the Northwest Frontier Provincial Assembly .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;6	Sharif 's conservative Pakistan Muslim League headed a coalition that controlled the province until a number of independents defected earlier this year to support Ms. Bhutto 's liberal Pakistan People 's Party .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;7	Ms. Bhutto 's coalition now controls the province , and Sharif said her party paid bribes to get the independents to switch sides .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;8	Ms. Bhutto is on a trip to London and was not immediately available for comment .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;9	She has said repeatedly that her party is not guilty of corruption and has put a stop to abuses initiated by Sharif when he was prime minister from 1990-93 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;10	Even Pakistani politicians acknowledge that the country 's political system is riddled with graft , though they inevitably accuse their opponents of the worst offenses .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;11	Ms. Bhutto 's government arrested Sharif 's father , Mohammed Sharif , last month on charges of fraud and tax evasion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;12	Ms. Bhutto also said that the Sharif business empire , one of the largest in Pakistan , was built through extensive fraud .
APW_ENG_19941201.0254;13	Sharif 's accusations Thursday were seen largely as a response to Ms. Bhutto 's charges against him and his family .

APW_ENG_19941201.0255;10	Humanitarian convoys were also blocked .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;11	In downtown Sarajevo , two buildings of the Interior Ministry were hit by anti-tank missiles .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;12	Four people were wounded .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;13	Sarajevo 's airport remained closed because Serbs denied flight clearance , ruling out any relief flights to the besieged Bosnian capital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;14	Neither side seemed ready for peace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;15	The Bosnian government rejected a cease-fire plan proposed by Boutros-Ghali during a brief visit on Wednesday , and Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic refused even to meet with the U.N. chief .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;16	The intransigence on both sides led Boutros-Ghali to suggest for the first time that the U.N. peacekeeping mission might have to end .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;17	Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic told Boutros-Ghali that his government would negotiate only after Serbs accepted a peace plan that they repeatedly have rejected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;18	He reiterated his government 's offer of a three-month cease-fire , but Serbs want something more permanent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;19	Comments by the Bosnian army commander , Gen. Rasim Delic to the Sarajevo daily Oslobodjenje underscored the government 's unwillingness to compromise further .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;20	He said Bihac would not fall , and that the Bosnian army eventually would win the war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;21	Bosnian Serbs snubbed Boutros-Ghali altogether .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;22	Radovan would not come to the Sarajevo airport to meet him , and Boutros-Ghali refused to enter Serb-held territory for the meeting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;23	But the U.N. chief executive will be in Geneva between Friday and Sunday to `` continue his intensive diplomatic efforts for a peaceful solution , especially for a cease-fire '' in Bosnia , his spokeswoman Therese Gastaut said .

APW_ENG_19941201.0255;25	Ivanko said later that Bosnian Serb forces kept the heat on the government 's hard-pressed 5th Corps , with significant fighting reported to the southwest and south of the Bihac pocket .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;26	But there was no immediate information on any changes in the frontlines .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;27	Serbs are holding 30-40 percent of the U.N.-declared `` safe area '' consisting of Bihac town and its environs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;28	One civilian was killed near the Bihac stadium by small-arms fire , while a number of shells exploded near the Bihac hospital , badly injuring one person , Ivanko said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;29	In Brussels , Christopher and Douglas Hurd , the British foreign secretary , said they may go to Belgrade , the Yugoslav capital , this weekend to preach reconciliation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0255;30	`` We will redouble our efforts to find a diplomatic solution , '' Christopher said .

APW_ENG_19941201.0256;0	American manufacturing surged in November to its strongest level in 10 years , said a widely followed survey of manufacturers released Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0256;1	The National Association of Purchasing Managers said its index of manufacturing growth rose to 61.2 percent in November from 59.7 percent in the previous month .
APW_ENG_19941201.0256;2	It is the fifteenth consecutive month of growth and the highest reading of the index since February 1984 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0256;3	A reading above 50 percent indicates the manufacturing economy is expanding , while a reading below 50 percent indicates a decline .
APW_ENG_19941201.0256;4	Factory production advanced to its highest level since December 1983 , indicating that factories are buzzing to keep up with demand .
APW_ENG_19941201.0256;5	The production index rose to 66.7 percent from 64.2 percent in October .
APW_ENG_19941201.0256;6	The NAPM report 's prices-paid index dipped in November to 77.9 percent from 79.9 percent in October , indicating that manuacturers saw fewer price increases for the raw materials they need .
APW_ENG_19941201.0256;7	But the decline was due to seasonal factors , the NAPM said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0256;8	The price index was at its second highest level in six years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0256;9	The highest level was in October .
APW_ENG_19941201.0256;10	The purchasing managers assocation , based in Tempe , Ariz. , surveys managers at more than 300 industrial firms nationwide .
APW_ENG_19941201.0256;11	The data , which represents the latest evidence on how the economy is performing , is widely followed by economists and the financial markets .

APW_ENG_19941201.0261;0	In a sweeping cost-cutting effort , Chemical Banking Corp. said Thursday that it will eliminate 3,700 positions , sell off most of its New Jersey operations and put nearly dlrs 1 billion in bad realty loans on the block .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;1	The actions will cost the nation 's fourth largest banking company approximately dlrs 410 million before taxes in the fourth quarter ending Dec. 30 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;2	That includes dlrs 260 million for severance and eliminating certain facilities and dlrs 150 million for the cost of selling bad realty loans .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;3	Chemical said the moves , which were expected , will reduce expenses by dlrs 440 million , with dlrs 210 million of the savings realized this year and dlrs 230 million recorded next year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;4	The cost-cutting program will allow Chemical to get out of businesses that do n't generate enough revenues and concentrate investments on areas that yield bigger profits .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;5	To this end , Chemical said it will spend dlrs 180 million over the next two years on `` high growth businesses , '' including corporate and investment banking and national consumer services such as mortgage lending and credit cards .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;6	The workforce reductions account for 9 percent of the bank 's 42,500 employees worldwide and will be achieved through attrition and layoffs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;7	Around half of the planned job cuts , to be carried out over the next two years , will occur in Chemical 's New York headquarters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;8	The other half will come from operations in Texas , where Chemical owns a bank , and from other locations around the world .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;9	The reductions do not include employees who work for Chemical Bank New Jersey , based in East Brunswick , according to spokesman Ken Herz .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;10	The bank will sell 60 percent of the operation , retaining branches located in the northeast quadrant of the state nearest to New York City .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;11	Chemical Bank New Jersey has 140 branches and employs over 2,000 people .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;12	Herz declined to comment about whether the bank is in talks with potential buyers for the operation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;13	Chemical also wants to sell its 40 percent stake in the CIT Group Holdings Inc. , a New Jersey-based lending company .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;14	Dai-ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan owns the other 60 percent of CIT .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;15	Chemical has been struggling to reduce its expense base ever since it merged with Manufacturers Hanover Corp. in 1992 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;16	The bank eliminated 6,200 jobs after the merger and closed more than 80 overlapping branches .
APW_ENG_19941201.0261;17	In January , the bank announced that it would close another 50 branches because many customers are banking by telephone , computer or at automated teller machines , rather than at branches .
