APW_ENG_19941201.0362;0	U.S. agricultural exports are expected to hit a record dlrs 45 billion in 1995 , an increase of dlrs 1.5 billion over this year , the U.S. Agriculture Department says .
APW_ENG_19941201.0362;1	If this estimate holds , the total would top the previous record of dlrs 43.8 billion in 1981 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0362;2	Although the new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade pact is not cited as a cause , the world trade accord has been promoted as a boost to future U.S. agricultural exports .
APW_ENG_19941201.0362;3	A report by the House Ways and Means Committee said exports could be as much as dlrs 8.5 billion higher by the time GATT is fully implemented in 2005 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0362;4	USDA estimates that agricultural imports for the upcoming year also will set a record , at dlrs 28 billion , up dlrs 1.6 billion from 1994 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0362;5	That makes the projected agricultural trade surplus dlrs 17 billion for 1995 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0362;6	Wheat and coarse grain exports are expected to rise 13 percent in volume .
APW_ENG_19941201.0362;7	However , due to expected lower prices for corn , the overall value of grain exports is forecast to increase only 8 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0362;8	Prices for wheat are expected to stay strong through next year , according to the USDA forecast .
APW_ENG_19941201.0362;9	Soybean exports will also mark a gain in volume , up 28 percent from 1994 , although low prices again will hold down value , it says .
APW_ENG_19941201.0362;10	Other high-value products -- including fruit , vegetables , red meat and poultry -- also are seen making export gains in 1995 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;0	A bid to salvage the near-bankrupt airline Iberia was stalled Thursday after overnight talks between management and the powerful pilots union ended in a stalemate over pay cuts .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;1	Management and representatives of the carrier 's two main unions had reached a tentative agreement Tuesday on a viability plan that entailed a wage freeze , salary cuts averaging 8.5 percent and a reduction of some 3,500 jobs through early retirements and pay-offs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;2	The viability plan is considered crucial if the European Commission is to consider allowing the Spanish government to grant Iberia a 130 billion peseta -LRB- dlrs 1 billion -RRB- capital injection .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;3	However , a similar plan to bailout out Air France faces a court challenge .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;4	Management of the state-owned company held talks Thursday with all of its unions -- except the pilots .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;5	The pilots union , meanwhile , said it would meet Friday with rank-and-file to evaluate the situation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;6	It was not immediately clear whether the lack of an across-the-board agreement meant a much more drastic plan touted last week by Iberia -- involving 5,200 job cuts and the sale of company assets -- might be implemented .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;7	That proposal triggered an one-day wildcat strike on Monday that paralyzed Spain 's airports and affected more than 100,000 travelers here and abroad .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;8	The wildcat action apparently prompted unions to cancel a strike called several weeks ago for Friday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;9	Airline officials said flights would operate normally .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;10	Negotiations with the pilots reached a dead end as Iberia demanded a salary reduction of 15 percent based on 1992 earnings .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;11	The pilots insisted that an existing wage agreement through 1995 must be implemented before the 15 percent salary cut could be enforced .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;12	`` The company has presented a generic plan that does not guarantee the future of Iberia and only concentrates on disproportionate salary cuts , '' said Armando Guajardo of the pilots union SEPLA .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;13	`` Management has let the situation rot to such an extent so that it could enforce such a plan worked out in advance , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;14	SEPLA said the company needed a complete overhaul and not just a reduction in salaries and staff .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;15	He said SEPLA had sent a letter to Iberia warning of drastic action by the pilots if the current wage agreement was broken .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;16	Pilots represent some 5 percent of the 24,000-strong staff .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;17	Salas has warned that the company would be technically bankrupt by March 1995 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;18	Iberia has posted losses since 1990 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0363;19	It ended last year 67 billion pesetas -LRB- dlrs 530 million -RRB- in the red while losses for this year are expected to top 40 billion pesetas -LRB- dlrs 300 million -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;0	President Clinton pledged Thursday to seek a dlrs 25 billion increase in military spending over the next six years to improve the living conditions and readiness of U.S. troops around the world .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;1	Flanked by Defense Secretary William Perry and the Joint Chiefs of Staff , Clinton also said he would ask Congress for an emergency increase in this year 's defense budget to pay for unanticipated military deployments .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;2	The measures would be presented to the new Republican-controlled Congress next year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;3	Republicans have called for increased defense spending .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;4	`` I have pledged that throughout the life of this administration our military will remain the best trained , best equipped , the best fighting force on earth , '' Clinton said at a White House announcement .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;5	`` We ask much of our military and we owe much to them . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;6	Clinton disputed a suggestion that his request for additional Pentagon spending was an acknowledgement that he had cut too much last year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;7	He said the request was mostly because of unanticipated deployments to the Persian Gulf , Haiti and elsewhere .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;8	`` We have seen the military having to deal with an amazing variety of challenges , '' Clinton said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;9	Clinton did not say how much extra money he would request for the Pentagon this year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;10	Without some increase , he said , the Pentagon would have to curtail training and find cuts elsewhere .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;11	The dlrs 25 billion in additional spending beginning next year is designed to cover a projected dlrs 40 billion shortfall over five years that had been created by a congressionally required pay raise , and by inflation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;12	This fiscal year 's Pentagon 's budget was dlrs 264 billion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;13	Congressional Republicans have criticized Clinton for defense cuts they say have eroded military readiness , and the House Republican agenda proposes a dlrs 60 billion increase in defense spending .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;14	Clinton 's announcement was an effort to answer the criticism and counter the Republican budget proposal .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;15	The president also seemed determined to answer Republican Sen. Jesse Helms ' recent suggestion that he was not fit to be commander in chief .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;16	In announcing his new spending initiative , Clinton rattled off a list of military actions he has ordered as president , including use of troops to help restore Haiti 's democracy and deployment of U.S. forces to Kuwait to counter an Iraqi troop buildup along the Iraq-Kuwait border .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;17	`` Saddam Hussein got the message , '' Clinton said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;18	And in a holiday season reassurance to U.S. troops , Clinton guaranteed they will receive pay increases approved by Congress .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;19	The amount of the increase is tied to inflation ; the last raise was about 2 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;20	Clinton said the increased spending next year and beyond would provide other `` quality of life '' improvements for U.S. forces and their families , including better housing , child care and family support services .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;21	Clinton 's announcement came just two weeks after the Army announced that three of its 12 divisions had fallen below peak readiness levels because money that would have gone to training exercises had been diverted to pay for operations in Rwanda , Haiti and elsewhere .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;22	Clinton said nothing about potential weapons program cuts being pondered by Deputy Defense Secretary John Deutch .
APW_ENG_19941201.0364;23	Deutch has been looking at the potential for canceling , stretching out or cutting back 10 major weapons programs , including such things as the Air Force 's F-22 fighter jet , the Army 's Commance helicopter , the TSSAM Tri-service Standoff Attack Missile and the Marine 's AAAV Advanced Amphibious Assault Vehicle .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;0	Serb fighters kidnapped more U.N. peacekeepers and pressed the stranglehold on the `` safe area '' of Bihac Thursday , underscoring their contempt for U.N. authority in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;1	The Bosnian Serbs did , however , agree to meet Yasushi Akashi , the top U.N. envoy , on Friday in Pale , their stronghold east of Sarajevo .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;2	They had refused to meet U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali on Wednesday because he insisted talks be held in Sarajevo , capital of the internationally recognized government of Bosnia-Herzegovina .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;3	They agreed to the Akashi meeting after Lt. Gen. Sir Michael Rose , the U.N. commander in Bosnia , traveled to Pale for talks with Radovan Karadzic and other Bosnian Serb leaders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;4	In addition to trying to calm the Bihac front , Rose is also concerned about the fate of more than 400 of his soldiers being held hostage by the Serbs as insurance against further NATO airstrikes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;5	Alexander Ivanko , a U.N. spokesman , said the latest kidnappings occurred Tuesday when Bosnian Serb units crossed the border into Croatia and seized seven Ukrainian peacekeepers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;6	They took the soldiers and a U.N. armored carrier into Bosnian Serb-held territory , and the United Nations has not heard from its troops since .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;7	The Ukrainians ' observation point is now occupied by the Serbs , allowing for the unimpeded movement into Bosnia of equipment and personnel from Serb-held Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;8	Serb fighters from the two countries have joined forces in the Bihac offensive .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;9	Rose 's talks in Pale were to have focused on Bihac and its demilitarization .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;10	But there appeared to be no narrowing of differences that could end the siege .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;11	Momcilo Krajisnik , leader of the so-called Bosnian Serb assembly , again rejected a three-month cease-fire , which the Bosnian government wants , saying Serbs would accept only a permanent cease-fire , leading to a formal end of war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;12	The Sarajevo government fears any permanent cease-fire agreement would cement Serb territorial gains of 70 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;13	An international peace plan , which the Bosnians have accepted and the Serbs rejected , would force Serbs to settle for 49 percent of the country .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;14	With new U.S. support for Europe 's position that diplomacy , not further NATO airstrikes , is the best way to deal with the Bosnian war , French Foreign Minister Alain Juppe and his British counterpart , Douglas Hurd , planned to meet Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade Sunday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;15	Milosevic is considered responsible for the violent breakup of Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;16	But he continues to wield the power , including with the Bosnian Serbs , with whom he allegedly broke ties last summer after they again rejected the international peace plan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;17	Senior Western officials now talk of altering that plan to allow the Bosnian Serbs confederal links with Yugoslavia , a right the plan already gives Bosnian Croats with Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;18	Critics say that is appeasement and a step toward creation of Serb nationalists ' goal , a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;19	But Krajisnik said possible linkage with Yugoslavia was not as important as changing the proposed territorial maps , the Bosnian Serb news agency SRNA reported .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;20	Continuing the squeeze on the Bosnian government , Serbs again denied U.N. requests to supply the Bihac enclave and other vulnerable U.N.-patrolled sites with food and supplies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;21	Monique Tuffelli , the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees staffer in the Bihac enclave , said food stocks would last only another week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;22	`` We have run out almost of everything , '' she said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;23	The last UNHCR food convoy reached Bihac on Oct. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;24	Between May and October , Serbs allowed only a dozen to pass through their territory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;25	U.N. spokesman Thant Myint-U said food and fuel supplies for peacekeepers were running increasingly short in the government-held eastern Bosnian enclaves , as well as Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;26	Heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire erupted around Bihac late Wednesday and early Thursday , along with heavy fighting southwest and south of the Bihac pocket , U.N. officials said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;27	Two civilians were killed in Bihac Wednesday by gunfire , Ms. Tuffelli said , but overall the area was calmer Thursday morning with only sporadic shelling and small arms fire .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;28	Bosnian radio and Bihac regional officials painted a different picture by Thursday afternoon .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;29	Radio said Serbs intensified their attacks later in the day on Bihac , Cazin and Velika Kladusa , all government-held towns in the Bihac enclave .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;30	Hamdija Kabiljagic , the regional mayor , also reported increased fighting along the perimeters of Bihac and shelling of the town itself .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;31	He accused the United Nations of deliberately downplaying the situation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;32	There was no U.N. confirmation of the reported afternoon upsurge in fighting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;33	In downtown Sarajevo , Serbs targeted two government buildings with anti-tank missiles , wounding four people .
APW_ENG_19941201.0365;34	Sarajevo 's airport remained closed , and the humanitarian airlift suspended , because Serbs had not given security guarantees and are able to threaten planes ' approach route with surface-to-air missiles .
APW_ENG_19941201.0366;0	NATO on Thursday moved closer than ever to admitting its former Warsaw Pact adversaries into the alliance by ordering aides to set out the criteria for membership in the years ahead .
APW_ENG_19941201.0366;1	But , in an extraordinary session , Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev strongly criticized the alliance for going ahead with its plans for expansion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0366;2	`` If the strategy of NATO has changed , then that is something which requires further discussion , '' Kozyrev told grim-faced group of foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization .
APW_ENG_19941201.0366;3	The Russian had been invited to the allies ' meeting to endorse a wide-ranging program of military and political contacts with Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0366;4	The special ties had been put together to try to ease Russia 's fears of an eastward drive by the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;0	Moscow backed off from a threat to send troops Thursday into the breakaway Chechnya republic , where leaders defied a Russian ultimatum and called on armed volunteers to defend their capital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;1	Air attacks continued on the outskirts of Grozny , the Chechen capital , and a Russian delegation arrived from Moscow and began talks with Chechen officials .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;2	Meanwhile , residents continued to flee the mainly Muslim city of 300,000 people in the Caucasus Mountains of southern Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;3	The city has become a war zone between forces loyal to Chechen President Dzhokhar Dudayev , who declared independence from Moscow in 1991 , and Chechen rebels trying to topple him .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;4	Dudayev accuses Moscow of arming and leading the rebels , who launched an offensive last week that began with helicopters and escalated in recent days to jet fighters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;5	Russia says it offers the rebels only political support .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;6	It refuses to recognize independence for Chechnya , which was incorporated into the Russian Empire in the 19th century after a series of long and bloody wars .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;7	President Boris Yeltsin threatened on Tuesday to impose a state of emergency in Chechnya if both sides did not surrender prisoners and stop fighting by Thursday morning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;8	On Thursday evening , Yeltsin 's office issued an altered text of the ultimatum saying `` there was some disagreement in the media in interpreting certain clauses . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;9	The reissued document skipped all reference to a state of emergency .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;10	Trying a different tack , Yeltsin offered limited amnesty Thursday to Chechens who `` voluntarily lay down arms by Dec. 15 . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;11	`` The use of force in Chechnya is doomed to failure , '' said Sergei Yushenkov , head of the Russian parliament 's Defense Committee , who led the delegation to Grozny and met briefly with Dudayev , according to an aide in Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;12	In another sign that Russia sought to avoid direct confrontation , Defense Minister Pavel Grachev told reporters in Moscow that some Russian servicemen who `` carried out certain military tasks for material compensation '' from anti-Dudayev forces had been brought back to central Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;13	He said more would be evacuated .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;14	Grachev insisted such servicemen were volunteers who were not in Chechnya on Army orders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;15	Dudayev 's government captured up to 70 Russians in fighting last weekend and alleges that some were Army officers and soldiers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;16	Chechen officials initially threatened to execute them ; Dudayev said Thursday they would be tried in court .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;17	Despite Moscow 's softened tone , it still appeared to be beefing up troops on the borders of Chechnya , according to media reports .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;18	Dudayev , who held a news conference in the basement of his presidential palace as jets roared overhead , remained defiant , calling Yeltsin 's government a `` satanic power . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;19	Looking tired under neon lights , Dudayev said his house had been bombed Thursday morning after the deadline on Yeltsin 's ultimatum passed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;20	A small military air base near Grozny also was hit in an air raid Thursday and a woman 's corpse was seen .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;21	The ITAR-Tass news agency said two women were killed and fuel depots were burning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;22	Opposition air raids on the two previous days destroyed aircraft at military and civilian airports .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;23	In Freedom Square outside Dudayev 's offices , several hundred volunteer fighters cradling Kalashnikov rifles and grenade launchers gathered to hear speeches while a tank maneuvered into position .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;24	Elders in tall fur hats , tunics and high leather boots danced in a circle , chanting , `` Freedom or death ! ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;25	Grozny 's central bazaar , once thronged , was nearly empty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;26	Although life has gotten tougher and the economy is in shambles , many Chechens feel united in one thing : distrust of Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;27	`` I do n't like the opposition or Dudayev , but I 'll fight the Russians , '' said a restaurant owner who refused to give his name .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;28	Many Russians are content to let the Chechens go their own way , according to a poll Thursday by the International Opinion Research Center .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;29	The poll of 3,250 said 74.2 percent said Russia should recognize Chechnya 's independence , while 5.5 percent said it should n't and 20.3 said they could n't answer .
APW_ENG_19941201.0367;30	The firm said the poll 's margin of error was 1 percent .

APW_ENG_19941201.0369;0	An 82-year-old man who guarded his garden shed with a shotgun was ordered Thursday to pay 3,633 pounds -LRB- dlrs 5,704 -RRB- to a burglar he wounded .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;1	Six years ago Ted Newbury of Ilkeston , central England , fired a 12-gauge shotgun from about five feet -LRB- 1.5 m -RRB- away at Mark Revill , 27 , tearing a hole in his right arm and injuring his chest .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;2	Doctors said Revill , 27 , can not straighten his fingers , had lost some feeling in his hand and still had pain in his chest .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;3	`` To fire a gun when you have no idea who is there is a highly dangerous thing to do , '' Justice Richard Rougier told Newbury , a retired hospital porter .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;4	`` To poke a shotgun through a hole and fire it with the knowledge that there are people outside constitutes negligence to the point of recklessness . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;5	The judge awarded a total of 12,100 pounds -LRB- dlrs 18,995 -RRB- to Revill , who had filed suit for compensation for his injuries , medical expenses and hardship finding work .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;6	But since Revill was found to be two-thirds at fault , Newbury was ordered to pay only 4,033 pounds -LRB- dlrs 6,332 -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;7	But the judge also ordered Revill to pay 400 pounds -LRB- dlrs 628 -RRB- to Newbury for his shock and distress .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;8	The judge noted that Newbury , who was fearful of burglars , had reinforced the shed with metal plates , padlocks and holes wide enough to fit his shotgun .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;9	Newbury , who had been sleeping in the shed for four years , was awakened by Revill and another intruder in March 1988 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;10	The judge said it was `` a shattering experience '' for Newbury to be awakened and hear one of the intruders say , `` If you are in there , you old bastard , we are having you . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;11	However , the judge added , `` Mr. Newbury has to face the obvious question as to why he did not scare off the intruders by some less drastic means .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;12	He could have switched on the light . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;13	Revill had been jailed for six months after pleading guilty to trespass and other offenses .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;14	Newbury had been acquitted of weapons offenses in a jury trial .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;15	`` I still ca n't understand what has happened .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;16	I will have to get an explanation from my solicitor -LRB- lawyer -RRB- , '' Newbury said Thursday after the hearing .
APW_ENG_19941201.0369;17	`` All I was trying to do was to protect my belongings . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;0	NATO asked Germany on Thursday to send fighter planes to patrol the skies over Bosnia in a mission that would place the German military in a combat role for the first time since World War II .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;1	Defense Minister Volker Ruehe said Germany must take on the mission but the foreign minister , Klaus Kinkel , raised doubts about it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;2	If Chancellor Helmut Kohl decides to accept , it could mean a bruising battle in the new parliament , where Kohl holds the narrowest of majorities .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;3	The liberal opposition said it opposed any combat role in the Balkans .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;4	Germany has shied from direct involvement in Bosnia-Herzegovina because of the history of Nazi atrocities in former Yugoslavia and anti-German sentiment among many Serbs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;5	But Germany 's credibility in NATO could be threatened if it refuses the mission , given Kohl 's repeated assertions that his nation , seeking more international influence , must bear its share of peacekeeping responsibilities .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;6	NATO requested German Tornado planes equipped with electronic gear that can locate and identify radar sites , and rockets designed to destroy such sites , a German defense official said , speaking on background .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;7	The Tornado planes could help prevent Serb attacks on NATO planes patrolling Bosnia to enforce the U.N. humanitarian mission and also could protect the air bridge to Sarajevo , the official said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;8	The need for the specialized planes was highlighted last week , when supply flights to Sarajevo from Italy were broken off after Serbs fired missiles at two British Tornados .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;9	German officials could not confirm a report in the weekly Rheinischer Merkur newspaper that the request to Germany was made because Britain wanted to withdraw its fighters from the Bosnia mission .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;10	German acceptance of the mission could mean a greater say for Germany in NATO 's policy toward Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;11	German officials have ceded key decisions to nations like France and Britain , which have ground troops in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;12	In an interview distributed by the Defense Ministry , Ruehe said that if Germany turns down the mission , `` we lose the right to intelligently take part in the discussion on Bosnia-Herzegovina . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;13	But ground troops are out of the question , Ruehe said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;14	German soldiers would be `` part of the problem , not the solution '' because of the bitter memories over the hundreds of thousands of Serbs , Jews and others murdered by the German army and SS officers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;15	The opposition Social Democrats said any German combat mission in Bosnia was unacceptable .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;16	`` Every Serbian family mourns a victim of the Germans .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;17	I have to ask whether it makes a difference if we 're on the ground or in the air , '' said Walter Kolbow , a defense expert for the party .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;18	A July decision of Germany 's highest court gave the government the green light for the first time in the postwar era to engage in peacekeeping missions outside the NATO area .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;19	But a majority of parliament must approve each mission .
APW_ENG_19941201.0370;20	`` Whether we ... should really choose former Yugoslavia as the place to step up our engagement is something I believe we should consider very carefully , '' Foreign Minister Kinkel said in Brussels , Belgium .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;0	Here are excerpts of editorials from publications in various countries :
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;1	Gulf Daily News , Manama , Bahrain , on Bosnia :
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;2	Bosnian Serbs were ... on the verge of military victory in Bihac -- and five major world powers seeking a peace settlement seem powerless to stop them .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;3	The statement issued after ... French talks feebly demanded an immediate cease-fire -- and Washington , Moscow , Paris , London and Bonn are clinging to a facade of unity .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;4	Pledges to continue diplomatic efforts are now not enough .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;5	An ultimatum is needed followed by strong NATO intervention to save Bihac and prevent the resulting massacre .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;6	This could be preceded by an extension of the U.N.-declared `` safe area '' around the town , using NATO air power to enforce it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;7	For this , European allies would need to plough in extra ground troops .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;8	Without such drastic action the Western alliance 's already discredited policy in Bosnia will completely collapse .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;9	Jerusalem Post , Jerusalem , Israel , on Bosnia :
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;10	The new sniping between Europeans and the United States over the humiliation of the United Nations in Bosnia is a disturbing sign of how deeply this cancerous war has eaten into the monolithic Atlantic alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;11	What has also emerged from the fall of the Bihac `` safe area '' is that European states have been tilting steadily toward a Russian , rather than American , foreign policy perspective .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;12	This is a development which has implications far beyond the mess in what was once Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;13	The grand coalition of over 30 states that converged to liberate Kuwait from the grasp of -LRB- Iraq 's -RRB- Saddam Hussein now seems as far away as the Cold War itself .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;14	Le Figaro , Paris , on Bosnia :
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;15	The conflict in Bosnia has revealed the true state of relations between the United States and Europe in the area of defense .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;16	It 's no exaggeration to say the divergences are deep , for the basic reason that the U.S. administration does n't consider its strategic interests threatened by the torching of Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;17	The Europeans , in contrast , fear that the rewards given to the aggressor will encourage him to pursue his policy of ethnic cleansing in Kosovo and Macedonia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;18	... It is high time to engage in a deep reflection on NATO , and that the Europeans and Americans become aware of the danger of this family quarrel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;19	Nihon Keizai Shinbun , Tokyo , on guns :
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;20	Recent shooting incidents like the one in which a waitress was shot in the head in a restaurant robbery are on the rise in Japan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;21	... What really points up the seriousness of the problem is that now it is n't just gangsters , but ordinary citizens who are being targeted .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;22	What 's really terrifying about guns is that , compared with the powerful effort and will to kill required to murder with a knife or sword , there 's very little psychological deterrent for someone killing from a distance with a gun .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;23	Serious discussion is needed to make sure that Japan , which was the safest country in the world , does not become a gun society like America .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;24	The Australian , Sydney , Australia , on Japan 's `` comfort women '' :
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;25	Japan 's rejection of the recommendation by the International Commission of Jurists that it should pay compensation to surviving `` comfort women '' forced into sexual slavery during World War II is regrettable .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;26	It indicates a return to the attitude that predominated among Japan 's immediate postwar generations -- to disguise the past by contriving not to discuss it -- and represents a setback for the gradual attempts of recent years to reflect on the war through more open , honest and mature debate .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;27	The Geneva-based ICJ took 19 months to find that up to 200,000 women -- mainly from Korea but also from the Philippines , Taiwan and China -- were forced to work as prostitutes in military brothels .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;28	However , the Japanese government rejected the report within 24 hours , saying it did not recognize the ICJ and would not be responding to its findings .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;29	If Japan is serious about properly mending its international relationships , and participating fully in the regional economy on any footing other than economic mastery , it needs to do more to acknowledge its wartime record .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;30	Making due reparations to survivors of brutality in the occupied countries should be part of that .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;31	The Financial Times , London , on the European Union :
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;32	In the hearts of Europe 's policy makers , hope springs eternal .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;33	Faster-than-expected recovery from recession has revived the idea that a group of countries centered on Germany could attain economic and monetary union as early as 1997 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;34	Yet there is an unfortunate corollary to the improved prospects for the European `` core . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;35	Economic divergences in the Continent 's periphery , particularly the European Union 's southern members , are increasing at a disconcerting pace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;36	Action to cope with the south 's economic challenges has been half-hearted or curbed by political difficulties or both .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;37	The south 's structural weaknesses can not be overcome without painful measures , particularly in reforming labor markets and welfare systems .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;38	... Yet without such restructuring , the task of adjustment will become still more difficult .
APW_ENG_19941201.0371;39	If growth migrates permanently from the south , the EU is unlikely to be robust enough to enlarge itself to the east .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;0	Bosnian Serbs detained more peacekeepers , denied resupply convoys and fired missiles at Sarajevo on Thursday in a further challenge to the United Nations ' crumbling bid to keep control .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;1	A day after U.N. chief Boutros Boutros-Ghali 's failed peace mission , defenders and attacking Serbs also traded heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire around embattled Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;2	U.N. spokesman Alexander Ivanko said in Zagreb , Croatia , that Bosnian Serb units had made an incursion across the border into Croatia and kidnapped seven Ukrainian peacekeepers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;3	They took the soldiers and a U.N. armored carrier into Bosnian Serb-held territory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;4	The Ukrainians ' observation point is now occupied by the Serbs , Ivanko said , and the United Nations has not been able to make contact with its troops .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;5	More than 400 other U.N. soldiers are detained by the Serbs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;6	In Sarajevo , U.N. spokesman Thant Myint-U said Serbs failed to react to 21 requests for convoy passage through Serb-held territory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;7	He said food and fuel supplies for the United Nations were running increasingly short in government-held eastern Bosnian enclaves and in Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;8	Humanitarian convoys were also blocked .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;9	In downtown Sarajevo , two buildings of the Interior Ministry were hit by one and three anti-tank missiles respectively , and four people were wounded .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;10	Sarajevo 's airport remained closed because Serbs denied flight clearance , ruling out any relief flights to the besieged Bosnian capital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;11	Intransigence by both sides led Boutros-Ghali to suggest for the first time Wednesday that the U.N. peacekeeping mission might have to end .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;12	Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic told Boutros-Ghali that his government would negotiate only after Serbs accepted a peace plan they repeatedly have rejected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;13	He reiterated his government 's offer of a three-month cease-fire .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;14	Serbs want something more permanent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;15	Comments by the Bosnian army commander , Gen. Rasim Delic to the Sarajevo daily Oslobodjenje underscored the government 's unwillingness to compromise further .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;16	He said Bihac would not fall , and that the Bosnian army eventually would win the war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;17	Bosnian Serbs snubbed Boutros-Ghali altogether .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;18	Their leader , Radovan Karadzic , refused to come to the Sarajevo airport to meet him , and Boutros-Ghali rejected entering Serb-held territory for the meeting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;19	But the U.N. chief executive will be in Geneva Friday through Sunday to `` continue his intensive diplomatic efforts for a peaceful solution , especially for a cease-fire '' in Bosnia , his spokeswoman Therese Gastaut said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;20	Maj. Herve Gourmelon , a U.N. spokesman in Sarajevo , said heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire broke out around Bihac late Wednesday and in the predawn hours Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;21	Ivanko said later that Bosnian Serb forces kept the heat on the government 's hard-pressed 5th Corps , with significant fighting reported to the southwest and south of the Bihac pocket .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;22	But there was no immediate information on any changes in the frontlines .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;23	Serbs are holding 30-40 percent of the U.N.-declared `` safe area '' consisting of Bihac town and its environs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;24	One civilian was killed near the Bihac stadium by small-arms fire , while a number of shells exploded near the Bihac hospital , badly injuring one person , Ivanko said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;25	NATO ministers meeting in Brussels on Thursday were to hear a proposal from U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher for a new international conference on former Yugoslavia at which the Serbs could make demands for new peace proposals .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;26	Already , senior Western officials are proposing that the Bosnian Serbs be allowed links to Serb-led Yugoslavia , which they long have desired .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;27	That would be a step toward creation of Serb nationalists ' goal , a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;28	Bosnian Serbs have rejected a peace plan that would reduce their holdings in Bosnia to 49 percent from about 70 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0373;29	More than 200,000 are dead or missing in the 31-month conflict launched by Serbs who rebelled against a Muslim-Croat vote to declare independence from Serb-led Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;0	A rebel Serb assembly met Thursday in a session likely to endorse an economic agreement with Croatia despite two days of fighting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;1	Croatia 's army and Serbs lobbed artillery shells at each other most of Wednesday and Thursday , said U.N. spokesman Paul Risley .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;2	The two sides have had thousands of skirmishes and larger confrontations since ending their 7-month war with an uneasy , U.N.-patrolled truce in January 1992 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;3	On Wednesday , the Croatian army fired 33 shells at Serb-held territory over a six-hour period , U.N. spokesman Alexander Ivanko said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;4	Artillery duels continued Thursday in the same locations close to Knin , Risley said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;5	Negotiations between the two sides have been stalled , but the Serbs ' self-styled government late Wednesday recommended that the assembly meeting in this Croatian Serb stronghold approve the deal .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;6	If accepted , it would be the first accord between the foes since they agreed March 29 on a formal cease-fire to end their seven-month war in 1991 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;7	The draft agreement under discussion at the closed-door Knin meeting calls for restoration of water and electricity supply and reopening oil pipelines and the highway linking Zagreb , the Croatian capital , and the Yugoslav capital Belgrade .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;8	Two sections of the 360-kilometer -LRB- 220-mile -RRB- highway are controlled by Croatian Serbs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;9	The deal , supported by powerful Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic and drafted with the help of international negotiators , was viewed as a possible step toward the gradual reintegration of the Serb Krajina region into Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;10	Croatian Serb leaders rejected the economic accord two weeks ago .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;11	After meeting Milosevic , they dropped those objections .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;12	But the session started amid fresh threats of possible new warfare between Croatia and rebel Serbs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0374;13	Croatia is chafing at Serb control over one-third of its territory , and holds out the option of taking the territory back by force .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;0	NATO asked Germany on Thursday to send fighter planes to patrol the skies over Bosnia in a mission that would place the German military in a combat role for the first time since World War II .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;1	Defense Minister Volker Ruehe said Germany must take on the mission but the foreign minister , Klaus Kinkel , raised doubts about it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;2	If Chancellor Helmut Kohl decides to accept , it could mean a bruising battle in the new parliament , where Kohl holds the narrowest of majorities .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;3	The liberal opposition said it opposed any combat role in the Balkans .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;4	Germany has shied from direct involvement in Bosnia-Herzegovina because of the history of Nazi atrocities in former Yugoslavia and anti-German sentiment among many Serbs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;5	But Germany 's credibility in NATO could be threatened if it refuses the mission , given Kohl 's repeated assertions that his nation , seeking more international influence , must bear its share of peacekeeping responsibilities .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;6	NATO requested German Tornado planes equipped with electronic gear that can locate and identify radar sites , and rockets designed to destroy such sites , a German defense official said , speaking on background .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;7	The Tornado planes could help prevent Serb attacks on NATO planes patrolling Bosnia to enforce the U.N. humanitarian mission and also could protect the air bridge to Sarajevo , the official said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;8	The need for the specialized planes was highlighted last week , when supply flights to Sarajevo from Italy were broken off after Serbs fired missiles at two British Tornados .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;9	German officials could not confirm a report in the weekly Rheinischer Merkur newspaper that the request to Germany was made because Britain wanted to withdraw its fighters from the Bosnia mission .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;10	German acceptance of the mission could mean a greater say for Germany in NATO 's policy toward Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;11	German officials have ceded key decisions to nations like France and Britain , which have ground troops in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;12	In an interview distributed by the Defense Ministry , Ruehe said that if Germany turns down the mission , `` we lose the right to intelligently take part in the discussion on Bosnia-Herzegovina . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;13	But ground troops are out of the question , Ruehe said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;14	German soldiers would be `` part of the problem , not the solution '' because of the bitter memories over the hundreds of thousands of Serbs , Jews and others murdered by the German army and SS officers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;15	The opposition Social Democrats said any German combat mission in Bosnia was unacceptable .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;16	`` Every Serbian family mourns a victim of the Germans .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;17	I have to ask whether it makes a difference if we 're on the ground or in the air , '' said Walter Kolbow , a defense expert for the party .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;18	A July decision of Germany 's highest court gave the government the green light for the first time in the postwar era to engage in peacekeeping missions outside the NATO area .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;19	But a majority of parliament must approve each mission .
APW_ENG_19941201.0375;20	`` Whether we ... should really choose former Yugoslavia as the place to step up our engagement is something I believe we should consider very carefully , '' Foreign Minister Kinkel said in Brussels , Belgium .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;0	Al-Arab , Doha , Qatar , on the European Union :
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;1	`` The European Union 's steps to reinstate its own independent decision-making by rebuffing U.S.-diktat and shedding off the Israeli hegemony is laudable .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;2	The newest evidence of this orientation is the opening by the EU of a new chapter of understanding with Syria by lifting the arms embargo imposed in 1986 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;3	The EU move would restore the Continent 's key Mideast role , which had dwindled .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;4	The strong words by Israeli Foreign Minister Shimon Peres on the European move unveils Israel 's intention to dictate its own version of the settlement conditions on Syria .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;5	The lifting of the arms embargo on Syria caused serious dissatisfaction for the Israelis , who wanted to pressure Syria .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;6	The German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel , who is also the present EU chairman , should be praised for asserting that the statements of Peres are offending to the entire Europe , a key aid-donor to the Middle East peace process and the Palestinian national self-rule authority .

APW_ENG_19941201.0376;8	The Straight Times , Singapore , on Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;9	`` Who did Bosnia in ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;10	Who gave it to the Serbs ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;11	Who is responsible for the disgraceful surrender of the ` safe haven ' of Bihac ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;12	Who delivered the coup de grace ending an entire phase of contemporary Balkan history ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;13	The answer to each question can be found in the Byzantine corridors of power constituting the institution called the United Nations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;14	It is there that peacekeeping was allowed to descend into appeasement , a fiasco into a farce ...
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;15	However , a peacekeeping mission can hope to succeed only if its goals are clear and achievable , and if they are spelt out before troops are committed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;16	If they evolve in response to escalating stages of the conflict , then confusion , discord and deadlock are only to be expected ... '' ------
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;17	Der Bund , Bern , Switzerland , on Bosnia :
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;18	`` Symbol of Betrayal ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;19	`` Bihac : the U.N.-protected zone tormented by Karadzic 's Chetniks has become a further symbol of sadness of the Western failure in the Bosnian conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;20	Based on the conduct and positions of the international community , the assumption is that this protected zone wo n't be the last symbol of betrayal of a regligious community , which at best is suspect to Western countries and at worst is accused of fundamentalism .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;21	At the bitter end of a brutal tragedy logically stands the demise of the Republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;22	`` Bihac : Under the hail of mortars from the Bosnian Serbs the Western concept of pacification of the Balkans through diplomatic means has collapsed like a house of cards -- a house of cards that was built from the beginning on illusions , on open and hidden partisanship favoring Serbia , an excessive regard for Yeltsin 's colossus with feet of clay ...
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;23	`` Bihac : the unimpeded invasion of the Serbs from Krajina and Bosnia into the protected zone confirmed the capitulation European diplomacy before the new destructive power that replaced communism -- ethno-nationalism . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;24	The Lyons Daily News , Lyons , Kansas , on GATT :
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;25	Three good reasons for supporting GATT are : Ross Perot , Pat Buchanan and Ralph Nader , for a common opposition placing them among the strangest of bedfellows .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;26	In any other arena it would be a three-way dog fight ; but , that 's America .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;27	The concerns are reminiscent of not so long ago when fear spread that rich Arabs were buying up America .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;28	That fright lost its way when Japan went on a buying binge that stirred another round of foreboding predictions .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;29	The vastness of America 's economy literally swallowed both , without a burp .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;30	There is a problem , but not with supposed intruders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;31	Rather , it is with certain narrowly-focused citizens blind to their own country 's presence .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;32	If they are so insecure as to believe the Japanese or Arabs were going to tip the balance of greatness , then it stands to reason that GATT and WTO will stir anxiety .
APW_ENG_19941201.0376;33	For the majority of Americans , though , GATT holds more hope than despair , more promise than pain , tradeoffs that are well worth the investment .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;0	Britain on Thursday announced its face-to-face showdown with the IRA 's political allies , at last confronting the difficult issues that imperil a budding peace in Northern Ireland .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;1	Peace talks next Wednesday between teams from Britain 's Northern Ireland Office and the Sinn Fein party will be the first formal , publicly acknowledged meeting between the two sides since the conflict over British rule of Northern Ireland ignited in 1969 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;2	The meeting will mark the transition from an at-a-distance `` peace process '' -- begun last December when the British and Irish governments offered Sinn Fein a place in talks if the IRA laid down its arms -- to deeply problematic negotiations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;3	Prime Minister John Major 's private secretary , Roderic Lyne , informed Sinn Fein of the British decision in a fax to the party leader , Gerry Adams .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;4	`` The exploratory talks will be a vital step in the process of consolidating a lasting peace in Northern Ireland through a common commitment to exclusively peaceful methods and the democratic process , '' Lyne wrote .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;5	Leading the Sinn Fein team will be Martin McGuinness , a former IRA commander who engaged Britain in secret contacts from 1990 to November 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;6	The outlawed group began an open-ended truce Sept. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;7	Leading the British side will be Quentin Thomas , a soft-spoken intellectual who has advised the government on political matters in Northern Ireland since 1988 but shied from the public eye .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;8	He has been a keen backer of the doctrine of denying Sinn Fein public contact in advance of a lasting IRA cease-fire .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;9	`` Sinn Fein must be accorded the same equality of treatment and parity of esteem afforded all other political parties , '' said Adams , who next week will be in Washington to meet National Security Adviser Tony Lake and other U.S. officials .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;10	The peace talks are likely to take place at Stormont east of Belfast , the impressive setting for Northern Ireland 's Protestant-dominated parliament from the state 's foundation in 1921 to 1972 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;11	Britain abolished the assembly because of its inability to draw Catholic support in the midst of the worst violence Northern Ireland had ever seen .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;12	Since then Britain has tried but failed to draw moderate Catholics into a reformed power-sharing government alongside Protestants , while shunning Sinn Fein and its working-class Catholic supporters because of the party 's IRA roots .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;13	The gap between Wednesday 's historic meeting and the creation of a round-table forum for Protestant politicians to sit down alongside Sinn Fein is wide .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;14	The Rev. Ian Paisley , leader of the province 's hard-line Democratic Unionist Party , said it was wrong for Britain to talk with `` the men of blood . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;15	But the larger , more moderate pro-British party , the Ulster Unionists , said the time was right to test whether Sinn Fein had renounced IRA violence for good .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;16	`` We are now at the right stage to enter the next phase of this development , which is to establish if Sinn Fein really is to become a normal political party , '' said John Taylor , an Ulster Unionist lawmaker who survived an IRA assassination bid in 1972 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;17	`` They will have to learn that in the political arena , they have got to compromise , '' Taylor said , adding , `` We want to convert their cease-fire into real peace . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;18	British officials have indicated they will press Sinn Fein for a surrender of IRA arms .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;19	For the first time , McGuinness said Thursday that the future of the IRA arsenal would be discussed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;20	Previously he has suggested that Sinn Fein could not discuss the handover of weapons and explosives -- most of them hidden in underground bunkers in the Irish Republic -- because Sinn Fein had no authority over the IRA .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;21	But Sinn Fein sees `` demilitarization '' of all sides as the end result of a political settlement , not a precondition for negotiating one .
APW_ENG_19941201.0377;22	`` There is an awful lot of hard work ahead of us , '' McGuinness said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0378;0	But Kozyrev said he read the ministers ' statement on membership and immediately called Russian President Boris Yeltsin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0378;1	`` This communique raises more questions than it answers , '' he said impromptu remarks that were broadcast to reporters at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization .
APW_ENG_19941201.0378;2	`` We have to understand what are the intentions of the other partners . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0378;3	In the past , Moscow has strongly opposed any move by NATO to draw in its one-time partners in the Warsaw Pact , the defunct Eastern military alliance led by the Soviet Union .
APW_ENG_19941201.0378;4	The Europeans in particular have been uneasy about pushing expansion for fear of upsetting Russia , still a formidable military power at the edge of allied territory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0378;5	In an effort to overcome Russian objections , the allies had agreed to develop a `` far-reaching relationship , corresponding with Russia 's size , importance and capabilities . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0378;6	They had insisted they had no intention of forming a hostile bloc threatening Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0378;7	`` Having just overcome the division of Europe , we have no desire to see the emergence of new lines of partition , '' the ministers said in a statement .
APW_ENG_19941201.0378;8	A senior U.S. official , speaking a few hours before Kozyrev 's outburst , said , `` The Russians are undoubtedly ambivalent about this . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0378;9	He spoke on condition of anonymity .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;0	Here are excerpts of editorials from publications in various countries :
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;1	Gulf Daily News , Manama , Bahrain , on Bosnia :
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;2	Bosnian Serbs were ... on the verge of military victory in Bihac -- and five major world powers seeking a peace settlement seem powerless to stop them .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;3	The statement issued after ... French talks feebly demanded an immediate cease-fire -- and Washington , Moscow , Paris , London and Bonn are clinging to a facade of unity .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;4	Pledges to continue diplomatic efforts are now not enough .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;5	An ultimatum is needed followed by strong NATO intervention to save Bihac and prevent the resulting massacre .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;6	This could be preceded by an extension of the U.N.-declared `` safe area '' around the town , using NATO air power to enforce it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;7	For this , European allies would need to plough in extra ground troops .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;8	Without such drastic action the Western alliance 's already discredited policy in Bosnia will completely collapse .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;9	Jerusalem Post , Jerusalem , Israel , on Bosnia :
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;10	The new sniping between Europeans and the United States over the humiliation of the United Nations in Bosnia is a disturbing sign of how deeply this cancerous war has eaten into the monolithic Atlantic alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;11	What has also emerged from the fall of the Bihac `` safe area '' is that European states have been tilting steadily toward a Russian , rather than American , foreign policy perspective .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;12	This is a development which has implications far beyond the mess in what was once Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;13	The grand coalition of over 30 states that converged to liberate Kuwait from the grasp of -LRB- Iraq 's -RRB- Saddam Hussein now seems as far away as the Cold War itself .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;14	Le Figaro , Paris , on Bosnia :
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;15	The conflict in Bosnia has revealed the true state of relations between the United States and Europe in the area of defense .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;16	It 's no exaggeration to say the divergences are deep , for the basic reason that the U.S. administration does n't consider its strategic interests threatened by the torching of Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;17	The Europeans , in contrast , fear that the rewards given to the aggressor will encourage him to pursue his policy of ethnic cleansing in Kosovo and Macedonia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;18	... It is high time to engage in a deep reflection on NATO , and that the Europeans and Americans become aware of the danger of this family quarrel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;19	Nihon Keizai Shinbun , Tokyo , on guns :
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;20	Recent shooting incidents like the one in which a waitress was shot in the head in a restaurant robbery are on the rise in Japan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;21	... What really points up the seriousness of the problem is that now it is n't just gangsters , but ordinary citizens who are being targeted .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;22	What 's really terrifying about guns is that , compared with the powerful effort and will to kill required to murder with a knife or sword , there 's very little psychological deterrent for someone killing from a distance with a gun .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;23	Serious discussion is needed to make sure that Japan , which was the safest country in the world , does not become a gun society like America .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;24	The Australian , Sydney , Australia , on Japan 's `` comfort women '' :
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;25	Japan 's rejection of the recommendation by the International Commission of Jurists that it should pay compensation to surviving `` comfort women '' forced into sexual slavery during World War II is regrettable .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;26	It indicates a return to the attitude that predominated among Japan 's immediate postwar generations -- to disguise the past by contriving not to discuss it -- and represents a setback for the gradual attempts of recent years to reflect on the war through more open , honest and mature debate .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;27	The Geneva-based ICJ took 19 months to find that up to 200,000 women -- mainly from Korea but also from the Philippines , Taiwan and China -- were forced to work as prostitutes in military brothels .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;28	However , the Japanese government rejected the report within 24 hours , saying it did not recognize the ICJ and would not be responding to its findings .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;29	If Japan is serious about properly mending its international relationships , and participating fully in the regional economy on any footing other than economic mastery , it needs to do more to acknowledge its wartime record .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;30	Making due reparations to survivors of brutality in the occupied countries should be part of that .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;31	The Financial Times , London , on the European Union :
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;32	In the hearts of Europe 's policy makers , hope springs eternal .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;33	Faster-than-expected recovery from recession has revived the idea that a group of countries centered on Germany could attain economic and monetary union as early as 1997 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;34	Yet there is an unfortunate corollary to the improved prospects for the European `` core . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;35	Economic divergences in the Continent 's periphery , particularly the European Union 's southern members , are increasing at a disconcerting pace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;36	Action to cope with the south 's economic challenges has been half-hearted or curbed by political difficulties or both .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;37	The south 's structural weaknesses can not be overcome without painful measures , particularly in reforming labor markets and welfare systems .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;38	... Yet without such restructuring , the task of adjustment will become still more difficult .
APW_ENG_19941201.0379;39	If growth migrates permanently from the south , the EU is unlikely to be robust enough to enlarge itself to the east .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;0	A rebel Serb assembly met Thursday in a session likely to endorse an economic agreement with Croatia despite two days of fighting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;1	Croatia 's army and Serbs lobbed artillery shells at each other most of Wednesday and Thursday , said U.N. spokesman Paul Risley .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;2	The two sides have had thousands of skirmishes and larger confrontations since ending their 7-month war with an uneasy , U.N.-patrolled truce in January 1992 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;3	On Wednesday , the Croatian army fired 33 shells at Serb-held territory over a six-hour period , U.N. spokesman Alexander Ivanko said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;4	Artillery duels continued Thursday in the same locations close to Knin , Risley said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;5	Negotiations between the two sides have been stalled , but the Serbs ' self-styled government late Wednesday recommended that the assembly meeting in this Croatian Serb stronghold approve the deal .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;6	If accepted , it would be the first accord between the foes since they agreed March 29 on a formal cease-fire to end their seven-month war in 1991 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;7	The draft agreement under discussion at the closed-door Knin meeting calls for restoration of water and electricity supply and reopening oil pipelines and the highway linking Zagreb , the Croatian capital , and the Yugoslav capital Belgrade .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;8	Two sections of the 360-kilometer -LRB- 220-mile -RRB- highway are controlled by Croatian Serbs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;9	The deal , supported by powerful Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic and drafted with the help of international negotiators , was viewed as a possible step toward the gradual reintegration of the Serb Krajina region into Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;10	Croatian Serb leaders rejected the economic accord two weeks ago .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;11	After meeting Milosevic , they dropped those objections .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;12	But the session started amid fresh threats of possible new warfare between Croatia and rebel Serbs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0380;13	Croatia is chafing at Serb control over one-third of its territory , and holds out the option of taking the territory back by force .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;0	Under a furious lobbying barrage from the Clinton administration and a small army of corporate executives , the Senate stood on the verge Thursday of ratifying a sweeping expansion of global free trade .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;1	The climatic vote will not occur until the end of a second full day of debate , but supporters were claiming they now had an ample number of votes for the agreement itself and , more importantly , a small cushion for the three-fifths majority they need on a budget waiver .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;2	`` By the time the vote is actually taken tonight , we expect GATT will pass , '' said presidential press secretary Dee Dee Myers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;3	While administration officials and Senate supporters said their vote counts showed victory in their grasp , they did not let up in their lobbying efforts .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;4	President Clinton met at the White House with a group of mostly undecided senators in an attempt to build the victory margin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;5	Sen. Kent Conrad , D-N.D. , said Bentsen told senators `` they will regret the vote the rest of their lives '' if they oppose GATT and that its defeat would have an `` adverse reaction '' in both the stock and bond markets .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;6	Opponents , while conceding that the momentum was not going their way , did not let up in their efforts , either .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;7	A group of two-dozen protesters , one dressed as a lame-duck , chanted outside the White House as senators arrived for breakfast with Clinton .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;8	Sen. Fritz Hollings of South Carolina said that the new trade agreement was a bad deal that , by lowering trade barriers , would subject American workers to even more unfair competition from low-wage countries , further weakening the country 's economic standing .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;9	`` The reality is that we are in decline .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;10	Everybody knows that , '' said Hollings , whose home-state textile industry will be one of the biggest losers in the deal .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;11	`` Wake up , Washington . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;12	However , GATT supporters said that the Senate 's choice on the last day of the 103rd Congress was between continuing to hold a position of economic leadership in the global economy or retreating behind protectionist barriers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;13	The House endorsed the accord , negotiated under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade , by a 288-146 vote on Tuesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;14	Thirty-three other countries already have ratified the 124-nation accord and supporters said other countries are poised to act before Jan. 1 if the Senate follows the House .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;15	According to an Associated Press survey , GATT proponents appeared on the verge of victory , when counting those who were leaning in favor but not firmly committed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;16	The AP head count had 65 senators for or leaning for waiving budget rules , 28 against or leaning against and seven undeclared .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;17	Opponents ' only hope was to change enough senators ' minds to muster 41 votes in favor of the procedural hurdle imposed by Sen. Robert Byrd .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;18	Under Senate rules , the implementing bill must offset all of the projected dlrs 43 billion in lost tariff revenues over the first decade of the accord .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;19	To make up for the lost tariffs , the administration is cutting farm subsidies and raising revenue with a number of measures , including changing the minimum rate on savings bonds and auctioning licenses for a new generation of wireless broadcast services .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;20	Byrd said the bill falls dlrs 14.5 billion short and some senators , while declaring themselves in favor of free trade , said they would not vote to bust the budget .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;21	Byrd and others also complain that a new Geneva-based World Trade Organization , created to referee trade disputes , will inevitably infringe on U.S. sovereignty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;22	The administration is predicting 500,000 new American jobs as a result of increased U.S. export sales under GATT .
APW_ENG_19941201.0381;23	In addition to bringing foreign tariffs closer to U.S. levels , it reduces barriers to trade in agricultural goods and services and protects U.S. intellectual property , such as computer programs , from being pirated .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;0	and when -- to open its doors to its former foes in Eastern Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;1	Poland , Hungary and others have repeatedly demanded coveted membership cards and the security guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;2	In an effort to meet their demands -- but without upsetting Russia , the allies thought they had found a good formula .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;3	At a summit last January , President Clinton and other allied leaders approved a U.S. initiative , Partnership for Peace , to bring former foes closer , but without membership .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;4	Twenty-three nations , including Russia , have enrolled in the project , which allows them to take part for the first time in military exercises and other alliance activities .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;5	On Thursday , the allies decided to go further by ordering aides to conduct a 12-month study of the terms and conditions for expanding the Western military alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;6	`` We took significant , concrete steps toward ... expansion '' of the alliance , Christopher said afterward .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;7	The move was intended to be a cautious one .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;8	No list of front-runners for membership will be made ; no date set for the first admissions will be set .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;9	But Kozyrev accused NATO of trying to make a fresh division on the European continent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;10	Some members of Partnership for Peace , he said , were destined to become members , while others would remain behind .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;11	`` Not all countries will be able to obtain membership at the same time , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;12	`` There needs to be some sort of clarification . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;13	Kozyrev 's criticism only added to the alliance 's troubles .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;14	There have been unprecedented strains in recent weeks between the United States and its European allies over the crisis in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;15	In an effort to heal the divisions , Christopher swung behind the European view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;16	That marks a major policy switch by Washington under pressure from the Europeans , led by Britain and France .
APW_ENG_19941201.0383;17	With the policy turnaround , ministers agreed to relaunch diplomatic efforts to end the Bosnian war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;0	Bread price increased by 11 times Thursday as the government started implementing its ambitious market-reform plan aimed at freeing prices and slashing the deficit .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;1	The government ordered bread price increased from 6 drams -LRB- 1.3 cents -RRB- to 66 drams -LRB- 15 cents -RRB- a kilogram -LRB- 2.2 pounds -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;2	However , bread rationing remained in force with a daily norm of 350 grams -LRB- 12 ounces -RRB- per person in the capital , and 250 grams -LRB- 9 ounces -RRB- in the countryside .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;3	Armenia is one of the poorest of the former Soviet republics with the average monthly salary at about dlrs 7 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;4	Its economy has been severely hit by an economic blockade imposed by Azerbaijan as part of a six-year war over the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;5	Armenia 's only source of energy is a natural-gas pipeline from Georgia that has been repeatedly bombed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;6	The government has vowed to gradually deregulate all prices to meet requirements for international loans .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;7	Armenia hopes to get dlrs 250-300 million in credits from the International Monetary Fund , World Bank and some Western governments over the next year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;8	The authorities have said all prices would be freed until the fall of 1995 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;9	On Thursday , the government also ordered a six-fold increase in the price of electricity , transport and communal services , and rent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;10	Other prices were expected to rise soon .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;11	Officials have promised to ease the impact of price hikes by doubling wages and increasing aid to the poor .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;12	The government has said its economic plan would result in cutting inflation from the current 8-9 percent a month to 1 percent by the end of next year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;13	To ease the energy crunch , Armenia has also announced plans to build an oil refinery and is negotiating to get oil from Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0386;14	It also plans to reopen a nuclear power plant shut down after the December 1987 earthquake .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;0	Key events in post-Soviet Russia 's struggle with Chechnya :
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;1	Sept. 6 -- Dzhokhar Dudayev , retired Soviet air force general , leads ouster of Chechnya 's Soviet government , which supported the failed August coup by hard-liners in Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;2	Oct. 6 -- Dudayev elected president .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;3	Moscow lawmakers say the election lacks legal basis .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;4	Nov. 2 -- Dudayev declares Chechnya independent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;5	Oct. 11 -- Dudayev declares state of emergency after thousands of Russian troops mass on border .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;6	Nov. 18 -- Troops from both sides pull back but tensions remain high between Dudayev and Yeltsin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;7	April 2 -- Dudayev dissolves parliament and declares one-man rule .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;8	June 5 -- Dudayev calls out tanks and troops to halt referendum on one-man rule .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;9	Thousands protest against president .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;10	June 13 -- Open fighting between pro- and anti-Dudayev forces breaks out in capital , Grozny .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;11	Aug. 2 -- Russia openly supports the opposition Provisional Council .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;12	Aug. 11 -- Yeltsin rules out use of force in Chechnya .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;13	Nov. 25 -- Helicopter gunships attack government positions near Grozny .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;14	Officials say airships had Russian markings ; Moscow says military uninvolved .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;15	Nov. 26 -- Fierce fighting in Grozny as opposition tries to seize presidential palace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;16	Retreats after day-long battle .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;17	Nov. 28 -- Chechen authorities warn they will execute about 70 Russians , including army officers and soldiers , captured in the attempt to seize the presidential palace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;18	Dudayev later says the prisoners will be tried in court .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;19	Nov. 29 -- Yeltsin issues ultimatum to Chechens to lay down their arms by Dec. 1 or face direct Russian intervention .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;20	Hours later , opposition jets bomb Grozny .
APW_ENG_19941201.0387;21	Dec. 1 -- Yeltsin 's deadline expires , Moscow appears to back away from threats to send troops into Chechnya .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;0	Bosnian Serbs detained more peacekeepers , denied resupply convoys and fired missiles at Sarajevo on Thursday in a further challenge to the United Nations ' crumbling bid to keep control .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;1	A day after U.N. chief Boutros Boutros-Ghali 's failed peace mission , defenders and attacking Serbs also traded heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire around embattled Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;2	U.N. spokesman Alexander Ivanko said in Zagreb , Croatia , that Bosnian Serb units had made an incursion across the border into Croatia and kidnapped seven Ukrainian peacekeepers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;3	They took the soldiers and a U.N. armored carrier into Bosnian Serb-held territory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;4	The Ukrainians ' observation point is now occupied by the Serbs , Ivanko said , and the United Nations has not been able to make contact with its troops .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;5	More than 400 other U.N. soldiers are detained by the Serbs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;6	In Sarajevo , U.N. spokesman Thant Myint-U said Serbs failed to react to 21 requests for convoy passage through Serb-held territory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;7	He said food and fuel supplies for the United Nations were running increasingly short in government-held eastern Bosnian enclaves and in Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;8	Humanitarian convoys were also blocked .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;9	In downtown Sarajevo , two buildings of the Interior Ministry were hit by one and three anti-tank missiles respectively , and four people were wounded .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;10	Sarajevo 's airport remained closed because Serbs denied flight clearance , ruling out any relief flights to the besieged Bosnian capital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;11	Intransigence by both sides led Boutros-Ghali to suggest for the first time Wednesday that the U.N. peacekeeping mission might have to end .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;12	Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic told Boutros-Ghali that his government would negotiate only after Serbs accepted a peace plan they repeatedly have rejected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;13	He reiterated his government 's offer of a three-month cease-fire .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;14	Serbs want something more permanent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;15	Comments by the Bosnian army commander , Gen. Rasim Delic to the Sarajevo daily Oslobodjenje underscored the government 's unwillingness to compromise further .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;16	He said Bihac would not fall , and that the Bosnian army eventually would win the war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;17	Bosnian Serbs snubbed Boutros-Ghali altogether .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;18	Their leader , Radovan Karadzic , refused to come to the Sarajevo airport to meet him , and Boutros-Ghali rejected entering Serb-held territory for the meeting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;19	But the U.N. chief executive will be in Geneva Friday through Sunday to `` continue his intensive diplomatic efforts for a peaceful solution , especially for a cease-fire '' in Bosnia , his spokeswoman Therese Gastaut said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;20	Maj. Herve Gourmelon , a U.N. spokesman in Sarajevo , said heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire broke out around Bihac late Wednesday and in the predawn hours Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;21	Ivanko said later that Bosnian Serb forces kept the heat on the government 's hard-pressed 5th Corps , with significant fighting reported to the southwest and south of the Bihac pocket .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;22	But there was no immediate information on any changes in the frontlines .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;23	Serbs are holding 30-40 percent of the U.N.-declared `` safe area '' consisting of Bihac town and its environs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;24	One civilian was killed near the Bihac stadium by small-arms fire , while a number of shells exploded near the Bihac hospital , badly injuring one person , Ivanko said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;25	NATO ministers meeting in Brussels on Thursday were to hear a proposal from U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher for a new international conference on former Yugoslavia at which the Serbs could make demands for new peace proposals .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;26	Already , senior Western officials are proposing that the Bosnian Serbs be allowed links to Serb-led Yugoslavia , which they long have desired .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;27	That would be a step toward creation of Serb nationalists ' goal , a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;28	Bosnian Serbs have rejected a peace plan that would reduce their holdings in Bosnia to 49 percent from about 70 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0388;29	More than 200,000 are dead or missing in the 31-month conflict launched by Serbs who rebelled against a Muslim-Croat vote to declare independence from Serb-led Yugoslavia .
