APW_ENG_19941201.0429;0	Canadian peacekeepers serving with the United Nations in Bosnia-Herzegovina are detained by Bosnian Serbs after NATO planes bomb Serb positions in Bosnia and Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;1	Here are some key dates surrounding the detention :
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;2	Nov. 19 -- UN Security Council extends NATO air authority to Croatia after Serb warplanes flying from an air base in Udbina , in Serb-controlled Croatia , launch air strikes on the UN-declared safe haven of Bihac in northwest Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;3	Nov. 21 -- NATO planes bomb the Udbina airport and two Serb missile sites in Bosnia near Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;4	Nov. 22 -- Serbs fire surface-to-air missiles at two NATO jets flying over Serb-held Banja Luka , in northwest Bosnia , and set villages ablaze and send civilians fleeing in the Bihac pocket in retaliation for NATO air strikes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;5	Nov. 23 -- Serbs detain some 250 UN peacekeepers , including 55 Canadian troops near their base in Visoko , Bosnia , hours after renewed NATO air strikes against Serb positions near Bihac in Bosnia and Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;6	Nov. 24 -- UN officials attempt to negotiate the release of the Canadians and the other UN peacekeepers in talks with Serb leaders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;7	Bosnian Muslim-led government troops block attempt to transfer 150 non-essential personnel from the Canadian base at Visoko to Kiseljak , some 15 kilometres away .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;8	Nov. 25 -- NATO jets fly over Serb positions near Bihac but due to darkness drop no bombs as Serb forces advance into the enclave , controlled by the Muslim-led government army .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;9	Serbs allow some of the detained Canadians to carry out work at their observation posts .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;10	Muslims lift blockade of Canadian camp .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;11	Nov. 26 -- Canadian troops come under fire three times .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;12	No one is injured : a convoy of buses carrying Canadians to Visoko from Split , Croatia , is hit by five mortars ; two rifle grenades hit Canadian headquarters in Knin in Serb-controlled Croatia ; mortar round lands near Canadian vehicle in Knin area .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;13	Nov. 27 -- Between six and 10 rockets fired by Bosnian Serbs land near the Canadian camp in Visoko .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;14	Shrapnel from two rockets damages a camp building where Canadian soldiers are sleeping .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;15	No one is injured .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;16	Negotiations to free the detained Canadians continue .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;17	Nov. 28 -- The UN commander in Bosnia , Lt.-Gen .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;18	Sir Michael Rose , and Col. Bill Brough , commander of the Canadian battalion in Visoko , fail to win release of the Canadians .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;19	A Serb offer to let the Canadians return to base if they 're replaced by another 55 Canadians is rejected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;20	Nov. 30 -- a Bosnian Serb threat to shell the Canadian camp within 48 hours passes without incident .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;21	However , the peacekeepers increase security and place sandbags around sleeping quarters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0429;22	Dec. 1 -- Bosnian Serbs respond to letters from Canadian and UN commanders protesting the detention of 55 Canadian peacekeepers , but military sources say the response was too general to satisfy the UN as it tries to restart serious talks on releasing 400 UN troops , including the Canadians .
APW_ENG_19941201.0430;0	The government complained to the Spanish ambassador Thursday about `` intrusive '' checks on Gibraltar citizens entering Spain .
APW_ENG_19941201.0430;1	The intensity of car and body searches by Spanish border police reportedly can cause delays of several hours .
APW_ENG_19941201.0430;2	David Davis , the Foreign Office minister for Europe , called in Spanish ambassador Alberto Aza Arias , according to a Foreign Office statement that described the checks as having `` seriously interfered with cross-border traffic and daily life in Gibraltar . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0430;3	Davis told Arias `` the checks were intrusive and could not seriously be presented as a search for drugs and tobacco , '' the statement said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0430;4	`` Mr. Davis warned the checks could damage prospects for practical cooperation between the Gibraltar and Spanish authorities in a number of important areas of mutual concern , '' the Foreign Office statement said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0430;5	Spain claims sovereignty over the 5.8-square-kilometer -LRB- 2.25-square-mile -RRB- territory of limestone rock at the southern tip of the Iberian peninsula .
APW_ENG_19941201.0430;6	Gibraltar 's approximately 30,000 residents want continued allegiance to Britain , which since 1704 has held the strategic territory overlooking the mouth of the Mediterranean Sea .
APW_ENG_19941201.0430;7	Britain 's determination to retain Gibraltar has proved a chronic sore point in British-Spanish relations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0430;8	British-Spanish talks on Gibraltar 's future have been stalled since 1989 over the issue of who should control its airport .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;0	Amnesty International accused the upcoming Summit of the Americas Thursday of paying too little attention to punishing human rights abuses in the hemisphere .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;1	The human rights group also challenged the idea that trade and democracy alone can bring about respect for human rights .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;2	Despite the advent of democracy to all Western Hemisphere countries except Cuba , `` The human rights records of far too many of the countries , including the United States , remain tarnished and dismal , '' said William Schulz , executive director of Amnesty International USA .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;3	`` Most discouragingly , it appears as if the whole topic of human rights may receive the shortest of shrifts at the summit . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;4	Human rights is one of many issues mentioned in the declaration to be signed next week by President Clinton and 33 other presidents from the Americas .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;5	But the major focus of the summit , hosted by Clinton in Miami , will be the leaders ' pledge to create a hemisphere-wide free-trade area .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;6	Mike Canning , a spokesman for the State Department office organizing the summit , rebutted Amnesty 's criticism .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;7	Consultations among summit nations to produce the presidents ' communique `` more than adequately recognized the importance of protecting human rights , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;8	`` It 's not just something mentioned in passing .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;9	This is something that the countries and the leaders are going to take very seriously at the summit . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;10	But Argentine human rights activist Emilio Fermin Mignone , participating in the Amnesty International news conference , said the draft communique does not call for an end to impunity for the perpetrators of human rights abuses such as kidnappings , torture , rape and murder .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;11	He called on Clinton and the other leaders to `` eliminate a tacit acceptance of impunity in the hemisphere . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;12	Many countries that have switched from military dictatorships to democracy -- including Brazil , Argentina , Chile and Uruguay -- have amnesty laws or arrangements that permit human rights abusers to avoid prosecution , he noted .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;13	Violators linked to mass killings or other notorious abuses in Peru , Colombia and El Salvador also went free , Schulz said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;14	Human rights groups have cited numerous Latin countries for gross human rights violations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;15	`` Sometimes children are killed simply because they are seen as a nuisance , a tragedy repeated again and gain for the street children of Brazil , Guatemala and Colombia , '' said an Amnesty report prepared for the Miami summit .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;16	The report accuses the United States of police brutality and criticizes it for using the death penalty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;17	Guatemalan rights activist Carmen Angelica Valenzuela , a former professor and physician in Guatemala City , spoke Thursday of her abduction and torture by members of the Guatemalan army in 1990 , saying the military apparently considered her subversive .
APW_ENG_19941201.0431;18	She said Guatemala 's armed forces are `` directly responsible for the most brutal campaign of terror in the Western Hemisphere . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;0	Yasser Arafat 's government on Thursday took control of the health and taxation systems in the West Bank , broadening Palestinian autonomy despite a pall cast on peacemaking by a series of Islamic terror attacks .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;1	The move completed the initial stage of handing over day-to-day affairs in the West Bank to Palestinians .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;2	It also came amid growing calls in Israel for shutting off Palestinians from Israel because of a series of attacks in which 32 Israelis have been killed since early October .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;3	About 1,000 people gathered Thursday in the northern Israeli town of Afula for the funeral of the latest victim , 19-year-old woman soldier Liat Gabai , who was axed to death on Wednesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;4	A suspect detained Wednesday , Wahib Abu Rub , 24 , from the West Bank town of Qabatiyah , has told interrogators he was from the Islamic Resistance Movement or Hamas , Israel radio said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;5	The same group claimed the Oct. 19 Tel Aviv bus bombing that killed 22 people .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;6	Abu Rub admitted to the slaying in an interview on Israel television .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;7	Speaking as he was led to the Nazareth court Thursday , he said he wanted to prove to fellow Palestinians he was n't collaborating with Israel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;8	`` They accused me of being a traitor .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;9	I wanted to prove that I was n't , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;10	`` I killed the soldier to prove to my people I am a decent man . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;11	Police Minister Moshe Shahal responded by calling Thursday for completely shutting off the West Bank and Gaza Strip from Israel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;12	`` There is no alternative other than to demand separation , '' Shahal said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;13	`` Separation means that we do not have to open the territory out of economic and employment concerns until the Palestinians prove that they can prevent attacks . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;14	A closure could also bring further violence , by preventing thousands of Palestinian day workers from entering Israel to earn a living .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;15	Palestinian and Israeli leaders have blamed growing support for Islamic radicals on economic troubles in the PLO-run Gaza Strip .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;16	Despite the violence , talks were expected to begin next week on stage two of the autonomy given Gaza and the West Bank town of Jericho last May -- redeployment of Israeli troops in the West Bank and Palestinian elections .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;17	Israel 's concern for the safety of 120,000 Jewish settlers has prompted some officials to propose skipping the interim phase altogether and negotiating the final status of these territories now , rather than in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;18	Still , a gradual hand over of responsibilities to Palestinians proceeded in the West Bank where two ceremonies were held marking the transfer of the health and tax systems .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;19	The PLO has since August also taken charge of education , tourism and welfare in the West Bank .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;20	`` What we have completed gives the Palestinians a first entrance to the West Bank , '' said West Bank military governor Brig. Gen. Gadi Zohar , signing over the tax department to Palestinian Finance Minister Mohammed Nashashibi in Ramallah .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;21	In Brussels , foreign donors this week released dlrs 125 million pledged earlier , mostly to help the Palestinians meet running costs for a few months .
APW_ENG_19941201.0432;22	Deputy Finance Minister Atef Alawneh said he hoped to collect dlrs 300-400 million annually in taxes to try to overcome dependency on donor nations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;0	Russia on Thursday upset NATO 's plans for expanding its membership to former Warsaw Pact foes by claiming the move would create a new division in Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;1	In an extraordinary session , Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev departed from prepared remarks to criticize the allies for agreeing to a U.S. initiative to draw up the terms and conditions for future membership .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;2	`` If the strategy of NATO has changed , then that is something which requires further discussion , '' Kozyrev told a group of grim-faced foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;3	Afterward , Portuguese Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Durao Barroso said Kozyrev `` threw a bucket of cold water on the meeting . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;4	The Russian had been invited to the meeting to endorse a wide-ranging program of military and political contacts with Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;5	The special ties had been designed to ease Russia 's fears of an eastward drive by the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;6	But Kozyrev refused to agree to the documents .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;7	He said he read the ministers ' statement on membership and immediately called Russian President Boris Yeltsin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;8	`` This communique raises more questions than it answers , '' he said impromptu remarks that were broadcast to reporters at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;9	`` We have to understand what are the intentions of the other partners . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;10	Willy Claes , the alliance 's new secretary-general , sought to respond to Kozyrev 's remarks .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;11	`` It is no change in strategy or policy of NATO .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;12	... There is nothing new , '' he told the Russian just before he left NATO headquarters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;13	`` We are not willing to organize new divisions in Europe . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;14	Kozyrev 's outburst only added to the alliance 's woes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;15	There have been unprecedented strains in recent weeks between the United States and its European allies over the crisis in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;16	In an effort to heal the wounds , Christopher swung behind the European view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;17	It was a major policy switch by Washington under pressure from the Europeans , led by Britain and France .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;18	In the past , Moscow has strongly opposed any move by NATO to draw in its one-time partners in the Warsaw Pact , the defunct Eastern military alliance led by the Soviet Union .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;19	The Europeans in particular have been uneasy about pushing expansion for fear of upsetting Russia , still a formidable military power at the edge of allied territory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;20	In an effort to overcome Russian objections , the allies had agreed to develop a `` far-reaching relationship , corresponding with Russia 's size , importance and capabilities . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;21	They had insisted they had no intention of forming a hostile bloc threatening Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;22	`` Having just overcome the division of Europe , we have no desire to see the emergence of new lines of partition , '' the ministers said in a statement .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;23	NATO has been anguishing in recent years over whether -- and when -- to open its doors to its former foes in Eastern Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;24	Poland , Hungary and others have repeatedly demanded coveted membership cards and the security guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;25	In an effort to meet their demands -- but without upsetting Russia , the allies thought they had found a good formula .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;26	At a summit last January , President Clinton and other allied leaders approved a U.S. initiative , Partnership for Peace , to bring former foes closer , but without membership .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;27	Twenty-three nations , including Russia , have enrolled in the project , which allows them to take part for the first time in military exercises and other alliance activities .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;28	On Thursday , the allies decided to go further by ordering aides to conduct a 12-month study of the terms and conditions for expanding the Western military alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;29	`` We took significant , concrete steps toward ... expansion '' of the alliance , Christopher said afterward .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;30	The move was intended to be a cautious one .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;31	No list of front-runners for membership will be made ; no date set for the first admissions will be set .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;32	But Kozyrev accused NATO of trying to make a fresh division on the European continent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;33	Some members of Partnership for Peace , he said , were destined to become members , while others would remain behind .
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;34	He said the Russians too `` do not exclude the possibility of wanting to become members of NATO . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0433;35	He insisted `` There needs to be some sort of clarification . ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0435;0	Russia wants its key western partners to back a confederation of Bosnian Serbs with neighboring Serbia itself , Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev said Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0435;1	`` We do support the suggestion that the ` Contact Group ' comes out with an unambiguous recognition '' of Bosnian Serbs ' right to forge political links with the government in Belgrade , Kozyrev told reporters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0435;2	The foreign ministers of the Contact Group nations -- Russia , France , Britain , Germany and the United States -- meet here on Friday to debate the way forward in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0435;3	On Thursday , the United States swung behind the European view that diplomacy is the best way to deal with the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0435;4	It thus sought to heal a rift with the European allies over NATO 's use of force in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0435;5	Kozyrev met here with this NATO counterparts .
APW_ENG_19941201.0435;6	Speaking to reporters as he left the NATO headquarters , he said a Serb confederation would be akin to the confederation of Croatia and the Muslim-led government in Sarajevo .
APW_ENG_19941201.0435;7	The latter is part of the current Contact Group peace plan for Bosnia that Bosnian Serbs have refused to accept .
APW_ENG_19941201.0435;8	Kozyrev said if Croatia and the government in Sarajevo can link up politically , `` the Bosnian Serbs have ... equal right to confederate with Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0435;9	Earlier , French Foreign Minister Alain Juppe said he hoped Friday 's meeting of the Contact Group would launch `` a new initiative '' to end the fighting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0435;10	Juppe will travel to Belgrade , the Serbian capital , on Sunday with British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd for talks with President Slobodan Milosevic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;0	Rewards given to North Korea for promising to freeze its nuclear program could lead to nuclear blackmail from other rogue nations such as Iran , senators contended in a hearing Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;1	The Clinton administration 's chief negotiator with North Korea , Robert Gallucci , countered that the agreement reached on Oct. 21 has already stopped the North Korean nuclear weapons program and `` achieves more than we and the international community thought possible '' when talks began in early 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;2	But Gallucci met a skeptical audience in the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific affairs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;3	`` I have serious reservations about giving North Korea the benefit of the doubt , '' said subcommittee Chairman Charles Robb .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;4	Robb said the agreement to supply North Korea with oil and new nuclear power reactors in exchange for shutting down its current nuclear program was a `` fundamental shift '' in the U.S. policy of penalizing nations that violate international nuclear proliferation accords .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;5	`` Some have even characterized this as nuclear blackmail '' that might encourage such countries as Iran to demand similar favors for not developing nuclear weapons programs , he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;6	Republican Sen. Frank Murkowski a leading critic of the agreement with North Korea , faulted the administration for giving North Korea years before it will have to open up two radioactive waste sites to international inspectors .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;7	The sites are thought to provide a key to whether Pyongyang has diverted plutonium for nuclear weapons .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;8	`` Why did n't we insist that they come clean ? ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;9	But Murkowski , the likely next chairman of the subcommittee when the Republicans take over Congress next year , did not suggest , as he has in past interviews , that he might try to block the accord .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;10	`` I 'm not sitting here saying we should cancel the agreement , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;11	Under the agreement , an international group headed by South Korea and Japan is to supply the North with two light water nuclear reactors , worth about dlrs 4 billion , that are less susceptible to plutonium extraction .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;12	The United States will provide 150,000 tons of heavy oil next year and 500,000 tons a year after that to compensate North Korea for shutting down its existing 5-megawatt gas graphite reactor and scuttling plans to build 50 - and 200-megawatt reactors .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;13	The United States also agreed to remove some trade barriers and take initial steps toward opening diplomatic contacts .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;14	North Korea also agreed not to reprocess 8,000 spent fuel rods and to eventually open up all facilities to International Atomic Energy Agency inspections .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;15	Gallucci stressed that all major technology for the nuclear reactors will be withheld until North Korea allows the inspections , ship the spent fuel rods out of the country and dismantles its current reactor program .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;16	`` We entered into this agreement without any uncertainty or delusions about past North Korean behavior .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;17	The agreement framework is not based on trust , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0436;18	Gallucci acknowledged that U.S. negotiators made concessions on the inspections issue , but said they did not harm U.S. security interests .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;0	Russians , angry at having to pay for U.S. visa applications even if they are rejected , lashed out Thursday at `` the latest insult '' to would-be visitors to the United States .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;1	Ambassador Thomas Pickering announced the $ 20 application fee on Wednesday as part of changes intended to improve an application process that has been criticized as rude and humiliating .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;2	The fee , charged on top of the price of a visa , took effect Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;3	`` I wonder why we 're trying so hard to go to this ` wonderful ' country , America , when its embassy has so little respect for us , '' said Sergei Tumbasov , a construction engineer hoping to go to Virginia on business .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;4	Tumbasov said no one told him about the fee until he arrived at the embassy Thursday morning , not even the consular officer he spoke to the day before .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;5	The application fee , equal to nearly a week 's wages for the average Russian , is especially painful for the more than 100 visa applicants who are rejected every day at the U.S. Embassy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;6	`` This unexpected fee is the final insult in an absolutely absurd process , '' said Dr. Marina Orlova , an eye doctor from the prestigious Fyodorov Clinic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;7	She was turned away for failing to prove she would return to Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;8	`` Who do they think we are ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;9	We 're doctors , professionals , '' she said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;10	If Orlova returns with documents to support her application , she has to pay another $ 20 fee .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;11	That does n't include the fee for the visa itself , which is $ 20 for one entry , or $ 120 for a multiple-entry permit .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;12	`` The system is made for the mafia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;13	No one else can afford it , '' Orlova added loudly , prompting a guard to ask her to leave the crowded sidewalk in front of the embassy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;14	An average of 550 people apply for visas at the U.S. Embassy every day , and about 133,000 people have applied in the past year , according to the embassy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;15	The consular office is n't big enough to hold the crowd of waiting applicants , many of whom wait for hours outdoors , even in Moscow 's bitter December weather .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;16	Vladimir Gulagin , a technical consultant planning a business trip to New York , brushed falling snow off a suitcase full of documents Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;17	Gulagin was refused a visa on Tuesday and was told to return with further documentation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;18	He was not told , however , about the new fee .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;19	`` It 's a good thing I had borrowed money from my wife this morning , '' Gulagin said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;20	`` I spent most of my paycheck yesterday , getting all these documents copied . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;21	The steps announced Wednesday by Pickering include an `` express lane '' and easier processing for business visa applications .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;22	Vasily Ignatkin , head of the visa department at the Diplomatic Corps Administration Bureau , welcomed the changes , but said it would be `` some time before any serious improvements are evident . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;23	Those in line outside the embassy were skeptical .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;24	`` It 's all talk , '' Tumbasov said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0437;25	`` They 're trying to comfort us while they ask us for more money . ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0439;0	The latest assassinations of two journalists in Algeria was carried out by gunmen who forced them out of their homes , then shot and decapitated them , Algerian television reported Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0439;1	The killings bring the number of journalists slain to 27 since the profession became a target of Islamic extremists 18 months ago , according to the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists .
APW_ENG_19941201.0439;2	Ahmed Issaad , a reporter for the state television , and Nasseredine Lekhal , a journalist for the state-run daily El-Massa , were earlier reported by security services to have been stabbed to death in Boufarik , south of Algiers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0439;3	Three other people were also slain , including the vice president and a member of Boufarik 's municipal council , appointed to replace fundamentalists elected but later banned from office .
APW_ENG_19941201.0439;4	TV footage showed the victims ' bullet-riddled , headless bodies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0439;5	More than 11,000 people have been killed in a three-year insurgency pitting Muslim fundamentalist militants against the army-backed government .
APW_ENG_19941201.0439;6	The toll sharply increased in November , with more than 400 people killed in the bloodiest month since the start of the insurgency .
APW_ENG_19941201.0439;7	Most of the known victims for November were extremists killed by security forces , ordered to step up their campaign to `` eradicate terrorists '' after a failed government effort to negotiate with fundamentalists .
APW_ENG_19941201.0439;8	The militants , depicting the media as government pawns , have designated journalists as a prime target of their assassination campaign , along with foreigners and intellectuals .
APW_ENG_19941201.0439;9	An estimated 200 Algerian journalists have left the country because of the killings and harsh government action against newspapers which violate strict security regulations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;0	Russia on Thursday upset NATO 's plans for expanding its membership to former Warsaw Pact foes by claiming the move would create a new division in Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;1	In an extraordinary session , Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev departed from prepared remarks to criticize the allies for agreeing to a U.S. initiative to draw up the terms and conditions for future membership .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;2	`` If the strategy of NATO has changed , then that is something which requires further discussion , '' Kozyrev told a group of grim-faced foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;3	Afterward , Portuguese Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Durao Barroso said Kozyrev `` threw a bucket of cold water on the meeting . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;4	The Russian had been invited to the meeting to endorse a wide-ranging program of military and political contacts with Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;5	The special ties had been designed to ease Russia 's fears of an eastward drive by the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;6	But Kozyrev refused to agree to the documents .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;7	He said he read the ministers ' statement on membership and immediately called Russian President Boris Yeltsin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;8	`` This communique raises more questions than it answers , '' he said impromptu remarks that were broadcast to reporters at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;9	`` We have to understand what are the intentions of the other partners . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;10	Willy Claes , the alliance 's new secretary-general , sought to respond to Kozyrev 's remarks .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;11	`` It is no change in strategy or policy of NATO .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;12	... There is nothing new , '' he told the Russian just before he left NATO headquarters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;13	`` We are not willing to organize new divisions in Europe . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;14	Kozyrev 's outburst only added to the alliance 's woes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;15	There have been unprecedented strains in recent weeks between the United States and its European allies over the crisis in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;16	In an effort to heal the wounds , U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher swung behind the European view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;17	It was a major policy switch by Washington under pressure from the Europeans , led by Britain and France .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;18	In the past , Moscow has strongly opposed any move by NATO to draw in its one-time partners in the Warsaw Pact , the defunct Eastern military alliance led by the Soviet Union .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;19	The Europeans in particular have been uneasy about pushing expansion for fear of upsetting Russia , still a formidable military power at the edge of allied territory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;20	In an effort to overcome Russian objections , the allies had agreed to develop a `` far-reaching relationship , corresponding with Russia 's size , importance and capabilities . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;21	They had insisted they had no intention of forming a hostile bloc threatening Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;22	`` Having just overcome the division of Europe , we have no desire to see the emergence of new lines of partition , '' the ministers said in a statement .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;23	NATO has been anguishing in recent years over whether -- and when -- to open its doors to its former foes in Eastern Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;24	Poland , Hungary and others have repeatedly demanded coveted membership cards and the security guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;25	In an effort to meet their demands -- but without upsetting Russia , the allies thought they had found a good formula .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;26	At a summit last January , President Clinton and other allied leaders approved a U.S. initiative , Partnership for Peace , to bring former foes closer , but without membership .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;27	Twenty-three nations , including Russia , have enrolled in the project , which allows them to take part for the first time in military exercises and other alliance activities .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;28	On Thursday , the allies decided to go further by ordering aides to conduct a 12-month study of the terms and conditions for expanding the Western military alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;29	`` We took significant , concrete steps toward ... expansion '' of the alliance , Christopher said afterward .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;30	The move was intended to be a cautious one .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;31	No list of front-runners for membership will be made ; no date set for the first admissions will be set .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;32	But Kozyrev accused NATO of trying to make a fresh division on the European continent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;33	Some members of Partnership for Peace , he said , were destined to become members , while others would remain behind .
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;34	He said the Russians too `` do not exclude the possibility of wanting to become members of NATO . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0440;35	He insisted `` There needs to be some sort of clarification . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;0	President Ernesto Zedillo promised Thursday to maintain the tenuous cease-fire in southern Mexico and fight a war on the crushing poverty that inspired the rebellion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;1	Zedillo sought in his inaugural address before 1,500 foreign and local dignitaries to be a voice of reconciliation in a country shaken by kidnappings , assassination and the New Year 's Day rebellion in Chiapas .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;2	`` This year Mexican spirits have been saddened by the events in Chiapas , by the violence and even more so by conditions of deep-rooted injustice ; by the conditions of extreme poverty and neglect that fuels that violence , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;3	But Zedillo , who had not yet publicly said how he would handle the Chiapas rebellion , signaled he intended to try to restart peace talks last held in March .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;4	The rebels rejected one peace plan by Zedillo 's predecessor , Carlos Salinas de Gortari , and broke off talks with the government in October .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;5	`` I am convinced that it is possible to achieve a new negotiation in Chiapas that will lead us to a just honorable and definitive peace , '' Zedillo said to loud applause in the Chamber of Deputies , where he took his oath .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;6	`` There will be no violence by the government and I am confident that neither will there be by those who dissent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;7	The Mexican army will maintain its unilateral cease-fire . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;8	Zedillo was the campaign manager for the ruling party 's first candidate , Luis Donaldo Colosio , and assumed the candidacy after Colosio 's March 23 assassination in Tijuana .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;9	Six months later , another top political figure , ruling party secretary-general Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu , was assassinated .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;10	`` The brutal assassinations of two of Mexico 's most outstanding public figures have deeply hurt our citizens .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;11	Some seeds of concern and doubt regarding some institutions , have divided the people of Mexico , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;12	Both killings raised speculation of a political conspiracy to silence reformist voices in government since the victims were relative moderates within the Institutional Revolutionary Party .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;13	`` Thus far , the investigations have not been to the entire satiafaction of society .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;14	We the people of Mexico want to be sure we know the truth .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;15	At this moment I am specifically directing the attorney general of the republic to significantly intensify the investigations , '' Zedillo said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0441;16	`` We will not rest until justice has been served , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;0	Mexico 's new president , Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon , is a bookish , mild-mannered economist with little experience in the rough and tumble of Mexican politics .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;1	He was a poor public speaker and lacked charisma when he was first pushed into the race .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;2	But he appears to have had some intensive coaching since his election last summer and his inaugural speech Thursday was well delivered .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;3	Colleagues give Zedillo , 42 , high marks as an economist , administrator and negotiator and say that unlike former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari , whom he succeeds , he prefers conciliation to confrontation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;4	He is more comfortable at home , analyzing a difficult economic problem , or sharing a meal with Patricia Nilda Velasco , his wife of 21 years , than attending a diplomatic reception .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;5	His first exposure to politics came when the first presidential candidate of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party , Luis Donaldo Colosio , named him campaign manager .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;6	Zedillo ran for the presidency only after Colosio , a charismatic crowd pleaser , was shot dead March 23 at a Tijuana rally .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;7	The new candidate looked downright bewildered when he began campaigning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;8	`` I certainly never thought I 'd be here , never in my life , '' Zedillo said recently .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;9	But his party , which has not lost a presidential election in 65 years , geared up its huge machine and got him elected Aug. 21 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;10	The Zedillos , who have five children , have long lived in Lomas de Las Quebradas , a middle-class neighborhood at the foot of a towering dormant volcano , on Mexico City 's southern edge .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;11	He understands what poor people go through .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;12	He was one of them for years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;13	Born in Mexico City on Dec. 27 , 1951 , Zedillo was the second of six children of Rodolfo Zedillo Castillo , a poor electrician , and Martha Alicia Ponce de Leon , who abandoned her studies to become a homemaker .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;14	Work was scarce and word was jobs were available along the U.S. border .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;15	So the family moved to Mexicali and the muddy neighborhood of Pueblo Nuevo , just yards from the California border .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;16	Mrs. Zedillo was the mainstay of the struggling family .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;17	To make ends meet , she sold candy at a neighborhood movie house , and the children could watch movies free on Saturdays .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;18	Zedillo shined shoes and sold newspapers on the streets , learning to speak a `` Spanglish '' variant called `` pocho . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;19	Few of his childhood dreams became reality .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;20	One was to become a big league baseball player , he confided to a friend .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;21	Instead , he went on to become a straight-A student .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;22	After he finished high school , he and his elder brother Luis Eduardo moved to Mexico City in 1966 , sharing a tiny apartment in a low-income project .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;23	Zedillo studied economics at the National Polytechnic Institute , the so-called poor man 's university .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;24	Still poor , the rest of the family moved back to Mexico City in search of a better life .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;25	The death of his mother a few months later came as a terrific blow -- she was only 38 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;26	Zedillo joined Mexico 's ruling party in 1967 , and party bosses helped him get bigger and better scholarships that allowed postgraduate work at the University of Bradford , England , and the University of Colorado .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;27	He also taught at the Polytechnic , where he met his future wife .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;28	A few weeks after their wedding , they left for New Haven , Conn. , where he earned a master 's , then a doctorate in economics at Yale in 1978 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;29	Back in Mexico City , Zedillo worked for the Bank of Mexico -- the nation 's federal reserve .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;30	He then moved to the Treasury Department and then the Department of Budget and Planning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0442;31	There he became friends with Salinas and other young technocrats , most of them Ivy League graduates bent on modernizing Mexico .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;0	In open contempt for U.N. authority in Bosnia , Serb fighters kidnapped more international peacekeepers and pressed their stranglehold on a town in the northwest on Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;1	In a small sign of willingness to negotiate , however , Bosnian Serbs agreed to meet Yasushi Akashi , the top U.N. envoy , on Friday in Pale , their stronghold east of Sarajevo .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;2	The Serbs snubbed U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali on Wednesday because he insisted talks be held in Sarajevo , capital of the Muslim-led , internationall recognized governmment .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;3	Bosnian Serb fighters on Tuesday crossed the border into Croatia and seized seven Ukrainian peacekeepers , taking them and a U.N. armored carrier into Bosnian Serb-held territory , Alexander Ivanko , a U.N. spokesman , said Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;4	He said the United Nations has not heard from the troops since .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;5	The Ukrainians ' observation point is now occupied by the Serbs , allowing for the unimpeded movement into Bosnia of equipment and personnel from Serb-held Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;6	Serb fighters from the two countries have joined forces in the Bihac offensive .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;7	The Serbs have taken more than 400 U.N. peacekeepers hostage as insurance against further NATO airstrikes since allied planes bombed Serb positions in Bosnia and Croatia three times last week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;8	Continuing the squeeze on the Bosnian government , Serbs again denied U.N. requests to supply the Bihac enclave and other vulnerable U.N.-patrolled sites with food and supplies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;9	Monique Tuffelli , the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees staffer in the Bihac enclave , said food stocks would last only another week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;10	`` We have run out almost of everything , '' she said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;11	The last UNHCR food convoy reached Bihac on Oct. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;12	Between May and October , Serbs allowed only a dozen to pass through their territory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;13	The Serbs agreed to the Akashi meeting after Lt. Gen. Sir Michael Rose , the U.N. commander in Bosnia , traveled to Pale for talks with Radovan Karadzic and other Bosnian Serb leaders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;14	Rose 's talks in Pale were to have focused on Bihac and its demilitarization , but there appeared to be no narrowing of differences that could end the siege .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;15	Momcilo Krajisnik , leader of the so-called Bosnian Serb assembly , again rejected a three-month cease-fire , which the Bosnian government supports , saying Serbs would accept only a permanent cease-fire leading to a formal end of war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;16	The Sarajevo government fears a permanent agreement would cement the Serb hold over 70 percent of the country .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;17	An international peace plan , which the Bosnians have accepted and the Serbs rejected , would force Serbs to settle for 49 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;18	With new U.S. support for Europe 's position that diplomacy , not further NATO airstrikes , is the best way to deal with the Bosnian war , French Foreign Minister Alain Juppe and his British counterpart , Douglas Hurd , planned to meet Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade on Sunday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;19	Milosevic is considered responsible for the violent breakup of Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;20	But he still has influence with the Bosnian Serbs , despite his breaking with them last summer after they rejected the international peace plan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;21	Senior Western officials now talk of altering that plan to allow the Bosnian Serbs to establish confederal links with Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;22	The plan also gives Bosnian Croats the right to set up a confederation with Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;23	Critics , however , say that is appeasement and a step toward creation of Serb nationalists ' goal , a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;24	But Krajisnik said possible linkage with Yugoslavia was not as important as changing the proposed territorial maps , the Bosnian Serb news agency SRNA reported .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;25	U.N. spokesman Thant Myint-U said food and fuel supplies for peacekeepers were running increasingly short in the government-held eastern Bosnian enclaves , as well as Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;26	Heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire erupted around Bihac late Wednesday and early Thursday , along with heavy fighting southwest and south of the Bihac pocket , U.N. officials said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;27	Two civilians were killed in Bihac Wednesday by gunfire , Ms. Tuffelli said , but overall the area was calmer Thursday morning with only sporadic shelling and small arms fire .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;28	Bosnian radio and Bihac regional officials painted a different picture by Thursday afternoon .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;29	Radio said Serbs intensified their attacks later in the day on Bihac , Cazin and Velika Kladusa , all government-held towns in the Bihac enclave .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;30	Hamdija Kabiljagic , the regional mayor , also reported increased fighting along the perimeters of Bihac and shelling of the town itself .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;31	He accused the United Nations of deliberately downplaying the situation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;32	There was no U.N. confirmation of the reported afternoon upsurge in fighting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;33	In downtown Sarajevo , Serbs targeted two government buildings with anti-tank missiles , wounding four people .
APW_ENG_19941201.0443;34	Sarajevo 's airport remained closed , and the humanitarian airlift suspended , because Serbs had not given security guarantees and are able to threaten planes ' approach route with surface-to-air missiles .
APW_ENG_19941201.0444;0	A fireworks warehouse exploded in a town in southern Brazil , killing at least one person and wounding about a dozen others , a fire official said Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0444;1	The explosion occurred at 9:30 p.m. -LRB- 1130 GMT -RRB- Wednesday on a block of small shops in the downtown business district of Uruguaiana , a city of 120,000 people near the border with Argentina .
APW_ENG_19941201.0444;2	The blast leveled five one-story buildings and damaged 10 stores .
APW_ENG_19941201.0444;3	Two people are believed missing under the wreckage , said Sgt. Paulo Flores of the Uruguaiana fire department .
APW_ENG_19941201.0444;4	`` The explosion was felt more than 30 blocks away , '' Flores said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0444;5	Earlier , a Uruguayan fire official who helped contain the blaze said as many as 10 people were killed and 20 were hurt in the blast .
APW_ENG_19941201.0444;6	Brazilian , Argentine and Uruguayan firemen continued to fight several fires around the blast site on Thursday afternoon .
APW_ENG_19941201.0444;7	The cause of the explosion was not yet known , he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;0	Proponents of the world-trade agreement chant a mantra of impressive-sounding figures : a dlrs 744 billion global tax cut , dlrs 150 billion a year in added U.S. economic growth , up to 500,000 new American jobs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;1	But some of the pact 's most important provisions deal with ideas , not numbers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;2	For the first time in its 47-year history , the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will include basic rules protecting patents , copyrights and other so-called intellectual property .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;3	That 's a powerful catalyst for more exports and investment in some of America 's most dynamic industries .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;4	With the sweeping deal to liberalize commerce , the 124 nations in GATT not only agree to slash import duties and other trade barriers , they pledge to prosecute sales of knock-off drugs , purloined software , pirated videos and the like .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;5	That may sound trivial .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;6	But U.S. companies that make idea-intensive products lose tens of billions of dollars annually in potential export revenues because thieves are stealing their stuff .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;7	GATT should especially be welcomed in places like Research Triangle Park , N.C. , and northern New Jersey , where many pharmaceutical manufacturers are concentrated , and California 's Silicon Valley and the Seattle area , home to numerous software makers and other high-tech firms .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;8	Such industries are significant creators of new , high-paying jobs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;9	They 're also among the most aggressive exporters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;10	`` Some of GATT 's biggest winners are high-tech industries , those that are our most globally competitive and make world-leading products , '' says C. Michael Aho , international economist for Prudential Securities Inc. `` The rules provide a more certain framework for them and should open markets overseas . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;11	For companies like Merck and Co. to develop a world-class medication or Intel Corp. to devise a faster computer chip , hundreds of millions of dollars must be spent on research and testing .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;12	The GATT provisions , which require many countries to enact their first intellectual property protection laws , will encourage more American investment in new products , says David Walters , chief economist at the U.S. Trade Representative 's office .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;13	Companies partly base their research and development budgets on expected rate of return and market size .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;14	`` If you 're a pharmaceutical company investing lots of money in developing a new drug , you have X number of years to recoup your R and D costs , '' Walters says .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;15	`` If a country rips off your patent and pays you next to nothing , getting minimum standards of intellectual property protection is very important .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;16	If you 're a software developer , it 's also real important . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;17	The U.S. government estimates that American drug makers lose roughly dlrs 5 billion annually from piracy worldwide -- a big percentage of the nearly dlrs 28 billion worth of products they 're expected to sell overseas this year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;18	`` If you look at any of the top-ten selling products in the world market , you can assume they are copied , '' said Tom Bombelles , a trade expert for the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;19	With GATT 's new Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property rules , or TRIPS , he said , `` our companies over the long run can save several billion a year in lost sales . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;20	One disadvantage is that many developing countries , which are the fastest-growing markets , get 10 years to comply .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;21	Still , executives at Pfizer Inc. are happy that foreign copycats eventually wo n't be able to sell knockoffs of products like Diflucan , the world 's leading anti-fungal drug and a medication widely used by cancer and AIDS patients .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;22	`` It enables us to continue funding research , '' said Lou Clemente , a senior vice president at New York-based Pfizer .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;23	`` As the company is more successful , there 's going to be more employment in the United States . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;24	Other prominent beneficiaries will be producers of computer software -- a U.S.-dominated industry since its inception .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;25	Overseas piracy of personal computer applications such as word processors and spreadsheets alone cost American makers dlrs 6 billion in 1993 , says the Software Publishers Association , a Washington-based trade group .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;26	Exports of such programs , by comparison , were about dlrs 4.5 billion last year and total worldwide sales were dlrs 8 billion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;27	`` There are n't many businesses that can function when they 're suffering theft that nearly equals revenues , '' says association counsel Mark Traphagen .
APW_ENG_19941201.0445;28	`` For smaller companies , it becomes a practical question whether they want to export and suffer serious piracy . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;0	Moscow backed off from a threat to send troops Thursday into the breakaway Chechnya republic , where leaders defied a Russian ultimatum and called on armed volunteers to defend their capital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;1	Air attacks continued on the outskirts of Grozny , the Chechen capital , claiming at least a few civilian lives .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;2	And a Russian delegation arrived from Moscow and began talks with Chechen officials .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;3	Meanwhile , residents continued to flee the mainly Muslim city of 300,000 people in the Caucasus Mountains of southern Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;4	The city has become a war zone between forces loyal to Chechen President Dzhokhar Dudayev , who declared independence from Moscow in 1991 , and Chechen rebels trying to topple him .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;5	Dudayev accuses Moscow of arming and leading the rebels , who launched an offensive last week that began with helicopters and escalated in recent days to jet fighters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;6	Russia says it offers the rebels only political support .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;7	It refuses to recognize independence for Chechnya , which was incorporated into the Russian Empire in the 19th century after a series of long and bloody wars .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;8	President Boris Yeltsin threatened on Tuesday to impose a state of emergency in Chechnya if both sides did not surrender prisoners and stop fighting by Thursday morning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;9	On Thursday evening , Yeltsin 's office issued an altered text of the ultimatum saying `` there was some disagreement in the media in interpreting certain clauses . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;10	The reissued document skipped all reference to a state of emergency .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;11	Trying a different tack , Yeltsin offered limited amnesty Thursday to Chechens who `` voluntarily lay down arms by Dec. 15 . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;12	`` The use of force in Chechnya is doomed to failure , '' said Sergei Yushenkov , head of the Russian parliament 's Defense Committee , who led the delegation to Grozny and met briefly with Dudayev .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;13	In another sign that Russia sought to avoid direct confrontation , Defense Minister Pavel Grachev told reporters in Moscow that some Russian servicemen who `` carried out certain military tasks for material compensation '' from anti-Dudayev forces had been brought back to central Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;14	He said more would be evacuated .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;15	Grachev insisted such servicemen were not in Chechnya on Army orders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;16	Dudayev 's government captured up to 70 Russians in fighting last weekend and alleges some were Army officers and soldiers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;17	Chechen officials initially threatened to execute them ; Dudayev said Thursday they would be tried in court .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;18	Despite Moscow 's softened tone , it still appeared to be beefing up troops on the borders of Chechnya , according to media reports .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;19	Dudayev , who held a news conference in the basement of his presidential palace as jets roared overhead , remained defiant , calling Yeltsin 's government a `` satanic power . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;20	Dudayev said his house had been bombed Thursday morning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;21	A small military air base near Grozny also was hit in the air raid Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;22	And missiles hit a residential district at Katayama , about 20 kilometers -LRB- 12 miles -RRB- from town , according to duty surgeon Aslanbek Otsalayev at Grozny 's main hospital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;23	Two women 's corpses were at the hospital , and Otsalayev said four people , including a 1-year-old , were killed and at least six wounded .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;24	In Freedom Square outside Dudayev 's offices , several hundred volunteer fighters cradling Kalashnikov rifles and grenade launchers gathered to hear speeches while a tank maneuvered into position .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;25	Elders in tall fur hats , tunics and high leather boots danced in a circle , chanting , `` Freedom or death ! ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;26	Although the economy is in shambles , many Chechens feel united in one thing : distrust of Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;27	`` I do n't like the opposition or Dudayev , but I 'll fight the Russians , '' said a restaurant owner who declined to be identified .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;28	Many Russians are content to let the Chechens go their own way , according to a poll Thursday by the International Opinion Research Center .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;29	The poll of 3,250 people said 74.2 percent believe Russia should recognize Chechnya 's independence , while 5.5 percent said it should n't and 20.3 said they could n't answer .
APW_ENG_19941201.0446;30	The margin of error was 1 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;0	Moscow backed off from a threat to send troops Thursday into the breakaway Chechnya republic , where leaders defied a Russian ultimatum and called on armed volunteers to defend their capital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;1	Air attacks continued on the outskirts of Grozny , the Chechen capital , claiming at least a few civilian lives .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;2	And a Russian delegation arrived from Moscow and began talks with Chechen officials .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;3	Meanwhile , residents continued to flee the mainly Muslim city of 300,000 people in the Caucasus Mountains of southern Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;4	The city has become a war zone between forces loyal to Chechen President Dzhokhar Dudayev , who declared independence from Moscow in 1991 , and Chechen rebels trying to topple him .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;5	Dudayev accuses Moscow of arming and leading the rebels , who launched an offensive last week that began with helicopters and escalated in recent days to jet fighters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;6	Russia says it offers the rebels only political support .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;7	It refuses to recognize independence for Chechnya , which was incorporated into the Russian Empire in the 19th century after a series of long and bloody wars .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;8	President Boris Yeltsin threatened on Tuesday to impose a state of emergency in Chechnya if both sides did not surrender prisoners and stop fighting by Thursday morning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;9	On Thursday evening , Yeltsin 's office issued an altered text of the ultimatum saying `` there was some disagreement in the media in interpreting certain clauses . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;10	The reissued document skipped all reference to a state of emergency .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;11	Trying a different tack , Yeltsin offered limited amnesty Thursday to Chechens who `` voluntarily lay down arms by Dec. 15 . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;12	`` The use of force in Chechnya is doomed to failure , '' said Sergei Yushenkov , head of the Russian parliament 's Defense Committee , who led the delegation to Grozny and met briefly with Dudayev .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;13	In another sign that Russia sought to avoid direct confrontation , Defense Minister Pavel Grachev told reporters in Moscow that some Russian servicemen who `` carried out certain military tasks for material compensation '' from anti-Dudayev forces had been brought back to central Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0447;14	He said more would be evacuated .

APW_ENG_19941201.0448;0	CHICAGO -LRB- AP -RRB- - Soybean futures steepened their slide Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade as nervous speculators cashed out .
APW_ENG_19941201.0448;1	Wheat , corn and oat futures rose modestly .
APW_ENG_19941201.0448;2	Soybean traders have become increasingly doubtful of the market 's ability to remain above dlrs 5.50 a bushel in light of this year 's record-large harvest .
APW_ENG_19941201.0448;3	Soybeans have been propped up by strong world demand for soybean oil and other vegetable oils , but those markets have been volatile this week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0448;4	`` This market stayed up a lot longer than everybody thought it would , '' said Jack Salzieder , marketing consultant with Commodity Services Inc. in West Des Moines , Iowa .
APW_ENG_19941201.0448;5	Soybean prices have fallen for three straight days .
APW_ENG_19941201.0448;6	Salzieder said soybean prices could be poised for a drop similar to wheat prices , which have plunged about 9 percent since early October .
APW_ENG_19941201.0448;7	In trading Wednesday , wheat for December delivery rose 2 1-2 cents to dlrs 3.74 3-4 a bushel ; December corn rose 1 cent to dlrs 2.14 a bushel ; December oats rose 2 cents to dlrs 1.08 a bushel ; January soybeans fell 6 3-4 cents to dlrs 5.56 3-4 a bushel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0449;0	Tennis great Martina Navratilova says she 's right where she wants to be : traveling and playing for fun after 22 years of pressure and high-stakes competition .
APW_ENG_19941201.0449;1	`` Now I will rest more .
APW_ENG_19941201.0449;2	I will travel the world , but will keep on playing tennis for pleasure , '' said Navratilova before her first public matches since retiring last month after a first-round loss in the Virginia Slims Championships in New York .
APW_ENG_19941201.0449;3	Navratilova , 38 , was joined in Florence by one of the rising stars of women 's tennis : 14-year-old Martina Hingis , the reigning Wimbledon junior 's champion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0449;4	They were scheduled to play a match dubbed the `` generations game . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0449;5	The Czech-born Hingis , who lives in Switzerland , made her professional debut in October .
APW_ENG_19941201.0449;6	Navratilova said she has considered teaching tennis , but has `` not yet developed my own method . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0449;7	`` Why did I not retire last year ? ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0449;8	`` My heart told me that 1994 was the year to call it a day .
APW_ENG_19941201.0449;9	I might be wrong when I take decision with the head , but certainly not when they come from the heart . ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0449;11	Navratilova was teamed with Italian film producer Mario Cecchi Gori and Hingis played alongside retired Italian soccer star Giancarlo Antognoni .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;0	The 31st Chess Olympiad began in Moscow 's Cosmos Hotel on Thursday with a record 122 national sides competing in the men 's event and 78 countries in the separate women 's section .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;1	Each men 's team has four players and each women 's team three .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;2	The Olympiad was originally to be held in Thessalonika , Greece , but the event was canceled because of financial difficulties .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;3	The World Chess Federation was then helped by world chess champion Garry Kasparov , who rallied financial support to hold the event in Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;4	The backing came even though last year he had set up an entirely new organization , the Professional Chess Association , with Britain 's Nigel Short .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;5	Kasparov also heads the Russian team , which is favored to win , followed closely by the English national side which boasts Nigel Short , Kasparov 's last challenger for the world title , on board one .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;6	Kasparov , however , was rested for the first of the 14 games and will only play when the Russian side begins to face the strongest opposition .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;7	The Russians dropped half a point when Yevgeny Bareev was held to a surprising draw .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;8	Notable absentees from the Olympiad include Anatoly Karpov , the current FIDE world champion , Gata Kamsky of the United States and Viswanathan Anand of India .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;9	Kamsky and Anand declined invitations as they are currently preparing for the final elimination of the PCA World Championship Cycle for the right to meet Kasparov .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;10	That event will be held in Las Palmas in April .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;11	Karpov , however , would not play below Kasparov on the Russian side and also does not participate .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;12	In the women 's section , the favorites are the Hungarians , who boast two of the three Polgar sisters , Zsusza and Sofia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;13	The third sister , Judit , is representing Hungary in the men 's event as she is currently the top player in Hungary .
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;14	Results of first round after six hours of play :
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;15	England-Mongolia 3-0 -LRB- 1 to finish -RRB-
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;16	United States-South Africa 3.5-0 .5
APW_ENG_19941201.0451;17	Holland-Tajikistan 3-0 -LRB- 1 to finish -RRB-
