APW_ENG_19941201.0453;0	Yasser Arafat 's government on Thursday took control of health and taxation in the West Bank , broadening Palestinian autonomy despite a pall cast on peacemaking by Islamic terror attacks .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;1	The move completed the initial stage of handing over day-to-day affairs in the West Bank to Palestinians .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;2	It also came amid growing calls in Israel for shutting off Palestinians from Israel because of a series of attacks in which 32 Israelis have been killed since early October .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;3	About 1,000 people gathered Thursday in the northern Israeli town of Afula for the funeral of the latest victim , 19-year-old woman soldier Liat Gabai , who was axed to death Wednesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;4	A suspect detained Wednesday , Wahib Abu Rub , 24 , from the West Bank town of Qabatiyah , has told interrogators he was from the Islamic Resistance Movement or Hamas , Israel radio said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;5	The same group claimed the Oct. 19 Tel Aviv bus bombing that killed 22 people .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;6	Abu Rub admitted to the slaying in an interview on Israel television .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;7	He said as he was led to the Nazareth court Thursday that he wanted to prove to fellow Palestinians he was n't collaborating with Israel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;8	`` They accused me of being a traitor .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;9	I wanted to prove that I was n't , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;10	`` I killed the soldier to prove to my people I am a decent man . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;11	Police Minister Moshe Shahal responded by calling Thursday for completely shutting off the West Bank and Gaza Strip from Israel .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;12	`` There is no alternative other than to demand separation , '' Shahal said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;13	`` Separation means that we do not have to open the territory out of economic and employment concerns until the Palestinians prove that they can prevent attacks . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;14	A closure could also bring further violence , by preventing thousands of Palestinian day workers from entering Israel to earn a living .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;15	Palestinian and Israeli leaders have blamed growing support for Islamic radicals on economic troubles in the PLO-run Gaza Strip .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;16	Despite the violence , talks were expected to begin next week on stage two of the autonomy given Gaza and the West Bank town of Jericho last May -- redeployment of Israeli troops in the West Bank and Palestinian elections .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;17	Israel 's concern for the safety of 120,000 Jewish settlers has prompted some officials to propose skipping the interim phase altogether and negotiating the final status of these territories now , rather than in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;18	Still , a gradual hand over of responsibilities to Palestinians proceeded in the West Bank , where two ceremonies were held marking the transfer of the health and tax systems .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;19	Since August , the Palestine Liberation Organization also has taken charge of education , tourism and welfare in the West Bank .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;20	`` What we have completed gives the Palestinians a first entrance to the West Bank , '' said West Bank military governor Brig. Gen. Gadi Zohar , signing over the tax department to Palestinian Finance Minister Mohammed Nashashibi in Ramallah .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;21	In Brussels , Belgium , foreign donors this week released dlrs 125 million pledged earlier , mostly to help the Palestinians meet running costs for a few months .
APW_ENG_19941201.0453;22	Deputy Finance Minister Atef Alawneh said he hoped to collect dlrs 300-400 million annually in taxes to try to overcome dependency on donor nations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;0	Russia protested NATO 's plan on Thursday for expanding its membership to east European countries and backed out of a program to improve cooperation between Moscow and the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;1	Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev departed from a prepared speech to criticize the allies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;2	He said their decision earlier Thursday to draw up the terms and conditions for future NATO membership would create a new division in Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;3	`` If the strategy of NATO has changed , then that is something which requires further discussion , '' Kozyrev told a group of grim-faced foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;4	Afterward , Portuguese Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Durao Barroso said Kozyrev `` threw a bucket of cold water on the meeting . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;5	The Russian had been invited to the meeting to endorse a wide-ranging program of military and political contacts with Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;6	The special ties had been designed to ease Russia 's fears of an eastward drive by the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;7	But Kozyrev refused to agree to the documents .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;8	He said he read the ministers ' statement on membership and immediately called Russian President Boris Yeltsin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;9	`` This communique raises more questions than it answers , '' he said in impromptu remarks that were broadcast to reporters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;10	`` We have to understand what are the intentions of the other partners . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;11	Willy Claes , the alliance 's new secretary-general , sought to respond to Kozyrev 's remarks .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;12	`` It is no change in strategy or policy of NATO .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;13	... There is nothing new , '' he told the Russian minister just before he left NATO headquarters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;14	`` We are not willing to organize new divisions in Europe . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;15	Kozyrev 's outburst only added to the alliance 's woes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;16	There have been unprecedented strains in recent weeks between the United States and its European allies over the crisis in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;17	In an effort to heal the wounds , Secretary of State Warren Christopher swung behind the European view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;18	It was a major policy switch by Washington under pressure from the Europeans , led by Britain and France .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;19	In the past , Moscow has strongly opposed any move by NATO to enlist former members of the Warsaw Pact , the defunct Eastern military alliance led by the Soviet Union .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;20	In an effort to overcome Russian objections , the allies had agreed to develop a `` far-reaching relationship , corresponding with Russia 's size , importance and capabilities . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;21	They also insisted they had no intention of forming a hostile bloc threatening Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;22	`` Having just overcome the division of Europe , we have no desire to see the emergence of new lines of partition , '' the ministers said in a statement .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;23	NATO has been anguishing in recent years over whether -- and when -- to open its doors to its former foes in central and eastern Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;24	Poland , Hungary and others have repeatedly demanded NATO membership and the security guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;25	In an effort to meet their demands , but without upsetting Russia , the allies thought they had found a good formula .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;26	At a summit last January , President Clinton and other allied leaders approved a U.S. initiative , Partnership for Peace , to bring former foes closer , but without membership .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;27	Twenty-three nations , including Russia , have enrolled in the project , which allows them to take part for the first time in military exercises and other alliance activities .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;28	On Thursday , the allies decided to go further by ordering aides to conduct a 12-month study of the terms and conditions for expanding the Western military alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;29	`` We took significant , concrete steps toward ... expansion '' of the alliance , Christopher said afterward .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;30	The move was intended to be a cautious one .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;31	No list of front-runners for membership would be made ; no date set for the first admissions would be set .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;32	But Kozyrev accused NATO of trying to make a fresh division on the European continent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;33	Some members of Partnership for Peace , he said , were destined to become members , while others would remain behind .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;34	`` Not all countries will be able to obtain membership at the same time , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0454;35	`` There needs to be some sort of clarification . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;0	After eight years of turbulent talks to draw up the new world trade accord , countries around the globe now are rushing the mammoth agreement through their national parliaments .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;1	Nearly 40 countries , including most of southeast Asia , have ratified the 124-nation pact .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;2	About 40 more -- including trade giants Japan , the European Union and Canada -- have indicated they will do so by the end of the year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;3	Three countries -- Switzerland , Liechtenstein and Cyprus -- have already told the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that domestic politics will prevent them from ratifying the accord this year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;4	But their absence alone wo n't stop the pact from taking effect as scheduled on Jan. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;5	All that is needed is for the all the big traders to come on board as founding members of the World Trade Organization -- GATT 's more powerful successor body that implement the accord .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;6	The mostly low-key approach in many countries contrasts sharply with the loud and energetic opposition the accord raised in the United States , where The U.S. Senate was debating the pact for two days .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;7	A vote was expected Thursday night .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;8	The agreement is considered the most ambitious attempt ever to free world trade and is expected to boost global income by dlrs 510 billion by the year 2005 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;9	It reduces customs duties on hundreds of thousands of products , liberalizes trade in service industries , protects against copyright theft and patent abuse and cuts protection of farm goods and textiles .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;10	Most governments object to at least some provisions because previously protected industries -- such as agriculture in Europe and textiles in the United States -- will suffer .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;11	But all participating countries agreed not to upset the carefully crafted compromises with amendments .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;12	The ratification situation in some of the main trading nations is as follows : -- European Union : Britain , Ireland , Greece and Germany have approved it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;13	The eight other EU members are meant to do so before foreign ministers meet Dec. 19-20 to approve the deal on behalf of the entire trade bloc .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;14	France and Portugal still have some qualms , but the EU Commission , the union 's executive body , said there are no real obstacles .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;15	An internal dispute between the Commission and member states over negotiating powers , which slowed national ratification , has been settled .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;16	-- Japan : A key parliamentary committee has approved the deal , and full passage is likely in the next few days .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;17	The government placated rice farmers , upset at potential competition from imports , with a six-year , 7.2 trillion yen -LRB- dlrs 74 billion -RRB- compensation package .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;18	-- South Korea : The ruling Democratic Liberal party , which has a big majority , plans to push the accord through the national assembly next week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;19	Opposition politicians and farmers accuse the government of making too many concessions under U.S. pressure to open the rice market .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;20	There have been frequent violent demonstrations against the accord .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;21	-- India : There was strong opposition from both left - and right-wing parties , especially to provisions that give foreign multinationals stronger patent claims to Indian seeds and medicines .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;22	The opposition , however , seems to have run out of steam and legislative passage appears more or less certain , though no date has been set .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;23	-- Canada : Hopes to ratify the accord by the end of the year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;24	-- Mexico : Under former President Salinas de Gortari , who is one of three candidates for the directorship of the WTO , Mexico was one of the first countries to ratify the trade accord .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;25	-- South America : Chile has ratified the accord and Argentina hopes to do so before the end of the year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;26	In Brazil , parliamentary passage is likely to be in February , not because the accord is contested but because of delays caused by this year 's election .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;27	-- China : In order to join the WTO , Beijing first has to enter GATT .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;28	Western concerns about China 's market reform programs and a possible flood of Chinese exports mean GATT membership talks are unlikely to finish by the end of the year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;29	Congressional clearance of a new world trade accord is expected to encourage ratification by other countries , enabling the mammoth export-boosting pact to enter into force as planned Jan. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;30	Around the world , big and small nations alike are trying to rush the 22,000 page GATT agreement through national parliaments , often in low-key processes that contrast with the rocky ride through the U.S. legislature .
APW_ENG_19941201.0456;31	Others who have been waiting for U.S. leadership , will also follow suit .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;0	Forty to 50 Dominican prisoners ordered released by the courts but still behind bars rioted Thursday , burning mattresses and clothes in a call to be let out .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;1	`` We want justice , we want liberty , '' the inmates shouted .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;2	The uprising at the La Victoria prison 14 kilometers -LRB- 9 miles -RRB- north of the capital city began at 9 a.m. and continued late in the afternoon as police tried to negotiate with the inmates .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;3	No injuries were reported .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;4	An estimated 130 of La Victoria 's 4,000 prisoners were declared innocent or ordered released by the courts , including this country 's supreme court , months ago but remain in jail .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;5	Some were jailed only on the orders of police , without charges against them .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;6	Human rights groups and the inmates ' families have demanded the release of the prisoners , known locally as `` the disrespected . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;7	President Joaquin Balaguer has said the prisoners should remain behind bars , arguing that the decisions to release them were tainted by corruption .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;8	He created a committee to review the cases .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;9	The committee , headed by Attorney General Efrain Reyes Duluc , recommended in June that 30 of the prisoners be freed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;10	But they remain jailed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;11	Balaguer recently pardoned Jose Guillermo Chiari , a Panamanian pilot who was serving a five-year sentence on a conviction of trafficking 163 kilograms -LRB- 359 pounds -RRB- of cocaine .
APW_ENG_19941201.0457;12	His appeal was scheduled to go to court here Friday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;0	Retired Gen. Colin Powell , a child of Jamaican immigrants who worked his way up to become America 's military chief , returned `` home '' Thursday to receive one of Jamaica 's highest honors .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;1	His wife , Alma , his three children and two grandchildren watched as Governor-General Sir Howard Cooke draped a green sash with the insignia of the Order of Jamaica over Powell 's neck .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;2	`` Every Jamaican , at home and in the diaspora , sees in your achievement the embodiment of the best in us and an indicator that nothing is beyond the capacity of the Jamaican people , '' Prime Minister P.J. Patterson said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;3	Patterson and others recounted Powell 's climb from the South Bronx to Vietnam soldier , Army general , U.S. National Security Adviser , and chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;4	Even before Powell 's retirement in September 1993 , he had been frequently mentioned as a possible contender for the U.S. presidency in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;5	Patterson described General Powell as `` a beacon of hope and a source of inspiration . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;6	In an emotional but controlled response , Powell , 57 , reminded those attending that he was an American citizen and that the award was purely honorary .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;7	`` But let it be clear to all present that I consider myself a Jamaican , '' he said to prolonged applause .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;8	`` A true son of Jamaica . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;9	Speaking for the millions of Caribbean descendants in the United States , Britain and Canada , Powell said that old-country values of hard work , education and family helped him and others succeed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;10	`` Wherever we went in the world we always have this home , even if we never had been born here , because our parents instilled in us the love of this country , the love of the people of this country , but most importantly , a love of the values that fuel this country , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;11	His three children had never been to Jamaica before this week , Powell said , `` but now we continue the tradition .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;12	Now they know what it means to be a Jamaican and to come home . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;13	Later Thursday , Powell received a honorary degree from the University of the West Indies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;14	In an interview with The Associated Press , Powell said he was going to enjoy his retirement for a while and finish his memoirs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;15	`` And then , '' he added , `` I will see what to do with the rest of my life . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;16	The Order of Jamaica , the equivalent of a knighthood in the British system , entitles him to be called `` The Honorable . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0461;17	It is highest honor that can be given to non-Jamaicans .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;0	Serb fighters kidnapped more U.N. peacekeepers and pressed the stranglehold on the `` safe area '' of Bihac Thursday , underscoring their contempt for U.N. authority in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;1	The Bosnian Serbs did , however , agree to meet Yasushi Akashi , the top U.N. envoy , on Friday in Pale , their stronghold east of Sarajevo .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;2	They had refused to meet U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali on Wednesday because he insisted talks be held at Sarajevo airport , in the capital of the internationally recognized government of Bosnia-Herzegovina .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;3	Fighting between government forces and allied Serbs from Bosnia and neighboring Croatia continued in the Bihac area Thursday , prompting a warning from Croatian Defense Minister Gojko Susak .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;4	`` Croatia will not wait for the fall of Bihac , '' Susak told reporters in the capital Zagreb .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;5	`` We are monitoring the situation , and if Croatia 's judgment is that Bihac is about to fall , Croatia will intervene . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;6	The fall of Bihac would effectively unite Serb territory in northern Bosnia with Serb-held land in Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;7	The Zagreb government would view that as a greater threat to its sovereignty , even as it increasingly talks of using force to regain control over the one-third of Croatia occupied by its Serbs since a truce halted their 1991 war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;8	The Akashi meeting was arranged during talks in Pale between Lt. Gen. Sir Michael Rose , the U.N. commander in Bosnia , and Radovan Karadzic and other Bosnian Serb leaders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;9	Rose went to Pale to discuss a possible cease-fire and demilitarization of Bihac , as well as the fate of more than 400 peacekeepers held hostage by the Serbs as insurance against further NATO airstrikes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;10	Alexander Ivanko , a U.N. spokesman , said the latest kidnappings occurred Tuesday when Bosnian Serb units crossed the border into Croatia and seized seven Ukrainian peacekeepers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;11	They took the soldiers and a U.N. armored carrier into Bosnian Serb-held territory , and the United Nations has not heard from its troops since .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;12	The Ukrainians ' observation point is now occupied by the Serbs , allowing for the unimpeded movement into Bosnia of equipment and personnel from Serb-held Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;13	However , there appeared to be no narrowing of differences that could end the Bihac siege .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;14	Momcilo Krajisnik , leader of the so-called Bosnian Serb assembly , again rejected a three-month cease-fire , which the Bosnian government wants , saying Serbs would accept only a permanent cease-fire as a prelude to a formal end of war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;15	The Sarajevo government fears any permanent cease-fire agreement would cement Serb territorial gains of 70 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;16	An international peace plan , which the Bosnians accept and the Serbs reject , would force Serbs to settle for 49 percent of the country .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;17	With new U.S. support for Europe 's position that diplomacy , not further NATO airstrikes , is the best way to deal with the Bosnian war , French Foreign Minister Alain Juppe and his British counterpart , Douglas Hurd , planned to meet Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade Sunday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;18	Karadzic later criticized the planned meeting , saying Milosevic `` did not start the war , and he can not finish it . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;19	The Bosnian Serb leader insisted that Juppe and Hurd come to Pale , adding , `` We can not accept to be treated like a rebel group . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;20	Nonetheless , Milosevic , who is considered responsible for the violent breakup of Yugoslavia , continues to wield the most power , even with the Bosnian Serbs , whom he rejected last summer over their repeated refusal to accept the peace plan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;21	Senior Western officials now talk of altering that plan to allow the Bosnian Serbs confederal links with Yugoslavia , a right the plan already gives Bosnian Croats with Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;22	Critics say that is appeasement and a step toward creation of Serb nationalists ' goal , a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;23	But Krajisnik said changing the proposed territorial maps was the crucial element to Serb acceptance of the plan , the Bosnian Serb news agency SRNA reported .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;24	Continuing the squeeze on the Bosnian government , Serbs again denied U.N. requests to supply the Bihac enclave and other vulnerable U.N.-patrolled sites with food and supplies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;25	Monique Tuffelli , the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees staffer in the Bihac enclave , said food stocks would last only another week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;26	The last UNHCR food convoy reached Bihac on Oct. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;27	`` We have run out almost of everything , '' she said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;28	U.N. spokesman Thant Myint-U said food and fuel supplies for peacekeepers were also running short in the government-held eastern Bosnian enclaves , as well as Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;29	Heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire erupted around Bihac Thursday , with sporadic shelling on its outskirts , said Maj. Herve Gourmelon , another U.N. spokesman .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;30	A mortar round slammed into a house in the center of town Thursday morning , but there were no casualties , he added .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;31	Bosnian Serb television showed close-up video of the city limits sign for Velika Kladusa , a government outpost north of Bihac , indicating how close they were to the town .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;32	In downtown Sarajevo , Serbs targeted two government buildings with anti-tank missiles , wounding four people .
APW_ENG_19941201.0462;33	Sarajevo 's airport remained closed , and the humanitarian airlift suspended , because Serbs had not given security guarantees and are able to threaten planes ' approach route with surface-to-air missiles .

APW_ENG_19941201.0464;34	That was because Serbs had not given security guarantees and are able to threaten planes ' approach route with surface-to-air missiles .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;0	Moscow backed off from a threat to send troops Thursday into the breakaway republic of Chechnya , where leaders defied the Kremlin 's ultimatum and called on armed volunteers to defend their capital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;1	Air attacks continued on the outskirts of Grozny , the Chechen capital , claiming at least four lives , according to hospital officials .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;2	A Russian delegation arrived from Moscow and began talks with Chechen officials .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;3	Residents continued to flee the mainly Muslim city of 300,000 people in the Caucasus Mountains of southern Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;4	The city has become a war zone between forces loyal to Chechen President Dzhokhar Dudayev , who declared independence from Moscow in 1991 , and Chechen rebels trying to topple him .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;5	Dudayev accuses Moscow of arming and leading the rebels , who launched an offensive last week that began with helicopters and escalated in recent days to jet fighters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;6	Russia says it has given the rebels only political support .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;7	It refuses to recognize independence for Chechnya , which was incorporated into the Russian Empire in the 19th century after a series of long and bloody wars .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;8	President Boris Yeltsin threatened Tuesday to impose a state of emergency in Chechnya if both sides did not surrender prisoners and stop fighting by Thursday morning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;9	On Thursday evening , Yeltsin 's office issued an altered text of the ultimatum , saying `` there was some disagreement in the media in interpreting certain clauses . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;10	The reissued document made no reference to a state of emergency .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;11	Trying a different tack , Yeltsin offered limited amnesty Thursday to Chechens who `` voluntarily lay down arms by Dec. 15 . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;12	In another sign of Russia 's desire to avoid direct confrontation , Defense Minister Pavel Grachev told reporters in Moscow that some Russian soldiers who `` carried out certain military tasks for material compensation '' from anti-Dudayev forces had been brought back to central Russia , and more would be evacuated .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;13	Grachev insisted the soldiers were volunteers and were not in Chechnya on army orders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;14	Dudayev 's government captured up to 70 Russians in fighting last weekend and alleged that some were army officers and soldiers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;15	Chechen officials initially threatened to execute them , but Dudayev said Thursday they would be tried in court .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;16	Despite Moscow 's softened tone , it still appeared to be beefing up troops on the borders of Chechnya .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;17	A tired-looking Dudayev held a defiant news conference in the basement of his presidential palace as jets roared overhead , calling Yeltsin 's government a `` satanic power . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;18	Dudayev said his house had been bombed Thursday morning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;19	A small military air base near Grozny also was hit in an air raid Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;20	The ITAR-Tass news agency said two women were killed and fuel depots were burning .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;21	Missiles hit a residential district at Katayama , about 12 miles from town , said the duty surgeon Aslanbek Otsalayev at Grozny 's main hospital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;22	Two women 's corpses were at the hospital .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;23	Otsalayev said four people , including a 1-year-old child , were killed and at least six wounded .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;24	In Freedom Square outside Dudayev 's offices , several hundred volunteer fighters cradling Kalashnikov rifles and grenade launchers gathered to hear speeches .
APW_ENG_19941201.0465;25	Chechen elders in tall fur hats , tunics and high leather boots danced in a circle , chanting , `` Freedom or death ! ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0467;0	Incomes are growing so rapidly that free-spending Americans are n't keeping up -- and therefore the savings rate is improving , new figures show .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;1	A flurry of reports Thursday points to a remarkably strong economy with `` no dark clouds , '' said one private analyst .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;2	A day after reporting that the economy expanded in the third quarter more rapidly than earlier estimates , the Commerce Department released data that suggest the fourth quarter got off to a quick start .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;3	Americans ' income surged 1.4 percent in October , the biggest jump in eight months and the ninth straight gain , the department said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;4	With millions more Americans employed and being paid more , analysts expect a strong Christmas shopping season that got off to a brisk start last week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;5	Spurred by a big gain in average hourly earnings and bonus pay for auto workers , the income advance easily outpaced consumer spending -- which rose 0.7 percent in October for its strongest showing since a 0.9 percent rise in August .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;6	`` These are very strong numbers , '' said economist Eugene Sherman of the Wall Street firm of M.A. Schapiro and Co. `` It 's a very positive figure on the income side , so much so that people saved more money .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;7	And you know how much Americans hate to save . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;8	`` Everything is doing remarkably well , '' he added .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;9	`` There are n't any dark clouds . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;10	Analysts said new sales figures show the Christmas season began strongly for retailers , helping to overcome a weak early November when warmer weather held down clothing purchases .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;11	Many analysts predict a 6 percent sales increase for the holiday season .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;12	In other reports : -- Construction spending rose 0.9 percent in October , the second straight gain , although the advance was limited to non-residential and government spending .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;13	The Commerce Department said residential spending , nearly half of construction outlays , fell .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;14	-- The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing the first time for state unemployment benefits dropped last week to the lowest level in two months .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;15	-- American manufacturing surged in November to its strongest level in 10 years and its 15th straight month of growth , said a widely followed survey by the National Association of Purchasing Managers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;16	Financial markets were lower .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;17	At midafternoon , the Dow Jones industrial average was down more than 20 points and the yield on the 30-year U.S. Treasury bond , which moves in the opposite direction of its price , was up to 8.02 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;18	The Commerce Department said the income gain was the largest since it rose 1.7 percent in February .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;19	Income last fell in January , when it slipped 0.6 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;20	In September , personal income increased 0.6 percent and spending rose just 0.2 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;21	Disposable income -- income after taxes -- also climbed 1.4 percent in October .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;22	Americans ' savings rate -- savings as a percentage of disposable income -- rose to 4.7 percent in October , from 4.1 percent the previous month .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;23	The new rate is the highest since April 1993 , when it was 5 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;24	Consumer spending , which accounts for two-thirds of the nation 's gross domestic product , was up for the sixth straight month and eight of the last nine .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;25	On Wednesday , the government reported that the economy expanded at a 3.9 percent annual rate in the third quarter of 1994 despite rising interest rates and is on target for its best yearly performance in six years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;26	The figure was revised upward from a 3.4 percent estimate a month earlier .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;27	`` The current quarter is off to a brisk start and fourth quarter consumer spending could rise at around a 3.5 percent rate , '' said Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch and Co.
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;28	But , he added , `` that pace is unsustainable . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;29	The Federal Reserve has raised interest rates six times this year , most recently on Nov. 15 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0467;30	Analysts expect the next boost to come Feb. 1 when Fed policy-makers conclude a two-day meeting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;0	Ernesto Zedillo was sworn in as president Thursday , vowing to broker peace with Indian rebels , work for his country 's impoverished millions and phase out Mexico 's one-party rule .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;1	Zedillo , who was honored with a parade by thousands of rifle-carrying soldiers backed by armored carriers , smartly saluted the army and navy marching bands as new commander-in-chief and 63rd president of Mexico .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;2	`` We want a homeland of peace , '' declared Zedillo , 42 , a Yale-trained economist , in an inaugural address promising greater prosperity for all Mexicans .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;3	The oath was taken at a simple midday ceremony .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;4	Departing President Carlos Salinas de Gortari transferred over the green , red and white sash of the office before 1,500 dignitaries including U.S. Vice President Al Gore and Cuba 's Fidel Castro .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;5	The dignitaries were then taken in a caravan of gleaming black limousines to the National Palace , trailing Zedillo 's luxury car , guarded by jogging security agents and showered by confetti thrown from balconies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;6	`` We think he will be a good president ! ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;7	said Carmen Valencia , a 60-year-old housewife and exuberant ruling party supporter out for the national holiday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;8	`` He came from below and understands poverty . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;9	More than 10,000 anti-government demonstrators , however , rallied at the Monument of the Revolution and shouted slogans against the Institutional Revolutionary Party , or PRI , which has governed Mexico for 65 years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;10	`` Out with Zedillo ! ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;11	the protesters shouted , jamming the plaza and raising banners calling for a civil insurgency near the monument , which commemorates Mexico 's bloody 1910-20 revolution .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;12	Many of the protesters were civil supporters of the Zapatista National Liberation Army , a guerrilla force that rebelled on Jan. 1 in the impoverished southern state of Chiapas .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;13	Others were backers of Mexico 's leftist Democratic Revolution Party , the biggest opponent to PRI rule and the free-market reforms Salinas undertook during his six years in office .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;14	The crowd at the Monument to the Revolution grew by the hour , although police made no moves to intervene .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;15	Some protesters , mostly farmers in straw hats , had clubs and machetes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;16	Some residents were wary of the new administration .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;17	The past year was marked by an unresolved Indian rebellion in Chiapas , the March 23 slaying of the first PRI presidential candidate , Luis Donaldo Colosio , kidnappings and drug feuds .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;18	`` We are all a little bit skeptical , '' said taxi driver Juan Angel Mendoza .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;19	`` They all say the same thing and nothing happens .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;20	But who knows , maybe Zedillo will be different . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;21	The 42-year-old president , who will guide Mexico until the year 2000 , promised to expand democracy and prosperity while stripping away many of the powers that have made presidential power nearly absolute .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;22	`` The time has come to do away with centralism , '' vowed Zedillo in the ceremony at the ornate Chamber of Deputies , the lower house of Congress .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;23	Zedillo pledged to balance the power of the presidency with greater independence for the courts , the congress and state governments , as well as for his own party .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;24	Zedillo promised to launch a war on poverty and maintain a cease-fire with the Chiapas rebels .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;25	`` Our most important challenge is to provide dignified living conditions for every Mexican family , '' he said , and vowed to use the free trade agreement with Canada and the United States `` to help generate the jobs we need and raise living standards . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;26	Bypassed once for his party 's presidential nomination , Zedillo was thrust into the campaign by Colosio 's assassination , the first major political killing in decades .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;27	He went on to win the presidency Aug. 21 in the most credible elections ever held in Mexico .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;28	Zedillo , former budget and planning minister under Salinas , is sure to continue his predecessor 's free-market economic policies -- a commitment underlined by the Cabinet choices announced Wednesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;29	Leading negotiators of NAFTA -- the North American Free Trade Agreement -- were named heads of treasury , trade and foreign policy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;30	Seven other free-market economists also were named to the 25-person cabinet .
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;31	Gore said 1994 was a year of `` unprecedented progress in the bilateral relationship between the United States and Mexico ... and we look forward to even greater improvement in the year ahead . '
APW_ENG_19941201.0468;32	Zedillo also showed signs of a political opening with the appointment of a conservative opposition party member , Antonio Lozano , as attorney general .

APW_ENG_19941201.0470;0	Former President Daniel Ortega was hospitalized in Cuba after suffering a minor heart attack , his Sandinista party announced Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0470;1	Ortega was in `` satisfactory '' condition at a specialized hospital in Havana , the Cuban capital , a party statement said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0470;2	Ortega , 49 , president from 1985 to 1990 , is secretary-general of the Sandinista party and a leading contender for the party 's presidential nomination in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0470;3	Ortega was hospitalized `` after a heart attack that he suffered approximately three months ago was detected during a medical checkup , '' the statement said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0470;4	It said doctors were carrying out further tests .
APW_ENG_19941201.0470;5	Ortega , a prominent figure among world leftists , went to Cuba a week ago for undisclosed reasons .
APW_ENG_19941201.0470;6	He has been embroiled in a power struggle over the past six months for leadership of the party .

APW_ENG_19941201.0470;10	He lost a 1990 re-election bid to President Violeta Chamorro .
APW_ENG_19941201.0471;0	With many players taking a tough stance , the National Hockey League Players Association went back to the bargaining table Thursday still hoping to find labor peace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0471;1	`` Many of the players -- I 'd say 90 per cent -- feel we 've given up too much already and we 're not going to give up any more , '' said Chicago 's Jeremy Roenick .
APW_ENG_19941201.0471;2	`` I hope people realize how much the players have given up to get hockey back on the ice . ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0471;12	The players have been against this so-called luxury tax , believing it has the same effect as a salary cap .
APW_ENG_19941201.0471;13	Since team owners locked out the players on Oct. 1 , 347 games have been canceled .
APW_ENG_19941201.0471;14	Only 60 games remain on the schedule .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;0	Researchers have isolated a genetic switch that separates the boys from the girls .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;1	It turns off the female in the human embryo and starts biological changes that eventually put hair on the chest .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;2	Dr. Michael Weiss of the University of Chicago said the new study advances the understanding of the complex cascade that determines whether people are male or female and sheds new light on how this process can sometimes go awry .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;3	In research to be published Friday in the journal Science , Weiss and his team use sophisticated imaging techniques to explore on an atomic level the biological pathway to manhood .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;4	Their research report traces the development of maleness , from the turning on of the SRY gene , which is on the Y chromosome , to the work of another gene , called MIS , that removes the female parts of the original embryo .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;5	Weiss said that science has long known that everybody at conception is female , but the precise biological mechanism that changes an embryo to male is still incompletely understood .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;6	Solving the puzzle on molecular level may answer questions about other basic cellular changes , such as the development of cancer .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;7	`` If we can understand the general switches involved in sex determination , then we could possibly relate that to other basic processes , such as how organs differentiate or how cancer arises , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;8	For the first weeks after conception , all mammal embryos start forming the basic female structures -- uterus , fallopian tubes and vagina .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;9	`` The embryo destined to become a boy begins as a female , '' Weiss said in an interview .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;10	`` It lays down first female structures and not male structures at a phase when the embryo looks like a recognizable mammal , with toes , fingers and eyes and a heart .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;11	This is 35 to 40 days into human gestation . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;12	After that , he said , a gene called SRY switches on to start the embryo on its way toward manhood .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;13	The new study shows that SRY also triggers the work of another gene , called MIS , that dissolves the female parts of the original embryo .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;14	`` SRY is the master switch , '' said Weiss .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;15	`` For the first time we have shown that SRY can activate a male specific pattern of gene expression leading to activation of MIS , which is the key signaling molecule for half of the male pathway . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;16	Sex determination in mammals originates with the chromosome of the sperm that fertilizes the egg .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;17	Male sperm can carry one of two chromosomes , X or Y. The Y chromosome is the male element that carries the SRY gene .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;18	The female egg has an X chromosome .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;19	If the egg is fertilized with the father 's X chromosome , then the embryo continues its development as a female .
APW_ENG_19941201.0472;20	But if the egg is fertilized with Y , then the SRY gene sets off a series of changes that eventually creates a male .
APW_ENG_19941201.0473;0	Deaths from drunken driving accidents in the United States have dropped by nearly one-third over the last 12 years as states raised their drinking ages and grass-roots campaigns raised awareness of the problem , the government said Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0473;1	Last year , 17,461 people were killed in alcohol-related traffic accidents , down 31 percent from 25,165 in 1982 , the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported .
APW_ENG_19941201.0473;2	In 1982 , alcohol accounted for 57.3 percent of traffic deaths ; that had declined to 43.5 percent by 1993 , said the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration , which collected the data .
APW_ENG_19941201.0473;3	The number of intoxicated drivers involved in fatal accidents dropped 33 percent , from 21,780 in 1982 to 14,589 in 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0473;4	The agency attributed the drop in deaths to improved law enforcement , states ' raising their drinking ages to 21 and lowering their legal limits for intoxication , fewer people drinking , social pressure against driving drunk and heightened public awareness because of groups that include Mothers Against Drunk Driving .
APW_ENG_19941201.0473;5	All states now have a drinking age of 21 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0473;6	The standard for intoxication in 45 states is a blood-alcohol level of .10 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0473;7	For a 72-kilo -LRB- 160-pound -RRB- man , that amounts to about five drinks within an hour on an empty stomach .
APW_ENG_19941201.0474;0	Toronto 's Mats Sundin set up the opening goal as Djurgarden edged Brynas 3-2 Thursday to take a three-point lead in the Swedish Elite League .
APW_ENG_19941201.0474;1	Djurgarden , which will play Wayne Gretzky 's NHL All Star team in an exhibition Dec. 9 at Stockholm 's Globe Arena , improved to 12-3-4 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0474;2	Sundin , who was traded to the Maple Leafs from Quebec in the off-season , assisted on Ola Josefsson 's power-play goal at 18:52 in the first period .
APW_ENG_19941201.0474;3	Sundin now has five goals and two assists in seven games for his old Swedish team .
APW_ENG_19941201.0474;4	He was cleared to play again in Sweden last month .
APW_ENG_19941201.0474;5	Djurgarden 's victory , before a sellout crowd of 13,840 , snapped a three-game losing streak to Brynas at the Globe Arena .
APW_ENG_19941201.0474;6	No NHLer scored in Thursday 's six games .

APW_ENG_19941201.0475;0	The independent counsel who investigates U.S. government officials will bring no criminal charges in the search of Bill Clinton 's passport files during the 1992 presidential campaign , he said Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0475;1	Joseph diGenova , who has been investigating the matter for nearly two years , said his report will exonerate the former Bush administration officials who had been the subject of his probe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0475;2	`` No question about it , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0475;3	A three-judge federal panel appointed diGenova nearly two years ago , after President Bush 's attorney general , William Barr , found possible evidence of criminal intent in the search of the Democratic presidential candidate 's passport files .
APW_ENG_19941201.0475;4	Late in the campaign , rumors had surfaced that while Clinton was a student in England , he had sought information on how to renounce his U.S. citizenship .
APW_ENG_19941201.0475;5	The unfounded rumors triggered Freedom of Information Act requests from the news media and an inquiry from a Republican House member , Rep. Gerald Solomon of New York .
APW_ENG_19941201.0475;6	Sources said the counsel will conclude that the case should never have been referred to the Justice Department in the first place , and that the investigation was bungled by State Department Inspector General Sherman Funk and his staff .
APW_ENG_19941201.0475;7	DiGenova 's report , expected to be submitted in the next two weeks to the three-judge panel that appointed him , will fault Funk for overzealousness that drove his staff to do sloppy work , said one source familiar with the case who spoke on condition of anonymity .
APW_ENG_19941201.0475;8	Funk defended his investigation and said he had `` no choice '' in whether to refer the matter to the Justice Department .
APW_ENG_19941201.0475;9	`` Right or wrong , we had grounds for believing there was a violation . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0475;10	The report also is expected to raise questions about the use by members of Congress of their positions to launch politically motivated inquiries , such as the search of Clinton 's files .
APW_ENG_19941201.0475;11	And it is likely to show that James A. Baker III , then White House chief of staff , knew about the file search and could have cut it off almost immediately , but did not , two sources familiar with the investigation said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;0	Showing more contempt for U.N. authority , Bosnian Serb fighters kidnapped more U.N. peacekeepers and tightened their stranglehold Thursday on the `` safe area '' of Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;1	The Serbs did , however , agree to meet top U.N. envoy Yasushi Akashi on Friday in Pale , their stronghold east of Sarajevo .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;2	They had refused to meet U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali on Wednesday because he insisted talks be held at Sarajevo airport , in the capital of the internationally recognized government of Bosnia-Herzegovina .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;3	Fighting between government forces and allied Serbs from Bosnia and neighboring Croatia continued in the Bihac area Thursday , prompting a warning from Croatian Defense Minister Gojko Susak .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;4	`` Croatia will not wait for the fall of Bihac , '' Susak told reporters in the capital Zagreb .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;5	`` We are monitoring the situation , and if Croatia 's judgment is that Bihac is about to fall , Croatia will intervene . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;6	The fall of Bihac would effectively unite Serb territory in northern Bosnia with Serb-held land in Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;7	The Zagreb government would view that as a greater threat to its sovereignty , even as it increasingly talks of using force to regain control over the third of Croatia occupied by its Serbs since a truce halted their 1991 war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;8	The Akashi meeting was arranged during talks in Pale between Lt. Gen. Sir Michael Rose , the U.N. commander in Bosnia , and Radovan Karadzic and other Bosnian Serb leaders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;9	Rose went to Pale to discuss a possible cease-fire and demilitarization of Bihac , as well as the fate of more than 400 peacekeepers held hostage by the Serbs as insurance against further NATO airstrikes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;10	Alexander Ivanko , a U.N. spokesman , said the latest kidnappings occurred Tuesday when Bosnian Serb units crossed the border into Croatia and seized seven Ukrainian peacekeepers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;11	They took the soldiers and a U.N. armored carrier into Bosnian Serb-held territory , and the United Nations has not heard from its troops since .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;12	The Ukrainians ' observation point is now occupied by the Serbs , allowing for the unimpeded movement into Bosnia of equipment and personnel from Serb-held Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;13	However , there appeared to be no narrowing of differences that could end the Bihac siege .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;14	Momcilo Krajisnik , leader of the so-called Bosnian Serb assembly , again rejected a three-month cease-fire which the Bosnian government wants , saying Serbs would accept only a permanent cease-fire as a prelude to a formal end of the war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;15	The Sarajevo government fears any permanent cease-fire agreement would cement Serb territorial gains of 70 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;16	An international peace plan , which the Bosnians accept and the Serbs reject , would force Serbs to settle for 49 percent of the country .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;17	With new U.S. support for Europe 's position that diplomacy , not further NATO airstrikes , is the best way to deal with the Bosnian war , French Foreign Minister Alain Juppe and his British counterpart , Douglas Hurd , planned to meet Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade on Sunday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;18	Karadzic later criticized the planned meeting , saying Milosevic `` did not start the war , and he can not finish it . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;19	The Bosnian Serb leader insisted that Juppe and Hurd come to Pale , adding , `` We can not accept to be treated like a rebel group . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;20	Nonetheless , Milosevic , who is considered responsible for the violent breakup of Yugoslavia , continues to wield the most power , even with the Bosnian Serbs he spurned last summer for their repeated refusal to accept the peace plan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;21	Senior Western officials now talk of altering that plan to allow the Bosnian Serbs confederal links with Yugoslavia , a right the plan already gives Bosnian Croats with Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;22	Critics say that is appeasement and a step toward creation of Serb nationalists ' goal , a Greater Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;23	But Krajisnik said changing the proposed territorial maps was the crucial element to Serb acceptance of the plan , the Bosnian Serb news agency SRNA reported .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;24	Continuing the squeeze on the Bosnian government , Serbs again denied U.N. requests to supply the Bihac enclave and other vulnerable U.N.-patrolled sites with food and supplies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;25	Monique Tuffelli , the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees staffer in the Bihac enclave , said food would last only another week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;26	The last UNHCR food convoy reached Bihac on Oct. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;27	`` We have run out almost of everything , '' she said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;28	U.N. spokesman Thant Myint-U said food and fuel supplies for peacekeepers were also running short in the government-held eastern Bosnian enclaves , as well as Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;29	Heavy machine-gun and small-arms fire erupted around Bihac on Thursday , with sporadic shelling on its outskirts , said Maj. Herve Gourmelon , another U.N. spokesman .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;30	A mortar round slammed into a house in the center of town Thursday morning , but there were no casualties , he added .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;31	Bosnian Serb television showed close-up video of the city limits sign for Velika Kladusa , a government outpost north of Bihac , indicating how close they were to the town .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;32	In downtown Sarajevo , Serbs targeted two government buildings with anti-tank missiles , wounding four people .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;33	Sarajevo 's airport remained closed and the humanitarian airlift suspended .
APW_ENG_19941201.0476;34	That was because Serbs had not given security guarantees and are able to threaten planes ' approach route with surface-to-air missiles .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;0	American schoolchildren face widespread fear , violence , weapons in school , victimization and poor communication with teachers and parents , according to a new survey .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;1	While violence in schools is not as pervasive as news media make it out to be , said pollster Humphrey Taylor on Thursday , `` the levels are obviously totally unacceptable . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;2	`` The survey suggests to me the need to stamp out the first signs of violence before they become commonplace , to have zero tolerance for violent behavior and to do whatever more is necessary to keep weapons out of school , '' said Taylor , chairman and chief executive officer of Louis Harris and Associates , which conducted the poll .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;3	Parents delude themselves if they think their children talk to them about such problems , the results show .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;4	Only 13 percent of parents interviewed thought their children do n't confide in them about school problems but more than 37 percent of the students said they hardly ever or never speak to their parents about them .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;5	The results were released at a forum cosponsored by MetLife , which commissioned the survey , and the U.S. Chamber of Commerce Center for Workforce Preparation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;6	`` It 's easy for me to stand here and say these things , but very tough to achieve them , '' said Humphrey .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;7	Harry P. Kamen , his counterpart at MetLife , stressed the need for more involvement by parents .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;8	`` Fifty-eight percent of all students believe their parents never exchange notes with a teacher or school official , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;9	`` Two in five students who have been victims of violence say their parents never talk to the school staff , not even by telephone . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;10	More than 1,000 parents with at least one child in public school and 2,500 students in grades three through 12 were interviewed by telephone in a one-month period beginning in April .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;11	The poll had a possible sampling error of 3 percent for the students and 4 percent for the parents .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;12	In the month preceding the survey , `` a sizable proportion of public school students have had personal experiences with angry scenes or confrontations -LRB- 44 percent -RRB- , and physical fights -LRB- 24 percent -RRB- , '' the report said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;13	In that month , 5 percent of all students surveyed said they had been threatened at least once with a gun and 7 percent with a knife .
APW_ENG_19941201.0477;14	Among students with mostly A 's and B 's , 4 percent had been threatened with a gun and 3 percent with a knife .

APW_ENG_19941201.0480;0	Russia upset NATO 's plans for expanding its membership to former Warsaw Pact foes Thursday by claiming the move would create a new division in Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;1	In an extraordinary session , Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev departed from a prepared speech to criticize the allies for ordering aides to draw up terms and conditions for future membership .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;2	`` If the strategy of NATO has changed , then that is something which requires further discussion , '' Kozyrev told foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;3	`` Moscow 's strategy is partnership .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;4	If NATO 's strategy is partnership as well then we can begin working on this program as soon as possible .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;5	If the strategy of NATO is now aimed at enlargement then that is something that requires further discussions and possibly a different decision .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;6	The Russian had been invited to the meeting to endorse a wide-ranging program of military and political contacts with Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;7	The special ties had been designed to ease Russia 's fears of an eastward drive by the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;8	But Kozyrev refused to agree to the documents .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;9	He said he read the ministers ' statement on membership and immediately called Russian President Boris Yeltsin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;10	`` This communique raises more questions than it answers , '' he said impromptu remarks that were broadcast to reporters at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;11	`` We have to understand what are the intentions of the other partners . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;12	`` Moscow 's strategy is partnership .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;13	If NATO 's strategy is partnership as well then we can begin working on this program as soon as possible , '' Kozyrev added .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;14	Willy Claes , the Western military alliance 's new secretary-general , tried to reassure Kozyrev that NATO was not taking a new direction .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;15	`` It is no change in strategy or policy of NATO .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;16	... There is nothing new , '' he told the Russian just before he left NATO headquarters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;17	`` We are not willing to organize new divisions in Europe . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;18	Kozyrev 's outburst only added to the alliance 's woes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;19	There have been unprecedented strains in recent weeks between the United States and its European allies over the crisis in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;20	In an effort to heal the wounds , U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher swung behind the European view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;21	It was a major policy switch by Washington under pressure from the Europeans , led by Britain and France .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;22	In the past , Moscow has strongly opposed any move by NATO to draw in its one-time partners in the Warsaw Pact , the defunct Eastern military alliance led by the Soviet Union .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;23	The Europeans in particular have been uneasy about pushing expansion for fear of upsetting Russia , still a formidable military power at the edge of allied territory .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;24	In an effort to overcome Russian objections , the allies had agreed to develop a `` far-reaching relationship , corresponding with Russia 's size , importance and capabilities . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;25	They had insisted they had no intention of forming a hostile bloc threatening Russia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;26	`` Having just overcome the division of Europe , we have no desire to see the emergence of new lines of partition , '' the ministers said in a statement .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;27	NATO has been anguishing in recent years over whether -- and when -- to open its doors to its former foes in Eastern Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;28	Poland , Hungary and others have repeatedly demanded coveted membership and the security guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;29	In an effort to meet their demands -- but without upsetting Russia , the allies thought they had found a good formula .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;30	At a summit last January , President Clinton and other allied leaders approved a U.S. initiative , Partnership for Peace , to bring former foes closer , but without membership .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;31	Twenty-three nations , including Russia , have enrolled in the project , which allows them to take part for the first time in military exercises and other alliance activities .
APW_ENG_19941201.0480;32	On Thursday , the allies decided to go further by ordering aides to conduct a 12-month study of the terms and conditions for expanding the Western military alliance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;0	In the final act of the 103rd Congress , the Senate moved toward final U.S. approval Thursday of a historic world trade agreement eight years in the making .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;1	In advance of the Thursday night vote , an Associated Press survey showed 66 senators for or leaning in favor of waiving Senate budget rules -- six more than needed for the crucial procedural question that opponents had seen as their best hope of killing the agreement .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;2	While debate took up the entire two days , supporters predicted confidently that they would win approval of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade by a comfortable margin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;3	The Senate vote followed a surprisingly large 142-vote margin of victory in the House on Tuesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;4	Before the congressional action , only 36 other nations had approved GATT .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;5	But many other nations were simply waiting to see what the United States did .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;6	The agreement is scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;7	`` I feel victory in the air , '' a jubilant Commerce Secretary Ron Brown told a crowd of cheering corporate lobbyists .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;8	Taking no chances on approval , President Clinton hosted a group of Democratic and Republican senators at a White House breakfast and worked through the day telephoning uncommitted senators .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;9	The 124-nation trade agreement cuts tariffs by an average of 38 percent worldwide , and for the first time extends GATT rules to such new areas as reduction of trade-distorting agriculture subsidies , lowering trade barriers in service industries , such as banking and clamping down on copyright piracy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;10	It also creates a more powerful World Trade Organization to referee trade disputes and eliminates the one-country veto that a losing nation could use to block an adverse ruling .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;11	Supporters said the agreement , by cutting the border taxes Americans have to pay while at the same time lowering barriers U.S. businesses and farmers face overseas , would provide a tremendous boost to the U.S. economy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;12	The Clinton administration estimated this would create a half-million new jobs and mean an annual increase of dlrs 150 billion in U.S. economic growth a decade from now , when the deal is fully implemented .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;13	That extra growth would put dlrs 1,700 more a year in the pockets of the average family , the administration said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;14	However , opponents charged that the WTO represented a dangerous encroachment on U.S. sovereignty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;15	They said that seven previous GATT negotiating rounds to lower trade barriers have not cured America 's chronic trade deficit nor stopped the hemorrhage of manufacturing jobs overseas .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;16	They warned that in textiles alone , one of America 's most protected industries , 1 million jobs could be lost .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;17	`` We are not leading in world trade .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;18	We are losing , '' Sen. Ernest Hollings , a Democrat from South Carolina , a leading textile state , said during floor debate .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;19	`` The reality is that we are in decline .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;20	Everybody knows that . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;21	The administration was anxious for a healthy bipartisan victory margin as a way to show that a Democratic White House will be able to work next year with the first Republican-controlled Congress in four decades .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;22	Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell took note of the fact that the vote on the GATT deal was the last act of what has been an often contentious Congress and the last vote of his congressional career .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;23	`` This agreement can fairly be characterized as historic , '' Mitchell said , saying he was happy that his last vote was `` on a matter that will have significance for generations to come . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;24	`` Those who oppose the GATT look to the past .
APW_ENG_19941201.0481;25	We look to the future , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;0	Lynn Jennings has won seven straight U.S. women 's cross country championships .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;1	She wo n't be satisfied until she wins 10 in a row .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;2	`` It wo n't mean much until I get 10 , '' said Jennings , who will go for her eighth consecutive victory -- and ninth overall -- Sunday at Blue Lake Park in Portland , Ore. `` Nine is a boring number . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;3	If Jennings wins , she would be the first U.S. athlete -- male or female -- to win nine national cross country titles .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;4	A victory also would tie her with Pat Porter for the longest winning streak in championship history .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;5	Porter won eight consecutive men 's titles from 1982 to 1989 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;6	The only year since 1985 that Jennings did n't win was 1986 , when Lesley Welch was the champion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;7	Jennings , 34 , also has won the World Cross Country Championships three times , from 1990 to 1992 , and has been on two Olympic teams -- she finished sixth in the 10,000 meters in 1988 and won the bronze medal in the 10,000 at the 1992 Barcelona Games .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;8	In addition , she has been a successful road racer for several years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;9	Of the three types of running , she prefers the track .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;10	`` I have a real love for cross country , '' Jennings said Thursday during a U.S. Olympic teleconference call .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;11	`` But it 's not what I 'm about as a runner .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;12	I have an Olympic medal on the track .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;13	I think of myself as a track runner . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;14	Jennings said she had not yet decided on which event to focus for the 1996 Atlanta Olympics -- the 5,000 meters , 10,000 meters or marathon .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;15	She will make that decision after Sunday 's race , with her coach John Babington .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;16	Jennings , of Newmarket , N.H. , said she did not feel any extra pressure despite the historical significance of another victory Sunday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;17	`` I just look at it as another race , '' she said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;18	`` I do n't think about winning another title . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;19	The field for the 6,000-meter race will be loaded with seasoned runners , including Olga Appell , Gwyn Coogan , Kathy Franey , Ceci St. Geme and Elaine van Blunk .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;20	Meanwhile , the men 's 10,000 meters will include four past winners -- Porter ; Bob Kempainen , who broke Porter 's winning streak in 1990 ; Todd Williams -LRB- 1991 and 1993 -RRB- and Bob Kennedy -LRB- 1992 -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;21	Other top contenders include Mark Coogan and Marc Davis .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;22	Williams , who beat Porter by 6 seconds at last year 's championships at Missoula , Mont. , and Kennedy have been training together at Bloomington , Ind. , under the guidance of Indiana coach Sam Bell .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;23	Williams , 25 , of Knoxville , Tenn. , thinks it has been beneficial .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;24	`` It worked out well , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;25	`` We were not trying to kill each other , we were trying to help each other . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;26	Williams twice competed in the World Cross Country Championships , with his best finish being 19th in 1992 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;27	He also was a 1992 Olympian , placing 10th in the 10,000 meters , the event he is focusing on for the '96 Games .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;28	Sunday 's program also includes a 5,000-meter junior women 's race and an 8,000-meter junior men 's race .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;29	The senior and junior men 's races will serve as qualifiers for the International Amateur Athletic Federation World Cross Country Championships March 25 at Durham , England .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;30	The first nine senior men 's finishers qualify for the U.S. team , along with the top six finishers in the junior men 's race .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;31	The women 's champions earn automatic berths on the U.S. team .
APW_ENG_19941201.0482;32	The remaining five spots on each women 's team will be selected at a trials race at Birmingham , Ala. , on Feb. 18 .

APW_ENG_19941201.0486;0	What if you were a nation that , after decades of not collecting income and other kinds of taxes , decided to start taxing your citizens and businesses again ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;1	And let 's say your new tax system was frequently criticized , generally disliked by the public , plagued by protesters and still struggling two years after adopting a controversial new tax policy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;2	Where to go for help ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;3	Maybe a country with two solid centuries of experience in the fine art of collecting taxes .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;4	One that hauls in more than a trillion dollars a year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;5	Internal Revenue Service Ogden Service Center , meet State Tax Service , headquarters Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;6	A delegation of three high-ranking Russian finance and taxation officials toured the Ogden IRS center Wednesday for a closer look at America 's sophisticated , automated and oft-excoriated system of income tax collection .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;7	Rolling through the center more swiftly than a 1040 Short Form , the delegation observed the flow of work and walked through small canyons of computer hardware merrily going about the business of transferring personal income to federal government .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;8	It was an impressive sight , said Vladilen Vorontsov , head of the Russian Federation State Tax Service 's accounting , reporting and analysis department .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;9	`` Russia is undergoing dramatic changes economically , politically and in terms of its new tax policy and administration , '' said Vorontsov , a slender bespectacled man in his late 50s with gray hair and a flawless pinstripe suit .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;10	The country is entering the third year of a new tax system adopted after the collapse of the Soviet Union 's communist economy , he explained .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;11	The conversion is difficult because of Russia 's present economic situation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;12	He was accompanied by Alla Zubkova , deputy head of the Russian Federation 's budget department , and Maria Reoutova , head of the STS ' accounting , tax statistics and information division .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;13	The Russian officials were scheduled to wrap up their Ogden visit Thursday with sessions on statistical analysis and tours of the Freeport Center and the U.S. Postal Service building in downtown Ogden .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;14	Vorontsov , who served as spokesman for the trio during an interview , said the delegation found the visit informative and helpful but added there is little chance the new Russian tax system will be modeled after its American counterpart .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;15	For one thing , he said , the Russian system is much simpler with only about a dozen taxes of any kind at the federal level .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;16	Instead , it draws the bulk of its revenues from corporate rather than individual income taxes , which provide only about 10 percent of the federation 's tax collections .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;17	`` Like anyone else , Russians are unwilling to pay taxes , '' Vorontsov noted .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;18	`` The negative attitude is very deep , and I think one of the reasons is our people have had very little tax education .
APW_ENG_19941201.0486;19	`` It will take us quite some time before our taxpayers understand each -LRB- tax -RRB- is a contribution to a civilized society , '' Vorontsov said .
