APW_ENG_19941201.0581;0	The United States should resist any temptation to deal with organized crime in Russia or China , says a security expert recalling World War II contacts with the Italian Mafia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;1	`` The time may come when American national interests may clash most seriously with Russian or Chinese interests , '' and `` individuals in our government might then be tempted to form alliances with Russian or Chinese organized crime , as their predecessors did on Sicily in the 1940s , '' said Brian R. Sullivan , a fellow at the National Defense University 's Institute for Strategic Studies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;2	`` That probably would be a very bad idea , '' said Sullivan , mentioning the spread of crime in post-Soviet Russia and Triads `` reportedly gaining unprecedented strength '' in Chinese mainland cities and among overseas Chinese .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;3	Sullivan spoke at a forum on organized crime sponsored by the American Bar Association and other legal groups .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;4	It began Thursday and was continuing Friday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;5	`` Weighing the gains and losses ... it seems that American interests were far more damaged by the Mafia over the years than they were served , '' said Sullivan , who has closely studied Italy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;6	`` And the damage continues , particularly given heavy Mafia involvement in drug trafficking . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;7	Preparing for the allied invasion of Italy in 1943 in the campaign to overthrow the Rome-Berlin Axis , U.S. Naval Intelligence opened contact with Sicilian organized crime `` including with Italian-American criminals who had been deported from the United States ... -LRB- and -RRB- men who could be considered both well-informed and anti-Fascist , '' Sullivan said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;8	`` After the invasion , American authorities employed the same men and their associates , '' he continued , affording them access to arms `` to begin highly lucrative black market operations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;9	The modern Mafia began to form . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;10	In postwar Italy , the Vatican and U.S. administrations supported Italy 's Christian Democrats against the Communists `` in every way possible , '' Sullivan said , turning a blind eye to Christian-Democrat connections with organized crime that finally brought down seven-time Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti in 1992 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;11	`` There is reason to believe that the Italian Mafia benefited greatly from American government support in 1943-45 and again in 1947-48 , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;12	Even today , `` the outcome of the war against the Mafia '' remains uncertain , Sullivan said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;13	But a lesson to be drawn from the vigorous anti-Mafia efforts of the late prosecutors Giovanni Falcone and Paolo Borsellino is that feared crime syndicates become powerful because of government support and turn vulnerable when they lose it , he added .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;14	With the Mafia on the defensive , Falcone and Borsellino were both assassinated in 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;15	A senior Federal Bureau of Investigation official , Jim E. Moody , told the gathering Italy has new laws to deal with organized crime that are as effective as laws in the United States .
APW_ENG_19941201.0581;16	Public outrage over the Falcone and Borsellino killings demanded their enactment , he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;0	An unmanned Ariane rocket carrying an American communications satellite crashed into the Atlantic Ocean 15 minutes after blastoff Thursday due to failure in the third-stage engine , which was using a new fuel mix .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;1	Technicians at the Arianespace launching pad on the edge of the South American jungle said that the third-stage engine inexplicably lost pressure 218 kilometers -LRB- 135 miles -RRB- above Earth .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;2	The failure indicated continuing problems in the third stage .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;3	In January , a third-stage breakdown forced engineers to explode a rocket in mid-flight .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;4	A Turkish and a European telecommunications satellites were also destroyed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;5	Six perfect launches followed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;6	Thursday 's crash was the seventh in 70 launches since the European Space Agency 's commercial Arianespace program lifted off 15 years ago .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;7	It should not shake Ariane 's dominance as the world 's most successful launcher of lucrative private satellites .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;8	`` We hope to get back into operation very quickly , '' said Charles Bigot , Arianespace 's chief executive officer .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;9	An investigation was opened immediately and a news conference scheduled for Friday to explain the initial findings .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;10	Liftoff was on schedule at 7:38 p.m.
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;11	The first two stages fired perfectly and controllers confidently expected another of what have become almost routine shots for the Ariane launchers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;12	The third stage also lit properly , but then mysteriously sputtered and went out .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;13	Officials said that the third stage was a new type using a new oxygen-hydrogen mixture to maximize performance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;14	The rocket took down with it a 2,985-kilogram -LRB- 3.3-ton -RRB- PanAmSat-3 telecommunications satellite built by Hughes Space and Communications in El Segundo , California .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;15	Belonging to PanAmSat of Greenwich , Conn. , the satellite would have channeled telephone , fax and television communications for most of North and South America , Europe and Africa over 15 years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;16	It would have traveled in geostationary orbit over the mid-Atlantic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;17	January 's accident was blamed on a turbo-pump failure freezing the third-stage rocket motor .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;18	That failure followed 26 straight successful launches in which the European rocket distanced itself from its competitors , the United States and China .
APW_ENG_19941201.0582;19	The Arianes have put 94 satellites in orbit and have a backlog of 38 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;0	Anti-government demonstrators pelted riot police with rocks and burned a police jeep Thursday to protest the inauguration of President Ernesto Zedillo .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;1	At least 58 people were injured in the violence , which marred a festive national holiday , according to a Red Cross spokesman who refused to give his name .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;2	He said 30 of the injured were taken to a Red Cross hospital and 28 were treated at the scene .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;3	Five of the injured were reported in serious condition .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;4	The violence erupted after a rally by 10,000 anti-government demonstrators scattered from the downtown Monument of the Revolution .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;5	Hundreds of rowdy youths ran up against a column of riot police at a major intersection near the Zocalo , the city 's main plaza .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;6	For more than an hour , shirtless youths heaved a steady stream of stones against plastic shields of riot police , who stood shoulder to shoulder blocking the route to a post-inaugural military parade attended briefly by Zedillo .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;7	A government official telephoned The Associated Press and said the violence was an isolated incident caused by `` a small group of provocateurs . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;8	He did not elaborate .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;9	At one point , a handful of demonstrators wielding stout wooden clubs charged against the plastic shields of a phalanx of riot police , who counterattacked , forcing hundreds to flee .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;10	Protesters also torched a truck that bore the symbol of Zedillo 's Institutional Revolutionary Party , or PRI .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;11	Police clubbed one young man and tore his shirt off after his burst through the phalanx of helmeted and baton-wielding officers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;12	Another man in a straw sombrero stumbled , bleeding from the head .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;13	There was no immediate report on police injuries .
APW_ENG_19941201.0583;14	The protesters , ranging from city residnents to farmers in straw hats , raised banners of the leftist Democratic Revolution Party , a vocal opponent of the PRI 's monopoly on power .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;0	JoAnne Carner and Jim Albus were one of three teams tied for the lead Thursday after the first-round of the JCPenney Classic , a mixed-team event that pairs male and female pros .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;1	Playing a best-ball format , Carner , 55 , and Albus , 54 , had a 7-under-par 64 on the Innisbrook Resort 's Copperhead Course .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;2	They were tied with the teams of Jane Geddes and Brian Claar and Marta Figueras-Dotti and Brad Bryant .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;3	Eight other teams were at 6-under .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;4	`` Oh , yeah ! ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;5	`` Two over-50 players against players in their late 20s and early 30s .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;6	I think that 's pretty good . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;7	Carner was aided by an early-week lesson from Albus , the former club pro who never played the Professional Golf Assocation Tour .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;8	`` I used to give 15 lessons a day , '' Albus said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;9	`` But that was the first one in about three years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;10	And I never gave one to a player like JoAnne . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;11	But she says it 's done wonders for her game .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;12	`` I look up now and the ball is going right where I aimed it , '' Carner said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;13	The Carner-Albus team had a seven-birdie , no-bogey round .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;14	Carner made birdie putts from 12 , 25 and 6 feet , while Albus drained birdie putts from 15 , 12 , 12 and 3 feet .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;15	Forty-six of the 52 teams were under par and 27 teams were within three strokes of the lead .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;16	The format Friday changes to alternate-stroke before returning to best-ball Saturday and finishing with alternate-stroke on Sunday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;17	One stroke behind the co and leaders at 6 and under 65 were : Judy Dickinson and Jay Sigel , Dana Dormann and Fred Funk , Amy Alcott and Robin Freeman , Chris Johnson and Neal Lancaster , Gail Graham and Dave Barr , Beth Daniel and Davis Love III , Vicki Goetze and Steve Striker and Nancy Ramsbottom and Mike Sullivan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0584;18	The players are all members of the PGA Tour , the Ladies Professional Golf Association , or the Senior Professional Golf Association .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;0	The U.S. Senate overwhelmingly approved and sent to President Clinton the historic 124-nation GATT trade agreement that will slash tariffs worldwide .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;1	Clinton called Thursday night 's vote a `` victory for America '' and said he hopes it is a harbinger of cooperation between his Democratic administration and the opposition Republicans who soon will assume control of Congress .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;2	The Senate gave final congressional approval to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade on a vote of 76-24 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;3	The House of Representatives had approved the accord on Tuesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;4	The Senate had voted 68-32 just minutes earlier to waive its own budget rules and remove a key procedural hurdle to passage .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;5	Sixty votes were needed in the earlier vote .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;6	Clinton had worked throughout the day to convince wavering lawmakers to support the deal , and he exulted in its passage .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;7	`` Let 's make the GATT vote the first vote of a new era of cooperation , '' said Clinton , who was joined by Democrats and Republicans alike in a victory celebration on the south lawn of the White House .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;8	`` America 's best days are ahead of us . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;9	Retiring Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell said the vote sends a signal to the world that America and its workers remain the world 's leaders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;10	`` We do not fear competition ; we welcome it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;11	We do not shrink from the future ; we welcome that , '' Mitchell said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;12	On the crucial budget waiver vote , the accord was supported by 31 Republicans and 37 Democrats and was opposed by 15 Republicans and 17 Democrats .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;13	Senate Republican Leader Robert Dole said his office was still getting up to 2,000 calls a day protesting the agreement .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;14	Dole said he had decided to support agreement , even with its flaws , because the alternative of defeat would be far worse .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;15	`` The bottom line is we just ca n't isolate ourselves from the rest of the world , '' Dole said before the Senate began voting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;16	The trade agreement cuts tariffs by an average of 38 percent worldwide .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;17	For the first time , it extends GATT rules to such new areas as reduction of trade-distorting agriculture subsidies , lowering trade barriers in service industries such as banking , and clamping down on copyright piracy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;18	It also creates a more powerful World Trade Organization to referee trade disputes and eliminates the one-country veto that a losing nation could use to block an adverse ruling .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;19	Supporters said the agreement , by cutting the border taxes Americans have to pay while at the same time lowering barriers U.S. businesses and farmers face overseas , would provide a tremendous boost to the U.S. economy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;20	The Clinton administration estimated this would create a half-million new jobs and mean an annual increase of dlrs 150 billion in U.S. economic growth a decade from now , when the deal is fully implemented .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;21	That extra growth would put dlrs 1,700 more a year in the pockets of the average American family , the administration said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;22	However , opponents charged that the WTO represented a dangerous encroachment on U.S. sovereignty .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;23	They said that seven previous GATT negotiating rounds to lower trade barriers have not cured America 's chronic trade deficit nor stopped the hemorrhage of manufacturing jobs overseas .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;24	They warned that in textiles alone , one of America 's most protected industries , 1 million jobs could be lost .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;25	`` We are not leading in world trade .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;26	We are losing , '' Sen. Ernest Hollings , a Democrat from South Carolina , a leading textile state , said during floor debate .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;27	`` The reality is that we are in decline .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;28	Everybody knows that . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;29	The administration was anxious for a healthy bipartisan victory margin as a way to show that a Democratic White House will be able to work next year with the first Republican-controlled Congress in four decades .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;30	The Senate vote followed a surprisingly large 142-vote margin of victory in the House on Tuesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;31	Before the congressional action , only 36 other nations had approved GATT .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;32	But many other nations were simply waiting to see what the United States did .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;33	The agreement is scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;34	The debate over the WTO came during the first outgoing session of Congress in 12 years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;35	It was forced by Hollings , who used his power as a chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee to block a vote before the November elections .
APW_ENG_19941201.0585;36	A diverse group of opponents worked down to the wire to defeat the deal , taking out newspaper ads and mobilizing opponents to telephone lawmakers .

APW_ENG_19941201.0587;0	For more than 40 years their wives and offspring waited , asked questions and waited some more .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;1	Finally they have pieced together much of the story of how their men on a secret mission were shot down over Korea -- by the Soviets .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;2	Here is the first published account of what the Air Force called simply a `` mission over enemy territory . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;3	FORT WORTH , Texas -LRB- AP -RRB- -- On Dec. 5 , 1950 , the day after Capt. Charles E. McDonough was shot down in his Korean War spy plane , an Air Force telegram arrived in Glen Rose , Texas .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;4	With official regret and a note of haunting finality it informed his wife , Mary Jo , that the plane had disappeared .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;5	`` All possible search completed , '' it said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;6	He was gone , silently swallowed up in a war that would keep many grim secrets .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;7	The search , though , was anything but completed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;8	In a sense , it had not yet begun .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;9	Nearly 44 years after the Air Force gave up on McDonough and the three other Americans aboard his silvery RB-45 reconnaissance bomber , new information has come to light -- evidence which points to Soviet involvement not only in the shootdown but also in exploiting McDonough after his capture .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;10	The evidence , not yet publicly disclosed by the U.S. government , contradicts recent denials by Moscow that the former Soviet Union had played any role .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;11	The loss of the RB-45 and its crew on Dec. 4 , 1950 , is n't even mentioned in the Air Force 's official history of the Korean War , although it notes that two planes of that type flew in the war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;12	-LRB- The unmentioned McDonough plane , tail number 8-015 , made three . -RRB-
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;13	McDonough , of New London , Conn. , was commander of the three-plane detachment which flew missions mainly over North Korea from Yokota Air Base , Japan .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;14	At 31 , this was his second war ; he flew bombers in Europe in World War II .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;15	The RB-45 , well before the U-2 and now an artifact of the Cold War , was no ordinary plane .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;16	It was converted from a jet bomber as the most advanced photo reconnaissance plane in the world , and this was its first wartime use .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;17	The Air Force knew the RB-45 was a target of Soviet intelligence .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;18	Moscow was aware that U.S. Air Force planes were overflying its territory throughout the 1950s , but it did n't become an international issue until the Soviets shot down Francis Gary Powers in a CIA-operated U-2 spy plane on May 1 , 1960 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;19	This story of the RB-45 is based on interviews with relatives of two of the four crewmen , officers who knew them , and retired Korean War RB-45 pilots , as well as declassified war records and other government documents .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;20	It is the first published account of what the Air Force called simply a `` mission over enemy territory . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;21	Leading the effort to unravel the case are Jeanne Dear , the only child of Charles and Mary Jo McDonough , and Nancy Dean , the daughter of Col. John R. Lovell , a top Air Force intelligence officer who was based at the Pentagon but happened to be aboard the plane for reasons that may never be fully known .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;22	Mrs. Dear , 44 , of Fort Worth , was 6 months old at the time .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;23	Because she never knew her father , she says , the pain of sifting through his past does n't sting as badly .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;24	But her voice makes clear that the emotional armor she wears is not impenetrable .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;25	`` It 's hard , '' she says .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;26	`` It 's a commitment I feel to my mother . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;27	For her and Mrs. Dean the search has been complicated by the secret nature of the RB-45 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;28	Although never officially acknowledged by Washington , men who flew this plane in Korea say their top-secret missions sometimes took them deep into Chinese and Soviet airspace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;29	More routinely , it flew photo reconnaissance over North Korea .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;30	Records that could shed light on McDonough 's mission that fateful day have not been found .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;31	Louis Carrington of Tyler , Texas , one of the two other pilots in McDonough 's unit , recalls that `` Mac '' and his crew , attired in blue flight suits , took off into clear skies from Yokota Air Base at about lunchtime on Dec. 4 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;32	He remembers McDonough , 6-foot-3 -LRB- 1.9-meter -RRB- and blue-eyed , as a likable , accomplished , robust man .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;33	`` He could do anything , '' Carrington says .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;34	The last word from the RB-45 crew was a routine radio contact 100 minutes after takeoff , signalling their entry into North Korean airspace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;35	Then , everlasting silence .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;36	The crash site was never pinpointed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;37	No bodies were recovered .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;38	The McDonough and Lovell daughters have n't lived on hope that their fathers are alive .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;39	`` I ca n't get sucked into the emotional quagmire , '' said Mrs. Dean , 62 , who was a freshman at the College of William and Mary when her father was listed as missing .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;40	`` My father would not have wanted that . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;41	Yet she 's convinced there is more to the story than the Air Force admits .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;42	John `` Jack '' Lovell , then 46 , worked directly for the head of Air Force intelligence , Maj. Gen. Charles P. Cabell .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;43	Lovell 's presence on the plane is a mystery .
APW_ENG_19941201.0587;44	He was not a regular crew member , but Mrs. Dean believes he had a hand in overseeing the RB-45 's spy role .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;0	Mrs. Dean recalls helping her father pack his bags on Nov. 23 , the U.S. Thanksgiving Day holiday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;1	He left that night , saying only that he was headed to the Far East .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;2	For years there were only two hints of his fate : -- His name was mentioned in an `` enemy broadcast '' picked up by U.S. intelligence in China on May 21 , 1951 , which suggested he had been captured in Korea .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;3	-- His was among 71 names of Americans listed by the U.S. Far East Command as `` men positively identified as remaining in the hands of the Communists '' after the final exchange of Allied and Communist POWs in September 1953 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;4	Yet he never was officially listed as a POW .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;5	Mrs. Dean recently obtained the list from a declassified Dec. 14 , 1954 , report in the files of the U.S. Far East Command .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;6	Nearly a year earlier , on Feb. 28 , 1954 , the government had declared Lovell dead .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;7	He was a graduate of West Point -LRB- class of ' 27 -RRB- , a former U.S. Olympic boxing team coach , and veteran of Cold War espionage .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;8	The two other men on board were co-pilot Capt. Jules E. Young , 29 , of East Rochester , N.Y. , and 1st Lt. James J. Picucci , 32 , of New York City , the navigator .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;9	When the daughters of Lovell and McDonough started researching the incident in detail in 1992 , both were surprised to learn that many records from that period are lost ; many are still classified secret , off-limits to most citizens .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;10	Mrs. Dear began her quest in earnest in 1992 when she called the Air Force casualty office at Randolph Air Force Base , Texas , to ask for the file on her father .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;11	The news was a bombshell : Her father 's name was on a list of U.S. airmen provided by the Russian government .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;12	`` I was absolutely stunned , '' Mrs. Dear recalls .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;13	But no one could tell her what the list was , whether she should think her father had been taken by the Russians .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;14	The Russian list indicates that McDonough and other U.S. POWs were interrogated by Soviet officers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;15	Indeed , the Russians later released a copy of a McDonough interrogation which says a Soviet `` prepared the questions '' and `` a Chinese comrade translated '' the answers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;16	Still , Moscow denies it ever had contact with the RB-45 crew .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;17	Mrs. Dear began digging .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;18	She attended congressional hearings in Washington , searched Air Force archives and read books on the Korean War .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;19	She also found Nancy Dean , who had begun her own research , helped by her husband , Dick , at their Wheaton , Md. , home .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;20	Many questions about the RB-45 case went unanswered in the years after the last American POWs returned from Korea , but the one that mattered most to each crew member 's family was : Did he , in fact , die ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;21	Mary Jo McDonough stayed in Glen Rose after her husband was listed as missing .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;22	She did n't wait idly , but she got no answers to her requests for information about her husband 's fate .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;23	Then , thanks to her daughter 's persistence , an answer came in October 1993 : McDonough died about two weeks after his plane was shot down .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;24	Not all details are known , and the body has not been recovered .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;25	`` My mother had been waiting for 40 years , '' Mrs. Dear says .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;26	`` For us it 's like a miracle '' to know for sure he died , and to complete their grieving .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;27	Ironically , the clinching evidence came not from U.S. government files but from Russia , whose MiG fighters shot down McDonough 's plane near the Yalu River that separates North Korea from China .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;28	McDonough parachuted from the plane .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;29	The one-page document which said McDonough had died was found in Russian archives by Paul Cole of the research firm Defense Forecasts Inc. , who has extensively studied Soviet links to Korean War MIA cases .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;30	Mrs. Dear got a copy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;31	It was dated Dec. 18 , 1950 -- exactly two weeks after the shootdown -- but did not indicate the exact date or cause of death .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;32	Routing notations on the document indicate it circulated at the highest levels of the Soviet military staff in Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;33	`` I am informing you that the pilot from the shot-down B-45 aircraft died en route and the interrogation was not finished , '' said the note in Russian .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;34	It was signed by Marshal Stepan Krasovsky , the senior Soviet military adviser to China , and addressed to Marshal Pavel Batitsky , chief of the General Staff in Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;35	This fits with recollections of the only American known to have talked to McDonough after he was shot down .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;36	Retired Air Force pilot Hamilton B. Shawe Jr. , of Reno , Nev. , said he spent about three days with McDonough as a POW in a bombed-out prison in Sinuiju , in northern Korea , starting about Dec. 14 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;37	He says he last saw McDonough being taken away from the prison on an ox cart , and that he was in such bad condition that it seemed unlikely he could live much longer .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;38	Shawe said McDonough told him he had parachuted from the burning wreckage of the RB-45 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;39	He later suffered severe frostbite while trying to evade capture in the frozen wilds .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;40	When he sought food at an isolated Korean house , the occupants turned him in to the military .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;41	The exact time sequence is still unclear .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;42	Shawe reported his contact with McDonough to the Air Force in 1953 when he was released from captivity .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;43	On the basis of his information , and the lack of other news , the Air Force issued a presumptive finding of death on March 1 , 1954 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;44	Although the McDonough family members accept the Russian document as evidence that he died , they realize it raises other questions .
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;45	Where were they taking him when he died ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;46	What did the Soviets want from him ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0588;47	What was done with the body ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0589;0	A second Russian document obtained by Cole this year makes the Soviet link even clearer .
APW_ENG_19941201.0589;1	It says the RB-45 was shot down about 45 miles -LRB- 72.5 kilometers -RRB- east of Andung , China , just across the border from Sinuiju , North Korea .
APW_ENG_19941201.0589;2	The report summarizes what McDonough said under a Soviet-controlled interrogation and asks that Russian `` advisers '' in Korea help retrieve downed American aircraft and `` details . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0589;3	This document was dated Dec. 17 , 1950 , and was signed by the Soviet commander of the 64th Fighter Aviation Corps , which headed Soviet air operations in Korea .
APW_ENG_19941201.0589;4	The note was addressed to top military officers in the Kremlin .
APW_ENG_19941201.0589;5	In November 1994 , Mrs. Dear learned more painful details through a confidential source who interviewed the MiG pilot , A.F. Andrianov , who is credited with shooting down the RB-45 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0589;6	Andrianov recalled being told by the Soviet officer who interrogated McDonough that while McDonough was being moved from Sinuiju , apparently on Dec. 18 , a sign was hung on him , `` U.S. War Criminal . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0589;7	A crowd of North Koreans gathered around the defiant American and beat him to death , Mrs. Dear said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0589;8	For that final injustice , she and her mother hold both the North Koreans and the former Soviet Union responsible , though she strongly doubts the American government will ever seek any sort of apology .
APW_ENG_19941201.0589;9	Because Andrianov said he saw only one parachute emerge from the RB-45 , Mrs. Dean now accepts that her father , Lovell the intelligence officer , died in the crash .
APW_ENG_19941201.0589;10	Her search , too , is ended , though she still wonders why her father was there .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;0	Prime Minister Rafik Hariri offered to resign after a stormy Cabinet meeting in which he accused his opponents of trying to sabotage government proposals , aides said early Friday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;1	Speaking on condition of anonymity , Hariri 's aides said the Syrian - and Saudi Arabian-backed billionaire offered his resignation in a telephone call late Thursday night to President Elias Hrawi .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;2	Hrawi , a Sunni Muslim , had not yet accepted or rejected the resignation because it must first be made in writing , presumably later Friday , the aides said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;3	The resignation offer was triggered by a heated exchange between Hariri and a Shiite Muslim Cabinet member , Housing Minister Mahmoud Abu Hamdan , the aides said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;4	The aides said Hariri accused Hamdan and other opponents of trying to block all government-proposed legislation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;5	Hamdan is one of a group of ministers in the 30-member Cabinet that is aligned with Nabih Berri , the Shiite speaker of Parliament and head of the Amal movement , a powerful militia in Lebanon 's 1975-1990 civil war .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;6	Critics have accused Hariri , a self-made tycoon with substantial real-estate and civil-engineering holdings , of trying to grab a large share of the multibillion-dollar postwar reconstruction projects for his own companies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;7	They also claim he is trying to ram his decisions through the Cabinet , ignoring the opposition .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;8	Hariri , 51 , was appointed prime minister Oct. 22 , 1992 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;9	At the time , he was hailed as Lebanon 's savior who would rescue the onetime `` Switzerland of the Middle East '' from economic oblivion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;10	The Lebanese hoped his wholesome image , his wealth and his powerful Syrian and Saudi connections would help him achieve what previous government had not : an economic turnaround to erase the war 's devastation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;11	His record has been mixed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;12	Much of war-ravaged central Beirut is being bulldozed as part of a massive reconstruction to make the Lebanese capital once more a financial and trade magnet for the region .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;13	But the reconstruction has been slower than expected .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;14	Earlier this year , Hariri refused to attend government meetings for several days to protest the slowness of government action on reconstruction .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;15	Hariri built much of his dlrs 3 billion fortune in Saudi Arabia and enjoys a close friendship with the Saudi royal family .
APW_ENG_19941201.0590;16	According to a national covenant dating to independence from France in 1943 , Lebanon 's president is a Maronite Catholic , the Parliament speaker is a Shiite and the prime minister is a Sunni .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;0	Of all the closets society has built to hide the people it would shun , none are as dreaded as the colonies that hide victims of leprosy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;1	The disease , as old as antiquity , has been conquered by medicine , but the stigma remains .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;2	Now a group of former victims wants society to heal its attitude as well .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;3	PETROPOLIS , Brazil -LRB- AP -RRB- -- It was the spring of 1947 when Haobin Kong learned he was a pariah .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;4	At dawn his mother woke the 16-year-old boy and walked him -- always keeping several paces ahead -- through the fields of Guandong province in southern China to a remote leprosy colony run by missionaries .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;5	`` She left me at the gate , turned and walked away without a goodbye , '' says Kong , a gaunt man of 63 , his hands twisted , his mouth deformed by leprosy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;6	`` I never saw her or my family again .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;7	I realized then what it was to be a victim of leprosy , to be an outcast , a nobody . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;8	Now Kong and dozens of former patients from around the world have joined to fight the stigma associated with leprosy , a stigma that has turned them into symbols of dread and reproach even among friends and family .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;9	They gathered recently at a Roman Catholic convent in this mountain city 40 miles -LRB- 65 kilometers -RRB- north of Rio de Janeiro and formed the first worldwide defense league for victims of Hansen 's disease -- leprosy .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;10	The weeklong conference brought together 70 former victims from China , India , Cuba , Japan , South Korea and Brazil , along with health advocates from the United States and Europe .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;11	`` This movement is historic , '' said Anwei Law , a public health expert from Oak Hill , W. Va. , and the organization 's new treasurer .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;12	`` It 's the first time people affected by leprosy have come together to fight the stigma of this disease , to tell the world they have a right to a normal life . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;13	Francisco Vieira Nunes , the new head of the defense league , said the first task was to rebuild the self-esteem of former patients who never had the courage to leave their colonies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;14	`` Once a leper , always a leper , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;15	`` You lose your name , you get eased out of your job , you lose your self-worth .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;16	Well , now we want our identities back .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;17	We want to join the world again . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;18	The stigma goes back to biblical times , when victims of leprosy were banished from communities under penalty of death , forced to wear cowbells around their necks and hoods and robes to hide their lesions .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;19	They remained outcasts through the centuries , even as science slowly peeled away the mysteries of their disease and discovered a combination of drugs that reversed the effects of leprosy bacteria .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;20	Today , with researchers expecting to announce a revolutionary anti-leprosy vaccine by 2000 , the disease still inspires fear and prejudice .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;21	The 1988 edition of Webster 's New World Dictionary , for example , defines a victim of leprosy as `` a person to be shunned or ostracized , because of the danger of moral contamination . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;22	`` Leprosy must be shifted from being just a medical problem to a social problem , '' says Dr. Joon Lew , chairman of the Lew Institute for Biomedical Research in Seoul , South Korea .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;23	`` Even if a vaccine is developed to prevent leprosy , you simply ca n't continue to ignore or treat with contempt millions of people who once had or are still treating the disease . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;24	The idea of a defense league began in August 1993 , during the 14th World Leprosy Congress in Orlando , Fla. , where 2,000 doctors and scientists gathered to discuss progress on vaccine research .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;25	Law , a medical and cultural historian , said a token number of 20 former leprosy patients were allowed to attend , but they were not permitted to meet any of the scientists , let alone address the conference .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;26	`` That was the last straw , '' Nunes says .
APW_ENG_19941201.0591;27	`` The doctors had no time for the people they were supposed to be helping , only for their cold medical data and theories . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;0	With donations from private and church groups , the league brought patients from leprosy colonies around the world to Brazil , where as many as a half-million people have leprosy -- second highest in the world behind India .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;1	After a life of fear and isolation , people who had never been allowed to ride a bus , obtain a passport , or shake hands with non-victims were suddenly face to face with foreigners who wanted to hear their story .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;2	Kong began by telling a tale of a life half-lived , an existence stunted by ignorance , prejudice and fear .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;3	After the Communist revolution of 1949 , Kong , like most of the half-million Chinese then afflicted with leprosy , was kept quarantined in a far-off colony because the government lacked the drugs available to treat the disease .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;4	For 13 years , he and 200 other patients never went farther than the hospital compound , never knowing when or if they would ever leave .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;5	Kong learned to read and write , and eventually married another patient .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;6	After dawn on Nov. 16 , 1960 , a medic shook him awake as he slept in his cot .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;7	`` You 're cured , '' said the medic , and walked out of the room .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;8	But by then , Kong 's family had moved away without a trace .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;9	He could n't find a job or a housing development that would take him .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;10	Months later , he and his wife returned to the colony to stay .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;11	Another participant , Guanzhou Chen , 45 , of China 's Guandong province , said he was interned at age 7 at a state colony .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;12	But although he was cured four years later , his family did not want him back .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;13	`` Fear was in their eyes , in their hearts , '' he said through an interpreter .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;14	`` So I returned to the colony .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;15	I never wanted to leave it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;16	I can not stand the rejection again . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;17	Chen said he tried to find a job in the `` outside world , '' but in 30 years has not been formally employed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;18	These days he fixes washing machines and television sets on the side to make extra spending money .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;19	But even for those who escaped the colonies , the wounds of social prejudice have not healed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;20	A South Korean executive told the gathering how he , too , was rejected by friends and family after contracting leprosy at a young age .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;21	He was cured of the disease quickly , but the stigma still haunts him .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;22	`` Please , do not give my name , or any details .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;23	It could wreck my business , '' he pleaded with a visiting reporter .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;24	`` No one knows where I am , and they should n't know , please . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;25	A special challenge for the league is how to raise money without pandering to stereotypes and at a time when donations for nonprofit organizations worldwide are drying up .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;26	`` We have to get away from the old fund-raising campaigns that showed horrible pictures of lepers solely to evoke pity , '' Law said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;27	`` Those images helped get money , but they also reinforced the stereotype of a miserable leper .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;28	We need to get away from that , to portray lepers as people with dignity , who are willing and able to work to survive . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;29	Pamela Parlapiano , a New York City resident who has photographed victims of Hansen 's disease from Africa to the Amazon , showed a picture of an Indian man with one hand carrying a clay pot of building materials to build a modest home .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;30	`` The idea is to show their ability , not dwell on their disability , '' Parlapiano said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;31	As the conference ended , the former patients hugged and kissed each other , and several wept .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;32	Kong extended his gnarled hand to a reporter .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;33	He squeezed tightly , his eyes shining and watery , reluctant to let go .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;34	`` This is the first week Mr. Kong has ever touched or shaken the hand of a person who never had leprosy , '' explained Dr. Wang Yang Shen , a specialist at the Hongwei Hospital in Beijing .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;35	`` For him , it is a special day .
APW_ENG_19941201.0592;36	It is the first time he has felt completely human in so long a time . ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0594;0	An unmanned Ariane rocket carrying an American communications satellite crashed into the Atlantic Ocean 15 minutes after blastoff Thursday due to failure in the third-stage engine , which was using a new fuel mix .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;1	Technicians at the Arianespace launching pad on the edge of the South American jungle said that the third-stage engine inexplicably lost pressure 218 kilometers -LRB- 135 miles -RRB- above Earth .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;2	The failure indicated continuing problems in the third stage .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;3	In January , a third-stage breakdown forced engineers to explode a rocket in mid-flight .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;4	A Turkish and a European telecommunications satellites were also destroyed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;5	Six perfect launches followed .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;6	Thursday 's crash was the seventh in 70 launches since the European Space Agency 's commercial Arianespace program lifted off 15 years ago .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;7	It should not shake Ariane 's dominance as the world 's most successful launcher of lucrative private satellites .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;8	`` We hope to get back into operation very quickly , '' said Charles Bigot , Arianespace 's chief executive officer , who apologized to the dlrs 150 million satellite 's owners .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;9	An investigation was opened immediately and a news conference scheduled for Friday to explain the initial findings .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;10	Liftoff was on schedule at 7:38 p.m.
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;11	The first two stages fired perfectly and controllers confidently expected another of what have become almost routine shots for the Ariane launchers .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;12	The third stage also lit properly , but then mysteriously sputtered and went out .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;13	Officials said that the third stage was a new type using a new oxygen-hydrogen mixture to maximize performance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;14	The rocket took down with it a 2,985-kilogram -LRB- 3.3-ton -RRB- PanAmSat-3 telecommunications satellite built by Hughes Space and Communications in El Segundo , California .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;15	Belonging to PanAmSat of Greenwich , Conn. , the satellite would have channeled telephone , fax and television communications for most of North and South America , Europe and Africa over 15 years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;16	It would have traveled in geostationary orbit over the mid-Atlantic .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;17	January 's accident was blamed on a turbo-pump failure freezing the third-stage rocket motor .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;18	That failure followed 26 straight successful launches in which the European rocket distanced itself from its competitors , the United States and China .
APW_ENG_19941201.0594;19	The Arianes have put 94 satellites in orbit and have a backlog of 38 .

APW_ENG_19941201.0595;9	He has to grab the bull by the horns -LRB- take the initiative -RRB- and this is what he has done . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;10	Bowe , who weighed 247 pounds -LRB- 112 kilos -RRB- for his aborted return to the ring in August against Buster Mathis Jr. , claims to be in his best shape since beating Holyfield in November 1992 to win the titles .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;11	On Thursday , Bowe weighed in at 241 pounds -LRB- 109 kilos -RRB- , a drop of six pounds -LRB- 3 kilos -RRB- from his last fight .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;12	Donald was at 228 pounds -LRB- 103 kilos -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;13	If Bowe is in the shape he claims to be , it 's because of a talk from Futch , his 83-year-old trainer , coupled with the shock of seeing the 45-year-old Foreman knock Michael Moorer out to win two-thirds of the title .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;14	`` The Foreman fight really ticked me off , '' Bowe said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;15	`` It 's unfortunate Michael Moorer is dumber than all outdoors .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;16	Why would you stand in front of George Foreman like that ?
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;17	After watching Foreman beat Michael Moorer , I became more determined . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;18	Futch had earlier threatened to leave Bowe 's New Orleans training camp unless the former champion rededicated himself to his training efforts .

APW_ENG_19941201.0595;21	I am here for you , '' ' Futch said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;22	The message seems to have sunk in for Bowe , who many thought would hold the heavyweight titles a long time after handing Holyfield his first loss .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;23	Instead , Bowe defended the title with two quick knockouts over Jesse Ferguson and Michael Dokes , then lost them last November in a close 12-round decision .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;24	`` I still think I won that fight , '' Bowe said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;25	`` I wanted to knock Evander Holyfield out so bad because no one had ever done that .

APW_ENG_19941201.0595;27	I allowed him to get too close to me . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;28	The 27-year-old Bowe , 34-1 with 29 knockouts , came into the Holyfield rematch 11 pounds heavier than he was when he won the title .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;29	Although both he and Futch said the extra weight was simply a result of Bowe continuing to grow , it seemed to take a toll on him during the fight .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;30	`` As long as I 'm in shape , I beat all the heavyweights out there , '' Bowe said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0595;31	`` They can only hope I 'm fat and come in out of condition . ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0595;35	Winning that title could give him the leverage needed to get the big fights .

APW_ENG_19941201.0595;37	`` I know I 'm the best heavyweight in the world and to see these guys out there as heavyweight champions , its ludicrous . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;0	Ernesto Zedillo began his term as Mexico 's president by vowing to clean up the justice system , fight poverty , strengthen democracy and renew efforts to end a Indian revolt in southern Mexico .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;1	Zedillo , who rose from youth as a shoeshine boy to earn an economics doctorate from Yale , was sworn in Thursday before 1,500 Mexican and foreign officials at the Chamber of Deputies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;2	He received the green , white and red presidential slash from former President Salinas de Gortari to begin a six-year-term at the helm of this nation of 90 million .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;3	`` We think he will be a good president ! ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;4	said Carmen Valencia , a 60-year-old housewife .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;5	`` He came from below and understands poverty . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;6	About 80 protesters among a crowd of hundreds clashed with riot police , hurling rocks and burning two vehicles after the ceremony .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;7	Police responded with tear gas .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;8	A Red Cross spokesman said 58 people were injured .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;9	The protesters had emerged from a peaceful gathering by about 10,000 at the Monument of the Revolution in downtown Mexico City .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;10	They shouted `` Out with Zedillo ! ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;11	and called for an end to the 65-year rule of his Institutional Revolutionary Party , or PRI .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;12	Zedillo , 42 , said one of his first acts would be to introduce a constitutional amendment for a `` profound transformation '' of the justice system , now subservient to politicians and often accused of corruption .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;13	He also vowed to balance the overwhelming power of the presidency by strengthening congress and local governments and to end the presidential practice of dominating PRI affairs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;14	`` If he fulfills what he said about not interfering with the party , then it will be a a great parting of the waters for reforms in the PRI , '' said Augustine Basave , a former PRI congressman from Monterrey .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;15	On the economic front , Zedillo promised to follow in the free-market footsteps of Salinas , who signed the North American Free Trade Agreement , slashed inflation and privatized hundreds of state-owned companies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;16	`` I shall continue to apply those principles in order to preserve our national sovereignty and promote Mexico 's legitimate interests in a world of keen competition ... '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;17	The ceremony was attended by representatives of 63 nations , including Vice President Al Gore , Cuban President Fidel Castro and Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;18	`` Mexico has certainly prospered , '' said Zedillo .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;19	But he added , `` We can not feel fully satisfied .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;20	Many millions of Mexicans lack the bare essentials . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;21	The bookish Zedillo would not have been at the helm of one of the most powerful presidencies in the world had it not been for the March 23 assassination of Luis Donaldo Colosio , the hand-picked successor to Salinas .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;22	Many Mexicans say they doubt the official theory of a lone gunman .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;23	Another killing shook the nation in September , when PRI secretary-general Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu was gunned down .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;24	Prosecutors charged that senior members of the ruling party were involved , possibly as an effort to stop reforms .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;25	`` The brutal assassinations of two of Mexico 's most outstanding public figures have deeply hurt our citizens , '' Zedillo said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;26	`` Thus , the investigations have not been to the entire satisfaction of society .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;27	We ... want to be sure that we know the truth . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;28	One of Zedillo 's biggest challenges comes from the southern state of Chiapas , where Indian guerrillas have refused to end a rebellion that has been stalled since a Jan. 12 cease-fire .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;29	`` I am convinced that it is possible to achieve a new negotiation in Chiapas that will lead us to a just , honorable and definitive peace , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0596;30	He promised the army would maintain the unilateral cease-fire .

APW_ENG_19941201.0597;4	It has been generally acknowledged there must be a labor agreement in place by mid-December to assure a season .
APW_ENG_19941201.0597;5	Neither side would characterize Thursday 's talks , but the Canadian Press reported the union had dropped its desired salary ceiling to dlrs 1.25 million from dlrs 1.5 million for first-round players , while the NHL remained at dlrs 700,000 .

APW_ENG_19941201.0597;7	The league also proposed that only two players per team per year be eligible for salary arbitration .
APW_ENG_19941201.0597;8	The NHL players union wants arbitration to be binding .
APW_ENG_19941201.0597;9	The two sides did agree that , in an arbitration case , an unrestricted free agent 's contract can not be used to provide comparisons and arrive at a decision , a source told CP .
APW_ENG_19941201.0597;10	On free agency , both sides agreed that players shall become unrestricted free agents upon reaching the age of 28 .

APW_ENG_19941201.0600;0	Russia has decided not to proceed with a threatened lawsuit that could have sought hundreds of thousands of dollars from Nova Scotia fishermen who blockaded a Russian ship last year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;1	`` It certainly is a relief that they 're not pursuing it , '' said Cliff Fanning of the Eastern Fishermen 's Federation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;2	In July 1993 , fishermen from Fanning 's group and the South West Nova Scotia Fixed Gear Association blockaded the fish-carrying freighter Pioner Murmana as it unloaded at the Continental Seafoods plant in Shelburne , N.S. , in July 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;3	Hemmed in by fishing boats , the freezer ship could n't move for seven days .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;4	Ivan Vidaneev , Russia 's fishery agent in Nova Scotia , said the Russian government company that owns the Pioner Murmana consulted a Nova Scotia law firm but then decided against the suit .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;5	Vidaneev said he believes there was enough publicity during the blockade to ensure that the Canadians responsible for the losses to the Russian government could be identified .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;6	However , he cited four complications that made the case difficult to pursue :
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;7	Vidaneev warned , however , that the decision might be different if there are similar blockades in the future .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;8	The Murmansk-based Pioner Mirmana was unloading 12,000 tonnes of frozen fish from the Barents Sea for processing at the Continental Seafoods plant in Shelburne when fishing boats blocked it from leaving .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;9	Cod stocks in the Barents Sea , between Russia and Norway , have been recovering while stocks off Atlantic Canada have declined to the point where the fishery is banned in most areas .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;10	The blockading fishermen were angry that Russian and other foreign vessels are allowed to fish in Canadian waters for low-value species such as silver hake , mackerel and squid that Canadians do n't want .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;11	There was a widely held belief among the blockading fishermen that the Pioner Murmana obtained the cod from Russian trawlers in Canadian waters , not the Barents Sea .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;12	Fisheries officials have said subsequently that genetic tests confirmed the fish was from the Barents Sea .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;13	However , Fanning said he still does n't believe it .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;14	`` It was n't Barents Sea cod ; it was our cod , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;15	The seven-day blockade was costly not only for the Pioner Murmana but also for the Russian factory trawler Dauriya , fishing in North American waters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;16	The Pioner Murmana 's next job after unloading at Shelburne was to take on the Dauriya catch at sea .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;17	The Dauriya had to stop fishing because it was full to capacity .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;18	Anatoliy Mikhailov , the Russian fishery agent at the time of the blockade , had talked about suing the fishermen for about $ 250,000 US -LRB- $ 322,250 Cdn -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;19	Meanwhile , hopes of developing a Canadian fishery for silver hake and processing the under-utilized species at an idle fish plant in Lockeport , N.S. , have never materialized .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;20	The fishermen remain upset that foreigners are still being allowed to fish such species in Canadian waters .
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;21	`` Instead of encouraging foreign allocation and having no real hold over these people , why not encourage our own fleets to develop those fisheries ? ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0600;22	`` Ports are folding up and here 's a way of keeping them open . ''

APW_ENG_19941201.0609;0	Prime Minister Paul Keating 's Labor government faces a problem that most national leaders would envy : a booming economy growing faster than that of any other developed nation .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;1	The Australian economy , which only a year ago still lingered in the doldrums of recession , may be overheating and heading for a boom-bust cycle , economists , executives and the conservative opposition say .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;2	If that 's true , Keating will be compelled to give up 1996 tax cuts he promised the public when he was elected last year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;3	In fact , Keating is already sending signals that higher taxes are on the way .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;4	Interest rates may also be boosted to restrain the economy , another move that would rub voters raw by increasing mortgage lending rates .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;5	Keating must call a general election by May 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;6	With the opposition at a record low in the polls , there has been speculation Keating would take advantage of that to call an early election in the first months of 1995 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;7	But if Keating 's government has to load tax hikes rather than cuts on the public , and raise interest rates , he probably will want to wait and let tempers cool off .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;8	The clearest sign of an overheated economy emerged this week with economic growth hitting a rate of 6.4 percent a year , the highest in the developed world , coupled with low inflation of about 1 percent a year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;9	Six months ago , the government had forecast a 4 percent growth rate , and warned anything over 5 percent could not be sustained .

''

APW_ENG_19941201.0609;12	But Thursday night , he signalled that tax hikes were the way to go by endorsing Willis ' remarks .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;13	Trade Minister Bob McMullan said Friday that Australians would vote for a government that introduced higher taxes if it was the right decision for the country .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;14	`` If we make a decision whether it 's about taxes or something else that 's on the face of it unpopular but good for the country , they 'll vote for it , '' he said .

APW_ENG_19941201.0609;16	He obviously relishes a chance to campaign against the Labor Party 's purported `` tax-and-spend '' policies .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;17	Long - and short-term rates on the Australian financial markets jumped when the growth figures came out , reflecting fears that overheated growth would spur inflation , prodding the government to increase interest rates to cope with it .

APW_ENG_19941201.0609;19	That would raise the average monthly mortgage rate by dlrs 114 -LRB- dlrs 87 U.S. -RRB- .

APW_ENG_19941201.0609;21	After all , they point out that inflation is still low , unemployment is declining , business investment in the economy has rebounded since the recession .
APW_ENG_19941201.0609;22	`` We do n't need to run around in a great panic about the fact that the economy is blowing its head off , '' Willis said .

APW_ENG_19941201.0618;0	Citizens in the Maldives archipelago voted Friday to elect a new 48-member Parliament which has little say in the Indian Ocean islands ' administration that is controlled by the President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom .
APW_ENG_19941201.0618;1	Forty lawmakers will be elected by the 109,072 voters in the daylong poll , while Gayoom will appoint eight others .
APW_ENG_19941201.0618;2	The results of the elections , held once in five years , will be known in six days , since the ballot boxes have to be ferried by boats from 19 atolls to the capital Male for counting .
APW_ENG_19941201.0618;3	Gayoom , who has ruled the nation comprising 1,196 Indian Ocean coral islands since 1978 , has promised to share powers with parliament , but there has n't been any transfer so far .
APW_ENG_19941201.0618;4	Serving his fourth term in office , Gayoom has instead banned political parties and crushed all forms of opposition to him by banishing dissenters to uninhabited islands .
APW_ENG_19941201.0618;5	But for the first time , many of the 248 candidates contesting the polls were publicly canvassing for votes this year , promising democracy , said a Maldivian diplomat in Colombo .

APW_ENG_19941201.0618;8	There have been no problems so far , '' Election Commissioner Abdullah Rashid told The Associated Press on telephone from Male .
APW_ENG_19941201.0618;9	Only 220 islands in the Maldives are inhabited by 200,000 people who are predominantly Muslim .
APW_ENG_19941201.0618;10	The islands are located 640-kilometers -LRB- 400-miles -RRB- south west of Sri Lanka .
APW_ENG_19941201.0618;11	About 55 islands have been developed as tourist resorts , which provide most of the nation 's earnings .
APW_ENG_19941201.0618;12	The country also exports fish and garments .
APW_ENG_19941201.0618;13	The Maldives remained a sultanate until 1897 when it was colonized by the British .
APW_ENG_19941201.0618;14	It won independence in 1965 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;0	China 's leaders are united behind an economic plan for 1995 to control the rapidly growing economy and curb runaway inflation , the country 's newspapers reported Friday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;1	The announcement that reforms would continue with no major changes followed four days of closed meetings on economic problems by top Communist Party leaders .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;2	`` China will continue to strengthen macroeconomic control over the national economy in order to seek a sustainable , rapid and healthy economic development next year , '' the Xinhua News Agency said in summing up the meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee and the State Council , or Cabinet .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;3	The latest announcement was placed on front pages of all major newspapers Friday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;4	Continuing policies include strict control of bank credit , the reports said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;5	China 's leaders already had announced that controlling inflation , now running over 20 percent , and reforming failing state enterprises would be top goals for the new year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;6	State-run industries account for about half of China 's industrial output , and just under half of them have been losing money .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;7	Fearing social instability , the government has so far stopped short of massive layoffs or cutting social services tied to state jobs .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;8	The growth rate this year has been over 11 percent .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;9	Other priorities listed in the latest economic plan included more spending on agriculture to ensure adequate food production .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;10	In an editorial on Friday , the People 's Daily , the mouthpiece of the party , outlined some of the economic problems facing China .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;11	The gap is growing between rich industrial areas and poor , rural inland areas , it noted .
APW_ENG_19941201.0619;12	In addition , high inflation for the past two years has aroused concern throughout society , it said , warning that while some inflation during rapid economic growth was unavoidable , too much was dangerous .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;0	Norway overcame an 11-second deficit to beat out Japan in a Nordic combined sprint relay and win the team event Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;1	The United States finished third , its first medal in a Nordic combined sprint relay and the first Nordic combined medal of any kind for the United States since 1983 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;2	`` I understand now what it takes to be an Olympic champion and World Cup champion .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;3	These guys -LRB- the Norwegians -RRB- have worked very hard and hopefully in a few years I 'll be the same caliber as they are , '' said American Todd Lodwick , who posted jumps of 112 and 112.5 meters to top the Americans in that phase .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;4	`` This is the first time I 've ever been on a World Cup podium and it 's pretty damn exciting . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;5	The Norwegian victory produced a double for Knut Tore Apeland , who won the individual event on Tuesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;6	His teammate , 1994 Olympic individual champion Fred Boerre Lundberg , added the team gold to the bronze he won Tuesday .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;7	`` You never know in cross-country , '' Lundberg said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;8	`` You could break a ski or ski off the track , but , yes , if everything was OK we were quite sure of winning . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;9	Japan 's Takanori Kono and Tsuguhara Ogiwara won the jumping phase Thursday afternoon with 463.6 points to Norway 's 460.1 and 448.4 for Lodwick and teammate Ryan Heckman .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;10	Under the scoring system used for Nordic combined , jump points are converted into a time penalty used for the start of the cross-country race .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;11	That meant that Norway would start 11 seconds behind Japan , with the Americans another 35 seconds behind .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;12	Midway through Norway 's second 1.2-kilometer lap , Lundberg went past Ogiwara on an uphill section and began to pull away .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;13	At the end of 15 kilometers , the Norwegians were almost a minute ahead .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;14	Norway completed both events in an adjusted time of 35 minutes , 31.1 seconds .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;15	Japan hit the finish in 36:30.2 and the United States in 38:14.1 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;16	Making the biggest move among the 13 teams was Finland , which moved from ninth in the jumps to fourth overall , 44 seconds behind the United States .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;17	The Finns posted the fastest time in the relay .
APW_ENG_19941201.0621;18	The Czech Republic , Switzerland , a second Japanese team , Austria , France and Germany rounded out the top 10 .

APW_ENG_19941201.0623;1	The list is based on a survey of the performance of the nearly 20,000 joint-stock companies across China , the China Daily said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0623;2	The newspaper did n't spell out in detail how it made the rankings but said profits and gross assets were the two major gauges of the companies ' performance .
APW_ENG_19941201.0623;3	The Fujian Jiuzhou Group Co.
APW_ENG_19941201.0623;4	Ltd. was the top joint-stock company in the trade sector , the report said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0623;5	Included in the list were 23 companies whose annual sales exceeded 2 billion yuan -LRB- dlrs 235 million -RRB- last year .
APW_ENG_19941201.0623;6	Of the 300 top joint stock companies , 107 ranked among the China 's 500 largest enterprises .
APW_ENG_19941201.0623;7	The shares of 51 percent of the 300 companies are listed in Shenzhen or Shanghai .
APW_ENG_19941201.0623;8	Some of the companies have issued shares only to staff members or business partners .
APW_ENG_19941201.0623;9	The report quoted Hong Hu , a State Commission for Economic Restructuring official , as saying the survey showed the vitality of the shareholding system , paving the way for the reform of China 's state-owned enterprises .
APW_ENG_19941201.0623;10	Regular monitoring of the share-holding system will help improve companies ' economic performance and will make investors in China 's fledgling stock markets more confident , Fu Fengxiang of the China Securities Regulatory Commission said .

APW_ENG_19941201.0625;0	The once grand idea of U.N. peacekeeping as a global 911 appears to be fading as the United Nations closes shop in Somalia and faces humiliation in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;1	With the United Nations in apparent retreat , observers are saying that future peacekeeping is likely to shy away from where it is needed most : the front lines .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;2	Bosnia is a `` bucket of cold water on ambitious plans for peacekeeping , '' said Richard Betts , professor of political science at Columbia University .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;3	`` I think there is a great future for peacekeeping that does not matter very much , and a very shaky future for messier operations . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;4	That seemed apparent this week .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;5	As Serb militiamen held hundreds of peacekeepers hostage and pounded a U.N.-declared safe haven in Bosnia , the Security Council met in New York , but high on its agenda was the Golan Heights , not Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;6	The quick meeting extending the mandate for the Israeli-Syrian border mission highlighted a U.N. success -- a mission where both sides want peace and the border is quiet .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;7	The council talks later dragged on about Bosnia , but without direct action .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;8	`` Peacekeeping is the role of referee , '' said Dan Plesch , director of the British-American Security Information Council in London .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;9	`` You can separate warring parties who want to be separated . ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;10	But in instances like Bosnia and Somalia , where the sides are n't willing to stop fighting , the United Nations is refusing to order its peacekeepers to separate the sides .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;11	Such a direct role would be war , not peacekeeping , council members say .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;12	Many observers say missions like those in Golan and Cyprus -- with clear and limited objectives such as monitoring borders or delivering aid to war zones -- are likely to expand in the coming years .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;13	`` But we will also see peacekeeping used by the United States and other powers as a way of repackaging war , '' Plesch said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;14	He cited Haiti and Georgia as examples .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;15	The United States pushed the Council to authorize military intervention in Haiti , offering its own soldiers to lead the mission that will give way to a U.N. peacekeeping force .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;16	Russia would like to do much the same in Georgia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;17	It has already sent its own troops to the former Soviet republic , but is pressing the United Nations to take over the mission .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;18	While Bosnia -- with 24,000 soldiers or almost a third of all U.N. peacekeepers -- would prove the greatest U.N. peacekeeping failure if it collapses , the United Nations has lost face on other missions .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;19	It was unable to foster peace in Somalia , and decided this fall to wind down its two-year mission .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;20	In Liberia , observers have been abused and humiliated by the warring factions .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;21	U.N. officials bristle at criticisms that peacekeeping has been ineffective and say the problem is that world leaders are not willing to commit the troops or money to ambitious peacekeeping operations .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;22	The world body is being made a scapegoat for the lack of global will to act , said Kofi Annan , the head of U.N. peacekeeping .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;23	`` It is absolutely unfair when member states do not want to take the risks , when they do not want to commit the resources , but blame the U.N. for failure to act , '' Annan said .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;24	U.N. peacekeeping costs have ballooned to $ 3.8 billion for the year ending April 1994 , but by October , members still owed the world body $ 1.6 billion for peacekeeping .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;25	There are some 80,000 U.N. peacekeepers worldwide .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;26	U.N. missions involved only about 10,000 soldiers in 1987 .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;27	With a more isolationist Congress coming into power in Washington , it is unlikely the United States -- which pays about a third of the peacekeeping budget -- would be willing to pay for additional operations that are not directly in the U.S. interest .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;28	`` There may be other Bosnias , but I do n't think there will be another UNPROFOR , '' said William Durch , a senior associate at the Henry L. Stimson Center in Washington .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;29	`` If the West is not willing to act on its own doorstep why would it do it elsewhere ? ''
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;30	UNPROFOR is the peacekeeping mission in former Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;31	Lewis MacKenzie , a veteran of nine peacekeeping operations and the former head of the Sarajevo operation , points out that despite its shortcomings , the U.N. mission in Bosnia still ensures that millions of people receive food every day .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;32	And the retired major-general says that despite the problems , there is still a need for peacekeeping .
APW_ENG_19941201.0625;33	`` People who talks about the loss of credibility will be on bended knees before the U.N. at the next crisis , '' MacKenzie said .

APW_ENG_19941202.0001;3	Parole is normally granted to inmates deemed to have been sufficiently rehabilitated .

APW_ENG_19941202.0001;5	Kennedy , whose brother , President John F. Kennedy , was assassinated in 1963 , had just won California 's Democratic presidential primary and finished thanking supporters moments before he was shot .
APW_ENG_19941202.0001;6	He died the next day .
APW_ENG_19941202.0001;7	Sirhan , a Christian Arab born in Jerusalem , said later that he was mad at Kennedy for supporting a shipment of 50 Phantom jets to Israel .
APW_ENG_19941202.0001;8	In 1969 , Sirhan was sentenced to die in California 's gas chamber , but the state Supreme Court declared unconstitutional the death penalty law in effect then .
APW_ENG_19941202.0001;9	That left Sirhan with a life sentence and the right to seek parole .
APW_ENG_19941202.0001;10	Sirhan is jailed at a special housing unit at California State Prison-Corcoran , 200 miles -LRB- 320 kilometers -RRB- north of Los Angeles .

APW_ENG_19941202.0004;1	Coast Guard spokesman Lt. Cmdr. Amado Samante said 449 other passengers had been rescued and the search was continuing for others .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;2	The dead included 11-month-old Jade Gonzales , said his mother Imelda , 26 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;3	She said another son , aged five , was fine but her 3-year-old son was missing .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;4	Another survivor , Erwin Maravilla , described the terrifying scene after the two ships hit .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;5	`` We were sleeping .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;6	Suddenly we heard a crash .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;7	I grabbed my two children , but when the ferry sank we were sucked under the water with it .

APW_ENG_19941202.0004;9	`` I was lucky to be able to swim to the surface .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;10	Otherwise I would be dead , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;11	He was one of the first group of survivors plucked from the sea by a navy patrol .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;12	The 12,500-ton , Singapore-registered Kota Suria , with a crew of 26 , suffered damage to its port bow but was joining the rescue effort , carrying 230 of those saved .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;13	There was no immediate cause reported for the accident , which occurred in calm seas under clear night skies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;14	The 2,452-ton ferry , the Cebu City , sank 30 minutes after the collision .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;15	Maximo Calamba , 38 , who survived the accident with wife Veneranda , 30 , and one-year-old son Marcelo , complained that the ferry crew failed to inform them about the approaching freighter and did not help people evacuate the ship after the collision .

APW_ENG_19941202.0004;17	We were thrown off our cots and everybody was on their own , '' Calamba said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;18	`` When we were rescued by the Suria I could still hear crying out for help . ''

APW_ENG_19941202.0004;20	At least eight patrol boats , a search and rescue ship and several other inter-island ferries were trying to recover survivors , it said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0004;21	The Cebu City had a capacity of 800 passengers , said a spokesman for the Williams Lines shipping company .

APW_ENG_19941202.0004;24	It had left the port of Manila bound for Tagbilaran , capital of Bohol Island , about 560 kilometers -LRB- 350 miles -RRB- southeast of Manila .

APW_ENG_19941202.0006;6	`` This situation necessitated two operations to drain and amputate the leg and control the infection , '' said D'Amico .
APW_ENG_19941202.0006;7	Radio-Canada and CTV , a Canadian television network , reported that Bouchard has a rare flesh-eating disease which has been linked to about a dozen deaths in Britain , one in Canada and few in other countries .
APW_ENG_19941202.0006;8	His doctors were reportedly conferring with specialists in Britain .
APW_ENG_19941202.0006;9	The rapidly-spreading disease is caused by a virulent form of streptococcus bacteria that enters the body through a cut or a wound and produces an infection .

APW_ENG_19941202.0009;0	Japan 's lower house of parliament passed the GATT world trade accord Friday , virtually assuring the world 's second-largest economy would adopt the landmark deal .
APW_ENG_19941202.0009;1	It also passed a six-year , 7.2 trillion yen -LRB- dlrs 74 billion -RRB- package of subsidies and aid to rural areas to quell farmers ' opposition to the accord , which opens Japan 's rice market for the first time .

APW_ENG_19941202.0009;7	He predicted Japan 's upper house would follow the more powerful lower chamber 's lead and approve the accord in time for it to take effect as planned Jan. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0009;8	Approval was expected next week .

APW_ENG_19941202.0009;10	The parliament there was conducting debate Friday in moving closer to approving the deal .
APW_ENG_19941202.0009;11	Under the plan , the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will be superseded Jan. 1 by the stronger World Trade Organization as the world 's main arbiter of trade disputes .
