APW_ENG_19941202.0067;29	In an effort to heal the wounds , Secretary of State Warren Christopher swung behind the European view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941202.0067;30	It was a major policy switch by Washington under pressure from the Europeans , led by Britain and France .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;0	U.S. intelligence in the late 1950s foresaw that the Soviets would make long-range missiles a focus of their nuclear arms buildup but greatly underestimated the surge once it began , newly declassified records show .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;1	The records , released Friday by the CIA at a Harvard University conference , paint a picture of American intelligence analysts in the early Cold War years struggling to understand Soviet military intentions with little hard information .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;2	The reports , prepared jointly by the CIA and the other main U.S. spy agencies , contain what the CIA called the most sensitive intelligence information ever made public .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;3	Although the CIA and the other U.S. spy agencies failed to recognize fully the 1960s buildup of Soviet missiles capable of striking U.S. soil , they did believe that whatever the size of the Soviet nuclear arsenal , it was not designed for deliberate attack on America .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;4	In fact the analysts generally ascribed much the same motives for the Soviet nuclear buildup as U.S. officials used to justify America 's : to deter the other side from starting a war and to be able to retaliate and survive if deterrence failed .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;5	This can be seen in many of the 80 formerly top-secret National Intelligence Estimates declassified and made public Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;6	The reports cover the years 1954 through 1983 and were declassified as part of a project started in 1992 to release all Cold War-era intelligence assessments that are at least 10 years old .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;7	The question of Soviet capabilities to launch a nuclear attack on America overshadowed all other issues facing U.S. intelligence for many years after World War II .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;8	The United States , which exploded the world 's first nuclear bomb in 1945 , had a monopoly on nuclear power until the Soviets successfully tested their first bomb in 1949 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;9	From that point the nuclear arms race was on .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;10	In early 1957 , intelligence forecasts put little stock in the threat of a buildup of Soviet intercontinental ballistic missiles , or ICBMs .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;11	Long-range bombers were seen as the main threat in the 1950s and 1960s , although the newly released records show U.S. intelligence greatly overestimated the bomber buildup .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;12	A special top-secret report on Sept. 18 , 1957 , informed President Eisenhower and his national security advisers that the Soviets probably had conducted their first flight tests of ICBMs , the first on Aug. 21 and the second on Sept. 7 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;13	In a follow-up special report to the president on Dec. 10 , the intelligence agencies said they had concluded that ICBM development was `` an extremely high priority in the USSR '' and may already be a rush building program .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;14	As late as 1963 , U.S. intelligence reported it was `` still unable to identify positively any ICBM launching facilities '' other than those at the Tyuratam test range .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;15	In fact the first Soviet ICBMs became operational in 1960 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;16	By 1965 , evidence indicated the Soviets had 224 ICBMs with launch units , but the intelligence reports indicated confusion and disagreement about the scope and pace of the missile production efforts in the USSR .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;17	A year later , in 1966 , U.S. intelligence began doubting its earlier projections .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;18	In 1967 , the U.S. forecasts of future Soviet ICBM deployments were adjusted upward and it was predicted that by 1968 the Soviets would have as many of the long-range missiles as the United State would have -- about 1,000 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;19	As it turned out , the Soviet ICBM force peaked in the 1970s at about 1,400 missiles ; it now is about half that .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;20	The U.S. force peaked at 1,000 and is now about 500 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0068;21	The United States always held an edge in sea-based and air-delivered nuclear arms .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;0	A ferry carrying more than 600 people collided with a Singapore-registered freighter and sank before dawn Friday in Manila Bay , killing at least 34 people , the Coast Guard reported .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;1	Coast Guard spokesman Amado Samante said 449 passengers had been rescued and the search was continuing for others .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;2	The bodies of 34 people who had drowned were recovered , he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;3	The 2,452-ton ferry , the Cebu City , sank 30 minutes after the collision .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;4	There was no immediate official report on the cause of the accident , but the company which owned the Cebu City said it had been rammed by the Singapore-registered freighter Kota Suria .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;5	Eugene Espedino , vice president of the company , said it was preparing a request for the coast guard to detain the freighter and its crew .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;6	Jacob Cabatuan , a crewman on the ferry , said the Kota Suria 's bow crashed into the Cebu City , destroying the bridge and ripping a one-meter -LRB- three-foot -RRB- hole in the lower deck .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;7	He said ship captain Wesceslao Lampong and several other officers were pinned on the bridge .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;8	Erwin Maravilla , one of the first group of survivors plucked from the sea by a navy patrol , said his family was sleeping at the time of the accident .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;9	`` Suddenly we heard a crash .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;10	I grabbed my two children , but when the ferry sank we were sucked under the water with it .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;11	A piece of metal hit my arm , and I lost hold of my two kids , '' he said , adding that his wife was also missing .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;12	`` I was lucky to be able to swim to the surface .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;13	Otherwise I would be dead , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;14	The 12,500-ton Kota Suria , with a crew of 26 , was damaged in its bow but joined the rescue effort , carrying 230 of those saved .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;15	President Fidel Ramos ordered an investigation into the cause of the accident , which occurred in calm seas under clear night skies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;16	Maximo Calamba , 38 , who survived with his wife Veneranda , 30 , and 1-year-old son Marcelo , complained that the ferry crew failed to inform them about the approaching freighter and did not help people evacuate the ship after the collision .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;17	`` There was no alarm .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;18	We were thrown off our cots and everybody was on their own , '' Calamba said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;19	`` When we were rescued by the Suria I could still hear crying out for help . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;20	Cargo containers and rubber rafts were floating at the scene , but it was unclear whether there were people aboard , said radio station DZRH , reporting from an airplane overhead .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;21	At least eight patrol boats , a search and rescue ship and several other inter-island ferries were trying to recover survivors , it said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;22	The Cebu City had a capacity of 800 passengers , but only 605 people were on board at the time of the accident , said a spokesman for the Williams Lines shipping company .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;23	The Cebu City sank near the mouth of Manila Bay near the town of Rosario , about 50 kilometers -LRB- 35 miles -RRB- southwest of Manila in Cavite province .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;24	It had left the port of Manila bound for Tagbilaran , the capital of Bohol Island , about 560 kilometers -LRB- 350 miles -RRB- southeast of Manila .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;25	Quirimon Tan , William Lines vice president , said each of the dead passengers was covered by 50,000 pesos -LRB- dlrs 2,173 -RRB- in insurance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;26	He said the company would also pay for medical and funeral expenses .
APW_ENG_19941202.0069;27	The Philippines ' worst peacetime ferry disaster was in December 1987 , when 3,537 people died in the collision of the ferry Dona Paz with the oil tanker Vector off Mindoro Island , about 130 kilometers -LRB- 80 miles -RRB- south of Manila .

APW_ENG_19941202.0070;2	Pakistan defeated Olympic champion Germany 5-3 in a penalty stroke shootout after the teams had drawn 1-1 .

APW_ENG_19941202.0070;4	Top seed Australia got its only goal from 19-year-old substitute Paul Gaudoin following a cleverly worked penalty corner 12 minutes into the second half .
APW_ENG_19941202.0070;5	It was Gaudoin 's first international goal .

APW_ENG_19941202.0070;7	Pakistan converted all five of its penalty strokes , while goalkeeper Mansoor Ahmed made a dramatic diving save to stop Germany 's third stroke -- from captain Christian Blunck .
APW_ENG_19941202.0070;8	Mansoor also saved a penalty stroke from Blunck in the Champions Trophy final in Lahore in March , a game Pakistan won 7-6 on penalties after a 2-2 draw .

APW_ENG_19941202.0070;18	`` We 've proved we are a good side . ''

APW_ENG_19941202.0070;28	The worst miss came two minutes from the end of the game when Andreas Becker was off target with the goal at his mercy .

APW_ENG_19941202.0073;0	What if you were a nation that , after decades of not collecting income and other kinds of taxes , decided to start taxing your citizens and businesses again ?
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;1	And let 's say your new tax system was frequently criticized , generally disliked by the public , plagued by protesters and still struggling two years after adopting a controversial new tax policy .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;2	Where to go for help ?
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;3	Maybe a country with two solid centuries of experience in the fine art of collecting taxes .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;4	One that hauls in more than a trillion dollars a year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;5	Internal Revenue Service Ogden Service Center , meet State Tax Service , headquarters Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;6	A delegation of three high-ranking Russian finance and taxation officials toured the Ogden IRS center Wednesday for a closer look at America 's sophisticated , automated and oft-excoriated system of income tax collection .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;7	Rolling through the center more swiftly than a 1040 Short Form , the delegation observed the flow of work and walked through small canyons of computer hardware merrily going about the business of transferring personal income to federal government .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;8	It was an impressive sight , said Vladilen Vorontsov , head of the Russian Federation State Tax Service 's accounting , reporting and analysis department .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;9	`` Russia is undergoing dramatic changes economically , politically and in terms of its new tax policy and administration , '' said Vorontsov , a slender bespectacled man in his late 50s with gray hair and a flawless pinstripe suit .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;10	The country is entering the third year of a new tax system adopted after the collapse of the Soviet Union 's communist economy , he explained .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;11	The conversion is difficult because of Russia 's present economic situation .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;12	He was accompanied by Alla Zubkova , deputy head of the Russian Federation 's budget department , and Maria Reoutova , head of the STS ' accounting , tax statistics and information division .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;13	The Russian officials were scheduled to wrap up their Ogden visit Thursday with sessions on statistical analysis and tours of the Freeport Center and the U.S. Postal Service building in downtown Ogden .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;14	Vorontsov , who served as spokesman for the trio during an interview , said the delegation found the visit informative and helpful but added there is little chance the new Russian tax system will be modeled after its American counterpart .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;15	For one thing , he said , the Russian system is much simpler with only about a dozen taxes of any kind at the federal level .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;16	Instead , it draws the bulk of its revenues from corporate rather than individual income taxes , which provide only about 10 percent of the federation 's tax collections .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;17	`` Like anyone else , Russians are unwilling to pay taxes , '' Vorontsov noted .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;18	`` The negative attitude is very deep , and I think one of the reasons is our people have had very little tax education .
APW_ENG_19941202.0073;19	`` It will take us quite some time before our taxpayers understand each -LRB- tax -RRB- is a contribution to a civilized society , '' Vorontsov said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0074;0	Among the revelations from the CIA 's newly declassified reports on Soviet nuclear forces : -- In 1963 , the U.S. government was worried that the Soviets might develop an `` orbital bombardment '' system -- one or more satellites with a nuclear bomb aboard .
APW_ENG_19941202.0074;1	The fear was that they would `` de-orbit '' the nuclear warhead and detonate it about 150,000 feet above Earth -- a burst that `` would cause severe damage to cities '' over a large part of the United States , `` primarily by means of fire . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0074;2	The analysts doubted that the Soviets would actually try this , but they cautioned that Moscow was technically able to do it `` at any time . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0074;3	This concern remained at least until the late 1960s , according to the reports .
APW_ENG_19941202.0074;4	-- In 1979 , the intelligence agencies predicted the Soviets would suffer 120 million casualties , including 85 million deaths , in a U.S. nuclear retaliatory strike , assuming minimal warning in Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941202.0074;5	They foresaw 100 million casualties , including 60 million killed , if the Soviets had time to occupy urban bomb shelters .
APW_ENG_19941202.0074;6	If all shelters were occupied and the Soviets had time to fully evacuate other areas , casualties would number 40 million , including 15 million deaths .
APW_ENG_19941202.0074;7	The report contained no comparable estimates of U.S. casualties .
APW_ENG_19941202.0074;8	-- Six months after President Ronald Reagan made his March 1983 `` Star Wars '' speech starting a crash research effort on a global shield against Soviet nuclear missiles , U.S. intelligence agencies foresaw a possibly disastrous Soviet response .
APW_ENG_19941202.0074;9	If the United States actually developed such a missile shield and the Soviets had none , a Sept. 12 , 1983 , report said , the Soviets might attack it militarily .
APW_ENG_19941202.0074;10	They might also clandestinely place nuclear or germ weapons in U.S. and allied cities and threaten to use them in the event of war .

APW_ENG_19941202.0075;11	Russia says it offers the rebels only political support .
APW_ENG_19941202.0075;12	It refuses to recognize independence for Chechnya , which was incorporated into the Russian Empire in the 19th century after a series of long and bloody wars .

APW_ENG_19941202.0075;18	Russian Defense Minister Pavel Grachev has said the prisoners are mercenaries .
APW_ENG_19941202.0075;19	Although Chechens are at odds , they are united in their distrust of Russia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0075;20	In Freedom Square outside Dudayev 's offices , several hundred volunteer fighters cradling Kalashnikov rifles and grenade launchers gathered to hear speeches Thursday while a tank maneuvered into position .
APW_ENG_19941202.0075;21	Elders in tall fur hats , tunics and high leather boots danced in a circle , chanting , `` Freedom or death ! ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0075;22	Russians are generally content to let the Chechens go their own way , according to a poll Thursday by the International Opinion Research Center .
APW_ENG_19941202.0075;23	The poll of 3,250 people said 74.2 percent believe Russia should recognize Chechnya 's independence , while 5.5 percent said it should n't and 20.3 said they could n't answer .
APW_ENG_19941202.0075;24	The margin of error was 1 percent .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;0	NATO foreign ministers sought Friday to reassure Russia that their plans for admitting former Warsaw Pact foes would n't create a new division in Europe .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;1	The ministers opened daylong talks with counterparts from more than 20 East European nations , including Russia , in a session likely to be dominated by Moscow 's unexpected opposition to a plan to expand the Western alliance in the coming years .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;2	Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev stunned the ministers Thursday by protesting the plan for drawing up conditions for future NATO membership .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;3	He also backed out of a program to improve cooperation between Moscow and NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;4	`` I think that we 'll all get -LRB- it -RRB- sorted out ... How soon I do n't know , '' British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said before Friday 's talks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;5	He said ties between Moscow and NATO were `` too important to be lost . ''

APW_ENG_19941202.0076;9	Poland , Hungary , the Czech Republic and others have repeatedly demanded NATO membership and the defense guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;10	To deal with the demands without upsetting Russia , the allies last January backed a U.S. initiative , Partnership for Peace , providing for closer ties without membership .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;11	Russia is among 23 nations enrolled in the project , which allows them to take part in NATO military exercises and other activities .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;12	On Thursday , the allies went further by ordering aides to draft a study of the terms and conditions for expanding NATO eastward .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;13	Meanwhile , the allies granted Russia a special relationship and denied they were forming a hostile bloc .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;14	But Kozyrev told grim-faced NATO ministers : `` If the strategy of NATO has changed , then that is something which requires further discussion . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;15	He refused to endorse a wide-ranging program of military and political contacts with Moscow intended to ease Russia 's fears of an eastward drive by the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;16	`` This communique raises more questions than it answers , '' Kozyrev said in impromptu remarks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;17	`` We have to understand what are the intentions of the other partners . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;18	NATO secretary-general Willy Claes immediately tried to reassure Kozyrev that NATO was n't shifting direction .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;19	`` It is no change in strategy or policy of NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;20	... There is nothing new , '' he told the Russian minister Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;21	`` We are not willing to organize new divisions in Europe . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;22	Kozyrev 's outburst added to the woes of an alliance long strained by U.S.-European disputes over dealing with the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;23	In an effort to mend the rift , U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher swung behind the European view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941202.0076;24	It was a major policy switch by Washington under pressure particularly from Britain and France .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;0	NATO foreign ministers sought Friday to reassure Russia that their plans for admitting former Warsaw Pact foes would n't create a new division in Europe .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;1	The allies opened daylong talks with counterparts from nearly two-dozen nations in Eastern Europe in a session likely to be dominated by Russia 's unexpected opposition to a plan to expand the alliance in the coming years .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;2	Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev stunned the ministers Thursday by protesting the plan for drawing up conditions for future NATO membership .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;3	He also backed out of a program to improve cooperation between Moscow and NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;4	`` I think that we 'll all get -LRB- it -RRB- sorted out ... How soon I do n't know , '' said British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd before Friday 's talks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;5	He said ties between Moscow and NATO were `` too important to be lost . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;6	Willy Claes , the new secretary-general of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization , opened the session by saying : `` The division of Europe has ended .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;7	We have worked ... to ensure that it never returns . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;8	Kozyrev 's comments cast a pall over the meeting and over NATO 's attempt to draw its former Warsaw Pact enemies into its alliance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;9	However , some diplomats suggested he was playing to an audience back in Russia , where the government is contending with a strong nationalist opposition .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;10	Poland 's foreign minister , Andrzej Olechowski , said the foreign ministers would `` explain everything to the Russians -- that -LRB- membership plans -RRB- are n't against them . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;11	`` It 's our problem and the alliance 's problem -- not the Russians ' , '' said Czech Foreign Minister Josef Zieleniec .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;12	Poland , Hungary , the Czech Republic and others have repeatedly demanded NATO membership and the security guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;13	The Russian outburst pushed , at least temporarily , the crisis in Bosnia off the ministers ' agenda .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;14	U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher , Hurd and Kozyrev were meeting later in the day with Foreign Ministers Alain Juppe of France and Klaus Kinkel of Germany to try to revive the peace process in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;15	Christopher wants formal approval from the others for a new diplomatic initiative to try to draw the Bosnian Serbs into negotiations with the Muslims and Croats in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;16	It calls for a cease-fire around Bihac , the northwestern Muslim enclave that Serbs are pummeling , a pledge to cease hostilities throughout the country for three to six months and then an international peace conference .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;17	The lure for the Serbs , who control about 70 percent of Bosnia , is an opportunity to press their demand for cross-border political ties to Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;18	`` The essence of any peace plan is a very substantial Bosnian Serb withdrawal -LRB- and -RRB- continuance of Bosnia-Herzegovina within its own borders , '' Hurd told reporters .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;19	Juppe and Hurd plan to fly to Belgrade this weekend to push the initiative .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;20	The NATO allies , in trying to meet East Europeans demands for membership without upsetting Russia , thought they had found a good formula .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;21	At a summit last January , President Clinton and other allied leaders approved a U.S. initiative , Partnership for Peace , to bring former foes closer , but without membership .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;22	Twenty-three nations , including Russia , have enrolled in the project , which allows them to take part for the first time in military exercises and other alliance activities .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;23	On Thursday , the allies decided to go further by ordering aides to conduct a 12-month study of the terms and conditions for expanding the Western military alliance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;24	To overcome Russian objections to its eastward expansion , NATO had agreed to a special relationship with Moscow and insisted they had no intention of forming a hostile bloc .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;25	But Kozyrev was n't impressed .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;26	`` If the strategy of NATO has changed , then that is something which requires further discussion , '' Kozyrev told a group of grim-faced NATO ministers .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;27	Kozyrev refused to endorse a wide-ranging program of military and political contacts with Moscow intended to ease Russia 's fears of an eastward drive by the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;28	He said he read the ministers ' statement on membership and immediately called Russian President Boris Yeltsin .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;29	`` This communique raises more questions than it answers , '' Kozyrev said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;30	`` We have to understand what are the intentions of the other partners . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;31	U.S. State Department spokesman Mike McCurry said Kozyrev gave no advance warning that he wanted clarification of the schedule for considering new NATO members next year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0077;32	`` I would be tempted to say it has to do with domestic politics in Russia , '' McCurry said .

APW_ENG_19941202.0080;0	Great Britain has canceled half the debt owed it by Vietnam while giving Hanoi more time to pay back the remaining amount , a British diplomat said Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0080;1	Britain formally reduced Vietnam 's debt from dlrs 26 million to dlrs 13 million in an agreement signed in Hanoi Thursday , said Martin Garrett , second commercial secretary at the British embassy .
APW_ENG_19941202.0080;2	The debt consists of principal and interest arising from unpaid bills to British exporters dating as far back as the late 1970s .
APW_ENG_19941202.0080;3	The agreement was a de facto condition for a British aid package of dlrs 75 million in grants and soft loans , Garrett said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0080;4	Britain will make the funds available as soon as Vietnam identifies the projects it wants to finance , he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0080;5	Britain joins other European countries that have taken similar steps to ease Vietnam 's debt burden .
APW_ENG_19941202.0080;6	France agreed in July to cancel dlrs 229 million in Vietnamese debt , while Germany wrote off dlrs 101 million in old loans in August .
APW_ENG_19941202.0080;7	Britain agreed in principle to cancel half its Vietnamese debt at a meeting of creditor nations in November 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0080;8	It played a leading role then in persuading other countries to do the same , Garrett said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0080;9	The diplomat gave no details about the new repayment terms for the remaining loans , except to say that Vietnam would have several years to pay them back .
APW_ENG_19941202.0080;10	Western countries such as Britain are eager to help Vietnam as it replaces socialist central planning with a free market .
APW_ENG_19941202.0080;11	Vietnam 's 72 million people and its average economic growth rate of 7.3 percent during each of the past three years make it an increasingly attractive economic market for them .

APW_ENG_19941202.0081;1	In a speech to French businessmen , Chretien welcomed the growth of regional trading blocs , such as the European Union and the U.S.-Canada-Mexico alliance forged by the North American Free-Trade Agreement -LRB- NAFTA -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941202.0081;2	`` Yet this also entails its share of risk , and I am particularly sensitive to defensive and protectionist attitudes that might lead the major regional blocs to withdraw timidly into their own shells , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0081;3	`` We must overcome the trade disputes that weigh down our relations and create unnecessary fears , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0081;4	`` We should look carefully at the idea of a global trade liberalization agreement between NAFTA and the European Union . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0081;5	He said Canada , which sends 80 percent of its exports to the United States , had experienced a stagnation of its trade relations with Europe .
APW_ENG_19941202.0081;6	`` We must re-energize our economic relations immediately , '' he said , urging closer cooperation in technology , entertainment industries and tourism .
APW_ENG_19941202.0081;7	`` We must strengthen one another 's competitive capacity on American , European , Asian and international markets , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0081;8	`` This is the best way to energize relations between Canada and France , and Canada and Europe , and to fight the temptation of isolation . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0081;9	He noted that France and Canada were well placed to influence transatlantic trade policy , because France holds the rotating presidency of the EU for the first half of 1995 and Canada will host next year 's Group of Seven economic summit .
APW_ENG_19941202.0081;10	Chretien was to meet later Friday with President Francois Mitterrand and Premier Edouard Balladur .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;0	With pleas to end vote-rigging and campaign violence , Taiwan wrapped up weeks of fierce campaigning for a local election Saturday that confronts the island 's rulers with their sternest electoral test in 45 years .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;1	The elections , a milestone in Taiwan 's seven-year shift from virtual dictatorship to democracy , could profoundly affect the future of this economically powerful but diplomatically isolated island .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;2	Victory for the opposition in the races for island governor and mayors of the two main cities would be a severe blow to President Lee Teng-hui 's prospects for another term in 1996 , when Taiwan holds its first direct presidential election .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;3	It also could buffet Taiwan 's fragile relationship with Communist China , its longtime rival .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;4	Where Lee 's Nationalists cling to the old doctrine of reunification with China , the opposition Democratic Progressive Party advocates Taiwanese independence , something China has vowed to resist by force .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;5	So although the election is largely a local affair , it has sparked heated debate among Taiwanese about their identity , the island 's international isolation and the Chinese giant across the Taiwan Straits .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;6	On Thursday , to cries of outrage from the DPP , heads of three major chambers of commerce placed newspaper ads warning that Taiwan 's dollar and the island 's appeal to investors would plummet if pro-independence forces gained power .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;7	The DPP may profit from a split in the Nationalist vote caused by the recently formed New Party , which quit the Nationalists , claiming they had abandoned the ideology of reunification .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;8	The Nationalists have ruled Taiwan since 1949 when they fled Mao Tse-tung 's Communists on mainland China .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;9	They ruled Taiwan by martial law until 1987 before embarking on a bloodless democratic revolution that culminates Saturday in the first election of a governor .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;10	Voters also will choose a provincial assembly , local councilors , and mayors for Taipei and Kaohsiung , which have n't elected their mayors since 1967 and 1979 respectively .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;11	The DPP 's Chen Shui-bian is thought to be a front-runner to become the capital 's mayor , while Nationalist James Soong has a 50-40 lead over the DPP 's Chen Ting-nan in the gubernatorial race , according to the most recent surveys .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;12	Newspapers predict that up to 70 percent of Taiwan 's 13.8 million eligible voters will turn out .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;13	The 11,825 polling stations open at 8:00 a.m. -LRB- 0000 GMT -RRB- , and results are expected about eight hours after polls close at 4 p.m. -LRB- 0800 GMT -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;14	The campaign has been characterized by an almost carnival atmosphere marred by violence that has left some Taiwanese unnerved by the democratic experience .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;15	`` We all have a responsibility to make the poll a success , '' the China News said in an editorial Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;16	`` Otherwise the nation 's political transformation from authoritarianism to pluralism will suffer a severe setback . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;17	Premier Lien Chan instructed officials Thursday to guard against violence , newspapers said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;18	Some 50,000 policemen are being mobilized .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;19	Officials also have appealed to people not to take bribes for votes -- a problem rampant in past elections and this one too .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;20	On Friday , governmemt-controlled TV stations ran advertisements showing vote-buyers being led away handcuffed .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;21	The Justice Ministry says courts have received some 400 complaints of campaign abuses .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;22	On Wednesday the DPP filed a lawsuit accusing the Nationalists of spending at least 150 million Taiwan dollars -LRB- U.S. dlrs 5.6 million -RRB- to buy votes for Huang Ta-chou , Taipei 's incumbent Nationalist mayor who has lagged in opinion polls .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;23	The Nationalists said the money was payment for volunteers distributing campaign leaflets .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;24	President Lee , who is credited with steering Taiwan toward democracy since he took office in 1988 , visited Huang 's campaign office Friday to lend support .
APW_ENG_19941202.0082;25	Huang led a convoy through Taipei 's streets , with supporters waving flags and lighting firecrackers .

APW_ENG_19941202.0084;1	The military last month began blowing up strategic missile silos concealed in the wilderness around Shila as part of nuclear disarmament accords with the United States .
APW_ENG_19941202.0084;2	The ITAR-Tass news agency said the latest silo explosion also blew out windows and shattered crockery and lights for miles around .
APW_ENG_19941202.0084;3	Residents of Shila , who were n't warned about the upcoming blast , were indignant , it said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0084;4	Shila is in the region of Krasnoyarsk , 3,400 kilometers -LRB- 2,100 miles -RRB- east of Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;0	`` Asian values '' are no excuse for corrupt and despotic rule , Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim of Malaysia said Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;1	He said that while the West is guilty of `` patronizing and condescending postures , '' the term `` Asian values '' too often is used to justify `` autocratic practices and denial of basic rights and civil liberties . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;2	He called this Asian attitude `` altogether shameful . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;3	Ibrahim 's speech to a symposium on `` ` Asian Values ' and the Media 's Role in Society '' was a spirited contribution to the debate that has raged in recent years between East and West over the merits of their respective societies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;4	That debate pits advocates of free speech , individual liberties and human rights against some Asian leaders who say such rights are not applicable in their countries , which are still struggling for stability and human rights of a different sort , like freedom from hunger and disease .
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;5	Although Malaysia has been prominent in accusing the West of hitting Asia with double standards , Ibrahim sought to show that the arguments on both sides are flawed .
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;6	He said Asians , in their growing self-confidence over their economic performance , had not shown `` a proportionate awareness '' of their shortcomings .
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;7	`` In all honesty , we must admit that we are still struggling to eradicate the vestiges of the so-called Oriental despotism , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;8	Asia has to `` vigorously develop and fortify the institutions of civil society ... promote the rule of laws rather than of men , and foster the cultivation of a free and responsible press , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;9	Ibrahim also took issue with the notion promoted by some governments , including that of his neighbor , Singapore , who justify their harsh penal codes and detention without trial on the grounds that social stability outweighs individual rights .
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;10	`` It is certainly wrong to regard society as a kind of false god upon whose altar the individual must constantly be sacrificed , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0085;11	`` No Asian tradition can be cited to support the proposition that in Asia the individual must melt into the faceless community . ''

APW_ENG_19941202.0087;0	Police evicted hunger-striking leaders of East Germany 's reformed communists from their own offices in the Berlin parliament building early Friday , so they resumed their interrupted slumber in a theater .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;1	The leaders of the Party of Democratic Socialism -LRB- PDS -RRB- began the fast Wednesday to protest a 67 million mark -LRB- dlrs 43 million -RRB- tax levy they called an unjust political attempt to bankrupt and destroy them .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;2	The politicians , seven including the intellectually agile parliamentary leader Gregor Gysi , initially occupied two federal offices but were removed by police on Wednesday night .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;3	Some 3,000 sympathizers held rallies and sit-ins in Berlin , Schwerin and Dresden on Thursday in support of the party leaders , who were sleeping on cots in their parliamentary offices when police roused and evicted them shortly after midnight .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;4	The parliament 's president , Hanna-Renate Laurien , condemned `` this hunger strike spectacle '' as `` an abuse of the parliament building . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;5	The hunger strikers groggily repaired to a theater across from their party headquarters in east Berlin .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;6	The levy the party is fighting was assessed by Berlin tax authorities based on property sales in the first half of 1990 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;7	At the time , just months before German unification , the newly created PDS held vast assets as successor to the communists .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;8	A large portion of those assets are now controlled by an independent federal commission that is supposed to determine how much of the property they can keep and how much belongs to the people .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;9	The PDS asked the commission to pay the tax bill .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;10	The commission refused , but its board raised questions about why Berlin tax authorities had assessed the PDS in the first place .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;11	A court ruled Thursday that the PDS would only have to pay 3 million marks -LRB- dlrs 1.8 million -RRB- security for the moment , pending further efforts to try to settle the dispute .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;12	But party leaders said they would not pay .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;13	The party won 20 percent of the vote in eastern Germany in Oct. 16 national elections , thanks mainly to resentment among eastern Germans who feel they have been demoted to second-class status in united Germany .
APW_ENG_19941202.0087;14	Chancellor Helmut Kohl has attacked the PDS as `` red-painted fascists , '' and Gysi , a lawyer , has been battered by accusations that in decades past he betrayed the secrets of his dissident clients to the East German secret police .
APW_ENG_19941202.0088;0	Thousands of teachers demonstrated outside Ukrainian government headquarters Friday to protest rising prices and shrinking salaries .
APW_ENG_19941202.0088;1	The three-day strike in Kiev is the most visible sign yet of the increasing unpopularity of an austerity plan President Leonid Kuchma says will eventually put Ukraine on the road to economic health .
APW_ENG_19941202.0088;2	Teachers braved freezing temperatures to brandish placards saying , `` Let -LRB- government -RRB- ministers try and live on teachers salaries ! ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0088;3	Around seventy per cent of Kiev 's 60,000 teachers boycotted classes in protest of an average monthly salary that is the equivalent of about dlrs 10 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0088;4	They have threatened a full strike on January 16 unless something is done to halt the deterioration of the school system .
APW_ENG_19941202.0088;5	`` The last time we saw new text books was over four years ago , '' grumbled Viktor Sichenko , principal of a Russian language school in the Moskva district of Kiev .
APW_ENG_19941202.0088;6	Many prices have recently been freed as part of Kuchma 's reforms .
APW_ENG_19941202.0088;7	As a result , the cost of basics like food , transport , housing and energy has skyrocketed for Ukraine 's 52 million people .
APW_ENG_19941202.0088;8	State employees , who make up the vast majority of this former Soviet republic 's work force , saw their real wages fall by up to 60 per cent in 1993 , according to the International Monetary Fund .

APW_ENG_19941202.0090;0	Businessmen in Bangladesh are making an appeal to the government and opposition parties to end a nine-month-long political crisis that has disrupted the economy .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;1	The Federation of Bangladesh Chambers of Commerce and Industry will meet on Sunday to discuss ways of getting rival politicians to negotiate an end to the crisis , Salman Rahman , a spokesman for the federation told reporters Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;2	`` We will tell the politicians that their conflict is hurting the economy .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;3	They must resolve their dispute as soon as possible , '' said Rahman .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;4	An offer by the federation to mediate was rejected by the opposition parties last month .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;5	The opposition wants Prime Minister Khaleda Zia to resign and set up a caretaker government to conduct general elections immediately .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;6	Elections are not due until 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;7	Mrs. Zia has agreed to share power with the opposition in an interim government to oversee balloting at the end of her five-year term in 1996 , but the offer has been rejected .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;8	After a boycott of Parliament by all opposition lawmakers since March failed to persuade the government , the opposition resorted to strikes and street demonstrations .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;9	The federation estimates that each day of closure due to strikes cost the economy 1,500 million takas -LRB- dlrs 38 million -RRB- in production , sales and export losses .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;10	Last month , opposition parties enforced at least four one-day strikes and they have planned another 48-hour strike next week .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;11	Bangladesh is one of the poorest nations with an average annual per capita income of dlrs 215 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0090;12	`` We will tell the government and the opposition that the political instability will ruin the economy and take it behind by 100 years , '' Rahman said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0091;0	The leftist-dominated parliament on Friday easily rejected President Lech Walesa 's veto against increased personal income tax rates for 1995 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0091;1	With a 327-93 vote with two abstentions , the powerful lower chamber , or Sejm , exceeded by 45 votes the two-thirds majority required to override presidential vetoes .
APW_ENG_19941202.0091;2	The vote proved the strength of the government coalition of former communists and Prime Minister Waldemar Pawlak 's Polish Peasants ' Party , which dominate the chamber .
APW_ENG_19941202.0091;3	During the debate Thursday , the lawmakers and finance ministry officials said accepting the veto would have reduced 1995 government revenues by about 13 trillion zlotys -LRB- dlrs 542 million -RRB- , further decreasing next year 's limited spending in the deficit-ridden budget .
APW_ENG_19941202.0091;4	Walesa vetoed last week the increase of tax rates from 20 to 21 percent , from 30 to 33 and from 40 to 45 percent .
APW_ENG_19941202.0091;5	The higher rates were temporarily raised for 1994 , but the government had promised to return to previous levels in 1995 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0091;6	According to Walesa , higher taxes threatened the stability of the tax system and of the economy and hampered long-term planning in enterprises .
APW_ENG_19941202.0091;7	Walesa argued that the society had expected lower taxes , as promised in earlier parliament decisions and pointed out that the government should improve tax collecting , rather than reach into the pockets of pensioners , unemployed and modestly earning employees .
APW_ENG_19941202.0091;8	Leftist lawmakers said the veto protected those earning the most and was designed to prop up Walesa 's dwindling popularity in face of next year presidential elections .
APW_ENG_19941202.0091;9	In a last-minute deal aimed at swiftly throwing out Walesa 's veto , the government received support from the 42-deputy Labor Union party caucus , which has roots in the Solidarity trade Union , but gradually becomes the most leftist parliamentary group .
APW_ENG_19941202.0092;0	Japan 's current account surplus dropped 19 percent in October from the same month last year to dlrs 8.9 billion , in the third straight month of decline , the Finance Ministry announced Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0092;1	The current account is a broad measure of a country 's international economic flows , including trade , services and tourism .
APW_ENG_19941202.0092;2	It registers a surplus when more money comes into a country than goes out .
APW_ENG_19941202.0092;3	Japan 's current account surplus was dlrs 11.03 billion in October 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0092;4	Even though the current account has declined for three months in dollar terms , many economists are still hesitant to call it a sustained trend , noting that the surpluses remain large and stem mainly from structural factors .
APW_ENG_19941202.0092;5	The trade component of the current account fell 10 percent in the month to dlrs 11.13 billion , as imports rose 24 percent from a year earlier to dlrs 22.19 billion .
APW_ENG_19941202.0092;6	Exports rose 10 percent to dlrs 33.32 billion .
APW_ENG_19941202.0092;7	Japan 's deficit in services widened by 80 percent to dlrs 1.70 billion from a year earlier as more Japanese tourists went abroad to take advantage of the high value of the yen .
APW_ENG_19941202.0092;8	Trade figures in the current account are based on settled contracts , and are different from the more widely circulated trade figures announced separately by the ministry each month based on customs-clearance data .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;0	As many as 10,000 Chinese may be infected with the AIDS virus , and 22 have died of the disease since China discovered its first case in 1985 , an official report said Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;1	By the end of July this year , 1,453 people in China had tested positive for the AIDS virus , HIV .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;2	Of those , 1,174 were Chinese citizens , 31 were overseas Chinese and 230 were foreigners .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;3	But Wang Youfa , of the China Xiehe Medical College , wrote in the Guangming Daily that AIDS tests in China have so far been administered only among high-risk groups .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;4	`` The actual infection rate is far higher .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;5	Chinese experts estimate that the -LRB- Chinese -RRB- mainland currently as 5,000 to 10,000 HIV carriers , '' Wang said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;6	He urged better control of the deadly disease , but proposed no specific measures .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;7	Most Chinese still have little knowledge of the disease and how it is spread .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;8	Some believe that they can catch it through dirty bed sheets or from underwear laundered by hotels or laundromats .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;9	AIDS is most commonly spread through sexual contact , contaminated needles shared by drug users , infected blood or blood products and from pregnant women to their offspring .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;10	The Chinese government long has characterized AIDS as a disease that strikes only foreigners or fringe groups such as drug users and homosexuals .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;11	Prevention measures were directed at foreigners coming to China and at Chinese with frequent contacts with foreigners .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;12	Chinese health officials were shocked in 1990 when they discovered 146 HIV-positive drug users in southwest China 's Yunnan province .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;13	Since then , the figure has ballooned to 1,133 cases , or 79 percent of the national total , Wang said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;14	The province borders Burma , which produces much of the world 's heroin , and has China 's most serious drug problem .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;15	The report said the infection rate among Yunnan 's intravenous drug users was as high as 78 percent .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;16	Drug users account for 66 percent of the HIV carriers .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;17	The virus has spread to 22 of China 's 39 provinces , Wang said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;18	Of the 40 Chinese citizens who have developed full-blown AIDS , 22 have already died , he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;19	Non-Chinese citizens with the HIV virus are deported from China .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;20	In some disturbing trends , 19 people were infected by their spouses , and eight are less than 15 years old , Wang said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;21	He added that outside of Yunnan , sexual relations was the main mode of transmission .
APW_ENG_19941202.0093;22	Previous reports have also said that contaminated blood products accounted for more than a dozen AIDS victims .

APW_ENG_19941202.0094;1	The leaders of the Party of Democratic Socialism -LRB- PDS -RRB- began the fast Wednesday to protest a 67 million mark -LRB- dlrs 43 million -RRB- tax levy they called an unjust political attempt to bankrupt and destroy them .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;2	The politicians , seven including the intellectually agile parliamentary leader Gregor Gysi , initially occupied two federal offices but were removed by police on Wednesday night .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;3	Some 3,000 sympathizers held rallies and sit-ins in Berlin , Schwerin and Dresden on Thursday in support of the party leaders , who were sleeping on cots in their parliamentary offices when police roused and evicted them shortly after midnight .

APW_ENG_19941202.0094;5	The hunger strikers groggily repaired to a theater across from their party headquarters in east Berlin .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;6	The levy the party is fighting was assessed by Berlin tax authorities based on property sales in the first half of 1990 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;7	At the time , just months before German unification , the newly created PDS held vast assets as successor to the communists .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;8	A large portion of those assets are now controlled by an independent federal commission that is supposed to determine how much of the property they can keep and how much belongs to the people .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;9	The PDS asked the commission to pay the tax bill , but it refused .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;10	The chairman of the commission , however , raised questions about why Berlin tax authorities had assessed the PDS in the first place .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;11	Another board member , Reinhard Kraemer , said the PDS had refused to cooperate with tax authorities , thereby blocking efforts to determine whether the party truly was liable for the taxes .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;12	A court ruled Thursday that the PDS would only have to pay 3 million marks -LRB- dlrs 1.8 million -RRB- security for the moment , pending further efforts to try to settle the dispute .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;13	But party leaders said they would not pay .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;14	The party won 20 percent of the vote in eastern Germany in Oct. 16 national elections , thanks mainly to resentment among eastern Germans who feel they have been demoted to second-class status in united Germany .
APW_ENG_19941202.0094;15	Chancellor Helmut Kohl has attacked the PDS as `` red-painted fascists , '' and Gysi , a lawyer , has been battered by accusations that in decades past he betrayed the secrets of his dissident clients to the East German secret police .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;0	Swedish divers on Friday planned to survey the wreck of the sunken ferry Estonia , a Baltic Sea tomb for an estimated 800 victims of the tragedy .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;1	The divers , making the first human surveillance of the wreck , intend to scrutizine the condition of the ship , which is resting on its side in 56-84 meters -LRB- 180-280 feet -RRB- of water off Finland 's southwestern coast , the news agency TT reported .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;2	`` The weather conditions are good .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;3	The weather wo n't hinder the work , '' Swedish maritime administration spokesman Lars-Goeran Bronow told TT .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;4	The divers are to gather evidence to help authorities decide the feasibility of retreiving the bodies or taking some other action to preserve them .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;5	More than 800 bodies are believed entombed in the wreck , although officials have said they may never know the exact number because of unreliable passenger lists .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;6	According to the latest official count , 136 people survived and 913 died .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;7	Only 94 bodies have bee recovered .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;8	Swedish authorities were focusing on three options , none of which included raising the entire wreck .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;9	Divers could scour the wreck to retreive the bodies they find , or could do that plus flip it over using cables to find more bodies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;10	The last alternative would be leaving all the bodies and filling the wreck with sand to `` bury '' the victims and protect the wreck from scavengers .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;11	The divers are using a large , floating research platform called SEMI 1 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;12	The work was scheduled to begin Wednesday , but was delayed due to poor conditions .
APW_ENG_19941202.0095;13	The Swedish government , meanwhile , said Friday it has decided to give 3 million kronor -LRB- dlrs 417,000 -RRB- to organizations helping victims ' families , in many cases including orphans .

APW_ENG_19941202.0100;1	`` It really needs to go home , '' Quinten Crockett said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0100;2	`` It means a lot to me .
APW_ENG_19941202.0100;3	But it means more to them . ''

APW_ENG_19941202.0100;7	They are a symbol of our ability to overcome trial . ''

APW_ENG_19941202.0100;10	They agreed on a purchase price : $ 10 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0100;11	The cross 's history is uncertain .

APW_ENG_19941202.0101;0	NATO foreign ministers sought Friday to reassure Russia that their plans for admitting former Warsaw Pact foes would n't create a new division in Europe .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;1	The allies opened daylong talks with counterparts from nearly two-dozen nations in Eastern Europe in a session likely to be dominated by Russia 's unexpected opposition to a plan to expand the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;2	Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev stunned the ministers Thursday by protesting the plan for drawing up conditions for future NATO membership .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;3	He also backed out of a program to improve cooperation between Moscow and NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;4	`` I think that will all get sorted out ... How soon I do n't know , '' said British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd before Friday 's talks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;5	He said ties between Moscow and NATO were `` too important to be lost . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;6	U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher met separately with Kozyrev for more than an hour Friday to discuss the dispute as well as the situation in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;7	They `` worked toward a clarification of some of the issues the foreign minister raised last night , '' said State Department spokesman Mike McCurry .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;8	Although NATO and East European officials intended to answer Kozyrev 's questions at the meeting , McCurry said it was unlikely the Russian would change his mind immediately and agree on the new cooperation plan .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;9	Willy Claes , secretary-general of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization , opened the formal session by saying : `` The division of Europe has ended .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;10	We have worked ... to ensure that it never returns . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;11	Kozyrev 's comments cast a pall over the meeting and over NATO 's attempt to draw its former Warsaw Pact enemies into its alliance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;12	However , some diplomats suggested he was playing to an audience back in Russia , where the government is contending with a strong nationalist opposition .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;13	Poland 's foreign minister , Andrzej Olechowski , said the foreign ministers would `` explain everything to the Russians -- that -LRB- membership plans -RRB- are n't against them . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;14	`` It 's our problem and the alliance 's problem -- not the Russians ' , '' said Czech Foreign Minister Josef Zieleniec .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;15	Poland , Hungary , the Czech Republic and others have repeatedly demanded NATO membership and the security guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;16	The Russian outburst pushed , at least temporarily , the crisis in Bosnia off the ministers ' agenda .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;17	Christopher , Hurd and Kozyrev were meeting later in the day with Foreign Ministers Alain Juppe of France and Klaus Kinkel of Germany to try to revive the peace process in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;18	Christopher wants formal approval from the others for a new diplomatic initiative to try to draw the Bosnian Serbs into negotiations with the Muslims and Croats in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;19	It calls for a cease-fire around Bihac , the northwestern Muslim enclave that Serbs are pummeling , a pledge to cease hostilities throughout the country for three to six months and then an international peace conference .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;20	The lure for the Serbs , who control about 70 percent of Bosnia , is an opportunity to press their demand for cross-border political ties to Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;21	`` The essence of any peace plan is a very substantial Bosnian Serb withdrawal ... and continuance of Bosnia-Herzegovina within its own borders , '' Hurd told reporters .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;22	Juppe and Hurd plan to fly to Belgrade this weekend to push the initiative .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;23	The NATO allies , in trying to meet East Europeans demands for membership without upsetting Russia , thought they had found a good formula .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;24	At a summit last January , President Clinton and other allied leaders approved a U.S. initiative , Partnership for Peace , to bring former foes closer , but without membership .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;25	Twenty-three nations , including Russia , have enrolled in the project , which allows them to take part for the first time in military exercises and other alliance activities .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;26	On Thursday , the allies decided to go further by ordering aides to conduct a 12-month study of the terms and conditions for expanding the Western military alliance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;27	To overcome Russian objections to its eastward expansion , NATO had agreed to a special relationship with Moscow and insisted they had no intention of forming a hostile bloc .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;28	But Kozyrev was n't impressed .

APW_ENG_19941202.0101;30	Kozyrev refused to endorse a wide-ranging program of military and political contacts with Moscow intended to ease Russia 's fears .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;31	McCurry said Kozyrev gave no advance warning he wanted clarification of the schedule for considering new NATO members next year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0101;32	`` I would be tempted to say it has to do with domestic politics in Russia , '' McCurry said .

APW_ENG_19941202.0104;0	ISLAMABAD , Pakistan -LRB- AP -RRB- - The World Bank has approved dlrs 490 million in aid to help Pakistan build power plants and develop energy projects , newspapers reported Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0104;1	The World Bank loan includes dlrs 250 million that will go into a private sector energy development fund established six years ago .
APW_ENG_19941202.0104;2	The bank also is providing dlrs 240 million in loan guarantees for the massive Hub Power Plant , a dlrs 1.8 billion dollar project outside the southern port city of Karachi .
APW_ENG_19941202.0104;3	Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto has focused her efforts on the energy sector as she tries to revitalize Pakistan 's economy , which has shown little growth at a time when many Asian economies are booming .
APW_ENG_19941202.0105;0	More people in the Asia-Pacific region will be able to watch Japanese programs under a plan announced Friday by Japan 's public broadcasting network .
APW_ENG_19941202.0105;1	The Japan Broadcasting Corp. -LRB- NHK -RRB- , said it plans in April to begin transmitting its programs over the PAS-2 satellite to an area stretching from Far Eastern Russia in the north to New Zealand in the south .
APW_ENG_19941202.0105;2	`` Our main aim is to foster a better mutual understanding with Asian countries , '' said Junichi Hayashi , chief of NHK 's Hong Kong Bureau .
APW_ENG_19941202.0105;3	He said the rapid rise in international satellite television services in the region had boosted the network 's plan for satellite broadcasting .
APW_ENG_19941202.0105;4	Koichiro Shoda , NHK 's international public relations director , said local broadcasters and cable operators will also be able to obtain NHK programs on a contract basis .

APW_ENG_19941202.0108;0	A yellow fever epidemic has killed at least 300 people , the national News Agency of Nigeria reported Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0108;1	It said the outbreak began two weeks ago in the Orsu area of eastern Imo state and spread this week to neighboring Orlu area , where at least 50 victims have been hospitalized .
APW_ENG_19941202.0108;2	Imo state government reportedly had given 25,000 naira -LRB- more than dlrs 1,000 -RRB- to local administrators to buy vaccines , but doctors at three hospitals in the area said none had arrived , the agency said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0108;3	Outbreaks of easily preventable and treatable diseases often kill dozens of people in Nigeria , where an economic crisis fueled by corruption has broken down health services .
APW_ENG_19941202.0108;4	Yellow fever was eradicated here by vaccination before independence from Britain in 1960 but has resurged .
