APW_ENG_19941202.0110;0	Swiss pharmaceutical giant Ciba-Geigy AG said Friday that it has signed an agreement with three Chinese partners to develop and market a new drug to combat malaria .
APW_ENG_19941202.0110;1	The new drug will combine two anti-malarial substances -- artemether and benflumetol -- which work together to produce a `` highly effective '' treatment that can be administered over a short time , Ciba said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0110;2	Benflumetol was developed at the Beijing Institute of Microbiology and Epidemiology in Beijing ; artemether is an existing treatment .
APW_ENG_19941202.0110;3	`` In developing this new drug with our Chinese partners , we will meet an urgent medical need in many countries , '' a company statement said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0110;4	The disease afflicts between 300 and 500 million people a year , killing about 2 million of them , the World Health Organization says .
APW_ENG_19941202.0110;5	The company said the drug could be brought to market as early as 1997 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0110;6	China has already conducted clinical trials , and further tests are planned in Africa , East Asia and Europe in the next two or three years , Ciba said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0110;7	Ciba , Switzerland 's largest chemical and pharmaceuticals group , said it signed the agreement with the Beijing institute and the Kunming Pharmaceutical Factory in Kunming and CITIC Technology Inc. of Beijing .
APW_ENG_19941202.0110;8	The venture will produce the active substances for the new drug .
APW_ENG_19941202.0110;9	Ciba 's facility in Changping , near Beijing , will make the finished product for export markets , the Kunming factory will make the drug for the Chinese market , Ciba said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0111;0	Their luxury cruise cut short by an inferno of smoke and fire , nearly 1,000 weary passengers and crew members of the abandoned Achille Lauro steamed toward safe ports Friday in a motley fleet of warships and cargo freighters .
APW_ENG_19941202.0111;1	Two elderly passengers died and eight were injured after fire erupted in the engine room of the Achille Lauro before dawn Wednesday and spread to engulf the ship , despite efforts by the crew to contain it .
APW_ENG_19941202.0111;2	`` The fire was so big you had to fight through smoke which poured down toward the cabins , '' survivor Tony Webb was quoted as telling London 's Daily Telegraph .
APW_ENG_19941202.0111;3	`` At about 8 a.m. , the captain said the fire was too strong and we would have to abandon ship , '' added Webb , 44 , a Briton living in Cape Town , South Africa .
APW_ENG_19941202.0111;4	Passengers clad in evening clothes and bed dress clambered aboard life boats and rafts and evacuated the ship , followed sometime later by the fire-fighting team and , finally , the captain , Giuseppe Orsi .
APW_ENG_19941202.0111;5	`` From what I saw , -LRB- the ship -RRB- is gone , '' Orsi said by radio from one of the rescue ships Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0111;6	The Achille Lauro was adrift in the Indian Ocean off Somalia on Friday , listing badly to port and still smoldering , its troubled history apparently nearing an end .
APW_ENG_19941202.0111;7	The ship 's name burst into headlines in 1985 when the Achille Lauro was hijacked by Palestinian terrorists who killed a wheelchair-bound American and dumped his body overboard .
APW_ENG_19941202.0111;8	The terrorists escaped the vessel and boarded a jet , but U.S. fighter planes forced it to land in Italy and the hijackers were captured .
APW_ENG_19941202.0111;9	Eight cargo vessels and two American warships , the USS Gettysburg and Halyburton , carried the Achille Lauro 's surviving passengers and crew members toward Djibouti , Mombasa in Kenya and Muscat , Oman .
APW_ENG_19941202.0111;10	Most were heading for Mombasa but none of the rescue ships was expected to dock before Sunday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;0	The opposition felt it was being denied equal TV time in Taiwan 's local election campaign , so it has taken the law into its own hands .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;1	The result is TNT , a pirate station that does daily battle with the ruling Nationalist Party from the bedroom of a rented Taipei apartment .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;2	It 's part of an explosion in pirate TV and radio broadcasting , always lively though sometimes abusive , by critics who feel the Nationalists have been too slow in relaxing their 45-year grip on the electronic media .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;3	TNT -- Taiwan News Telecommunication -- is funded by the Democratic Progressive Party , the main opposition , which claims Taiwan 's three major networks are biased toward Nationalist candidates .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;4	Those networks are controlled by the Nationalists , the military and the provincial government .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;5	There are others transmitting on cable , including some that support the DPP and one that supports the New Party , a Nationalist splinter .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;6	But Mike Chang , who founded TNT with some friends , says their station is the first in Taipei to broadcast over the airwaves .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;7	`` We had to break through the media domination by the Nationalist Party , which we think is not good for society , '' he said in an interview during a break from presenting Thursday night .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;8	They broadcast on channel 12 , hoping to net viewers who stray from 11 , the government channel , Chang said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;9	He does not know how many viewers TNT has , but TNT radio , which began in March , claims 300,000 regular listeners among Taipei 's 2.6 million people .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;10	Chang charges that instead of educating the public about the election issues and candidates , the Nationalists `` are doing a lousy job , insulting the people . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;11	The polls for governor and for mayors of Taiwan 's two largest cities are the sternest electoral test for the Nationalists since they fled to Taiwan from Communist China in 1949 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;12	Never before have Taiwanese elected their governor and the last mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung were in 1967 and 1979 respectively .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;13	Pirate stations would have been unthinkable before the Nationalists lifted martial law in 1987 and initiated Taiwan 's shift from virtual dictatorship to democracy .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;14	Today , they are forums for Taiwanese to oppose everything from Nationalist policies to nuclear power stations .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;15	But being a pirate is not without risks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;16	In July , police raided 14 pirate radio stations , including TNT , and confiscated their equipment .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;17	So far , however , the TV station has been left alone .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;18	Chang suspects the government does n't want a repeat of the riots that followed the July raids .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;19	Chang said TNT is editorially independent but shares many DPP points of view , including its support for making Taiwan independent , as opposed to the Nationalist doctrine of reunification with the mainland .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;20	TNT TV follows DPP candidates on the campaign trail and at DPP rallies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;21	The station also invites academics and commentators to a daily discussion show , with viewers phoning in .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;22	A bedroom serves as a studio shared by TV and radio , with black drapes providing a backdrop .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;23	Chang and his guests sit around tables pushed together and covered with a table cloth that has seen better days .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;24	As they talk , Ah Gui , the lone cameraman , dashes between two cameras on tripods .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;25	Chang claims the government 's licensing laws are too stringent .
APW_ENG_19941202.0112;26	`` We would like to follow the law , '' he says , `` but the law must be reasonable . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;0	NATO foreign ministers sought today to reassure Russia that the alliance 's plans for admitting former Warsaw Pact foes would n't create a new divide in Europe .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;1	The allies opened daylong talks with their counterparts from Eastern Europe and former Soviet republics in a session likely to be dominated by Russia 's unexpected opposition to a plan to expand the alliance in coming years .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;2	Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev stunned the ministers Thursday by protesting the plan for drawing up conditions for future NATO membership .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;3	He also announced Russia 's withdrawal from a program to improve military and political cooperation between Moscow and NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;4	Secretary of State Warren Christopher met separately with Kozyrev for more than an hour today to discuss the dispute as well as the situation in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;5	They `` worked toward a clarification of some of the issues the foreign minister raised last night , '' said State Department spokesman Mike McCurry .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;6	Willy Claes , secretary-general of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization , opened the formal session by saying : `` The division of Europe has ended .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;7	We have worked ... to ensure that it never returns . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;8	Kozyrev 's comments cast a pall over Thursday 's meeting and over NATO 's attempt to draw its former Warsaw Pact enemies into the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;9	However , some diplomats suggested he was playing to an audience back in Russia , where the government is contending with a strong nationalist opposition .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;10	Poland 's foreign minister , Andrzej Olechowski , said the foreign ministers would `` explain everything to the Russians -- that -LRB- membership plans -RRB- are n't against them . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;11	Poland , Hungary , the Czech Republic and others have repeatedly demanded NATO membership and the security guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;12	The Russian outburst temporarily pushed the crisis in Bosnia off the ministers ' agenda .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;13	Christopher and Kozyrev were to meet later today with the foreign ministers of France , Britain and Germany to try to revive efforts to end the 2 -LCB- - year Bosnian war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;14	Christopher wants formal approval from the others for a new diplomatic initiative to try to draw the Bosnian Serbs into negotiations with the Muslims and Croats in Bosnia , including a cease-fire around the U.N. `` safe area '' of Bihac and a pledge to stop fighting nationwide for three to six months .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;15	The lure for the Serbs , who control about 70 percent of Bosnia , is an opportunity to press their demand for political ties to Serb-controlled Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;16	The NATO allies , in trying to meet East Europeans ' demands for membership without upsetting Russia , thought they had found a good formula .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;17	At a summit last January , President Clinton and other allied leaders approved a U.S. initiative , Partnership for Peace , to bring former foes closer , but without membership .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;18	Twenty-three nations , including Russia , have enrolled in the project , which allows them to take part for the first time in military exercises and other alliance activities .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;19	On Thursday , the allies decided to go further by ordering aides to conduct a 12-month study of the terms , costs and conditions for expanding the Western military alliance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;20	In an effort to ease Russian fears about its eastward expansion , the NATO allies had agreed to a special relationship with Moscow and insisted they had no intention of forming a hostile bloc .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;21	But Kozyrev was n't impressed .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;22	`` If the strategy of NATO has changed , then that is something which requires further discussion , '' Kozyrev told a group of grim-faced NATO ministers .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;23	McCurry said Kozyrev gave no advance warning that he wanted clarification of the schedule for considering new NATO members next year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0113;24	`` I would be tempted to say it has to do with domestic politics in Russia , '' McCurry said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0114;0	A yellow fever oubreak has killed at least 300 people in Nigeria , a news agency said Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0114;1	The News Agency of Nigeria said the outbreak began two weeks ago in the Orsu area of eastern Imo state and spread to neighboring Orlu area , where at least 50 victims have been hospitalized .
APW_ENG_19941202.0114;2	Imo state government reportedly had given 25,000 naira -LRB- more than dlrs 1,000 -RRB- to local administrators to buy vaccines , but doctors at three hospitals in the area said none had arrived , the agency said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0114;3	Outbreaks of easily preventable and treatable diseases often kill dozens of people in Nigeria , where an economic crisis fueled by corruption has broken down health services .
APW_ENG_19941202.0114;4	Yellow fever was wiped out by vaccination before independence from Britain in 1960 but has been resurgent since .
APW_ENG_19941202.0115;0	Masked anarchists defending a squatter camp hurled paving stones and Molotov cocktails early Friday at police trying to evict them , injuring 22 officers , city authorities said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0115;1	The five-hour struggle against some 100 leftist rioters ended about 4 a.m. after police used an armored vehicle to break through a perimeter barricade the anarchists had erected .
APW_ENG_19941202.0115;2	Police , who also used water cannon against the bandana-masked demonstrators , were trying to enforce a court order to remove the camp , but left the scene without succeeding .
APW_ENG_19941202.0115;3	The squatters had built a head-high barrier of doors , window frames , tables , shopping carts and two of the seven disputed mobile homes at a square in the city 's Karolinen quarter .
APW_ENG_19941202.0115;4	Parts of the barricade were set on fire and police used water cannon to extinguish the blazes .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;0	NATO foreign ministers sought Friday to reassure Russia that their plans for admitting former Warsaw Pact foes would n't create a new division in Europe .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;1	The ministers opened daylong talks with counterparts from more than 20 East European nations , including Russia , in a session likely to be dominated by Moscow 's unexpected opposition to a plan to expand the Western alliance in the coming years .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;2	Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev stunned the ministers Thursday by protesting the plan for drawing up conditions for future NATO membership .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;3	He also backed out of a program to improve cooperation between Moscow and NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;4	`` I think that we 'll all get -LRB- it -RRB- sorted out ... How soon I do n't know , '' British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said before Friday 's talks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;5	U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher met separately with Kozyrev for more than an hour Friday to discuss the dispute and the situation in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;6	Later , foreign ministers from Britain , France and Germany were to join them to discuss a U.S. initiative to revive efforts for a negotiated settlement to the Bosnian war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;7	Willy Claes , secretary-general of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization , opened the main session saying : `` The division of Europe has ended .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;8	We have worked ... to ensure that it never returns . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;9	Kozyrev 's comments clouded NATO 's attempt to draw in its former Warsaw Pact enemies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;10	However , some diplomats suggested he was playing to a domestic audience in Russia , where the government faces a strong nationalist opposition .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;11	Poland 's foreign minister , Andrzej Olechowski , said the foreign ministers would `` explain everything to the Russians -- that -LRB- membership plans -RRB- are n't against them . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;12	Poland , Hungary , the Czech Republic and others have repeatedly demanded NATO membership and the defense guarantees that would go with it .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;13	To deal with the demands without upsetting Russia , the allies last January backed a U.S. initiative , Partnership for Peace , providing for closer ties without membership .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;14	Russia is among 23 nations enrolled in the project , which allows them to take part in NATO military exercises and other activities .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;15	On Thursday , the allies went further by ordering aides to draft a study of the terms and conditions for expanding NATO eastward .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;16	Meanwhile , the allies granted Russia a special relationship and denied they were forming a hostile bloc .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;17	But Kozyrev told grim-faced NATO ministers : `` If the strategy of NATO has changed , then that is something which requires further discussion . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;18	He refused to endorse a wide-ranging program of military and political contacts with Moscow intended to ease Russia 's fears of an eastward drive by the alliance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;19	`` This communique raises more questions than it answers , '' Kozyrev said in impromptu remarks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;20	`` We have to understand what are the intentions of the other partners . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;21	Claes immediately tried to reassure Kozyrev that NATO was n't shifting direction .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;22	`` It is no change in strategy or policy of NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;23	... There is nothing new , '' he told the Russian minister Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;24	`` We are not willing to organize new divisions in Europe . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;25	Kozyrev 's outburst added to the woes of an alliance long strained by U.S.-European disputes over dealing with the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;26	In an effort to mend the rift , Christopher swung behind the European view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941202.0116;27	It was a major policy switch by Washington under pressure particularly from Britain and France .

APW_ENG_19941202.0117;21	Claes immediately tried to reassure Kozyrev that NATO was n't shifting direction .
APW_ENG_19941202.0117;22	`` It is no change in strategy or policy of NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0117;23	... There is nothing new , '' he told the Russian minister Thursday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0117;24	`` We are not willing to organize new divisions in Europe . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0117;25	Kozyrev 's outburst added to the woes of an alliance long strained by U.S.-European disputes over dealing with the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina .
APW_ENG_19941202.0117;26	In an effort to mend the rift , Christopher swung behind the European view that diplomacy , not force , is the best way to deal with the conflict .
APW_ENG_19941202.0117;27	It was a major policy switch by Washington under pressure particularly from Britain and France .
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;0	PLO chief Yasser Arafat met with an Islamic opposition leader in Gaza Friday and formed a reconciliation committee to work out future differences and prevent violence .
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;1	The meeting between Arafat and Hamas leader Mahmoud Zahar ended two weeks of tense uncertainty in the Gaza Strip , sparked by a bloody confrontation between PLO police and Islamic activists on Nov. 18 that left 15 dead .
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;2	`` Both sides agreed this morning that the most important thing is to try and overcome obstacles and conquer this crisis , '' said Arafat advisor Ahmed Tibi .
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;3	`` The Palestinians can not achieve peace without being unified , '' he added .
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;4	Arafat faced off against the Islamic Resistance Movement , or Hamas , after Israel demanded that he crack down on militants responsible for attacks that left 32 Israelis dead in October and November alone .
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;5	Hamas and the more extremist Islamic Jihad organization oppose the peace accord that Arafat signed with the Palestinians .
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;6	But Arafat ca n't afford to ignore the grassroots support for the militant groups , especially among the poor , and is trying to woo them into participating in his self-rule government .
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;7	Tibi said Friday 's meeting was the start of a `` real dialogue between the sides . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;8	Another Israeli-Arab who served as a mediator , Sheikh Abdullah Nimr Darwish , called the meeting `` a gate of hope for the Palestinians . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;9	Darwish said that Hamas no longer rejected an Arafat-appointed judiciary probe into the Nov. 18 violence and had agreed to drop accusations blaming the Palestinian Authority for the clashes until investigators published their results .
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;10	`` It was a warm and fruitful meeting between myself and my brother and what we have agreed on is good for both sides , '' Zahar told The Associated Press .
APW_ENG_19941202.0118;11	Tibi said the nine-member committee , that includes Hamas and PLO officials as well as two Israeli Arabs , would meet Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;0	A ferry carrying more than 600 people collided with a Singapore-registered freighter and sank before dawn Friday in Manila Bay , killing at least 34 people , the Coast Guard reported .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;1	Coast Guard spokesman Amado Samante said 451 passengers had been rescued .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;2	The bodies of 34 people who had drowned had also been recovered , he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;3	The search for the remaining passengers was called off late in the day because of darkness and was to resume Saturday morning .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;4	William Lines , which own the 2,452-ton ferry , the Cebu City , said the ferry had 608 people on board .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;5	There was no immediate official report on the cause of the accident , but the ferry 's owner said it had been rammed by the Kota Suria .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;6	Eugene Espedido , vice president of the company , said it was preparing a request for the coast guard to detain the freighter and its crew .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;7	Jacob Cabatuan , a crewman on the ferry , said the Kota Suria 's bow crashed into the Cebu City , destroying the bridge and ripping a one-meter -LRB- three-foot -RRB- hole in the lower deck .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;8	He said ship captain Wesceslao Lampong and several other officers were pinned on the bridge .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;9	Erwin Maravilla , one of the first survivors plucked from the sea by a navy patrol , said his family was sleeping at the time of the accident .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;10	He lost both of his two children and his wife , he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;11	`` I was lucky to be able to swim to the surface .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;12	Otherwise I would be dead , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;13	The 12,500-ton Kota Suria , with a crew of 26 , was damaged in its bow but joined the rescue effort , carrying 230 of those saved .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;14	President Fidel Ramos ordered an investigation into the cause of the accident , which occurred in calm seas under clear night skies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;15	Maximo Calamba , 38 , who survived with his wife Veneranda , 30 , and 1-year-old son Marcelo , complained that the ferry crew failed to inform them about the approaching freighter and did not help people evacuate the ship after the collision .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;16	`` There was no alarm .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;17	We were thrown off our cots and everybody was on their own , '' Calamba said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;18	`` When we were rescued by the Suria I could still hear crying out for help . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;19	Radio station DZRH , reporting from an airplane overhead , said at least eight patrol boats , a search and rescue ship and several other inter-island ferries were involved in the rescue effort .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;20	William Lines said the Cebu City had a capacity of 800 passengers .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;21	It sank near the mouth of Manila Bay near the town of Rosario , about 50 kilometers -LRB- 35 miles -RRB- southwest of Manila in Cavite province .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;22	It had left the port of Manila bound for Tagbilaran , the capital of Bohol Island , about 560 kilometers -LRB- 350 miles -RRB- southeast of Manila .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;23	Quirimon Tan , William Lines vice president , said each of the dead passengers was covered by 50,000 pesos -LRB- dlrs 2,173 -RRB- in insurance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;24	He said the company would also pay for medical and funeral expenses .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;25	In a quirk of timing , the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday approved William Lines ' initial public offering .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;26	The company is selling 235 million shares for between 9.65 pesos -LRB- 41 U.S. cents -RRB- and 15.15 pesos -LRB- 65 cents -RRB- a share .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;27	An analyst who asked not to be named said the accident would probably not drag down the stock issue .
APW_ENG_19941202.0119;28	The Philippines ' worst peacetime ferry disaster was in December 1987 , when 3,537 people died in the collision of the ferry Dona Paz with the oil tanker Vector off Mindoro Island , about 130 kilometers -LRB- 80 miles -RRB- south of Manila .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;0	Congressional clearance of a new world trade accord is expected to encourage ratification by other countries , enabling the mammoth export-boosting pact to enter into force as planned Jan. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;1	Around the world , big and small nations alike are trying to rush the 22,000 page GATT agreement through national parliaments , often in low-key processes that contrast with the rocky ride through the U.S. legislature .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;2	Nearly 40 countries , including the United States and most of southeast Asia , have ratified the 124-nation pact .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;3	About 40 more -- including trade giants Japan , the European Union and Canada -- have indicated they will do so by the end of the year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;4	Four countries -- Switzerland , Liechtenstein , Cyprus and Poland -- have already told the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that domestic politics will prevent them from ratifying the accord this year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;5	But this wo n't stop the pact from taking effect as scheduled on Jan. 1 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;6	All that is needed is for the all the big traders to come on board as founding members of the World Trade Organization -- GATT 's more powerful successor body that implement the accord .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;7	The agreement is considered the most ambitious attempt ever to free world trade and is expected to boost global income by dlrs 510 billion by the year 2005 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;8	It reduces customs duties on hundreds of thousands of products , liberalizes trade in service industries , protects against copyright theft and patent abuse and cuts protection of farm goods and textiles .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;9	Most governments object to at least some provisions because previously protected industries -- such as agriculture in Europe and textiles in the United States -- will suffer .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;10	But all participating countries agreed not to upset the carefully crafted compromises with amendments .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;11	The ratification situation in some of the main trading nations is as follows : -- European Union : Britain , Ireland , Greece and Germany have approved it .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;12	The eight other EU members are meant to do so before foreign ministers meet Dec. 19-20 to approve the deal on behalf of the entire trade bloc .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;13	France and Portugal still have some qualms , but the EU Commission , the union 's executive body , said there are no real obstacles .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;14	An internal dispute between the Commission and member states over negotiating powers , which slowed national ratification , has been settled .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;15	-- Japan : A key parliamentary committee has approved the deal , and full passage is likely in the next few days .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;16	The government placated rice farmers , upset at potential competition from imports , with a six-year , 7.2 trillion yen -LRB- dlrs 74 billion -RRB- compensation package .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;17	-- South Korea : The ruling Democratic Liberal party , which has a big majority , plans to push the accord through the national assembly next week .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;18	Opposition politicians and farmers accuse the government of making too many concessions under U.S. pressure to open the rice market .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;19	There have been frequent violent demonstrations against the accord .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;20	-- India : There was strong opposition from both left - and right-wing parties , especially to provisions that give foreign multinationals stronger patent claims to Indian seeds and medicines .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;21	The opposition , however , seems to have run out of steam and legislative passage appears more or less certain , though no date has been set .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;22	-- Canada : Hopes to ratify the accord by the end of the year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;23	-- Mexico : Under former President Salinas de Gortari , who is one of three candidates for the directorship of the WTO , Mexico was one of the first countries to ratify the trade accord .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;24	-- South America : Chile has ratified the accord and Argentina hopes to do so before the end of the year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;25	In Brazil , parliamentary passage is likely to be in February , not because the accord is contested but because of delays caused by this year 's election .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;26	-- China : In order to join the WTO , Beijing first has to enter GATT .
APW_ENG_19941202.0121;27	Western concerns about China 's market reform programs and a possible flood of Chinese exports mean GATT membership talks are unlikely to finish by the end of the year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;0	Harassed and humiliated by Serbs , the United Nations on Friday dispatched a senior envoy to try to end detention of hundreds of peacekeepers and a freeze on U.N. movements in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;1	Officials hoped that Yasushi Akashi , the top U.N. official in former Yugoslavia , would have more success than his boss , Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali , who was rebuffed in even trying to meet with the Bosnian Serbs on Wednesday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;2	Akashi arrived Friday morning in Sarajevo for meetings with Bosnian government officials , and was to continue on to the Bosnian Serb headquarters at Pale , outside Sarajevo , later in the day .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;3	Akashi 's talks would follow a meeting Thursday between Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and the U.N. commander for Bosnia , Lt. Gen. Sir Michael Rose .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;4	A U.N. source said Karadzic promised to try to help , but added that such promises often are empty .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;5	Spokesman Thant Myint-U said Akashi wanted to discuss fighting around the government enclave of Bihac with Karadzic , as well as an end to restrictions on the movement of U.N. troops .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;6	Thant said Bihac , scene of heavy fighting for weeks , was quiet overnight .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;7	But strong Serb forces , which have seized 30-40 percent of the U.N.-declared `` safe zone '' encompassing the town of Bihac and environs , remained in the area .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;8	The United Nations has said the Serbs , from both Croatia and Bosnia , appeared strong enough to capture Bihac if they wanted .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;9	There were signs that frontlines south of Bihac were heating up .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;10	Bosnian Croats , allied with Muslim-led government forces against the Serbs , claimed they captured three villages north of the town of Kupres in central Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;11	A Croat militia and the Bosnian army took Kupres from the Serbs in a joint attack last month .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;12	Gen. Ante Roso , the Bosnian Croat military commander , charged that Croatian Serb forces also had shelled his forces across the border near the town of Livno .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;13	He said his troops returned fire .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;14	Alexander Ivanko , a U.N. spokesman , said Thursday that Bosnian Serb units in the Bihac area crossed the border into Croatia and seized seven Ukrainian peacekeepers from an observation post Tuesday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;15	They took the soldiers and a U.N. armored carrier into Bosnian Serb-held territory .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;16	More than 400 of the 24,000 U.N. soldiers in Bosnia are being detained by the Serbs as insurance against further NATO airstrikes .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;17	NATO struck three times last week , but the attacks did nothing to stop the Serb assault on Bihac .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;18	The Serbs also have been ignoring U.N. requests to send supply convoys across territory they hold .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;19	Monique Tuffelli , the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees staffer in Bihac , said Thursday that food stocks would last only another week .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;20	`` We have run out almost of everything , '' she said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;21	The Serbs repeatedly have rejected an international peace plan .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;22	With the threat of international force appearing to dissipate , their position is hardening .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;23	Momcilo Krajisnik , leader of the Bosnian Serbs ' self-proclaimed legislature , rejected a three-month cease-fire , which the Bosnian government wants .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;24	He said Serbs would only accept a permanent cease-fire .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;25	The Sarajevo government fears a permanent cease-fire would cement Serb territorial gains of 70 percent of Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;26	The peace plan they rejected would give the Serbs 49 percent of the country .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;27	Senior Western officials now talk of altering that plan to allow the Bosnian Serbs links with Serb-dominated Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0122;28	Opponents say that would be a step toward creation of Serb nationalists ' goal of a `` Greater Serbia . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;0	A Russian journalist said Friday he received a fax from a group threatening Russians abroad if Moscow does not recognize the independence of a rebellious southern territory .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;1	Igor Pavlov , head of the Copenhagen office of Russia 's Novosti news agency , got a letter from a `` North Caucasian Liberation Army '' demanding recognition of `` the Chechnya Republic 's independence without any conditions . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;2	Chechnya , a territory in Russia 's Caucasus Mountains , sought independence from Russia in 1991 but was rejected .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;3	Fighting broke out last week between its president , Dzhokhar Dudayev , and opponents who he says are backed by Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;4	In Denmark , the journalist said he received the English-language Wednesday evening , which included a number indicating it came from Copenhagen 's central railway station .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;5	The note said , in verbatim , `` We will consider the Russian officials as non-officials representations and hence as our military targets '' if the recognition is not granted .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;6	The one-page printed fax was signed `` K.K.K.O. 130 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;7	Police said the sign-off possibly could be initials for the North Caucasian Liberation Army .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;8	Police in Copenhagen said they heard the group has been active in other countries , but not in Denmark until now .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;9	They would give no details .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;10	`` Of course we take this threat seriously , '' a senior police officer said , speaking on condition of anonymity .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;11	No one has been arrested .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;12	The Russian embassy and the Aeroflot air carrier office in Copenhagen had not received similar threats , police said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;13	The domestic intelligence agency said it was investigating the case but declined to comment .
APW_ENG_19941202.0125;14	The note also demanded `` Russia 's recognition of the North Caucasian Federation 's official borders '' and `` the help of the United Nations to the Caucasian people 's return to their native country from where they were expelled 130 years ago . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;0	The government outmaneuvered angry opposition lawmakers Friday to pass a 54.8 trillion won -LRB- dlrs 68.5 billion -RRB- budget for 1995 just three hours before its deadline .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;1	The budget , 15.9 percent higher than the current year 's , includes a 9.9 percent increase in defense spending while hugely raising subsidies for farmers , who are angry over agricultural concessions by South Korea in the new world trade agreement .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;2	Approval followed two weeks of political bickering over an opposition demand that the government indict former presidents Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Tae-woo for engineering a 1979 military coup that put Chun in power .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;3	Roh succeeded him as president in 1988 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;4	The opposition Democratic Party had boycotted the National Assembly over the issue .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;5	The ruling Democratic Liberal Party waited until Friday , the legal deadline , to pass the budget .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;6	Chun and Roh , while still generals , established a junta to rule the country after the death of their mentor , President Park Chung-hee .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;7	The government fears their prosecution would trigger serious political unrest .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;8	With Speaker Hwang Nak-joo kept in his office by opposition politicians who blocked the door , Vice Speaker Lee Chun-koo appeared in a spectators ' gallery , convened a plenary session and announced approval of the budget .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;9	It took only 30 seconds .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;10	Opposition Democrats angrily protested , but there was no violent scuffle -- a set-piece parliamentary scene during past governments .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;11	Earlier Friday , the Democratic Liberals unilaterally pushed the government-drawn budget bill through an assembly budget deliberation committee after cutting 150 billion won -LRB- dlrs 187.5 million -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;12	The ruling party controls 171 of the 299 National Assembly seats .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;13	Hours before the assembly 's planned action on the budget , the Democrats abandoned their boycott and returned to try to block its passage .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;14	Defense , up to 11.07 trillion won -LRB- dlrs 13.8 billion -RRB- , takes a 20 percent share of the budget , reflecting South Korea 's preoccupation with threats from North Korea .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;15	South Korea also increased public works spending by 22 percent to 6.77 trillion won -LRB- dlrs 8.36 billion -RRB- -- much of it to tackle the country 's worsening traffic congestion .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;16	But the highlight of the budget is a rise of nearly 40 percent in farm subsidies to cushion farmers and fishermen against the opening of South Korea 's markets under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;17	Subsidies in the new budget total 8.06 trillion won -LRB- dlrs 1.01 billion -RRB- -- about 1.34 million won -LRB- dlrs 1,680 -RRB- a year for each of the nation 's 6 million farmers and fishermen .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;18	The government hopes to pass the GATT deal through Parliament this month .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;19	The opposition has vowed to block it .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;20	Farmers have staged violent protests over the government 's decision to open farm markets to foreign products .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;21	The government has used farm subsidies to buy rice at prices five or six times higher than in the United States and other countries .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;22	Also Friday , the assembly approved a government plan to buy 1.5 million tons of rice this year , 115,200 tons more than last year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;23	Farmers fear the new trade accord might threaten their livelihood .
APW_ENG_19941202.0126;24	South Korea produces 4.75 million tons a year of rice , the nation 's main staple food .

APW_ENG_19941202.0128;0	Legislators across the political spectrum said Friday they doubted Germany would accept NATO 's request to send fighter planes to patrol the skies over Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0128;1	NATO on Thursday asked Germany to send six to eight Tornado fighters equipped with electronic radar-suppression gear and rockets to destroy radar sites .
APW_ENG_19941202.0128;2	They would protect allied planes involved in the U.N. humanitarian mission in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0128;3	In July , the nation 's high court ruled that combat missions overseas were legal , but must be approved by parliament , where Chancellor Helmut Kohl 's coalition has a wafer-thin majority and the opposition is leery of military adventure .
APW_ENG_19941202.0128;4	Defense Minister Volker Ruehe spoke out for the mission , but Klaus Rose , the chief of the defense committee in parliament for Kohl 's party , called the
APW_ENG_19941202.0128;5	request `` problematic '' because NATO 's goals in Bosnia are n't clear .
APW_ENG_19941202.0128;6	The German military has n't been in combat since the disastrous Nazi era , when German troops and SS commandos killed hundreds of thousands of Serbs , Jews and others in the Balkans .
APW_ENG_19941202.0128;7	`` Given the historical component , we 're going to have to think clearly about whether we want our first combat mission to be against the Serbs , '' said Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel , whose Free Democrats are junior partners in Kohl 's coalition .
APW_ENG_19941202.0128;8	Kinkel said he doubted there was parliamentary support for the mission .
APW_ENG_19941202.0128;9	Kohl said he would take his time in deciding whether to push for the mission .
APW_ENG_19941202.0129;0	Australian Nicole Lowien shot a bogey-free 6-under-par 66 Friday and took a one-shot lead after the first round of the Mizuno Ladies Golf Tournament , the season 's final event on the Japan LPGA tour .
APW_ENG_19941202.0129;1	Lowien , still winless in her six years as a professional in Japan , birdied Nos. 1 , 5 , 6 and 7 and eagled the 529-yard , par-5 14th hole on the Kumamoto Chuo Country Club course in southern Japan .
APW_ENG_19941202.0129;2	Nayoko Yoshikawa and Taiwan 's Huang Bie-shyun were one shot off the pace at 67 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0129;3	Michiko Hattori , Mayumi Murai and Aiko Takasu were grouped at 68 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0129;4	Ikuyo Shiotani , currently second on the Japan LPGA money list , shot a 70 and was in a group of seven players that included Marie-Laure De Lorenzi of France .
APW_ENG_19941202.0129;5	Mayumi Hirase , who leads the money list , made a slow start with a 1-over-par 73 , and was tied with Hiromi Kobayashi , a regular on the U.S. LPGA Tour .
APW_ENG_19941202.0129;6	Ayako Okamoto turned in a 5-over-par 77 .

APW_ENG_19941202.0130;0	Police arrested 11,000 people heading toward Bhopal Friday to take part in a demonstration marking the 10th anniversary of the world 's worst industrial accident , organizers said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;1	The people were taken off trains at various stations outside this central Indian city and charged for traveling without tickets -- a common practice in India usually punishable by a fine or a few hours in jail .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;2	`` Shame on you , government , '' said Abdul Jabbar Khan , of the Gas Victims Organization .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;3	On Dec. 2 , 1984 , a cloud of toxic chemicals leaked from a pesticide plant owned by the Indian subsidiary of Union Carbide Corp. , of Danbury , Conn.
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;4	About 4,000 people died that night , and 3,000 more deaths were later attributed to the effects of the gas .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;5	A half-million people are still seeking compensation .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;6	Chief Minister Digvijay Singh , who is the chief executive of Madhya Pradesh state , admitted that many people were arrested on trains moving toward the city .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;7	But Singh could not confirm the number and said he was not sure the arrests were related to the planned anniversary rally .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;8	Tens of thousands of people routinely travel without tickets on Indian railroads every day , but few are caught and arrested .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;9	Meanwhile , Khan led a march of 3,000 people from a city park to a square near the state legislature on Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;10	Police barricaded the roads and red police vans patrolled the area .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;11	The city administration banned the assembly of people around the legislature .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;12	Khan said his group planned a bigger demonstration Saturday and called for a one-day strike in the city .
APW_ENG_19941202.0130;13	He said his main demand was to clear the logjam that has blocked compensation for the victims .

APW_ENG_19941202.0133;0	Legislators across the political spectrum said Friday they doubted Germany would accept NATO 's request to send fighter planes to patrol the skies over Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0133;1	NATO on Thursday asked Germany to send six to eight Tornado fighters equipped with electronic radar-suppression gear and rockets to destroy radar sites .
APW_ENG_19941202.0133;2	They would protect allied planes involved in the U.N. humanitarian mission in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0133;3	In July , the nation 's high court ruled that combat missions overseas were legal , but must be approved by parliament , where Chancellor Helmut Kohl 's coalition has a wafer-thin majority and the opposition is leery of military adventure .
APW_ENG_19941202.0133;4	Defense Minister Volker Ruehe spoke out for the mission , but Klaus Rose , the chief of the defense committee in parliament for Kohl 's party , called the
APW_ENG_19941202.0133;5	request `` problematic '' because NATO 's goals in Bosnia are n't clear .
APW_ENG_19941202.0133;6	The German military has n't been in combat since the disastrous Nazi era , when German troops and SS commandos killed hundreds of thousands of Serbs , Jews and others in the Balkans .
APW_ENG_19941202.0133;7	`` Given the historical component , we 're going to have to think clearly about whether we want our first combat mission to be against the Serbs , '' said Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel , whose Free Democrats are junior partners in Kohl 's coalition .

APW_ENG_19941202.0134;0	Japan 's economy expanded at a robust annual rate of 3.7 percent in the July-September quarter , the Economic Planning Agency reported Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0134;1	The 0.9 percent increase from the previous quarter in Japan 's gross domestic product , a broad indicator of what a country produces within its own borders , prompted the normally cautious EPA to predict a `` full-scale recovery '' by the end of the current fiscal year next March .
APW_ENG_19941202.0134;2	Private economists remain somewhat more cautious , however , saying the fast pace of expansion may not last and that structural drags on the economy , including mountains of bad debt , may hold Japan 's recovery to a slow pace .
APW_ENG_19941202.0134;3	EPA Vice Minister Tsutomu Tanaka told reporters that domestic demand during the quarter grew strongly , helped by a one-year income tax cut that the government implemented in June as well as by Japan 's record summer heat wave .
APW_ENG_19941202.0134;4	The EPA , the government 's economic forecasting agency , has so far only tentatively talked about Japan 's economy heading toward recovery .
APW_ENG_19941202.0134;5	Tanaka 's statements Friday mark a much more bullish assessment than government officials have so far been willing to make .
APW_ENG_19941202.0134;6	Tanaka said it 's still difficult to predict how strongly the Japanese economy will grow , noting that the yen 's strength and the pace of growth in capital outlays must both be watched .
APW_ENG_19941202.0134;7	The surprising upturn of capital outlays , which account for roughly 20 percent of Japan 's GDP and have been the major drag on the economy in recent years as companies retreated from the heavy investments made during the late 1980s , was seen as a good sign .
APW_ENG_19941202.0134;8	But private analysts say it 's doubtful that the strong gains in personal consumption and capital spending seen in the latest quarter can be sustained during the current quarter .
APW_ENG_19941202.0134;9	The report definitely points to recovery but `` let 's not get carried away , '' said Mineko Sasaki-Smith , senior economist with Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd.
APW_ENG_19941202.0134;10	The scenario of a gradual upturn still remains most likely , she said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0134;11	The strong growth in the July-September quarter followed a relatively mild 0.2 percent expansion in the April-June quarter , which works out to 0.7 percent growth at an annual pace .
APW_ENG_19941202.0135;0	Share prices on the London Stock Exchange were lower at midday Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0135;1	At noon GMT , the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was 3,022.6 , down 17 points .
APW_ENG_19941202.0135;2	Volume was 204.9 million shares .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;0	China 's leaders are united behind an economic plan for 1995 to control the rapidly growing economy and curb runaway inflation , the country 's newspapers reported Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;1	The leaders announced after a four-day , closed-door national working conference on the economy that reforms would continue with no major changes , the newspapers said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;2	The reports gave no hints of the content of the debates about the extent and timing of reform that were expected at the gathering of top national leaders , provincial chiefs and officials from around the country .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;3	In recent years , government targets for cooling the economy often have been ignored at the provincial and local levels , where officials want to make the most of growth opportunities .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;4	An editorial Friday in the Communist Party newspaper People 's Daily called on party committees and governments at all levels to `` safeguard the authority '' of national economic policies and actually implement them .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;5	Slogans such as `` deepen reform , '' `` maintain stability , '' and `` strengthen macro-economic control , '' were typically numerous in news reports in the state-controlled press .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;6	But there were no new figures .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;7	The reports did not give any new target for reducing inflation , now running at more than 20 percent .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;8	It was possible that officials did not want to set targets that might not be met , or that they could not agree on new ones .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;9	`` China will continue to strengthen macroeconomic control over the national economy in order to seek a sustainable , rapid and healthy economic development next year , '' the official Xinhua News Agency said in summing up the conference .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;10	The Xinhua report was spread across the front pages of all major newspapers .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;11	The meeting agreed that the major problems were a lack of agricultural development , poor performance of state enterprises , a breakdown of social order and the growing gap between rich industrial areas and poor , rural inland areas , it said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;12	In addition , high inflation for the past two years has aroused concern throughout society , it said , warning that while some inflation during rapid economic growth was unavoidable , too much was dangerous .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;13	China 's leaders already had announced that controlling inflation and reforming failing state enterprises would be top goals for the new year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;14	State-run industries account for about half of China 's industrial output , and just under half of them have been losing money .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;15	Concerned about the possibility of social unrest , the government has so far stopped short of massive layoffs or cutting social services tied to state jobs .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;16	Other priorities listed in the latest economic plan included more spending on agriculture to ensure adequate food production .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;17	Strict control of bank credit will be continued .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;18	The People 's Daily editorial predicted an 11 percent growth rate for 1995 , about the same as this year 's .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;19	In a separate report , the Guangming Daily reported Friday a directive from the State Economic and Trade Commission ordering links be severed between all government and party offices and all commercial and business enterprises before the end of the year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;20	In recent years , as part of the transition from a centrally planned economy to a market-oriented one , many government economic and trade offices have been transformed into companies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;21	But for many of these new companies , the change was in name only .
APW_ENG_19941202.0136;22	They retained the same staff and maintained the same relationships with government and party organs , giving them an edge over competitors .
APW_ENG_19941202.0137;0	The IRA expects negotiations about weapons with the British to include security force arms as well as it own hidden arsenals , the movement 's political allies signalled Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0137;1	`` We 're prepared , perfectly prepared , to discuss the issue of the amount of weapons that are in circulation in Ireland , both legal and illegal , '' Mitchel McLaughlin , a spokesman for Sinn Fein , said on BBC radio .
APW_ENG_19941202.0137;2	Britain and Sinn Fein are to start talks in Belfast on Wednesday , the next big step in the search for a political settlement in Northern Ireland following the 3-month-old cease-fire by the IRA in its battle to end British rule .
APW_ENG_19941202.0137;3	Martin McGuinness , a former IRA commander who will lead the Sinn Fein team , has said for the first time that the future of the IRA weapons , mostly hidden over the border in the Republic of Ireland would be discussed .
APW_ENG_19941202.0137;4	Michael Mates , a British legislator and former minister sometimes used by the government to argue publicly with Sinn Fein , said the change of heart was `` very good news . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0137;5	`` Only a month ago Martin McGuinness was saying ` if I asked the IRA to hand over their weapons they 'd laugh ' , '' Mates said on the same program .
APW_ENG_19941202.0137;6	He maintained that Protestant politicians would not negotiate directly with the Catholic-based Sinn Fein or the IRA `` while behind while behind that organization is still the threat of returning to violence if they do n't get their way . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0137;7	Sinn Fein 's McLaughlin , however , said the IRA would need evidence of real progress in the talks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0137;8	Only then , he said , would it be `` realistic to go to those who have weapons and say ` we believe the conditions now exist where it would be possible and practical to take the gun out of Irish politics forever . '' '
APW_ENG_19941202.0138;0	Rod McGeoch , who masterminded Sydney 's successful bid to host the 2000 Olympic Games , is to be an adviser to a joint Australia-New Zealand bid to host the rugby union World Cup in 1999 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0138;1	Australia and New Zealand plan to combine in opposition to England 's bid to host the World Cup , and New Zealand Rugby Football Union president Eddie Tonks already has had talks with his Australian counterparts .
APW_ENG_19941202.0138;2	`` Australia initially came up with the idea of bidding for the Cup and they decided to get this guy -LRB- McGeoch -RRB- involved , '' Tonks said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0138;3	`` I met him in Sydney recently and he seems a very professional and impressive man .
APW_ENG_19941202.0138;4	`` We 're likely to be guided by him on our presentation to the International Rugby Board . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0138;5	Bids for the right to host the World Cup have to be placed with the IRB by Dec. 31 and the host country will be decided at the board 's March meeting .
APW_ENG_19941202.0138;6	McGeoch , a Sydney lawyer , was head of the Sydney 2000 Bid Committee that won the 2000 Olympic Games ahead of Beijing .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;0	Russian lawmakers in Chechnya for negotiations with its defiant president on Friday called on Russia to halt its air strikes against the rebel republic .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;1	`` It is clear that these planes are not English or French but Russian , '' said Ella Pamfilova , a member of parliament and former welfare minister .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;2	`` This is against the law . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;3	Other members of the parliamentary delegation also called for an end to the air strikes , warning the conflict could spiral out of control .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;4	Pamfilova spoke while awaiting a meeting with Chechen President Dzhokhar Dudayev .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;5	She is a part of four-person delegation trying to negotiate the release of 70 Russians captured in the fighting in Chechnya , a tiny , mostly Muslim republic in the Caucasus Mountains of southern Russia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;6	Dudayev at first threatened to kill the prisoners , whom he identified as Russian soldiers .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;7	He later said they would be tried in military courts .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;8	Russian Defense Minister Pavel Grachev has said the captives are mercenaries .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;9	Dudayev , who declared his fiesty republic 's independence from Russia in 1991 , accuses Moscow of arming and leading the rebels who are now trying to topple him .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;10	The rebels began an offensive last week backed by combat aircraft .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;11	Thousands of people have fled Grozny , a city of 300,000 , this week .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;12	Chechen officials said there was another round of air raids early Friday morning east of Grozny , including one on Shali , home to a tank regiment .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;13	On Thursday , a small airfield near Grozny was hit in an air raid and four people died in a missile attack at Katayama , about 20 kilometers -LRB- 12 miles -RRB- from Grozny .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;14	`` We saw two planes fly over this morning , '' the commander of the air field , Biali Chimayev , said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;15	`` We 're expecting another attack . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;16	Thursday 's raid destroyed an Mi-8 helicopter and four propeller planes but 11 tanks , including five captured form the opposition survived .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;17	Moscow does not recognize the independence of Chechnya , which became part of the Russian Empire in the 19th century after a series of long and bloody wars .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;18	Officially , the Kremlin says its support for Dudayev 's opposition is political and financial -- not military .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;19	But President Boris Yeltsin threatened earlier this week to send in troops unless the fighting stopped .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;20	He later softened his stance , but there are media reports of Russian troop buildups near the border .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;21	`` Chauvinist forces in Russian are pushing President Yeltsin to act , saying he can not control ` little ' Chechnya , '' warned Vladimir Lysenko , another member of the parliamentary delegation .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;22	Although ultranationalists , like the flamboyant Vladimir Zhirinovsky , constantly lament the loss of Moscow 's empire , most Russians are ready to let the Chechens go their own way .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;23	More than 74 percent of the 3,250 people questioned in a new poll said Russia should recognize Chechnya 's independence .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;24	Only 5.5 percent opposed it and 20.3 percent had no opinion .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;25	The poll , released Thursday by the International Opinion Research Center , had a 1 percent margin of error .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;26	Although Chechens are at odds , they are united in their distrust of Russia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;27	In Freedom Square outside Dudayev 's offices , several hundred volunteers cradling assault rifles and grenade launchers gathered to hear speeches Thursday while a tank maneuvered into position .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;28	Elders in tall fur hats , tunics and high leather boots danced in a circle , chanting , `` Freedom or death ! ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;29	Chechnya 's ancient warrior culture holds clan elders in high esteem .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;30	Lysenko , the Russian deputy , warned that the conflict is endangering the lives of the 150,000 ethnic Russians in Chechnya .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;31	In Copenhagen , a Russian journalist said Friday he received a fax from a group threatening Russians abroad if Moscow does not recognize Chechnya 's independence .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;32	The threat was signed `` K.K.K.O. 130 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;33	year , '' which Danish police said might stand for the North Caucasian Liberation Army .
APW_ENG_19941202.0139;34	Police in Copenhagen said they heard the group has been active in other countries .

APW_ENG_19941202.0140;34	Police in Copenhagen said they heard the group has been active in other countries .
APW_ENG_19941202.0141;0	Verdy Kawasaki on Friday captured the Japanese Professional Soccer League championship for the second straight year , beating Sanfrecce Hiroshima 1-0 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0141;1	More than 50,000 spectators at National Stadium saw 37-year-old Brazilian-born Japanese Ruy Ramos , overcoming a leg injury , fire a shot from just inside the penalty area past goalkeeper Kazumasa Kawano 's head into the goal 35 minutes into the second half .
APW_ENG_19941202.0141;2	Verdy , the second-stage champion and the 12-team J-League 's inaugural season champion in 1993 , defeated first-stage champion Sanfrecce 1-0 in the first game of the championship series .
APW_ENG_19941202.0141;3	Sanfrecce played aggressively at the start of the first half but Verdy gradually found its rhythm and overpowered Sanfrecce in the rest of the first half , outshooting them 4-1 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0141;4	Sanfrecce 's Czech player Cerny had a chance for a score in the 15th minute of the second half but his free kick went over the cross bar .
APW_ENG_19941202.0141;5	The 1995 J-League first-stage season starts March 18 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;0	The trial of three British soldiers accused of killing a Danish woman bogged down in legal complications Friday , with defense attorneys demanding the case be thrown out on a technicality .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;1	The trial was adjourned until Tuesday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;2	There have been a string of adjournments on legal technicalities since the men were arrested Sept. 13 for slaying Louise Jensen , a 23-year-old tour guide from Hirthshals , northern Denmark , after kidnapping her .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;3	Friday 's move followed a ruling by the three-judge assize court in this south coast resort city that it was competent to hear arguments on a defense motion for dismissal .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;4	The defense claims the confiscation of confidential notes the men had written for their lawyers by a guard in Nicosia 's Central prison , the only one on the east Mediterranean island , was illegal .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;5	State prosecutor Petros Clerides asked for time to consult the attorney general and stressed that such a legal point has never been raised in Cyprus before .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;6	That opened the possibility the case will be referred to the Supreme Court , the republic 's highest court .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;7	That could delay the trial for weeks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;8	The soldiers are privates Alan Ford , 26 , of Birmingham ; Justin Fowler , 26 , of Falmouth , Cornwall ; and Jeff Parnell , 23 , of Oldbury , West Midlands .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;9	The men , making their eighth court appearance Friday , have yet to enter their pleas on charges of manslaughter .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;10	The original charge of premeditated murder was reduced last month because the prosecution decided it might not be able to prove the men had planned to kill Jensen before they abducted her .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;11	Police said the Britons have admitted kidnapping and killing Jensen in the tourist resort of Ayia Napa Sept. 13 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;12	Her battered body was found in a shallow grave two days later .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;13	The soldiers were arrested at a police roadblock with bloodstains on their clothes and a blood-covered shovel in their car a few hours after Jensen 's Cypriot boyfriend reported her abduction .
APW_ENG_19941202.0142;14	All three serve with the Royal Greenjackets Regiments at the British Sovereign Base of Dhekelia on the island 's south coast .
APW_ENG_19941202.0143;0	A 24-hour Spanish-language news network has begun broadcasting in the United States , Spain and Latin America .
APW_ENG_19941202.0143;1	TeleNoticias was launched Thursday by a consortium of media companies : Reuters Television Ltd. , Telemundo Group Inc. , Antena 3 of Spain and Artear of Argentina .
APW_ENG_19941202.0143;2	The cable network provides continuous news , sports and business information , features and international weather updates with an emphasis on news of importance to Hispanics .
APW_ENG_19941202.0143;3	`` Our goal is to provide Spanish-speaking people throughout the world with news and information presented from their own perspective with the highest standards of reporting and production possible , '' said Gustavo Pupo-Mayo , TeleNoticias president .
APW_ENG_19941202.0143;4	Reuters , a subsidiary of Reuters Holding PLC of London , and Telemundo , a Spanish-language network , are majority owners of the network based here .
APW_ENG_19941202.0143;5	Antena 3 is the first and largest private television network in Spain .
APW_ENG_19941202.0143;6	Artear is owned by the Clarin Group , a media consortium that includes Argentina 's largest-circulation daily newspaper .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;0	She arched her back and waved .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;1	For a fraction of a second , she was the gymnastics star who scored the first-ever perfect 10 in the 1976 Montreal Olympic Games .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;2	Then Nadia Comaneci relaxed , took American fiance Bart Conner by the arm and annouced the pair would marry in Romania in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;3	After a hectic 10 days in her homeland , the 33-year-old former number 1 gymnast , left Romania Friday , saying she was `` very moved '' by the warm welcome given her five years after she defected in what turned out to be the waning days of Communist rule .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;4	During her stay here , she returned to her hometown , met the president and performed in front of the prime minister .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;5	`` People are more open , they are freer and say what they think , '' said a smiling Comaneci , dressed in jeans and a denim shirt .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;6	`` I know how it was before , '' she said in Romanian , translating for Conner .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;7	Conner , also a gymnast gold medallist , talked about the `` warm and exciting reception '' the couple received , saying the most memorable moment was when he asked Gheorghe Comeneci for his daughter 's hand .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;8	Five years ago , Nadia Comaneci left Romania in a dramatic escape .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;9	It was just one month before the collapse of the regime of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;10	Nadia says she was at a dead end when she left .
APW_ENG_19941202.0144;11	Five years later , with a new man , an attractive job promoting underwear and a gym to manage in Norman , Okla. , she says she 's happy .
APW_ENG_19941202.0145;0	Premier Edouard Balladur assured world soccer chief Joao Havelange on Friday that France was on course to host a successful World Cup in 1998 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0145;1	But Balladur admitted his government 's influence was limited .
APW_ENG_19941202.0145;2	`` As for successes on the field , it 's up to our national team to achieve them , '' he said of the squad that failed to reach this year 's finals .
APW_ENG_19941202.0145;3	`` I wish them good luck . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0145;4	Havelange met Balladur and senior French soccer officials at the close of a week-long trip in which the president of FIFA visited eight of the 10 cities that will host matches during the 1998 finals .
APW_ENG_19941202.0145;5	`` With this meeting , we kick off the operational phase of organization , '' Balladur said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0145;6	`` All the essential decisions have been made .
APW_ENG_19941202.0145;7	Ten stadiums have been chosen . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0145;8	He said his government has agreed to pay 36 percent of the cost of stadium improvements and infrastructure expansion , up from 30 percent pledged by the Socialist government ousted in 1993 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0145;9	The major project is construction of France 's biggest stadium , in the Paris suburb of Saint Denis .
APW_ENG_19941202.0145;10	Balladur said the 80,000-seat Grande Stade , venue of the opening and final matches , will go under construction in the spring .
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;0	President Boris Yeltsin wants the Budapest summit of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to declare that military blocs like NATO have no `` real future , '' a news agency said Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;1	Russia has also proposed that the meeting , slated for Dec. 5-6 , adopt a declaration giving the CSCE the dominant role in ensuring European security , the ITAR-Tass news agency said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;2	Russia has tried to dilute the role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization after the collapse of the Warsaw Pact created a political and military vacuum in Europe , causing many former Soviet bloc nations to seek closer ties with the NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;3	In an effort to meet these demands , NATO approved a Partnership for Peace program to bring former foes closer , but without membership .
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;4	ITAR-Tass said Russia would seek the adoption of a declaration saying , `` the CSCE has always played and will go on playing the key role in ensuring Europe 's security and stability . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;5	The proposed document will also say , `` alignments have no real future . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;6	Twenty-three nations , including Russia , have enrolled in the Partnership for Peace project , which allows them to take part for the first time in military exercises and other alliance activities .
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;7	On Thursday , the allies decided to go further by ordering aides to conduct a 12-month study of terms and conditions for expanding the Western military alliance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;8	In an effort to overcome Russian objections to its eastward expansion , the NATO allies agreed to a special relationship with Moscow and insisted they had no intention of forming a hostile bloc .
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;9	But Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev said in Brussels on Thursday that NATO 's decision to draw up conditions for granting membership to former Soviet bloc countries would create a new division in Europe .
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;10	Kozyrev 's remarks stunned NATO foreign ministers who expected him to endorse the plan .
APW_ENG_19941202.0146;11	Yeltsin leaves for Budapest on Sunday and is expected to address the CSCE plenary session Monday afternoon , ITAR-Tass said .
