APW_ENG_19941202.0578;0	Marking a milestone in Taiwan 's shift to democracy , Taiwanese voters went to the polls Saturday in the toughest electoral test for the island 's Nationalist rulers in 45 years .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;1	The elections are part of the reforms initiated by the Nationalists , who ruled by martial law until unleashing a bloodless democratic revolution in 1987 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;2	Voters were electing a Taiwan governor , mayors for Taipei and Kaohsiung -- the island 's two largest cities -- local councilors and provincial assemblymen .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;3	Polling stations opened at 8 a.m. -LRB- 0000 GMT -RRB- , and results are expected about eight hours after the planned close of 11,825 polling stations islandwide at 4 p.m. -LRB- 0800 GMT -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;4	Newspapers predicted up to 70 percent of Taiwan 's 13.8 million eligible voters would turn out .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;5	The polls are a prelude to Taiwan 's first direct presidential election in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;6	President Lee Teng-hui 's prospects for another term will be measured by his Nationalists ' performance Saturday against the main opposition , the Democratic Progressive Party .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;7	The Nationalists fled to Taiwan to escape the 1949 Communist takeover of mainland China .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;8	They still say they hope one day to reunite Taiwan with the Chinese motherland .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;9	But the DPP advocates Taiwanese independence , something China has vowed to resist by force , and DPP successes Saturday could bring warnings from Beijing .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;10	The campaigning has focused largely on `` Tong-Du '' -- reunification vs. independence .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;11	To the annoyance of the DPP , business leaders placed newspaper ads days before the poll warning that Taiwan 's dollar and the island 's standing with investors could plummet if pro-independence forces gain power .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;12	But the DPP may profit from a split in the Nationalist vote caused by the recently formed New Party , which quit the Nationalists last year after accusing them of abandoning the commitment to reunification .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;13	The DPP 's Chen Shui-bian is thought to be a frontrunner in the race fo Taipei mayor , while Nationalist James Soong has a 50-40 lead over the DPP 's Chen Ting-nan in the gubernatorial race , according to latest surveys .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;14	Candidates held final rallies Friday night , including tens of thousands of cheering New Party supporters who packed Taipei 's municipal stadium .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;15	The feverish election campaign , which sometimes resembled a carnival , is a sign of Taiwanese enthusiasm for democracy .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;16	Taipei 's streets and many of its taxis were covered with flags .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;17	In the last few days , campaigners lulled the capital to sleep at night with drums and roused it each morning with firecrackers .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;18	Interior Minister Wu Poh-hsiung even complained that precious resources were wasted and that the campaign flags `` could have clothed 1 million refugees . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;19	Enthusiasm and heated debate sometimes spilled over into violence .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;20	Riot police were often at campaign rallies and 70,000 officers were keeping order Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;21	In a statement Friday , President Lee appealed for calm on polling day so Taiwan can `` welcome a new era of democracy for all . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;22	Other officials appealed to voters not to take bribes , a problem in past elections as well as this one .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;23	The DPP filed a lawsuit Wednesday accusing the Nationalists of earmarking about 150 million Taiwan dollars -LRB- U.S. dlrs 5.6 million -RRB- to buy votes for Huang Ta-chou , Taipei 's incumbent Nationalist mayor , who is lagging in opinion polls .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;24	The Nationalists denied the allegations and appealed against vote-buying .
APW_ENG_19941202.0578;25	Government-controlled TV ran advertisements showing vote-buyers in handcuffs .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;0	In a small , windowless room in public school No. 728 lies what 14-year-old Anton calls Russia 's `` future '' -- the school 's only computer .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;1	At School 728 , after spending hours in poorly heated classrooms where they have to share tattered Soviet-era textbooks , students come to the `` computer closet '' to work on the school 's innovative on-line newspaper .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;2	Or to send e-mail to students in Minnesota .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;3	Or to practice their French on an electronic conference with European schoolchildren .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;4	Like most of Russia 's roads , its information highway is still ridden with potholes and Soviet-style dead-end alleys .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;5	Nevertheless , the next generation of Russian leaders is building its own onramps and starting to cruise .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;6	`` The kids may not understand yet what this access , this communication , means for them , '' said Volodya Pilipchuk , the school 's computer adviser and a former 728 student .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;7	`` But 10 years from now , they will . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;8	Pilipchuk 's students have joined the millions of people -- from New York businessmen to human rights activists in East Timor -- who communicate via a worldwide web of tens of thousands of interconnected computer networks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;9	For Anton and his classmates , it does n't seem to matter that they were born in a society famous for restricting such free information flows .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;10	Or that some of their parents built careers on imposing those restrictions .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;11	What matters to these kids is the computer itself .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;12	Dozens of students huddle around its single screen during breaks , as Pilipchuk struggles to ration out computer time to eager users .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;13	The well-worn machine is especially popular among the students here , most of whom , unlike many of their U.S. counterparts , had never seen a computer before this project began .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;14	Olga Galkina , the founder of the school 's on-line newspaper , says the project is aimed at `` helping kids understand their global importance . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;15	And ultimately , she hopes , these children may be the ones to guide the rest of the former Soviet Union into the information age .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;16	Much of Russia 's wealth of computer expertise has been lured to the West , leaving a relatively small cadre of dedicated but underfunded programmers to bring new technologies to this vast nation .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;17	In the meantime , the kids are just having fun .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;18	`` Look , I can type in English , '' boasted Sasha , a 12-year-old in an L.A. Raiders sweatshirt .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;19	`` Even my older brother ca n't do that . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;20	The latest issue of `` Southern Zone , '' the on-line version of the school paper , included articles on topics from a nature reserve in Russia 's Far North to the music of David Lee Roth .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;21	The issue was posted on the local network Glasnet , which is connected to the worldwide Internet meganetwork , allowing computers around the world access to the newspaper .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;22	The latest publication has evoked responses from users from Holland to Minnesota .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;23	`` The messages from the American kids are funny , '' said Alyosha , tugging on his long blond bangs .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;24	`` Someone asked if Russia was bigger than California . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;25	These kids are also proving that the information highway does not have to remain a limited access tollroad , affordable for only an elite few .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;26	The school 's computer , a standard IBM-compatible 386 with an internal modem , is on long-term loan from John Whitely , a sociology professor at the University of California at Irvine .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;27	Whitely loaned the machine to Galkina for the on-line newspaper project in 1992 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;28	And Glasnet , a non-profit Russian computer network , donated an e-mail account to the school , bringing the total cost of the project to just a few dollars per year -- less than the budget for the on-paper version of the school newspaper .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;29	The project is a bargain even for public schools like this one .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;30	Russia 's cash-strapped public education system is struggling to support its 65,000 schools , where teachers earn about 120,000 rubles -LRB- dlrs 40 -RRB- a month .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;31	School 728 is just one of several seeds of hope .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;32	At least 300 Russian schools have access to e-mail accounts , at least 250 of which are outside of Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;33	`` The numbers are still not high , for a country this size , '' said Galkina , who is now working on a project to connect disabled children in Russia to on-line services .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;34	`` But Russia , like the United States , wo n't become computer literate overnight . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;35	Computer literacy is still not a top priority for School 728 's administrators , who pay little attention to the cramped computer closet .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;36	`` Yes , I know there 's something going on over there , '' said Nina Mikhailova , head of the student relations department , in the opposite wing of the school .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;37	`` But it does n't concern us .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;38	We do n't use computers over here . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;39	The administration may be wary , but its pupils are already making plans .
APW_ENG_19941202.0579;40	`` I want to be a programmer , '' Anton said , `` because the world ca n't survive without computers . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0580;0	Share prices rose slightly over the week on the British stock exchange .
APW_ENG_19941202.0580;1	The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed 16.2 points up over the week at 3,017.3 on Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;0	In a small , windowless room in public school No. 728 lies what 14-year-old Anton calls Russia 's `` future '' -- the school 's only computer .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;1	At School 728 , after spending hours in poorly heated classrooms where they have to share tattered Soviet-era textbooks , students come to the `` computer closet '' to work on the school 's innovative on-line newspaper .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;2	Or to send e-mail to students in Minnesota .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;3	Or to practice their French on an electronic conference with European schoolchildren .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;4	Like most of Russia 's roads , its information highway is still ridden with potholes and Soviet-style dead-end alleys .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;5	Nevertheless , the next generation of Russian leaders is building its own onramps and starting to cruise .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;6	`` The kids may not understand yet what this access , this communication , means for them , '' said Volodya Pilipchuk , the school 's computer adviser and a former 728 student .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;7	`` But 10 years from now , they will . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;8	Pilipchuk 's students have joined the millions of people -- from New York businessmen to human rights activists in East Timor -- who communicate via a worldwide web of tens of thousands of interconnected computer networks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;9	For Anton and his classmates , it does n't seem to matter that they were born in a society famous for restricting such free information flows .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;10	Or that some of their parents built careers on imposing those restrictions .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;11	What matters to these kids is the computer itself .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;12	Dozens of students huddle around its single screen during breaks , as Pilipchuk struggles to ration out computer time to eager users .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;13	The well-worn machine is especially popular among the students here , most of whom , unlike many of their U.S. counterparts , had never seen a computer before this project began .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;14	Olga Galkina , the founder of the school 's on-line newspaper , says the project is aimed at `` helping kids understand their global importance . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;15	And ultimately , she hopes , these children may be the ones to guide the rest of the former Soviet Union into the information age .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;16	Much of Russia 's wealth of computer expertise has been lured to the West , leaving a relatively small cadre of dedicated but underfunded programmers to bring new technologies to this vast nation .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;17	In the meantime , the kids are just having fun .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;18	`` Look , I can type in English , '' boasted Sasha , a 12-year-old in an L.A. Raiders sweatshirt .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;19	`` Even my older brother ca n't do that . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;20	The latest issue of `` Southern Zone , '' the on-line version of the school paper , included articles on topics from a nature reserve in Russia 's Far North to the music of David Lee Roth .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;21	The issue was posted on the local network Glasnet , which is connected to the worldwide Internet meganetwork , allowing computers around the world access to the newspaper .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;22	The latest publication has evoked responses from users from Holland to Minnesota .
APW_ENG_19941202.0581;23	`` The messages from the American kids are funny , '' said Alyosha , tugging on his long blond bangs .

APW_ENG_19941202.0582;0	The United States has offered shelter in its refugee camps to up to 900 of the Cubans who have fled to this tiny British territory , Cayman officials said Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;1	If the Cubans accept the offer , they would go to camps at the U.S. Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay , Cuba , and in Panama , Gerry Maguire , the territory 's chief immigration officer , told the refugees in a meeting at their tent camp .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;2	The U.S. camps already hold thousands of refugees .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;3	The Cayman refugees probably would n't be transferred until early next year , government spokeswoman Pat Ebanks said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;4	`` It will be a significant weight off our shoulders , '' Ebanks said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;5	The announcement came after months of talks with U.S. officials and a day after more than 300 Cuban women and children marched peacefully through George Town calling on the United States to let them in .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;6	Also Friday , the United States announced new immigration rules that will allow more Cuban families now sheltered in refugee camps to enter .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;7	Hundreds of Cubans fled here after an outbreak of hijackings and riots in early August prompted Cuban President Fidel Castro to allow people to leave by boat .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;8	President Clinton then barred the new wave of Cuban boat people from entering the United States .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;9	The approximately 1,150 Cubans now sheltered here represent about 4 percent of the 30,000 residents of this tourist resort and offshore banking center just 70 miles -LRB- 110 kilometers -RRB- south of Cuba .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;10	But the Caymans ' Cuban problem is far from resolved , Ebanks said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;11	Many Cubans have said they do n't want to go to Guantanamo because it 's too close to the homeland they want to escape and because a larger camp does n't appeal to them , Ebanks said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;12	Even if all 900 accept , that still would leave about 250 refugees .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;13	The Cayman government has decided to grant asylum to a small , as-yet-undetermined number of Cubans who fled political persecution , Ebanks said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;14	Twenty-four refugees have asked to return to Cuba and will be flown back , probably within two weeks , Ebanks said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;15	As a last resort , the Cayman government could repatriate those who remain , she said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;16	`` We 're really not heaving a sigh of relief .
APW_ENG_19941202.0582;17	Not for ourselves and not for the Cubans , '' Ebanks said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0583;0	A collector paid 6,325 pounds -LRB- dlrs 9,687 -RRB- on Friday for the only known letter from French author Alain Fournier to the woman on whom he based the heroine of his novel `` Le Grand Meaulnes . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0583;1	The 10-page love letter , written in 1905 when Fournier was 19 , was sold anonymously and bought by Roy Davids , a British-based dealer and private collector .
APW_ENG_19941202.0583;2	`` Le Grand Meaulnes '' was the only novel by Fournier , who was killed in action during World War I -- September 1914 , a year after the book 's publication .
APW_ENG_19941202.0583;3	The letter , with an envelope marked Y. H. , is addressed to `` Yvonne '' -- and her identity remains a mystery .
APW_ENG_19941202.0583;4	The seller of the letter was not identified .
APW_ENG_19941202.0583;5	Fournier referred to her as `` my first Yvonne '' -- one of two Yvonnes whom he admired from afar , fell in love with and followed at a distance .
APW_ENG_19941202.0583;6	Both women provided aspects of his heroine Yvonne de Galais .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;0	Lucien Bouchard , the charismatic Quebec separatist who leads the opposition in Canada 's House of Commons , lost his leg to a flesh-eating disease but doctors said his life was not in danger .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;1	Bouchard , 55 , vowed to continue his political career , dedicated to making Quebec an independent country .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;2	`` Mr. Bouchard has greatly improved over the past 12 hours , '' Dr. Patrick d'Amico told a news conference at Montreal 's St. Luc Hospital on Friday , a day after Bouchard 's leg was amputated .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;3	D'Amico said Bouchard underwent three operations since being admitted to the hospital Tuesday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;4	If no further complications occur , the doctor said , Bouchard should recover fully in about three or four months .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;5	Bouchard was struck by a rare disease known as necrotizing myositis .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;6	It is similar to necrotizing fasciitis , the `` flesh-eating disease '' that caused alarm in Britain this year , but attacks muscle rather than connective tissue .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;7	Dr. Francois Lamothe , a specialist in microbiology who also appeared at the news conference , said the disease is caused by the streptococcus A bacterium .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;8	It is fatal in 80 percent of the cases .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;9	The bacteria are common and infection usually results in sore throats or tonsillitis .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;10	But in about one case in a million , the bacterium turns deadly .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;11	Bouchard , a former Conservative Cabinet minister , bolted former Prime Minister Brian Mulroney 's government in 1990 and formed his own party .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;12	The new party became , effectively , the national arm of the Parti Quebecois , the provincial party dedicated to the secession of Quebec .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;13	In the 1993 federal elections , the Bloc Quebecois won 54 seats to become the official opposition to the ruling Liberals in the House of Commons .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;14	Few wanted to speculate on what the absence of Bouchard would have on the political scene or a referendum on independence expected next year in Quebec .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;15	`` Next week we 'll work with a great sense of solidarity , '' said Gilles Duceppe , the Bloc Quebecois whip .
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;16	`` We 'll just wait for Mr. Bouchard to come back . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0584;17	Prime Minister Jean Chretien , on a trip to France , expressed a `` sincere wish for a rapid return of his health . ''

APW_ENG_19941202.0587;0	The Muslim call to prayer drifted into Hanna Hashab 's garden cottage as Yever Rainesch surveyed the living room decorated with crocheted doilies and plastic red roses .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;1	`` How much does it cost to buy a house in the village ? ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;2	asked Mrs. Rainesch , who immigrated from Russia to this Arab village in northern Israel .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;3	Rainesch was interested in property , but she was invited to visit Hashab 's home with more grand visions in mind .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;4	She was introduced to Hashab , an Israeli Arab , as part wide-ranging Labor Party attempt to change attitudes toward Arabs and shore up support for its peace policies , especially among young voters and immigrants from the former Soviet Union .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;5	Russian immigrants voted 2-to-1 for Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin 's ruling Labor Party in 1992 , when it won a narrow victory over the right-wing Likud bloc .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;6	With the next elections less than two years away , Likud has pulled even with Labor in recent polls and Labor leaders fear that one of Israel 's most powerful constituencies will swing the balance of power to the right in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;7	By then , the immigrants will make up 10 percent of Israel 's population of 5.4 million and could theoretically control 12 swing seats in the 120-member Parliament .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;8	Aware of that possible electoral clout , immigrant leader Natan Sharansky says he may form a party to run in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;9	`` The immigrants in general feel frustrated and disappointed by the government 's treatment of their absorption , '' Sharansky said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;10	`` More and more immigrants feel alienated and like a second class in Israel . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;11	Past elections indicate Russians almost automatically vote against the establishment and carry anti-Muslim sentiment from ethnic conflicts at home .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;12	They are also generally suspicious of land-for-peace deals .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;13	In an effort to change those attitudes , The Golda Meir Association , an educational institute close to the Labor Party , is taking immigrants such as Rainesch and introducing them to Israeli Arabs in their daily lives .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;14	Earlier this month , 15 immigrants toured Kalansua 's mosque and flower hothouses , attended an Arab-style lunch and met with villagers in their homes .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;15	Addressing the visitors at a trade union clubhouse , union secretary Asad Hadiga said : `` We are all Muslims .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;16	We support peace as the way of Islam . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;17	However , the Russians were not so easily reassured .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;18	One woman said that since the bloody October bus bombing in Tel Aviv by a Muslim militant , she feels afraid whenever she sees an Arab .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;19	`` We Arabs are not terrorists , '' responded one middle-aged Arab in a checkered shirt .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;20	Another troublesome group for Labor are the 400,000 younger , first-time voters for whom Israeli control over the West Bank , the Golan Heights and Arab east Jerusalem is a fact of life .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;21	Israel captured the lands in the 1967 Mideast war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;22	`` They are vulnerable to right-wing principles of having political and historical , if not religious , rights to the land , '' said Stanley Ringler , a Labor official .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;23	In an effort to sway those voters , Labor started sending reserve generals and lawmakers to schools to explain land-for-peace policies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;24	Labor legislator Ori Orr , a reserve major general , kicked off the campaign this month by fielding questions at an Israeli high school .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;25	One student questioned Rabin 's credibility , noting that during the 1992 campaign the prime minister spoke of holding onto the Golan Heights , but has since proposed a significant withdrawal .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;26	Orr said Syria would first have to make concessions on water rights and its military presence in Lebanon before Israel would even consider giving back land .
APW_ENG_19941202.0587;27	`` If there are no answers to these questions , there wo n't be a peace treaty , '' Orr reassured the students .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;0	The Toronto Blue Jays said Friday they intend to honor Ontario law and wo n't use replacement players in the SkyDome if owners start the season without striking Major League players .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;1	Ontario Labor Minister Shirley Coppen said this week the province 's law barring replacement workers applies to the baseball team .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;2	`` As far as she can determine , the Blue Jays fall under this legislation , '' Blue Jays chairman Peter Widdrington said Friday by telephone .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;3	`` If it 's the law , we 're not going to try to obviate the law .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;4	We will follow the law . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;5	The Montreal Expos would be able to use replacement players because Quebec law applies only to unions certified in that province .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;6	`` This is not a certified union and we have very right to do so , '' Expos president Claude Brochu said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;7	Major League players , upset over proposals to limit their salaries , went on strike Aug. 12 , eventually forcing owners to cancel the rest of the season and the World Series .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;8	Boston Red Sox chief executive officer John Harrington , management 's chief labor negotiator , said Tuesday that owners intend to use replacement if the union 's strike continues into the start of the season next spring .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;9	`` I do n't want to get into the whole discussion of replacement players , '' acting commissioner Bud Selig said Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;10	`` That 's an option that at some point if we do n't have an agreement ... we 'll have to consider . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;11	Management lawyer Chuck O'Connor said the American League would have to decide how to handle the Blue Jays ' situation if other teams use replacements and Toronto ca n't play at home .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;12	But O'Connor said management lawyers still believe it is possible to use replacements in Toronto .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;13	`` We have n't completely foreclosed it yet , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;14	`` Our lawyers in Canada believe something can be done . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;15	Players and owners , who are n't scheduled to meet again until next Friday , both are preparing for the possibility of replacements .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;16	The Major League Baseball Players Association asked the U.S. Labor Department on Nov. 14 to certify the strike .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;17	If the department grants the request , non-U.S. citizens could n't obtain visas to play in the majors unless they were on 40-man rosters Aug. 11 , the day before the strike began .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;18	U.S. Employment Services , a division of Labor Department , will make the decision after owners repond .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;19	`` The importation of foreign labor for the purposes of breaking a strike is fundamentally inconsistent with the code of federal regulations that INS has issued , '' said Eugene Orza , the union 's No. 2 official .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;20	Immigration and Naturalization Service regulations state : `` If the Secretary of Labor certifies to the -LRB- INS -RRB- commissioner that a strike ... is in progress in the occupation and at the place where the beneficiary is to be employed or trained , and that the employment of training of the beneficiary would adversely affect the wages and working conditions of U.S. citizens and lawful resident-workers , a petition ... shall be denied . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;21	Labor Department spokesman Camille Johnston said it was unclear how long it would take for the agency to respond to the union 's request for strike certification .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;22	Some management officials , speaking on the condition they not be identified , have said in recent weeks that they expect Latin players will break ranks and report to spring training .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;23	The union says there 's no evidence to support that notion .
APW_ENG_19941202.0588;24	`` I have never heard anything like that discussed , '' Selig said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;0	Hundreds of angry Haitians menaced a neighborhood gunman after multinational soldiers freed him Friday , prompting the foreign soldiers to return to save him two hours later .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;1	Samuel Chery , who had terrorized a neighborhood in this Port-au-Prince suburb after the September 1991 military coup that ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide , had been held for nearly two months after U.S. soldiers arrested him .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;2	Chery , known as `` Ti Samuel , '' was an `` attache , '' one of thousands of thugs who had Haitian military support to beat or kill Aristide supporters .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;3	He was freed by foreign troops at 2 p.m. , prompting uncomprehending screams from neighbors .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;4	Hundreds of people gathered , grabbing sticks or carrying machetes .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;5	They surrounded Chery 's home .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;6	He had thrown rocks at them and locked his door .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;7	A Humvee carrying foreign soldiers arrived two hours later and took away Chery .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;8	Telephones were not functioning at the U.S. military 's Joint Information Bureau late Friday , and it was not clear why Chery was freed or where he was being held .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;9	Former U.S. Attorney General Ramsay Clark accused the United States on Friday of protecting members of the right-wing terror group FRAPH even after intervening to return Aristide .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;10	The Front for the Advancement and Progress of Haiti says it is converting into a political organization .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;11	A FRAPH leader , Emmanuel Constant , renounced violence at a U.S.-arranged news conference two months ago .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;12	`` The same forces that planned the coup '' are maintaining the level of violence , Clark told reporters after a five-day fact-finding mission of his Haiti Commission human rights group .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;13	`` The longer the criminals go unpunished , the more likely it is that the people will take justice into their own hands , '' said lawyer Michael Ratner , another commission member and director of the New York-based Center for Constitutional Rights .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;14	The U.N. civilian mission in a Nov. 22 communique said `` a certain degree of violence prevailed until the end of October .
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;15	Since then , without having entirely disappeared , violent incidents are much rarer . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0589;16	The mission reported , however , that many people believe `` that the disarmament and dismantlement of groups which were part of the former repressive apparatus have been insufficient . ''

APW_ENG_19941202.0590;7	`` But 10 years from now , they will . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;8	Pilipchuk 's students have joined the millions of people -- from New York businessmen to human rights activists in East Timor -- who communicate via a worldwide web of tens of thousands of interconnected computer networks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;9	For Anton and his classmates , it does n't seem to matter that they were born in a society famous for restricting such free information flows .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;10	Or that some of their parents built careers on imposing those restrictions .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;11	What matters to these kids is the computer itself .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;12	Dozens of students huddle around its single screen during breaks , as Pilipchuk struggles to ration out computer time to eager users .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;13	The well-worn machine is especially popular among the students here , most of whom , unlike many of their U.S. counterparts , had never seen a computer before this project began .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;14	Olga Galkina , the founder of the school 's on-line newspaper , says the project is aimed at `` helping kids understand their global importance . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;15	And ultimately , she hopes , these children may be the ones to guide the rest of the former Soviet Union into the information age .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;16	Much of Russia 's wealth of computer expertise has been lured to the West , leaving a relatively small cadre of dedicated but underfunded programmers to bring new technologies to this vast nation .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;17	In the meantime , the kids are just having fun .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;18	`` Look , I can type in English , '' boasted Sasha , a 12-year-old in an L.A. Raiders sweatshirt .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;19	`` Even my older brother ca n't do that . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;20	The latest issue of `` Southern Zone , '' the on-line version of the school paper , included articles on topics from a nature reserve in Russia 's Far North to the music of David Lee Roth .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;21	The issue was posted on the local network Glasnet , which is connected to the worldwide Internet meganetwork , allowing computers around the world access to the newspaper .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;22	The latest publication has evoked responses from users from Holland to Minnesota .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;23	`` The messages from the American kids are funny , '' said Alyosha , tugging on his long blond bangs .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;24	`` Someone asked if Russia was bigger than California . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;25	These kids are also proving that the information highway does not have to remain a limited access tollroad , affordable for only an elite few .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;26	The school 's computer , a standard IBM-compatible 386 with an internal modem , is on long-term loan from John Whitely , a sociology professor at the University of California at Irvine .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;27	Whitely loaned the machine to Galkina for the on-line newspaper project in 1992 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;28	And Glasnet , a non-profit Russian computer network , donated an e-mail account to the school , bringing the total cost of the project to just a few dollars per year -- less than the budget for the on-paper version of the school newspaper .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;29	The project is a bargain even for public schools like this one .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;30	Russia 's cash-strapped public education system is struggling to support its 65,000 schools , where teachers earn about 120,000 rubles -LRB- dlrs 40 -RRB- a month .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;31	School 728 is just one of several seeds of hope .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;32	At least 300 Russian schools have access to e-mail accounts , at least 250 of which are outside of Moscow .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;33	`` The numbers are still not high , for a country this size , '' said Galkina , who is now working on a project to connect disabled children in Russia to on-line services .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;34	`` But Russia , like the United States , wo n't become computer literate overnight . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;35	Computer literacy is still not a top priority for School 728 's administrators , who pay little attention to the cramped computer closet .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;36	`` Yes , I know there 's something going on over there , '' said Nina Mikhailova , head of the student relations department , in the opposite wing of the school .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;37	`` But it does n't concern us .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;38	We do n't use computers over here . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;39	The administration may be wary , but its pupils are already making plans .
APW_ENG_19941202.0590;40	`` I want to be a programmer , '' Anton said , `` because the world ca n't survive without computers . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;0	The Muslim call to prayer drifted into Hanna Hashab 's garden cottage as Yever Rainesch surveyed the living room decorated with crocheted doilies and plastic red roses .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;1	`` How much does it cost to buy a house in the village ? ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;2	asked Mrs. Rainesch , who immigrated from Russia to this Arab village in northern Israel .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;3	Rainesch was interested in property , but she was invited to visit Hashab 's home with more grand visions in mind .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;4	She was introduced to Hashab , an Israeli Arab , as part wide-ranging Labor Party attempt to change attitudes toward Arabs and shore up support for its peace policies , especially among young voters and immigrants from the former Soviet Union .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;5	Russian immigrants voted 2-to-1 for Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin 's ruling Labor Party in 1992 , when it won a narrow victory over the right-wing Likud bloc .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;6	With the next elections less than two years away , Likud has pulled even with Labor in recent polls and Labor leaders fear that one of Israel 's most powerful constituencies will swing the balance of power to the right in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;7	By then , the immigrants will make up 10 percent of Israel 's population of 5.4 million and could theoretically control 12 swing seats in the 120-member Parliament .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;8	Aware of that possible electoral clout , immigrant leader Natan Sharansky says he may form a party to run in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;9	`` The immigrants in general feel frustrated and disappointed by the government 's treatment of their absorption , '' Sharansky said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;10	`` More and more immigrants feel alienated and like a second class in Israel . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;11	Past elections indicate Russians almost automatically vote against the establishment and carry anti-Muslim sentiment from ethnic conflicts at home .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;12	They are also generally suspicious of land-for-peace deals .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;13	In an effort to change those attitudes , The Golda Meir Association , an educational institute close to the Labor Party , is taking immigrants such as Rainesch and introducing them to Israeli Arabs in their daily lives .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;14	Earlier this month , 15 immigrants toured Kalansua 's mosque and flower hothouses , attended an Arab-style lunch and met with villagers in their homes .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;15	Addressing the visitors at a trade union clubhouse , union secretary Asad Hadiga said : `` We are all Muslims .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;16	We support peace as the way of Islam . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;17	However , the Russians were not so easily reassured .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;18	One woman said that since the bloody October bus bombing in Tel Aviv by a Muslim militant , she feels afraid whenever she sees an Arab .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;19	`` We Arabs are not terrorists , '' responded one middle-aged Arab in a checkered shirt .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;20	Another troublesome group for Labor are the 400,000 younger , first-time voters for whom Israeli control over the West Bank , the Golan Heights and Arab east Jerusalem is a fact of life .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;21	Israel captured the lands in the 1967 Mideast war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;22	`` They are vulnerable to right-wing principles of having political and historical , if not religious , rights to the land , '' said Stanley Ringler , a Labor official .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;23	In an effort to sway those voters , Labor started sending reserve generals and lawmakers to schools to explain land-for-peace policies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;24	Labor legislator Ori Orr , a reserve major general , kicked off the campaign this month by fielding questions at an Israeli high school .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;25	One student questioned Rabin 's credibility , noting that during the 1992 campaign the prime minister spoke of holding onto the Golan Heights , but has since proposed a significant withdrawal .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;26	Orr said Syria would first have to make concessions on water rights and its military presence in Lebanon before Israel would even consider giving back land .
APW_ENG_19941202.0591;27	`` If there are no answers to these questions , there wo n't be a peace treaty , '' Orr reassured the students .
APW_ENG_19941202.0592;0	In a small , windowless room in public school No. 728 lies what 14-year-old Anton calls Russia 's `` future '' -- the school 's only computer .
APW_ENG_19941202.0592;1	At School 728 , after spending hours in poorly heated classrooms where they have to share tattered Soviet-era textbooks , students come to the `` computer closet '' to work on the school 's innovative on-line newspaper .
APW_ENG_19941202.0592;2	Or to send e-mail to students in Minnesota .
APW_ENG_19941202.0592;3	Or to practice their French on an electronic conference with European schoolchildren .
APW_ENG_19941202.0592;4	Like most of Russia 's roads , its information highway is still ridden with potholes and Soviet-style dead-end alleys .
APW_ENG_19941202.0592;5	Nevertheless , the next generation of Russian leaders is building its own onramps and starting to cruise .
APW_ENG_19941202.0592;6	`` The kids may not understand yet what this access , this communication , means for them , '' said Volodya Pilipchuk , the school 's computer adviser and a former 728 student .
APW_ENG_19941202.0592;7	`` But 10 years from now , they will . ''

APW_ENG_19941202.0593;0	Cuban exile leaders here lauded a Clinton administration decision Friday to admit Cuban children and their parents now detained at U.S. camps , but others criticized the change as politically motivated .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;1	`` We have seen it coming , '' said Andres Gomez , head of the exile group , the Antonio Maceo Brigade .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;2	`` -LRB- Clinton -RRB- wants to diffuse the resentment that exists among the Cubans in this city . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;3	The decision announced in Washington by Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner Doris Meissner comes one week before the Summit of the Americas , when 34 heads of state will convene in Miami .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;4	The policy would allow about 8,000 Cuban children and parents now held in Panama and at Guantanamo Bay , Cuba , to enter the United States if they have financial sponsorship .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;5	Cesar Odio , Miami 's city manager , said funding would be raised to cover relocation , education , health and living costs for the refugees .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;6	`` We are working together with the government to see that ... they have full sponsorship and they are not a burden on the community , '' said Odio .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;7	The change will not affect the status of at least 20,000 adult refugees in the camps .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;8	Odio denied a connection to the summit , saying negotiations had been under way with the federal government on this agreement since September .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;9	`` This has nothing to do with the summit , '' he said at a news conference early Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;10	`` And if it has something to do with it , so what ?
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;11	We want the children helped . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;12	The detention of the Cubans began in August , when President Clinton ordered all Cuban boat people picked up at sea to be sent to the U.S. naval base at Guantanamo Bay .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;13	Other camps were later set up in Panama .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;14	Under an deal reached in September with Cuban President Fidel Castro , the United States agreed to give 20,000 visas if Castro cracked down on illegal migration from his shores .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;15	The Cubans being detained were not to be allowed into the United States under the agreement .
APW_ENG_19941202.0593;16	They could remain at Guantanamo , return to Cuba or apply for asylum through a third country .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;0	Bosnian Serbs promised Friday to release hundreds of U.N. peacekeepers and allow the free movement of some U.N. convoys as the chief U.N. envoy tried to salvage what was left of the ailing U.N. mission in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;1	Earlier , two anti-tank missiles slammed into the presidency building in Sarajevo just minutes before U.N. envoy Yasushi Akashi arrived for talks with the Muslim-led Bosnian government .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;2	U.N. officials said the missiles appeared to come from Serb positions , but the Serbs said the government attacked itself to cause trouble .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;3	It was yet another sign of Serb contempt for the peacekeeping effort , which has virtually ground to a halt .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;4	The Serb rebels have stopped U.N. convoys , attacked a U.N.-declared `` safe area , '' and taken peacekeepers hostage .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;5	In Brussels , Belgium , U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher and European foreign ministers endorsed a U.S. plan for a cease-fire that would lead to peace talks in the 21\/2 - year-old war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;6	The plan would also grant the Serbs their main aim in the conflict : the right to ties with Serb-led Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;7	The Serbs on Friday released 70 Dutch peacekeepers who had been held a week , but more than 300 other U.N. peacekeepers remained hostage as insurance against NATO airstrikes .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;8	Akashi , who met with Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic at Serb headquarters in Pale , east of Sarajevo , said he was assured that Ukrainian peacekeepers held in northern Bosnia would be released , Dutch and British supply convoys detained since Saturday would be freed , and Bangladeshi peacekeepers stranded in Bihac would be allowed to receive supplies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;9	Karadzic said the Serbs and the U.N. `` are moving fast to normalization of our relations , '' but he issued a veiled warning against NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;10	`` We would like to see skies clear of our aircraft and of NATO aircraft , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;11	`` If NATO is flying around there is more risk of misunderstandings and incidents . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;12	Under current rules of engagement , the U.N. must request the NATO airstrikes , although NATO planes can defend themselves against attack without U.N. approval .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;13	U.N. officials fear that could escalate tensions .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;14	Akashi had met earlier with Bosnian government and military leaders in Sarevejo .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;15	Two wire-guided missiles hit the presidency building minutes before he arrived for the talks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;16	One destroyed the office of Miro Lazovic , an ethnic Serb member of Bosnia 's collective presidency .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;17	Three missiles hit nearby buildings while the meeting went on .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;18	There were no injuries .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;19	The Bosnian government blasted the United Nations for not using force to halt fighting at Bihac , the embattled government-held enclave in the northwest .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;20	Serb forces have seized 30 percent to 40 percent of the `` safe area , '' and fighting continued there Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;21	U.S. Ambassador to Germany Charles Redman held talks in Sarajevo with Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic and Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic on the U.S. peace plan .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;22	Redman helped draft an earlier international plan that the Serbs rejected .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;23	The war began when Serbs rebelled against a vote for independence from Yugoslavia by Bosnia-Herzegovina 's Muslims and Croats .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;24	More than 200,000 people are dead or missing in the war , and the Serbs have seized 70 percent of Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;25	Following the secession since 1991 of Slovenia , Croatia , Bosnia and Macedonia , Yugoslavia now comprises Serbia and Montenegro .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;26	Serb nationalists in Yugoslavia , Croatia and Bosnia have pressed for a unified `` Greater Serbia . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;27	The rejected peace plan denied Serbs the right to links with Yugoslavia as punishment for starting the war , but allowed Bosnia 's Croats and Muslims the right to ties with Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;28	The old plan also granted the Serbs 49 percent of Bosnia -- a condition the new plan also contains .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;29	Akashi had more success than U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali , who was rebuffed Wednesday when he tried to meet with Bosnian Serb leaders .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;30	Boutros-Ghali said afterwards that intransigence by the warring sides might force the U.N. mission to withdraw .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;31	Seventy Dutch peacekeepers arrived in Zagreb , Croatia , after being released from a seven-day detention by the Serbs in eastern Bosnia , U.N. officials said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;32	But Serbs continued to hold about 20 other Dutch peacekeepers , plus several hundred of Britons , Ukrainians and Canadians , at various points throughout Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;33	U.N. spokesman Thant Myint-U said Akashi also wanted to discuss the fighting around Bihac with Karadzic .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;34	The United Nations is trying to broker a cease-fire there .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;35	Machine-gun and small arms fire was reported on the outskirts of Bihac , U.N. officials said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;36	The heaviest fighting appeared concentrated around Velika Kladusa , north of Bihac , where Serbs were apparently closing in on the government army 's 5th Corps .
APW_ENG_19941202.0594;37	The Bosnian Serbs , backed by Serbs from neighboring Croatia , want to wipe out the 5th Corps , which launched a briefly successful offensive from the Bihac enclave in late October .
APW_ENG_19941202.0595;0	Bosnian Serbs promised Friday to release hundreds of U.N. peacekeepers and allow the free movement of some U.N. convoys as the chief U.N. envoy tried to salvage what was left of the ailing U.N. mission in Bosnia .

APW_ENG_19941202.0595;31	Seventy Dutch peacekeepers arrived in Zagreb , Croatia , after being released from a seven-day detention by the Serbs in eastern Bosnia , U.N. officials said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0595;32	But Serbs continued to hold about 20 other Dutch peacekeepers , plus several hundred of Britons , Ukrainians and Canadians , at various points throughout Bosnia .

APW_ENG_19941202.0595;34	The United Nations is trying to broker a cease-fire there .

APW_ENG_19941202.0596;0	A U.S. Army inspection found numerous deficiencies with a chemical-weapons disposal plant only a year before its scheduled opening .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;1	The report by the Army Inspector General found security gaps in and around the site in Tooele , Utah , along with an inadequate system for containing spills , and problems with tracking the deadly bombs and shells .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;2	An Army response attached to the report emphasizes that all the problems raised by the inspection will be addressed before the Tooele Chemical Agent Disposal Facility opens .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;3	`` The Army is committed to ensuring that security , safety and environmental protection are not compromised at the facility . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;4	The report , the Army stated , was `` aimed at identifying , in advance , problems that must be addressed before the TOCDF becomes operational . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;5	The Washington Post reported on the inspector general 's findings in Friday 's editions .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;6	Destruction of the vast U.S. chemical-weapons arsenal , a holdover from the Cold War , is part of a broader arms reduction effort and involves parallel actions by Russia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;7	After studying a variety of disposal methods , the Army settled on destruction by incineration .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;8	Eventually the Army plans to operate nine disposal incinerators .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;9	They are part of a dlrs 10 billion Army effort to comply with congressional orders to eliminate the stockpile .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;10	Although plans for the incinerator are proceeding , environmentalists continue to criticize the destruction method , predicting toxic leaks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;11	Among other findings , the inspector general found that : -- Equipment such as fork lifts and cranes that will be used to move chemical weapons stockpiles are not marked with capacity ratings , creating the risk they could be overloaded .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;12	-- There are no final plans on what to do with the solid residue of incineration .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;13	-- The Army has not yet settled on a system of marking and identifying each shell , bomb or other chemical-weapon container .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;14	-- During testing of one chemical-handling facility , `` a large amount of spillage was collected that exceeded the capacity of the secondary containment vessel . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;15	This spill was not toxic but once the facility opens , it will handle toxic chemicals .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;16	-- The perimeter fence could be penetrated by intruders either by cutting through or digging under the barrier .
APW_ENG_19941202.0596;17	-- Some windows and doors on buildings that will contain chemical weapons are inadequate and drainage structures and culverts leading out of the facility were not equipped with fences or grates to prevent intruders .

APW_ENG_19941202.0599;1	`` We think Mr. Salinas did an incredible job in bringing the new face of Mexico to the people of the world , and we hope that he will have a chance to continue to do that as president of the WTO , '' said Deputy Prime Minister Sheila Copps .
APW_ENG_19941202.0599;2	Copps was here to attend Thursday 's inauguration of Mexico 's new president Ernesto Zedillo .
APW_ENG_19941202.0599;3	`` President Salinas will be known for bringing business and economic skills to a country moving away from government ownership to private ownership and I think that Dr. Zedillo will actually ensure that economic direction is shared by the people , '' she said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0599;4	The World Trade Organization will replace the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade , or GATT , on Jan 1 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0599;5	Most countries in the Western Hemisphere are backing Salinas to head the new organization .
APW_ENG_19941202.0599;6	Europe and its former African colonies are firmly behind Renato Ruggiero , a one-time Italian trade minister , while Japan and its Asian neighbors are lobbying for Trade Minister Kim Chul-su of South Korea .

APW_ENG_19941202.0599;8	`` Mexico 's had a rough , turbulent year , and I think he gave the right signals to the people and certainly to the international community , '' she said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0599;9	`` The message he gave yesterday was very clear : that he 's there to serve all the people , that he wants to rebuild the public 's confidence in the integrity of the democratic system , '' said Copps .
APW_ENG_19941202.0599;10	Zedillo will meet Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien at next week 's Summit of the Americas in Miami , Copps said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0599;11	The three nations will also discuss the possible inclusion of Chile in the NAFTA free trade agreement linking Canada , the United States and Mexico , she said .

APW_ENG_19941202.0600;1	At least 60 people were injured , said National Police spokesman Laszlo Garamvoelgyi .
APW_ENG_19941202.0600;2	The accident occurred at Szajol , about 40 miles southeast of the Hungarian capital , when the second car of an express train derailed and dragged three other cars off the tracks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0600;3	Some of the overturned carriages smashed into the station building , railway officials said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0600;4	`` There was a tremendous explosion , like the end of the world , '' a railway employee who witnessed the accident said in a telephone interview .
APW_ENG_19941202.0600;5	People were still buried in the wreckage more than four hours after the crash , said the employee , who spoke on condition of anonymity .
APW_ENG_19941202.0600;6	State television showed pictures of battered and broken railway cars covered in bricks and rescue crews dragging bloody bodies from the wreckage .
APW_ENG_19941202.0600;7	Rescue workers said part of the destroyed building held sleeping quarters for railway personnel and their families .

APW_ENG_19941202.0604;0	President Clinton on Friday ordered that no U. S , government funds be spent on human embryos created for research purposes only .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;1	But Clinton did not specifically forbid federal financial support for research on human embryos that originate from in vitro fertilization -- the so-called test-tube baby technique .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;2	`` I do not believe that federal funds should be used to support the creation of human embryos for research purposes , '' Clinton said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;3	His order Friday was far less sweeping than previous restrictions imposed by Presidents Reagan and Bush .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;4	`` I have directed that the National Institutes of Health not allocate any resources '' for studies of human embryos that were created for research purposes , Clinton said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;5	White House press secretary Dee Dee Myers , asked to interpret Clinton 's terse statement , said `` it should be interpreted very narrowly . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;6	Asked if the statement would permit federally funded research using embryos that were surplus from IVF clinics , she said : `` The president 's statement does n't outlaw that . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;7	`` That 's the line that 's been drawn , '' said a senior White House official who asked not to be named publicly .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;8	In his statement , Clinton said that research on fertilized human eggs `` raises profound ethical and moral questions as well as issues concerning the appropriate allocation of federal funds . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;9	The report of the NIH 's human embryo committee said the research had the potential of finding news ways to correct infertility , to improve methods of preventing or correcting birth defects , and help combat cancer .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;10	After studying the issue for nine months , the committee delivered its recommendations this week to another panel that advises NIH Director Harold Varmus .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;11	That panel endorsed the recommendations , leaving the final decision up to Varmus on if , when and how the NIH would proceed with research grants -- until Clinton took it out of Varmus ' hands later in the day .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;12	In his statement , Clinton praised the work of the committees and said he understood how the research could make advances in in vitro fertilization .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;13	He also said he planned to establish a bioethics advisory commission to further deliberate such issues .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;14	The advisory committee acknowledged that many people had ethical and moral reservations about its recommendation .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;15	Under the recommendation , embryo research would be subject to strict controls , including limiting it to the first 14 days after fertilization .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;16	At that point , a fertilized human egg has grown to hundreds of cells but has not yet developed a nervous system , specific tissues or a human form .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;17	The White House announcement came as opponents of human embryo research , mostly groups that also oppose abortion , were gathering forces for a showdown in Congress .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;18	`` Regardless of any potential medical advancements , human dignity must not be degraded by having life created in a laboratory dish just to have it thrown out with the trash when scientists are finished with their Frankenstein-type experiments , '' said Rep. Robert Dornan , a California Republican who promised to carry the fight to Congress .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;19	Richard Doerfinger of the U.S. Catholic Conference said his organization would support efforts to block any federal funding for the embryo research .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;20	Guidelines for embryo research were first recommended by an NIH committee in 1979 , but Presidents Reagan and Bush opposed it and the process withered .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;21	Varmus , who was appointed by President Clinton , revived the effort by naming the embryo research committee earlier this year .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;22	Despite the lack of federal funds , clinics and universities that provide in vitro fertilization services have privately financed extensive research for more than a decade .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;23	Dr. Steven Muller , president emeritus of Johns Hopkins University and chairman of the embryo advisory panel that studied the issue , said the committee received more than 50,000 pieces of mail , most of it protesting the research .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;24	`` The public has no idea what human embryo research means , but to most people it does seem terrible , '' Muller said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0604;25	`` The extreme high level of public ignorance invites exploitation '' by opponents to the research .

APW_ENG_19941202.0605;1	It was the first council veto in a year and a half and the first on the Bosnian war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0606;0	Russia vetoed a Security Council resolution late Friday night aimed at stopping Yugoslav fuel supplies reportedly powering a Serb offensive in northern Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0606;1	It was the first council veto in a year and a half -- and the first on the Bosnian war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0606;2	The resolution was sponsored by Islamic and non-aligned states to show sympathy for the Bosnian Muslims .

APW_ENG_19941202.0611;0	Bosnian Serbs promised Friday to release hundreds of peacekeepers and allow aid deliveries as the chief U.N. envoy tried to salvage what was left of the ailing U.N. mission in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;1	Earlier , two anti-tank missiles slammed into the presidency building just minutes before U.N. envoy Yasushi Akashi arrived for talks with the Muslim-led Bosnian government .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;2	U.N. officials said the missiles appeared to come from Serb positions , but the Serbs said the government attacked itself to cause trouble .

APW_ENG_19941202.0611;4	The Serb rebels have stopped U.N. aid convoys , attacked a U.N.-declared `` safe area , '' and taken peacekeepers hostage .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;5	In Brussels , Belgium , Secretary of State Warren Christopher and European foreign ministers endorsed a U.S. plan for a cease-fire that would lead to peace talks in the 2 -LCB- - year-old war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;6	The plan would also grant the Serbs their main aim in the conflict : the right to ties with Serb-led Yugoslavia .

APW_ENG_19941202.0611;8	It was the first council veto in a year and a half and the first on the Bosnian war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;9	The Serbs on Friday released 70 peacekeepers who had been held a week , but more than 300 peacekeepers remained hostage as insurance against NATO airstrikes .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;10	Akashi , who met with Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic at Serb headquarters in Pale , east of Sarajevo , said he was assured that Ukrainian peacekeepers held in northern Bosnia would be released , Dutch and British supply convoys detained since Saturday would be freed , and Bangladeshi peacekeepers stranded in Bihac would be allowed to receive supplies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;11	Karadzic said the Serbs and the U.N. `` are moving fast to normalization of our relations , '' but he issued a veiled warning against NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;12	`` We would like to see skies clear of our aircraft and of NATO aircraft , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;13	`` If NATO is flying around there is more risk of misunderstandings and incidents . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;14	Under current rules of engagement , the U.N. must request the NATO airstrikes , although NATO planes can defend themselves against attack without U.N. approval .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;15	U.N. officials fear that could escalate tensions .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;16	Akashi had met earlier with Bosnian government and military leaders in Sarajevo .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;17	Two wire-guided missiles hit the presidency building minutes before he arrived for the talks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;18	One destroyed the office of Miro Lazovic , an ethnic Serb member of Bosnia 's collective presidency .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;19	Three missiles hit nearby buildings while the meeting went on .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;20	There were no injuries .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;21	The Bosnian government blasted the United Nations for not using force to halt fighting at Bihac , the embattled government-held enclave in the northwest .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;22	Serb forces have seized 30 percent to 40 percent of the `` safe area , '' and fighting continued there Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;23	U.S. Ambassador to Germany Charles Redman held talks in Sarajevo with Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic and Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic on the U.S. peace plan .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;24	Redman helped draft an earlier plan that the Serbs rejected .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;25	The war began when Serbs rebelled against a vote for independence from Yugoslavia by Bosnia-Herzegovina 's Muslims and Croats .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;26	More than 200,000 people are dead or missing in the war , and the Serbs have seized 70 percent of Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;27	Following the secession since 1991 of Slovenia , Croatia , Bosnia and Macedonia , Yugoslavia now comprises Serbia and Montenegro .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;28	Serb nationalists in Yugoslavia , Croatia and Bosnia have pressed for a unified `` Greater Serbia . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;29	The rejected peace plan denied Serbs the right to links with Yugoslavia as punishment for starting the war , but allowed Bosnia 's Croats and Muslims the right to ties with Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;30	The old plan also granted the Serbs 49 percent of Bosnia -- a condition the new plan also contains .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;31	Akashi had more success than U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali , who was rebuffed Wednesday when he tried to meet with Bosnian Serb leaders .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;32	Boutros-Ghali said afterwards that intransigence by the warring sides might force the U.N. mission to withdraw .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;33	Seventy Dutch peacekeepers arrived in Zagreb , Croatia , after being released from a seven-day detention by the Serbs in eastern Bosnia , U.N. officials said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;34	But Serbs continued to hold about 20 other Dutch peacekeepers , plus hundreds of British , Ukrainians and Canadians , at various points throughout Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;35	Machine-gun and small arms fire was reported on the outskirts of Bihac , U.N. officials said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;36	The heaviest fighting appeared concentrated around Velika Kladusa , north of Bihac , where Serbs were apparently closing in on the government army 's 5th Corps .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;37	The Bosnian Serbs , backed by Serbs from neighboring Croatia , want to wipe out the 5th Corps , which launched a briefly successful offensive from the Bihac enclave in late October .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;38	The Security Council resolution vetoed by Russia Friday night would have required U.N. border monitors to severely limit shipments of fuel and other supplies crossing the border between Serbia and Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;39	Russia , a traditional Serb ally , said it vetoed the resolution because it would tighten sanctions against Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;40	A Russian diplomat , speaking on condition of anonymity , stressed that the veto did n't represent a split with the United States and other Western nations which drafted the peace plan for Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;41	There were also signs that fronts south of Bihac were heating up .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;42	Bosnian Croats , allied with Muslim-led government forces , claimed they captured three villages north of the town of Kupres in central Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;43	Croat militia and Bosnian army soldiers took Kupres from the Serbs last month .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;44	Gen. Ante Roso , the Bosnian Croat military commander , charged that Serbs in neighboring Croatia had shelled his forces across the border , near the town of Livno .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;45	He said his troops returned fire .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;46	Karadzic claimed regular Croatian army troops were fighting alongside the Bosnian Croats and warned Akashi to get them out or `` we will be forced to declare we are in war with Croatia . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;47	In Knin , Croatia , the Croatian government and leaders of the rebel Serb minority signed an economic agreement that , if implemented , could lead to normalized relations between the two enemies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0611;48	The agreement calls for restoring water and electricity supplies and reopening oil pipelines and the highway linking Zagreb , the Croatian capital , and the Yugoslav capital of Belgrade .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;0	Russia vetoed a Security Council resolution late Friday night aimed at stopping Yugoslav fuel supplies reportedly powering a Serb offensive in northern Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;1	It was the first council veto in a year and a half -- and the first on the Bosnian war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;2	The resolution was sponsored by Islamic and non-aligned states to show sympathy for the Bosnian Muslims .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;3	Russia , a traditional Serb ally , said it vetoed the resolution because it would tighten sanctions against Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;4	`` We had no other choice than to vote against this draft , '' said Russian Ambassador Sergey Lavrov .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;5	`` We hope that ultimately there will be a sound and balanced approach '' toward a political process .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;6	Lavrov said `` a more untimely moment of this -LRB- resolution -RRB- is impossible , '' adding that Yugoslavia had closed its border with Bosnia and was cooperating with peace negotiators .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;7	Another Russian diplomat , speaking on condition of anonymity , stressed that the veto did not represent a split within the five-nation contact group pushing for a peace agreement in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;8	Hours before the veto , diplomats from Russia , the United States , France , Britain and Germany demonstrated their unity by endorsing a confederation of Bosnian Serbs and neighboring Serbia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;9	The last veto was in May 1993 , when Russia blocked its first resolution in nine years , killing a proposal to make all U.N. members pay for the small U.N. peacekeeping force in Cyprus .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;10	Friday night 's veto was also an opportunity for Russia to show its muscle in the council .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;11	Lavrov has repeatedly accused the United Nations of a `` double standard , '' saying that the council has imposed sanctions against Serbia , but has ignored Muslim acts against Serbs .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;12	The resolution would require U.N. border monitors to severely limit shipments of fuel and other supplies crossing the border between Serbia , the dominant member of Yugoslavia , and Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;13	The aim of the resolution is `` to totally shackle the Serb war-making capability , '' said Djibouti 's ambassador Roble Olhaye .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;14	U.N. resolutions already ban all but humanitarian supplies from crossing the border between Yugoslavia and Bosnia , but monitors have been permitting shipments to cross Bosnia if they are destined for Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;15	The resolution also called for the freedom of the 450 U.N. peacekeepers being held by Serb forces by requesting `` personal safety and unimpeded access '' for all peacekeepers and U.N. refugee workers in Bosnia and Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;16	Some 100 to 150 tankers filled with fuel are being allowed to cross the Yugoslav border and reach Serb forces in Croatia , said one diplomat , speaking on condition of anonymity .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;17	Croatian and Bosnian diplomats say the fuel is far in excess of humanitarian needs and is being used in the war effort in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;18	The ambassador of Pakistan , a co-sponsor of the resolution called the Bosnians `` victims of international indifference . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;19	Jamsheed Marker said his country had demanded a vote on the resolution because `` the U.N. can not stand by and permit this genocide ... -LRB- which -RRB- makes a mockery of what the U.N. stands for . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;20	Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic announced in August that the border with Bosnia was being sealed to all but humanitarian aid to pressure Bosnian Serbs into accepting a peace plan .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;21	The United Nations eased its sanctions against Yugoslavia in October .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;22	Belgrade had supplied the Bosnian Serbs throughout the 21\/2 - year war with Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;23	Classified U.N. reports shown to The Associated Press in Sarajevo say that U.N. observers had seen armed men crossing the border between Serb-held territory in Croatia and Bosnia in vehicles with Belgrade licenses .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;24	With Friday 's vote , the veto has been used 281 times in the Security Council since the founding of the United Nations in 1945 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0612;25	The last veto cast by the United States was in May 1990 and blocked a resolution criticizing Israel for its activities in the occupied territories .
APW_ENG_19941202.0613;0	American Bonnie Blair easily won the women 's 500-meter race in the World Cup Obihiro Meet Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0613;1	Blair , the gold medalist in the 500 - and 1,000-meter races at the 1994 Lillehammer Olympics , was timed in 41.20 seconds , 0.26 seconds ahead of Germany 's Franziska Schenk , who was clocked in 41.46 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0613;2	The third place finisher was Japan 's Shiho Kusunose in 41.49 .
APW_ENG_19941202.0613;3	The women 's 1,000-meter race and the men 's 500 - and 1,000-meter races were scheduled for later Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0613;4	A field of 71 skaters from 14 nations are competing in the two-day tournament in Obihiro , 1,000 kilometers -LRB- 620 miles -RRB- northeast of Tokyo in one of Japan 's coldest winter areas .

APW_ENG_19941202.0615;0	Bosnian Serbs have promised to release hundreds of peacekeepers and allow aid deliveries as the chief U.N. envoy tried to salvage what was left of the ailing U.N. mission in Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;1	Earlier Friday , two anti-tank missiles slammed into the presidency building just minutes before U.N. envoy Yasushi Akashi arrived for talks with the Muslim-led Bosnian government .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;2	U.N. officials said the missiles appeared to come from Serb positions , but the Serbs said the government attacked itself to cause trouble .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;3	It was yet another sign of Serb contempt for the peacekeeping effort , which has virtually ground to a halt .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;4	The Serb rebels have stopped U.N. aid convoys , attacked a U.N.-declared `` safe area , '' and taken peacekeepers hostage .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;5	In Brussels , Belgium , Secretary of State Warren Christopher and European foreign ministers endorsed a U.S. plan for a cease-fire that would lead to peace talks in the 21\/2 - year-old war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;6	The plan would also grant the Serbs their main aim in the conflict : the right to ties with Serb-led Yugoslavia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;7	At the United Nations , Russia late Friday vetoed a Security Council resolution aimed at stopping Yugoslav fuel supplies reportedly powering a Serb offensive in northern Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;8	It was the first council veto in a year and a half and the first on the Bosnian war .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;9	The Serbs on Friday released 70 peacekeepers who had been held a week , but more than 300 peacekeepers remained hostage as insurance against NATO airstrikes .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;10	Akashi , who met with Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic at Serb headquarters in Pale , east of Sarajevo , said he was assured that Ukrainian peacekeepers held in northern Bosnia would be released , Dutch and British supply convoys detained since Saturday would be freed , and Bangladeshi peacekeepers stranded in Bihac would be allowed to receive supplies .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;11	Karadzic said the Serbs and the U.N. `` are moving fast to normalization of our relations , '' but he issued a veiled warning against NATO .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;12	`` We would like to see skies clear of our aircraft and of NATO aircraft , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;13	`` If NATO is flying around there is more risk of misunderstandings and incidents . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;14	Under current rules of engagement , the U.N. must request the NATO airstrikes , although NATO planes can defend themselves against attack without U.N. approval .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;15	U.N. officials fear that could escalate tensions .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;16	Akashi had met earlier with Bosnian government and military leaders in Sarajevo .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;17	Two wire-guided missiles hit the presidency building minutes before he arrived for the talks .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;18	One destroyed the office of Miro Lazovic , an ethnic Serb member of Bosnia 's collective presidency .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;19	Three missiles hit nearby buildings while the meeting went on .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;20	There were no injuries .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;21	The Bosnian government blasted the United Nations for not using force to halt fighting at Bihac , the embattled government-held enclave in the northwest .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;22	Serb forces have seized 30 percent to 40 percent of the `` safe area , '' and fighting continued there Friday .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;23	U.S. Ambassador to Germany Charles Redman held talks in Sarajevo with Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic and Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic on the U.S. peace plan .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;24	Redman helped draft an earlier plan that the Serbs rejected .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;25	The war began when Serbs rebelled against a vote for independence from Yugoslavia by Bosnia-Herzegovina 's Muslims and Croats .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;26	More than 200,000 people are dead or missing in the war , and the Serbs have seized 70 percent of Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;27	Following the secession since 1991 of Slovenia , Croatia , Bosnia and Macedonia , Yugoslavia now comprises Serbia and Montenegro .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;28	Serb nationalists in Yugoslavia , Croatia and Bosnia have pressed for a unified `` Greater Serbia . ''
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;29	The rejected peace plan denied Serbs the right to links with Yugoslavia as punishment for starting the war , but allowed Bosnia 's Croats and Muslims the right to ties with Croatia .
APW_ENG_19941202.0615;30	The old plan also granted the Serbs 49 percent of Bosnia -- a condition the new plan also contains .
