APW_ENG_19941203.0049;1	Hirata , who won one tournament in 1993 , started the second round three shots behind leader Australian Nicole Lowien , and carded one eagle , four birdies and one bogey for a 8-under-par 136 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0049;2	Nayoko Yoshikawa was in second place at 137 after shooting a 70 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0049;3	Another shot back at 138 was Aiko Hashimoto , who fired a 68 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0049;4	Lowien sank to a 141 after turning in a 75 and was tied with Miyuki Shimabukuro in fifth place .

APW_ENG_19941203.0049;8	The 60 million yen -LRB- dlrs 600,000 -RRB- tournament is being held on the 6,274-yard , par-72 Kumamoto Chuo Country Club course in southern Japan .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;0	A kiss is just a kiss .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;1	But in Japan , it 's a social statement .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;2	Kissing in public , considered shocking a few years ago , has come into vogue .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;3	Japanese couples are bussing on buses and puckering up on park benches .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;4	The trend has set off a debate about changing mores in a country still strongly influenced by conservative Confucian standards .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;5	`` I feel very uncomfortable seeing them doing that , '' said Etsuko Yamashita , 38 , who lectures on feminism at Japan Women 's University .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;6	`` If my children did that , I would scold them . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;7	The kissing contingent , though , is unrepentant .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;8	`` That kind of public kissing should be accepted , '' said 18-year-old Yuko Asayama .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;9	Her boyfriend , Shiro Akiba , said he feels relaxed about kissing her in front of mutual friends but is still shy in public .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;10	Part of the reason public kissing is considered so provocative is that in Japan , a kiss has traditionally been viewed as a prelude to sex .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;11	Japanese people do not kiss and hug in greeting , but bow instead .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;12	Kissing was prohibited in movies until after World War II .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;13	But in a bizarre bit of social engineering , U.S. occupation forces instructed Japanese filmmakers to begin showing on-screen kisses .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;14	Japanese actors and actresses went along , but unwillingly , using tissue paper to avoid direct lip contact .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;15	Even with the film barrier broken , public displays of affection in Japan remained rare compared to the United States and Europe .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;16	Analysts say the public-kissing trend was pioneered by television commercials .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;17	A 1992 spot by the cosmetics firm Kose Corp. had a young woman exclaiming `` Chu shite ! ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;18	-- roughly translated as `` Kiss me , darling ! ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;19	Cosmetics rival Shiseido , not to be outdone , has been racking up big sales of no-smudge lipstick , which it markets with a boast that it will last through a long smooching session and leave the kissee unsmeared .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;20	Like most trends here , the bussing boom is being explored enthusiastically by Japanese media .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;21	One popular biweekly magazine had a recent article instructing young male readers in what it called `` the art of public kissing . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;22	The magazine , Popeye , recommended coffee shops and empty train cars as good places for beginners to practice .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;23	But it cautioned : `` Do n't get too excited . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;24	Michio Koseki , a senior editor at Popeye , said the kissing trend is a sign that young people are abandoning the reticence of their elders .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;25	`` It 's their statement that it is nothing to feel embarrassed to show the world that they 're in love and enjoying being in love , '' Koseki said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;26	Others believe it 's just a fad based on Western movies .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;27	`` Those couples look extremely unnatural , '' said lawyer Mizuho Fukushima .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;28	Japan 's sexual mores have always featured a mix of prudishness and brazen behavior .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;29	Many young `` office ladies '' who are expected to wear demure uniforms and pour tea by day don stripper-style garb for club nights out on the town .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;30	Scantily dressed women appear on television variety shows even during the day , and pictures of nude women are routinely printed in news magazines .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;31	Fukushima said that even if kissing in public is only a fad , at least it does n't exploit women .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;32	`` The current trend is not forcing women into being victims of sexism , '' she said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0051;33	`` Both parties seem to be equally enthusiastic . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;0	In cars , on foot and even in wheelchairs , Taiwanese thronged to the polls Saturday in the toughest electoral test for the island 's Nationalist rulers in 45 years .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;1	The local elections marked a milestone in Taiwan 's 7-year-old transformation from virtual dictatorship to multi-party democracy .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;2	Voters chose a governor for the first time , and mayors for Taipei and Kaohsiung for the first time since 1967 and 1979 respectively , as well as local councils and the provincial assembly .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;3	State-run TV said polling stations closed on schedule at 4 p.m. -LRB- 0800 GMT -RRB- and results were expected about eight hours later .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;4	Newspapers and TV estimated that 70 percent to 80 percent of Taiwan 's 13.8 million eligible voters turned out .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;5	President Lee Teng-hui , who is credited with steering Taiwan through its transition to democracy , cast his vote in a Taipei stadium shortly after polling stations opened at 8 a.m. -LRB- 0000 GMT -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;6	Older voters in wheelchairs and couples with children lined up in the rain to vote in schools , sports grounds and Buddhist temples , sometimes waiting half an hour for their turn .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;7	Campaigning for the election was feverish and , at times , violent .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;8	No incidents were reported during the voting , but there were fears that violence might erupt when results were announced .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;9	Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou appealed to people to watch the results on TV and not mass outside party headquarters .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;10	Police said 70,000 officers were deployed , and Lee appealed to Taiwanese to `` welcome a new era of democracy for all . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;11	The polls are a prelude to Taiwan 's first direct presidential election in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;12	Lee 's prospects for another term will be measured by his Nationalists ' performance against the main opposition , the Democratic Progressive Party .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;13	The Nationalists fled to Taiwan to escape the 1949 Communist takeover of mainland China .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;14	They still say they hope one day to reunite Taiwan with the Chinese motherland .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;15	But the DPP advocates Taiwanese independence , something China has vowed to resist by force , claiming Taiwan is a renegade province .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;16	Campaigning focused largely on `` Tong-Du '' -- reunification vs. independence -- and DPP successes could provoke misgivings in Beijing .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;17	Business leaders placed newspaper ads warning that Taiwan 's dollar and the island 's standing with investors could plummet if pro-independence forces gained power .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;18	But the DPP may profit from a split in the Nationalist vote caused by the recently formed New Party , which quit the Nationalists last year , accusing them of abandoning the commitment to reunification .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;19	Opinion polls were suspended several days before the election , making it difficult to forecast the result .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;20	But in the most recent polls , the DPP 's Chen Shui-bian was thought to be a front-runner for mayor of Taipei , while Nationalist James Soong had a 50-40 lead over the DPP 's Chen Ting-nan in the race for governor .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;21	Candidates held final rallies Friday night , including tens of thousands of cheering New Party supporters who packed Taipei 's municipal stadium .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;22	The carnival-like election campaign underlined Taiwan 's enthusiasm for democracy .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;23	Taipei 's streets and many of its taxis were covered with flags .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;24	In the last few days , campaigners lulled the capital to sleep at night with drums and roused it each morning with firecrackers .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;25	Interior Minister Wu Poh-hsiung even complained that precious resources were wasted and that the campaign flags `` could have clothed 1 million refugees . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;26	Voters also were urged not to take bribes , a problem in past elections as well as this one .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;27	The DPP filed a lawsuit Wednesday accusing the Nationalists of earmarking about 150 million Taiwan dollars -LRB- U.S. dlrs 5.6 million -RRB- to buy votes for Huang Ta-chou , Taipei 's incumbent Nationalist mayor , who is lagging in opinion polls .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;28	The Nationalists denied the allegations and denounced vote-buying .
APW_ENG_19941203.0052;29	Government-controlled TV ran advertisements showing vote-buyers in handcuffs .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;0	Ten months after his death at age 31 , the eldest son of President Hafez Assad is a towering presence across Syria .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;1	Giant portraits of Basil Assad , a lover of fast cars who died in a car wreck , drape the fronts of buildings .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;2	His photographs are displayed in car windows and on the walls of offices , shops and homes .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;3	They send a message -- not only of what might have been , but of what still can be : A new generation of the Assad family governing Syria .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;4	There are three more Assad sons .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;5	The second son , Bashar , is 29 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;6	Photographs of him are rarely seen .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;7	But in Syria , people are used to reading between the lines of propaganda .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;8	And hard-to-miss hints have been emerging .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;9	In the officially sanctioned `` Paean to the Thoughts of the Hero Basil Assad , '' the author , army Col. Bahjat Suleyman , begins :
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;10	`` Hope vanished ... on a bitter winter day after he brought to us a promise of a beautiful spring that 's full of colors and birds chirping . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;11	But , the book concludes , nothing can stop `` Basil Assad 's generation from clinging to the second brother , Bashar Assad , and accompanying him ... toward the third millennium A.D. ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;12	The question of succession is increasingly important as Syria undergoes social and economic changes and talks peace with its nemesis , Israel .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;13	President Assad , who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1970 , is 64 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;14	Ever since he suffered a heart attack a decade ago , some foreign governments have periodically speculated he is in poor health .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;15	But Assad remains very much in control and as shrewd as ever .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;16	Syrian officials insist his health is fine .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;17	Western diplomats in Damascus point out that many people whose health is less than robust live to old age .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;18	Diplomats and foreign-based political analysts question whether Bashar has the right stuff to guide a nation where stability traditionally has depended on a leader of undisputed strength .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;19	Bashar was training in England as an opthalmologist when his brother , an army major , died .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;20	He cut short his studies and came home to enter the military academy .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;21	He graduated in November as a captain in command of a tank regiment .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;22	Bashar now heads most of the committees his brother presided over , mainly ones relating to sports .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;23	Any presidential successor is likely to need the approval of Assad 's close cadre of military and intelligence advisers , many of them from Assad 's own minority Alawite sect of Islam .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;24	In March , longtime Defense Minister Mustafa Tlass signaled support for Bashar in a speech before the president .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;25	`` I see in the eyes of your son , Dr. Bashar Assad , the will , determination and ability to raise the banner that Basil raised , '' said Tlass , a member of the Sunni Muslim majority .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;26	The presidential succession is a highly sensitive subject and rarely discussed in public .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;27	Despite his severe rule , Assad is valued by many people for presiding over modern Syria 's longest-lasting government .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;28	There were 20 coups in the first 24 years after Syria became independent from France in 1946 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;29	In the second 24 years , there has been only Hafez Assad .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;30	Would-be challengers have been deterred by the example set by Assad 's suppression of a 1982 uprising by the Muslim Brotherhood in the city of Hama .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;31	The army killed up to 10,000 people and leveled much of the city , ending a bloody five-year campaign of bombings and subversion .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;32	But Basil 's death last Jan. 21 was a serious blow for Assad .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;33	For years , government propaganda had molded Basil into a national hero .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;34	He was dubbed `` the Golden Knight '' and lauded for his accomplishments as an amateur horseman .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;35	Pictures of Basil started appearing when he was alive , usually in the windows of cars and jeeps driven by young men from politically elite circles .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;36	Since his death , they have multiplied monthly across Syria .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;37	At a recent crafts show , nearly all the paintings depicted Basil -- glowing on black velvet or in ethereal oils .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;38	Along the streets and in offices , murals and photographs -- often trimmed with tinsel and decorative lights -- depict a macho young man in paratrooper 's fatigues at his father 's side or in an ivory riding suit on a polo field .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;39	Syrians insist their adoration of Basil is spontaneous and not fostered by the government .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;40	`` He did a lot of good things for the country , the kinds of things nobody could forget , '' said one merchant .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;41	But like many others , he was unable to give any examples .
APW_ENG_19941203.0053;42	He also declined to give his name .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;0	Thousands of gaunt men and women -- survivors of the world 's worst industrial disaster -- marched through Bhopal Saturday to mark the 10th anniversary of the calamity that killed 7,000 people .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;1	The central Indian city observed a partial strike in memory of those killed when methyl isocyanate gas leaked from a pesticide plant owned by an Indian subsidiary of the U.S.-based Union Carbide Corp.
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;2	Survivors and orphaned children gathered in front of the closed factory to beat and burn straw-and-bamboo effigies of Warren Anderson , who headed Union Carbide at the time .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;3	Elders , many with tears in their eyes , shouted `` death to Anderson . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;4	Local leaders made speeches demanding Anderson be tried in India for mass murder , while others spoke of the plight of the half-million people seeking compensation .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;5	`` I know all this may produce nothing , but I decided to come , '' said Kamal Pancham , who lost his daughter and father in the disaster .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;6	It was the second day of demonstrations to mark the disaster .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;7	About 3,000 people marched near the state legislature Friday , but police arrested 11,000 people as they headed to the city for the anniversary .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;8	Tens of thousands of people fled panic-stricken the night of Dec. 2 , 1984 , when a metal tank at the plant leaked the deadly gas .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;9	Some 4,000 people died that night ; 3,000 other deaths were later blamed on the effects of the gas .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;10	Five years ago , Union Carbide paid dlrs 470 million -- one-twelfth of India 's original claim -- in an out-of-court settlement that guaranteed immunity from prosecution for Carbide executives .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;11	India 's Supreme Court later struck down the immunity clause .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;12	Eight officials of Union Carbide 's Indian subsidiary were charged with manslaughter , but none has been brought to trial .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;13	Meanwhile , India 's slow-moving courts have been overwhelmed with claims , and bureaucratic corruption has further stymied those seeking compensation .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;14	So far , the government has paid out only dlrs 20 million while the fund has grown to dlrs 516 million .
APW_ENG_19941203.0054;15	`` Even after 10 years we look like beggars asking for alms , '' Rehena Begum , a voluntary worker , told a group of 500 women survivors .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;0	Step right up , it 's election time in Taiwan -- which means fun , feasting and cash to help undecided voters make up their minds .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;1	By all accounts , Saturday 's local elections were characteristically spicy and seamy , despite official efforts to stamp the bad habits out of Taiwan 's rapidly blossoming democracy .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;2	Saturday 's elections for a governor , mayors , local councillors and provincial assemblymen were Taiwan 's most extensive since the ruling Nationalist Party fled to the island to escape the 1949 Communist takeover of mainland China .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;3	Campaigning was feverish , the crash of drums , cymbals and firecrackers so loud that one newspaper joked Saturday that Taiwanese were looking forward to hearing just the usual din of traffic .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;4	Interior Minister Wu Poh-hsiung complained that the blizzard of campaign banners `` could have clothed 1 million refugees . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;5	Besides a number of brawls , there was mudslinging of a highly personal nature .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;6	For example , Chen Shui-bian , the Democratic Progressive Party 's candidate for mayor of Taipei , was reported by newspapers to have publicly declared that he had a vasectomy , thus rebutting allegations that he fathered an illegitimate son with a campaign aide .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;7	On Wednesday the DPP filed a lawsuit Wednesday accusing the Nationalists of earmarking about 150 million Taiwan dollars -LRB- U.S. dlrs 5.6 million -RRB- to buy votes for Huang Ta-chou , Taipei 's incumbent Nationalist mayor , who was lagging in opinion polls .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;8	The Nationalists denied the allegations and the government ran a vigorous publicity campaign against vote-buying , showing TV ads of offenders being led away handcuffed .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;9	The Justice Ministry said courts received some 400 complaints of vote abuse during the campaign .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;10	Nonetheless , newspapers reported the going rate for a vote was 500 to 1,000 Taiwan dollars -LRB- dlrs 20-40 -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;11	The practice is probably rooted in Taiwan 's early days , when it was regarded as natural to refund a farmer or laborer for income lost by taking a day off to vote .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;12	As democracy developed in the late 1980s and newspapers became free to expose abuses , the Nationalists were held up as the worst offenders , and they realized that ultimately their corrupt image would jeopardize their hold on power .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;13	So they have stiffened the penalties and launched a series of cleanup measures , forcing candidates to find more subtle means of persuasion , like banquets or sightseeing trips around the island .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;14	Banquets for 1,000 voters are not unusual .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;15	The sightseers are asked to pay a nominal fee so that the trip ca n't be formally termed a bribe .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;16	A controversial feature of Taiwanese campaigning is the lightly clad women who dance on the stage at rallies .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;17	At one rally , the attire was so scanty that James Soong , the Nationalist candidate for governor , refused to get on the stage .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;18	And then there are the campaign promises -- of new railroads , airports , old-age pensions , hospitals -- goodies which cost an estimated 2 trillion Taiwan dollars -LRB- U.S. dlrs 74 billion -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;19	`` It is part of Taiwanese culture to throw banquets and send presents when you need people 's help , or when you want to get close to them , '' said Huang Hwei-chen , director of the private Institute for National Policy Research .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;20	He saw it as an inevitable symptom of democratization .
APW_ENG_19941203.0055;21	`` Democracy seems sort of commercialized , but it is in a transition , '' he said .

APW_ENG_19941203.0058;0	Canadian peacekeepers at their camp near Sarajevo were anxiously awaiting the release of 55 Canadians today after a Bosnian Serb promise to stop holding hundreds of UN soldiers .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;1	But there was no sign this morning that the release was under way , said a spokesman in the Muslim village of Visoko , headquarters for the 800 Canadian troops serving with the UN Protection Force in Bosnia-Herzegovina .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;2	The more than 400 Canadians at the camp were watching every news bulletin on television and monitoring political developments in the capital of Sarajevo .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;3	`` Everybody here is up and hoping they 'll be released today , '' said Maj. Geoff Hall , second in command at the camp .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;4	`` Personally , I assume nothing in Bosnia , but this time this promise just might be for real . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;5	The Canadians have been held for 10 days at various sites in Serb-held territory near Visoko .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;6	Hall said the detained Canadians , who are in radio contact with the camp , said this morning there was no indication they were about to be released .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;7	`` There is no change among our detained Canadians , so we 'll just have to wait this one out and see what happens . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;8	UN special envoy Yasushi Akashi said Friday Serb leaders agreed to release Ukrainian peacekeepers in northern Bosnia , as well as Dutch and British convoys detained since last Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;9	`` In addition , we have agreed that normal activities be restored to the Canadians -- 55 Canadians near Visoko -- and all other soldiers from other countries that were doing their work at weapons collection sites , '' Akashi said after talks with Serb leader Radovan Karadzic in Pale , near Sarajevo .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;10	But Defense Minister David Collenette said in Ottawa on Friday Canadian officers in Bosnia could n't confirm the reports of agreement .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;11	And Maj. Rita Lepage , a Canadian military spokeswoman in Zagreb , Croatia , said today there was no timetable for the release .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;12	But she did not dismiss the Serb agreement as just another broken Serb promise to the UN .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;13	`` This is certainly the most encouraging development so far , '' she said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;14	The Serbs did release 70 Dutch troops in good condition Friday but are holding about 300 more to discourage NATO air strikes against a Serb siege of the Muslim pocket of Bihac , a UN-declared safe haven in northwest Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;15	About 20 Canadians are at a police complex in the village of Ilijas .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;16	The rest are at checkpoints and observation posts .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;17	Maj. Dean Milner , senior officer among the detainees , is able to drive around in his vehicle and visit his soldiers .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;18	The Serbs also let supply vehicles from camp bring the soldiers mail , food and other items .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;19	Hall said the Canadians , if released , would be given at least 24 hours to rest before being allowed to give media interviews .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;20	The camp was making preparations Friday for their release , including stocking up on food for a special steak-and-eggs meal for detainees .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;21	The detainees , when released , will be debriefed , given time to rest and then allowed to `` get things off their chest '' at counselling sessions with people of their own rank , Hall said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;22	The camp stayed at the high alert level of orange today , which requires personnel to wear flak jackets and helmets when moving around outside .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;23	Hall said the camp will stay at orange until the `` whole detention problem is over . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;24	Meanwhile , in Paris on Friday , Peter Donolo , a spokesman for Prime Minister Jean Chretien , said : `` Obviously we 're encouraged by the developments .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;25	We 're keeping our fingers crossed , but we 're not going to rest until our troops have full freedom of movement .
APW_ENG_19941203.0058;26	`` We 've been let down before . ''

APW_ENG_19941203.0061;1	Thousands of pedicab drivers burned cars and smashed dozens of store windows Thursday after hearing a rumor that a fellow driver had been killed in a collision with a car belonging to the city 's Public Order Office .
APW_ENG_19941203.0061;2	Four of the 12 cars set on fire by the protesters reportedly belonged to the city .

APW_ENG_19941203.0061;7	The more than 2,000 pedicabs , called `` becak , '' operating in Bandung are not allowed to enter the center of the city to prevent traffic jams .
APW_ENG_19941203.0061;8	They are only able to operate in narrow alleys , but drivers sometimes break the rules in an attempt to earn more money .

APW_ENG_19941203.0063;1	The organization will administer new international trade rules established under GATT , the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade .
APW_ENG_19941203.0063;2	U.S. participation in the trade pact got final approval from Congress this week .
APW_ENG_19941203.0063;3	Besides Salinas , candidates for the trade post are former Italian Trade Minister Renato Ruggiero and South Korean Trade and Industry Minister Kim Chul-su .
APW_ENG_19941203.0063;4	Ruggiero is the clear favorite .

APW_ENG_19941203.0063;6	A White House statement noted that Salinas is the only candidate who has served as a head of state and said he has a strong background in internal economics .
APW_ENG_19941203.0063;7	`` He would bring to the WTO a wealth of experience and important insights from the perspective of a developing country , '' the White House statement said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0063;8	`` As Mexico 's president for six years , President Salinas led his country through a successful process of economic reform and trade liberalization , '' it said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0063;9	`` The president believe he deserves widespread support . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;0	Japan , the only country attacked by atomic bombs , has formally asked the United States to reconsider a plan to issue a stamp showing a nuclear mushroom cloud , a Foreign Ministry official said Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;1	The Japanese Embassy in Washington conveyed the request on Friday , stressing that the Japanese people have strong feelings against the stamp , which is inscribed , `` Atomic bombs hasten war 's end , Aug. 1943 . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;2	The official said the U.S. Department of State replied that it is studying the Japanese request .
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;3	The U.S. Postal Service plans to begin selling the stamp next September .
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;4	The stamp depicts a mushroom cloud said to be a combination of images from the explosions of U.S. atomic tests and atomic bombs dropped by U.S. forces on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in the closing days of World War II .
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;5	Takashi Hiraoka , the mayor of Hiroshima , said in a statement Friday that `` it is regrettable that the description under the mushroom cloud will lead to an understanding that the use of the atomic bomb was right . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;6	`` Whatever reasons there were , the use of nuclear weapons is not forgiven .
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;7	It is not an appropriate time to show the power of nuclear weapons while the world is tackling nuclear disarmament , '' Hiraoka said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;8	In Washington , Postal Service spokesman Robin Wright said Friday that the stamp commemorated an `` historically critical event . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;9	`` Our purpose is to provide a comprehensive history of events of World War II and we are not making a value judgment on any of those events , '' Wright added .
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;10	The atomic bomb killed 140,000 people in Hiroshima .
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;11	Three days later , a second bomb was dropped on Nagasaki , killing another 70,000 people .
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;12	Several days later , on Aug. 15 , Japan surrendered to the Allied Forces .
APW_ENG_19941203.0064;13	Some historians say the bombs hastened Japan 's surrender , while other say Japan was already on the verge of surrendering .
APW_ENG_19941203.0065;0	Japan , the only country attacked by atomic bombs , has formally asked the United States to reconsider a plan to issue a stamp showing a nuclear mushroom cloud , a Foreign Ministry official said Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0065;1	The Japanese Embassy in Washington conveyed the request on Friday , stressing that the Japanese people have strong feelings against the stamp , which is inscribed , `` Atomic bombs hasten war 's end , Aug. 1943 . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0065;2	The official said the U.S. Department of State replied that it is studying the Japanese request .
APW_ENG_19941203.0065;3	The U.S. Postal Service plans to begin selling the stamp next September .

APW_ENG_19941203.0069;0	The death toll increased to 29 Saturday in the crash of a Budapest-bound express train that derailed and slammed into a station building , state radio reported .
APW_ENG_19941203.0069;1	At least 56 people were injured Friday when the second car of the train derailed and dragged three cars off the tracks , state radio said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0069;2	Some of the cars overturned and then smashed into the station building at Szajol , about 70 kilometers -LRB- 40 miles -RRB- southeast of the Hungarian capital , railway officials said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0069;3	Karoly Lotz , the transport minister , said the accident most likely was caused by a switching mistake .
APW_ENG_19941203.0069;4	About 200 soldiers and police officers worked into the night looking for survivors and keeping away the curious .
APW_ENG_19941203.0069;5	On Saturday , rescue crews frantically dragged bloody bodies from twisted railway cars covered in brick torn from the station .
APW_ENG_19941203.0069;6	One car skewered the building and a crane was brought in to remove it .
APW_ENG_19941203.0069;7	Twenty-nine bodies had been found , five more than state radio previously reported .
APW_ENG_19941203.0069;8	Part of the building housed sleeping quarters for railway personnel and their families .
APW_ENG_19941203.0069;9	Defense Minister Gyoergy Keleti said specially trained dogs located three children who were then dug out of the rubble .
APW_ENG_19941203.0069;10	Local Police Chief Gyoergy Lengyel said the train was not stopping at Szajol and was traveling at about 110 kilometers -LRB- 66 miles -RRB- per hour , its normal speed .
APW_ENG_19941203.0069;11	The train was en route from Nyiregyhaza , about 160 kilometers -LRB- 100 miles -RRB- east of Budapest .

APW_ENG_19941203.0071;0	A volcano which erupted two weeks ago , killing at least 52 people , has again begun releasing hot gas and lava , forcing authorities to call off a search for earlier victims .
APW_ENG_19941203.0071;1	Lieut. Col. Supiadin , military commander of Sleman regency , said red-hot lava was spewing down from the crater and more than 70 emissions of hot gas and steam had been recorded in the past day .
APW_ENG_19941203.0071;2	`` We are not taking chances and have asked everybody to stop their search until the situation gets better , '' he said Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0071;3	The searchers are looking for about 200 people who are still missing from the earlier eruption .
APW_ENG_19941203.0071;4	The search will resume when the volcanic activity subsides , Supiadin said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0071;5	More than 5,000 people were evacuated two weeks ago from villages which were devastated when a huge cloud of scorching steam and gas suddenly swept down the side of Mount Merapi .
APW_ENG_19941203.0071;6	The mountain is about 580 kilometers -LRB- 360 miles -RRB- east of Indonesia 's capital of Jakarta and 30 kilometers -LRB- 20 miles -RRB- north of the tourist city of Jogjakarta .
APW_ENG_19941203.0071;7	The eruption demolished homes , flattened forests , destroyed crops and wiped out livestock .
APW_ENG_19941203.0071;8	Tons of ash were dumped on the disaster site and some lava poured out .
APW_ENG_19941203.0071;9	Scores of people were badly burned by the fast-moving cloud , which had an estimated temperature of 200 degrees Celsius -LRB- 392 F -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941203.0071;10	Many working in rice fields or food gardens had no time to run for cover .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;0	A promise by new President Ernesto Zedillo to reform Mexico 's corrupt and inefficient judicial system could prove to be the most difficult to fulfill .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;1	And the most important .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;2	Zedillo 's predecessor , President Carlos Salinas de Gortari , always said his far-reaching economic reforms would eventually lead to the democratic and judicial reforms Mexico needs to become a truly modern , developed nation .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;3	Now it 's up to Zedillo to make sure that happens .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;4	Democracy and justice can not thrive in a country where the laws do not apply equally to all .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;5	`` It has to be done , '' said independent political analyst Sergio Sarmiento .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;6	`` Judicial reforms will be the most significant and difficult challenge of this administration . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;7	When he took office Thursday , Zedillo vowed one of his first acts would be to seek a constitutional amendment overhauling Mexico 's justice system .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;8	He said he would soon submit specific proposals to lawmakers .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;9	`` I am determined to head the creation of a nation where the rule of law prevails , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;10	`` In order to tackle the rampant crime , the frequent violations of civil and human rights , and the grave public insecurity , we will launch an in-depth and genuine reform of the institutions in charge of the procurement of justice , '' Zedillo added .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;11	Zedillo also named an opposition politician as his attorney general , the first such Cabinet appointment in the 65-year history of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party -LRB- PRI -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;12	Debate about Mexican justice has been heated in a year marked by the assassinations of two top PRI leaders and a rebel uprising in southern Mexico .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;13	Mexico 's is a system that often grants impunity to the rich and powerful -- too often party leaders -- while frequently denying basic human rights to the poor and powerless .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;14	From bribe-demanding traffic police to corrupt judges who let political cronies go free , the system has long been equated with graft , laziness and bureaucratic inpetitude .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;15	The chief investigator in the September assassination of Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu , the PRI secretary general , quit last month , charging that party leaders were blocking his probe .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;16	That revived questions about the March assassination of presidential candidate Luis Donaldo Colosio .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;17	Although officials insist Colosio was killed by a lone , deranged gunman , many Mexicans suspect a larger political conspiracy .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;18	`` The brutal assassinations of two of Mexico 's most outstanding public figures have deeply hurt our citizens , sown seeds of ... doubt regarding some institutions , and divided the people of Mexico , '' Zedillo admitted .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;19	Meanwhile , demands for justice continue to echo from the mountains of southern Mexico , where Indian rebels are threatening to revive their New Year 's Day rebellion .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;20	The guerrillas maintain that a left-leaning candidate for governor was cheated out of victory during August elections .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;21	Zedillo seems to realize that the economic and democratic reforms Salinas accomplished during his administration can never be truly effective without judicial reforms .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;22	New laws against electoral fraud are pointless unless those who burn and steal ballots are arrested and prosecuted by honest judges .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;23	Economic reforms encouraging foreign investment wo n't work if businessmen still have to pay bribes .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;24	Judicial reforms are likely to be opposed by many , including top government or party officials long considered above the law and the druglords who bribe police officers for protection .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;25	`` There are a lot of skeletons in the closet in Mexico , '' said Susan Kaufman Purcell , vice president of the New York-based Americas Society .
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;26	`` And a lot of people are going to be very reluctant to have those closets opened . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0072;27	Anita Snow is an AP correspondent based in Mexico City .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;0	A military court on Saturday found 16 suspected Muslim extremists guilty in the killing of a German tourist and two Egyptians , and sentenced two to death .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;1	The others received prison terms ranging from five to 15 years .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;2	The ruling was handed down at the military base at Haekstep , which is about 15 kilometers -LRB- 9 miles -RRB- northeast of Cairo .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;3	Earlier Saturday , two police guards were killed and two others wounded when suspected Muslim extremists opened fire on a police station in southern Egypt , security officials said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;4	The extremists fled with two of the policemen 's automatic rifles , the officials said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;5	The incident occurred in the town of Farshut in Qena province , about 465 kilometers -LRB- 290 miles -RRB- south of Cairo .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;6	The fatal attack on the German and Egyptians occurred Sept. 27 in the Red Sea resort of Hurghada .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;7	Another German and an Egyptian were wounded in the shooting on a crowded downtown square .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;8	It was the first known incident involving Muslim radicals in the Hurghada area , and government officials fear it will hurt tourism there .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;9	Muslim radicals have waged a campaign of violence since the spring of 1992 to try to overthrow Egypt 's secular government and replace it with strict Islamic rule .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;10	More than 460 people have been killed , most of them police and extremists .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;11	Seven foreigners have been among the victims .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;12	Most of the violence has been blamed on al-Gamaa al-Islamiya , or the Islamic Group , which has been most active in southern Egypt in villages around the city of Assiut .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;13	Foreign reporters and Egyptian reporters with foreign news organizations were banned from covering most sessions of the trial but were permitted in Saturday to hear the verdicts .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;14	Hearings began Nov. 5 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;15	The prosecutor had argued before the three-man military tribunal that the defendants wanted to damage Egypt 's economy by carrying out attacks on foreign tourists .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;16	Tourism is one of Egypt 's main sources of foreign currency .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;17	The two sentenced to death were Mohammed Omar Ahmed and Rabie Mahmoud Hassanein , who are accused of opening fire at the tourists .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;18	President Hosni Mubarak began referring Muslim extremist cases to military courts early last year to speed up the court process .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;19	This has been widely criticized by Egyptian and international human rights groups , which argue they should be heard in civilian courts .
APW_ENG_19941203.0073;20	Forty-three suspected extremists have been executed , all but two sentenced to die by military courts .
APW_ENG_19941203.0074;0	Former world junior champion Daniel Chopra of Sweden shot a 4-under-par 68 in Saturday 's final round to win the Malaysian PGA Golf title by two strokes .
APW_ENG_19941203.0074;1	Chopra , who was third after Friday 's third round , overcame bogeys on the par-4 first and second holes to beat his closest rival , Saneh Saengsui of Thailand , on the Tropicana Golf and Country Club course .
APW_ENG_19941203.0074;2	`` After the two bogeys in the first and second , I told myself to go for a 67 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0074;3	And in the last five holes , I managed to go three-under and finally finished with a 68 which was not bad at all , '' said Chopra .
APW_ENG_19941203.0074;4	The round , which was delayed for an hour due to heavy rain , gave Chopra a four-round total of 273 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0074;5	It was Chopra 's second win on Malaysian soil and his seventh victory since turning pro in 1991 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0074;6	Saengsui , who led after Friday 's third round , had to settle for second spot after an even-par round of 72 , while local pro Mohamed Ali Kadir , who was second Friday , took third place after posting a 72 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0074;7	Saengsui also had a bad start with bogeys on the first two holes , but managed to improve his score with birdies in the sixth , seventh and 13th holes for a 275 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0074;8	After the blunders on the first and second holes , Chopra kept his composure with birdies on the fourth , fifth , ninth , 10th , 15th and 18th holes .
APW_ENG_19941203.0074;9	For his win , Chopra received U.S. dlrs 5,100 , while Saengsui earned dlrs 3,850 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;0	Taiwan 's ruling Nationalists , fighting their toughest election in 45 years , took the lead in the race for the island 's governorship but were lagging in the contest for mayor of the capital , initial returns showed Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;1	With about 60 percent of the votes counted , incumbent Nationalist governor James Soong had 2.9 million , against 2.1 million for Chen Ting-nan , the candidate of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;2	But in Taipei , Nationalist Mayor Huang Ta-chou looked in trouble .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;3	With about 23 percent of votes counted , Huang had 90,000 , compared with 155,000 for the DPP 's Chen Shui-bian .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;4	A DPP victory in Taipei , Taiwan 's capital and largest city , would boost the credibility of the once-banned opposition and improve its chances in the island 's first direct presidential elections in 1996 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;5	But the Nationalists would draw comfort from winning the governorship , presently the highest fully elected post in Taiwan .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;6	In Kaohsiung , a port city on Taiwan 's southern coast , Nationalist incumbent Wu Tun-yi had a lead of more than 50,000 votes over the DPP 's Chang Chun-hsiung with about 30 percent of votes counted .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;7	Taiwanese thronged to the polls on foot , by car and even in wheelchairs to vote in the local elections , which marked a milestone in Taiwan 's 7-year-old transformation from virtual dictatorship to multi-party democracy .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;8	Never before had voters chosen a governor , and elections for mayor have not been held in Taipei and Kaohsiung since 1967 and 1979 respectively .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;9	Voters also chose local councils and the provincial assembly .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;10	State-run TV said polling stations closed on schedule at 4 p.m. -LRB- 0800 GMT -RRB- and results were expected about eight hours later .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;11	Newspapers and TV estimated that 70 percent to 80 percent of Taiwan 's 13.8 million eligible voters turned out .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;12	President Lee Teng-hui , who is credited with steering Taiwan through its transition to democracy , cast his vote in a Taipei stadium shortly after polling stations opened at 8 a.m. -LRB- 0000 GMT -RRB- .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;13	Voters lined up in the rain to vote in schools , sports grounds and Buddhist temples , sometimes waiting half an hour for their turn .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;14	Campaigning for the election was feverish and , at times , violent .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;15	No incidents were reported during the voting , but there were fears that violence might erupt after final results were announced .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;16	Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou appealed to people to watch the results on TV and not mass outside party headquarters .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;17	Police said 70,000 officers were deployed , and Lee appealed to Taiwanese to `` welcome a new era of democracy for all . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;18	The polls are a prelude to the 1996 presidential election .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;19	Lee 's prospects for another term will be measured by his Nationalists ' performance against the DPP , especially in the race for governor .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;20	The Nationalists fled to Taiwan to escape the 1949 Communist takeover of mainland China .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;21	They still say they hope one day to reunite Taiwan with the Chinese motherland .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;22	But the DPP advocates Taiwanese independence , something China has vowed to resist by force , claiming Taiwan is a renegade province .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;23	Campaigning focused largely on `` Tong-Du '' -- reunification vs. independence -- and DPP successes could provoke misgivings in Beijing .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;24	Business leaders placed newspaper ads warning that Taiwan 's dollar and the island 's standing with investors could plummet if pro-independence forces gained power .
APW_ENG_19941203.0076;25	But the DPP may profit from a split in the Nationalist vote caused by the recently formed New Party , which quit the Nationalists last year , accusing them of abandoning the commitment to reunification .

APW_ENG_19941203.0077;1	The company defeated fellow American competitors IBM and Digital Equipment in bidding to sell the machines to Vietnamese commercial banks , the Vietnam Investment Review reported .
APW_ENG_19941203.0077;2	The review is published by the State Committee for Cooperation and Investment , which regulates foreign investment here .
APW_ENG_19941203.0077;3	The review quoted AT and T representative Medi Pepper as saying the firm had n't yet signed a contract for the sale .
APW_ENG_19941203.0077;4	The State Bank of Vietnam announced plans earlier this year to install 30 to 40 automatic teller machines in the country 's major cities by the middle of 1995 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0077;5	It estimated the equipment would cost dlrs 2.8 million .
APW_ENG_19941203.0077;6	A modern banking system is one of Vietnam 's key development priorities as it seeks to double per capita national income to dlrs 450 by the end of the decade .
APW_ENG_19941203.0079;0	Sixteen people were injured Saturday in a mass pileup involving about 70 vehicles on an icy , foggy highway , police said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0079;1	Police said the accident happened about 7 a.m. -LRB- 0600 GMT -RRB- on the main route from St. Gallen to Rorschach in northeastern Switzerland .
APW_ENG_19941203.0079;2	Cars , apparently traveling too fast in the bad conditions , skidded into each other on the slippery surface , causing chaos within a matter of minutes .
APW_ENG_19941203.0079;3	Rescue vehicles were delayed by the resulting traffic jams .
APW_ENG_19941203.0079;4	A helicopter trying to reach the injured was unable to land because of the thick fog .
APW_ENG_19941203.0079;5	Police said two of the injured were in a serious condition .
APW_ENG_19941203.0079;6	The rest were mainly minor injuries .
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;0	Vietnam has not discussed letting U.S. ships use port facilities at Cam Ranh Bay , the naval base American forces built during the Vietnam War , the government said Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;1	Vietnam 's Foreign Affairs Ministry issued the denial when asked about Western news reports that the two countries have talked about arranging for American naval ships to call once again at the deep water port in former South Vietnam .
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;2	`` The issue of Cam Ranh has so far never been mentioned in any of the talks or meetings between the U.S. and Vietnam , '' the ministry said in a statement .
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;3	U.S. Admiral Richard C. Macke told reporters during an official visit to Hanoi in October that he did not rule out future military cooperation between Vietnam and the United States , once the former enemies showed more political and economic cooperation .
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;4	Asked then about Cam Ranh Bay , he said : `` I 'm a naval officer and naval officers are always looking for good ports . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;5	But he added that he did not specifically discuss the port with Vietnamese officials .
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;6	The ministry statement refutes speculation that Vietnam is keen to let the U.S. Navy use the port as a way to counterbalance Chinese ambitions in the region .
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;7	Vietnam and its huge northern neighbor , China , both claim the Spratly Islands , an archipelago in the South China Sea believed to lie atop rich oil and gas deposits .
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;8	The two Communist nations also dispute oil drilling rights closer to the coast of southern Vietnam .
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;9	China 's Foreign Ministry objected last month to a suggestion that the United States might want to return to Cam Ranh Bay .
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;10	China opposes the idea of any country basing its troops or forces on foreign soil , a Chinese ministry spokesman said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0080;11	After the Vietnam War , Hanoi allowed the Soviet Union to base its ships and submarines at Cam Ranh Bay .

APW_ENG_19941203.0084;0	Crew members on a ferry and freighter that collided in Manila Bay , killing at least 35 people , will be tested for drugs and alcohol , the Coast Guard said Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;1	Navy and coast guard divers , meanwhile , suspended a second day of searching for bodies trapped inside the ferry Cebu City after recovering the body of an elderly woman early in the day .
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;2	The ferry was carrying 608 people when it collided with the Kota Suria , a Singaporean-registered freighter , before dawn Friday and quickly sank .
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;3	At least 110 people are still missing , coast guard spokesman Lt. Cmdr. Loreto dela Cueva said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;4	Dela Cueva said divers were unable to open the cabin doors because some were locked and others were blocked by debris .
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;5	He said equipment to pry open the doors will be brought in by divers Sunday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;6	He said 453 people had been rescued , including two survivors brought to Manila Saturday after fishermen plucked them from the sea near Cavite province late Friday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;7	Lt. Cmdr. Federico Cabug , a coast guard intelligence officer , said the National Bureau of Investigation will take blood samples from the crew members on duty on the 2,432-ton ferry and the 12,500-ton freighter .
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;8	He said the blood tests were `` not a normal procedure , but in this case we have to do it . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;9	`` There could be some negligence on the part of those manning the ship at the time of the incident , '' Cabug said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;10	`` If you are on duty , you are not supposed to be drinking or be under the influence of any kind of drug . ''

APW_ENG_19941203.0084;13	It is still unclear which vessel had the right of way in the passage at the time .

APW_ENG_19941203.0084;18	The ferry sank into mud under about 25 meters -LRB- 85 feet -RRB- of water 30 minutes after the collision near Rosario town , about 50 kilometers -LRB- 35 miles -RRB- southwest of Manila in Cavite province .
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;19	The Cebu City had left Manila bound for Tagbilaran , the capital of Bohol Island , about 560 kilometers -LRB- 350 miles -RRB- to the southeast , a 28-hour boat trip .
APW_ENG_19941203.0084;20	The Philippines ' worst peacetime ferry disaster was in December 1987 , when 4,341 people died in the collision of the ferry Dona Paz with the oil tanker Vector off Mindoro Island , about 130 kilometers -LRB- 80 miles -RRB- south of Manila .

APW_ENG_19941203.0086;6	`` We 're checking constantly but nothing is happening on the ground yet , '' he said .

APW_ENG_19941203.0086;8	Hall said the detained Canadians , who are in radio contact with the camp , said this morning there was no indication they were about to be released .
APW_ENG_19941203.0086;9	`` There is no change among our detained Canadians , so we 'll just have to wait this one out and see what happens . ''

APW_ENG_19941203.0086;11	`` In addition , we have agreed that normal activities be restored to the Canadians -- 55 Canadians near Visoko -- and all other soldiers from other countries that were doing their work at weapons collection sites , '' Akashi said after talks with Serb leader Radovan Karadzic in Pale , near Sarajevo .
APW_ENG_19941203.0086;12	But Defense Minister David Collenette said in Ottawa on Friday Canadian officers in Bosnia could n't confirm the reports of agreement .
APW_ENG_19941203.0086;13	And Maj. Rita Lepage , a Canadian military spokeswoman in Zagreb , Croatia , said today there was no timetable for the release .
APW_ENG_19941203.0086;14	But she did not dismiss the Serb agreement as just another broken Serb promise to the UN .
APW_ENG_19941203.0086;15	`` This is certainly the most encouraging development so far , '' she said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0086;16	The Serbs did release 70 Dutch troops in good condition Friday but are holding about 300 more to discourage NATO air strikes against a Serb siege of the Muslim pocket of Bihac , a UN-declared safe haven in northwest Bosnia .
APW_ENG_19941203.0086;17	About 20 Canadians are at a police complex in the village of Ilijas .
APW_ENG_19941203.0086;18	The rest are at checkpoints and observation posts .
APW_ENG_19941203.0086;19	Maj. Dean Milner , senior officer among the detainees , is able to drive around in his vehicle and visit his soldiers .

APW_ENG_19941203.0086;22	The camp was making preparations Friday for their release , including stocking up on food for a special steak-and-eggs meal for detainees .
APW_ENG_19941203.0086;23	The detainees , when released , will be debriefed , given time to rest and then allowed to `` get things off their chest '' at counselling sessions with people of their own rank , Hall said .

APW_ENG_19941203.0087;2	Residents of the village where the plant is located , Obrikom , fled as the blast sent a fireball into the sky and sparked blazes in nearby homes .

APW_ENG_19941203.0087;10	`` The government may resort to the sale of refining and distribution assets in part or in whole to the highest bidder or companies with a track record in refinery management , '' Etiebet said .

APW_ENG_19941203.0093;2	The main opposition force , led by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar , is dug in on the southern and eastern outskirts of Kabul and rockets the city almost daily .

APW_ENG_19941203.0093;12	If successful , it will be the first UN relief convoy to reach Kabul since June .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;0	Chechen authorities released two Russian prisoners Saturday and turned them over to a parliamentary delegation from Moscow seeking the release of all Russians captured in a rebel offensive last week .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;1	Chechen Foreign Minister Yousef Shamsedin said the prisoners were released because they had been wounded in the fighting .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;2	He said they were being flown back to Moscow with the delegation .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;3	The Interfax news agency identified the released prisoners as Lt. Dmitry Volfovich and Pvt. Alexander Danilov , both serving in the Russian army .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;4	The four-person delegation was in the Chechen capital to negotiate the release of about 70 Russians , including army officers and soldiers , captured in an opposition assault on Grozny a week ago .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;5	Shamsedin , asked if all the prisoners would eventually be released , obliquely replied , `` many prisoners have asked us not to send them back because they are afraid for their security . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;6	Chechen President Dzhokhar Dudayev , who declared independence for his Caucasus Mountain republic in 1991 , claims Moscow is arming and leading the rebels against him .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;7	President Boris Yeltsin 's government has denied providing anything but political support , even as the rebel offensive has escalated from small-arms fire to jet attacks throughout the week .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;8	There was no fighting reported in Chechnya Saturday , and Grozny began a return to normal .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;9	The city 's central bazaar , which had been deserted most of the week , was again buzzing with activity .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;10	Earlier in the week , air raids killed at least four civilians and an airport guard , and destroyed planes at civilian and military airports .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;11	`` It is clear that these planes are not English or French but Russian , '' Ella Pamfilova , a delegation member , said Friday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;12	`` This is against the law . ''

APW_ENG_19941203.0094;14	A dozen of the prisoners , interviewed Friday by The Associated Press , said they were hired by Russia 's Federal Counterintelligence Service for secret operations with the Chechen rebels .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;15	Counterintelligence spokesman Alexander Mikhailov , asked about such reports at a news conference , said only that Chechnya is part of Russia and that the servicemen should therefore be called volunteers , not mercenaries , ITAR-Tass and Interfax said Friday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;16	Dudayev first threatened to kill the prisoners if Russia did not claim them , but later said they would be tried in court .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;17	Yeltsin threatened to send troops if they were not released .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;18	Moscow has since toned down the threat .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;19	But it continued to beef up troops on Chechnya 's borders , news reports said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;20	The opposition accuses Dudayev of running Chechnya 's economy into the ground .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;21	The main industry , oil refining , is operating at about 10 percent of capacity .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;22	But Chechen pride and age-old enmity with Russia have rallied many people to Dudayev 's side , including some volunteers from other Caucasus regions .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;23	Russia conquered the mainly Muslim Chechens in its imperial drive towards the Black Sea last century .
APW_ENG_19941203.0094;24	Ethnic tensions suppressed in Soviet times have boiled over since the 1991 Soviet collapse .

APW_ENG_19941203.0095;1	Chechen Foreign Minister Yousef Shamsedin said the prisoners were released because they had been wounded in the fighting .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;2	He said they were being flown back to Moscow with the delegation .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;3	The Interfax news agency identified the released prisoners as Lt. Dmitry Volfovich and Pvt. Alexander Danilov , both serving in the Russian army .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;4	The four-person delegation was in the Chechen capital to negotiate the release of about 70 Russians , including army officers and soldiers , captured in an opposition assault on Grozny a week ago .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;5	Shamsedin , asked if all the prisoners would eventually be released , obliquely replied , `` many prisoners have asked us not to send them back because they are afraid for their security . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;6	Chechen President Dzhokhar Dudayev , who declared independence for his Caucasus Mountain republic in 1991 , claims Moscow is arming and leading the rebels against him .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;7	President Boris Yeltsin 's government has denied providing anything but political support , even as the rebel offensive has escalated from small-arms fire to jet attacks throughout the week .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;8	There was no fighting reported in Chechnya Saturday , and Grozny began a return to normal .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;9	The city 's central bazaar , which had been deserted most of the week , was again buzzing with activity .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;10	Earlier in the week , air raids killed at least four civilians and an airport guard , and destroyed planes at civilian and military airports .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;11	`` It is clear that these planes are not English or French but Russian , '' Ella Pamfilova , a delegation member , said Friday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;12	`` This is against the law . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;13	Sergei Yushenkov , the delegation 's leader , said , `` You can rest assured that President Yeltsin has recognized the prisoners as members of the Russian Army . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;14	A dozen of the prisoners , interviewed Friday by The Associated Press , said they were hired by Russia 's Federal Counterintelligence Service for secret operations with the Chechen rebels .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;15	Counterintelligence spokesman Alexander Mikhailov , asked about such reports at a news conference , said only that Chechnya is part of Russia and that the servicemen should therefore be called volunteers , not mercenaries , ITAR-Tass and Interfax said Friday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;16	Dudayev first threatened to kill the prisoners if Russia did not claim them , but later said they would be tried in court .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;17	Yeltsin threatened to send troops if they were not released .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;18	Moscow has since toned down the threat .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;19	But it continued to beef up troops on Chechnya 's borders , news reports said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;20	The opposition accuses Dudayev of running Chechnya 's economy into the ground .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;21	The main industry , oil refining , is operating at about 10 percent of capacity .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;22	But Chechen pride and age-old enmity with Russia have rallied many people to Dudayev 's side , including some volunteers from other Caucasus regions .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;23	Russia conquered the mainly Muslim Chechens in its imperial drive towards the Black Sea last century .
APW_ENG_19941203.0095;24	Ethnic tensions suppressed in Soviet times have boiled over since the 1991 Soviet collapse .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;0	A merchant ship brought the first shipload of Achille Lauro survivors to port Saturday , three days after a blaze on the bad-luck Italian cruise liner sent nearly 1,000 passengers and crew scrambling aboard lifeboats in the Indian Ocean .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;1	The Liberian-registered Bar Du arrived in this former French colony port near the entrance to the Red Sea at 3 p.m. -LRB- 1200 gmt -RRB- , the Italian Coast Guard said in Rome .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;2	It said the merchant vessel carried 71 passengers from the Achille Lauro -- Britons , South Africans and Italians and Irish -- but did not have an exact breakdown of nationalities .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;3	In all , two U.S. Navy ships and eight commercial vessels picked up the passengers and crew , most of whom originally took refuge aboard an oil tanker off the coast of Somalia when the Achille Lauro was abandoned .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;4	All the other ships except one were due in to Djibouti or Mombasa , Kenya , on Sunday , the Italian Coast Guard said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;5	The last ship was due to arrive Monday in an Oman port .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;6	The Italian news agency ANSA reported that medical personnel from aboard the Italian Merchant Marine vessel the Zeffiro went aboard the Bar Du during the night to check up on passengers ' health .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;7	It said several survivors had cuts and bruises and one passenger had a suspected appendix problem .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;8	On Friday , as the Achille Lauro sunk into the Indian Ocean , a surviving passenger blamed the crew for dropping inflatable rafts on top of a crowded lifeboat , injuring one man who later died .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;9	The victim was one of two elderly passengers who died as a result of the fire .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;10	The survivors numbered 979 including crew and passengers .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;11	The Achille Lauro was best known for the 1985 hijacking by Palestinian terrorists , who killed an elderly Jewish American passenger , Leon Klinghoffer , and dumped his body overboard .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;12	According to passenger Geoffrey Wall , interviewed Friday by Britain 's Sky TV , one man was injured when crew members released inflatable rafts onto the lifeboat , which held about 35 people .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;13	`` It was tilting at an angle , '' said Wall , a Briton , describing attempts to lower a lifeboat .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;14	`` They got it near the water .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;15	They could n't lower it properly .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;16	Then somebody hit the wrong -- I do n't know what it is that they release them with -- but they dropped two of these inflatable life boats on top of us , resulting in injury to one man . ''
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;17	He said people gave the ailing man mouth-to-mouth resuscitation before a rescue ship arrived about four hours later .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;18	`` We were in 100 yards -LRB- meters -RRB- or so of the rescue ship when he started to go ... Unfortunately , he died , '' Wall said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;19	It was not immediately clear if the man died of his injuries .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;20	The ship 's owner , Naples , Italy-based Starlauro , had no immediate comment .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;21	Passenger Dennis Bassett , also told Sky TV that crew members did not alert all the passengers until only minutes before the order sounded to abandon ship .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;22	`` Some passengers at 7 o'clock in the morning were still in bed , '' he said .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;23	The ship 's captain , Giuseppe Orsi , was the last to abandon the ship , which sank Friday evening about 125 miles -LRB- 200 kms -RRB- off the coast of Somalia in about 14,700 feet -LRB- 4,450 meters -RRB- of water .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;24	Alitalia said Starlauro had chartered two 747s to pick up passengers from Djibouti and Mombasa and take them to Rome , for travel to their homes in Europe .
APW_ENG_19941203.0096;25	The planes leave Sunday and return Monday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;0	TIGNES , France -LRB- AP -RRB- - Liechtenstein 's Achim Vogt captured the first race of the men 's World Cup of Alpine Skiing season by winning the giant slaom Saturday .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;1	Vogt , who trains with the Swiss team , had the lead after the first run course that dropped 440 meters -LRB- 1,443 feet -RRB- with a time of 1 minute , 14.19 seconds .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;2	He then went through the second run in 1:16.57 for a total time of 2:30.76 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;3	Swiss Michael Von Gruenigen was second , 2:30.92 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;4	Third was last year 's overall World Cup winner , Kjetil-Andre Aamodt of Norway , with a total time of 2:31.06 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;5	Alberto Tomba , the two-time Olympic giant slalom champion , moved from 22nd to fourth with the fastest time of the second run , 1:15.44 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;6	His total time was 2:31.51 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;7	Fifth was Swiss Urs Kaelin , the silver medalist in this year 's Olympic giant slalom , 2:31.58 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;8	Jure Kosir of Slovenia was sixth , 2:3.88 .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;9	Vogt , who turns 24 , had only two top ten finishes in his career , a fifth in Hinterstoder , Austria and a sixth in Park City , Utah , both in giant slaloms .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;10	The men finally opened their competition after weather had canceled races in three countries .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;11	Tignes was one of the few places in Europe to be able to handle a race on its glacier , more than 2,600 meters -LRB- 8,500 feet -RRB- above sea level .
APW_ENG_19941203.0097;12	A slalom is scheduled for Sunday and a decision will be made concerning two downhills possibly being located in Val d'Isere next week .
